Text: S300 The Arts in Education: Philosophical Dimensions and Reflective Practicesâ€”Part One Fridays from 8:30 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. Larsen 203/214 Click here for the full FA2016 S300 Syllabus Go to Assignments to see weekly readings and The Exercise (written assignments) Fall 2016 S300 Overview The Structure of this Course: Class Sessions Class meets on Fridays from 8:30 to noon. Each class session will include discussion of required readings, â€ ̃exercise studioâ€TM time, and a short time for reflection on our individual and/or collective work. Readings There are required readings each week and some weeks there are suggested readings, as well. (Suggested readings may be referenced in class discussions, but students will not be held responsible for being prepared to discuss them. That said, please do the suggested readings whenever possible.) Required readings can be found in the iPa@ page on the S300 iSite or via links in the posted assignment. In some cases, short readings will be available as handouts in class. Weekly assignments are posted each Friday on the S300 course site. The Exercises Just as there are exercises designed for pianists to develop and maintain their technical abilities, I believe that there are exercises that artist/educators can learn and do throughout their careers. These exercises, however, are more reflective, analytic, interpretive, and philosophical than strictly technical. In each class session, we will have â€ ̃exercise studioâ€TM time in which we will introduce new exercises and then you will do them outside of class. In addition, in the studio time you will share your exercise work with a small group of â€ ̃exercise buddiesâ€TM and members of the Teaching Team. The purpose of this sharing is to expand your understanding of the nature of the exercise and how others interpret it, as well as getting responses to what you have done. Sections All students are required to participate in a weekly, one-hour section meeting led by a member of the Teaching Team. Students are assigned to one section for the duration of the semester. Mondays 6-7PM Tuesdays 10-11AM Tuesdays 12-1PM Assignments Required Readings: All of the required readings are available either in pdf form on the iPac page of the course website or online (available through URL links or posted on the course website); â€œrecommendedâ€​ readings may sometimes also be found on the iPac page, but usually on reserve at the circulation desk of Gutman Library. The texts cited below are recommended as texts to purchase as we will read substantial portions of them. The Exercises           There will be six exercises assigned during the termâ€”one every other week. The first five of those will be new exercises and the sixth will be your choice of one to do again. The exercises for the fall term will be: 1. Listening Circlesâ€”DUE: Friday, September 9 2. Images & Identities of Artists/Educatorsâ€”DUE: Friday, September 23 3. Making Implicit Learning Theories Explicitâ€”DUE: Friday, October 7 4. Talking with Artists who Teachâ€”DUE: Friday, October 21 5. Honoring Inspirationsâ€”DUE: Friday, November 4 6. Free choiceâ€”DUE: Friday, December 2 All exercises can be done in a wide variety of forms and with diverse materials, including words on paper, as well as any other visual media. But all exercises must have an artifact that can be brought to class. In the case of large-form sculptural work or performances that canâ€TMt be done in class due to space and/or time issues, you are responsible to bring to class and to have on record some documentation of that work that can be shared in whole or in part. You must also keep the products of your exercises throughout the term. You can work with the same forms/materials across all exercises, but you can also vary form/materials for each exercise. Reflection/Self-Assessment: DUE Friday, December 9 What have I been learning from these exercises and about myself as a reflective practitioner? This personal essay will be a self-assessment of your experience doing the six exercises during the term. More detailed instructions will be posted toward the end of the term. However, this will be a written product handed in to the Teaching Team. 750-1000 words. Weekly Course Topics (explored via readings, class sessions & sections) CLASS 1--FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 2: Introduction to S300, the foundational questions of the course, and the â€ ̃exercisesâ€TM in reflective practice for artist/educators CLASS 2â€”FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 9: Learning: Images of learning, learners, and teaching CLASS 3â€”FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 16: Learning: Making sense of gleaning meaning CLASS 4â€”FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 23: Identity/Values/Learning: Considering our images of artists, educators, and artist/educators CLASS 5â€”FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 30: Identity/Responsibility: Artists, educators, and imaginationâ€”What are the roles of the artist and the arts in the world and in education? CLASS 6â€”FRIDAY, OCTOBER 7: Identity/Values/Responsibility/Learning: â€œThe past didnâ€TMt go anywhere.â€​ (Utah Phillips) CLASS 7â€”FRIDAY, OCTOBER 14: Responsibility/Learning: Our students and ourselvesâ€”What is our relationship? What are our images of each other? What do we need to know about each other? What do we need from each other? CLASS 8â€”FRIDAY, OCTOBER 21: Identity/Purposes/Values: Why artists teach. CLASS 9â€”FRIDAY, OCTOBER 28: Values/Responsibility/Learning: Community cultural wealth as a context for art and education CLASS 10--FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 4: Identity/Purposes/Learning: Not art in education, but education in art. CLASS 11â€”FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 18: Purposes/Values/Responsibility/Learning: Questions of qualityâ€”What constitutes quality in arts learning experiences? CLASS 12â€”FRIDAY, DECEMBER 2: Identity/Purposes/Values/Responsibility/Learning: Revisiting, reconsidering, and reflecting.

Text: S-301 The Arts and Learning Spring, 2020 Fridays from 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. Room: Larsen 203 and 214 https://docs.google.com/document/d/1weChzNoZqRm7tw3PQstDLoxE6ZBh-5Btzip6MsQwh2Q/edit? usp=sharing Teaching Fellows: Allegra Fletcher afletcher@gse.harvard.edu Office hours: By appointment Cora Higgins cah845@mail.harvard.edu Office hours: By appointment Course Description: This course is an inquiry into the nature of learning in and through the arts. It focuses on what happens in the interactions between students, teachers, works of art, and artistic processes in formal and informal spaces of arts learning. Issues related to learning theory, curriculum design, assessment, student-teacher relationships, and the ways in which artistic processes function as learning processes will be explored. At the heart of the course, though, are questions about the purposes of the arts in education and the nature of quality in arts learning experiences. In considering various purposes, we will investigate differences between teaching in the arts (teaching specific artistic practices) and teaching through the arts (the use of the arts to enrich the study of non-arts subject matter). We explore these topics through the study of readings, sharing stories of practice, dialogue with each other and with guest artists and educators, and through the practice of a series of reflective and analytic exercises. Learning and practicing these exercises will comprise a major portion of the course work. In some ways, S301 builds on S300 and AIE students are welcome and encouraged to take both, but they are designed to stand independently from each other. In both terms, we consider aspects of a series of core questions (below). In S301, we focus on these questions in relation to the ways in which teaching and learning happen in a wide range of settings. The questions are: 1) Identityâ€”How do I identify in this work? And in the world? 2) Purposesâ€”Why do I do what I do? 3) Valuesâ€”Why do I do what I do in the way I do it? What do I value and what does it mean to live and work in alignment with my values? 4) Responsibilityâ€” To whom and what am I responsible in my work and in the world? How do I understand my responsibility for imagining â€œthings as if they could be otherwise,â€​ as Maxine Greene wrote, and for working to achieve what I imagine? What are the particular contributions that artists,     educators, and artist/educators can make to address issues and conditions they believe need to be addressed? 5) Learningâ€”What does it mean to really learn something and what does it mean to teach? S301 is open to all HGSE Masterâ€TMs and Doctoral students. Students from other schools are welcome to apply to the instructor for permission to enroll in S301. Class sessions are videotaped for posting on the course website. These videos are accessible to all members of the S300 community, notably to provide documentation of class for those who have to miss a class session. Anyone missing class for any reason is expected to watch the posted videos from that session and discuss what happened during the session with several students and a Teaching Fellow or the course instructor. *** The Structure of this Course: Class Sessions Class meets on Fridays from 9:00 to noon. Each class session will include a check-in or warm-up, discussion of required readings, activities related to the focus of the week, work on our â€ ̃exercisesâ€TM, and a period for reflection on our â€ ̃learning stories.â€TM Readings There are required readings and/or videos each week and some weeks there are suggested readings as well. (Suggested readings may be referenced in class discussions, but students will not be held responsible for being prepared to discuss them. That said, please do the suggested readings whenever possible.) Required readings can be found on the S301 course website in Canvas. Weekly assignments are posted each Friday on the S301 course website and may reflect changes in the syllabus. It is important to check the S301 course website and not simply rely on the syllabus. Exercises Just as there are exercises designed for pianists to develop and maintain their technical abilities, I believe there are exercises that artist/educators can learn and do throughout their careers. These exercises, however, are more reflective, analytic, interpretive, and philosophical than strictly technical. In each class session, we will introduce new exercises and/or discuss your experiences doing them, though the exercises themselves will be done outside of class. Sections All students are required to participate in a weekly, one-hour section meeting led by a member of the Teaching Team. Course Requirements: Each student will be expected to: 1. Be present at all class sessions and participate in all class activities and discussions*; 2. Keep up with all assigned course readings (assignments posted weekly); 3. Be present at and participate in weekly section meetings; 4. Complete all assigned work on time; 5. Make all reasonable efforts to support the work and learning of your classmates; 6. Respect and adhere to guidelines for participation in class, as established by the Teaching Team and the class during the term. Assessment of Student Performance: Students will be evaluated on the basis of: 1. Dedication to inquiry and exploration in all aspects of class work; 2. Organization and care in preparation for class; 3. Familiarity with and thoughtfulness about issues and readings as reflected through participation in class and section; 4. Depth and rigor of thought, structure, and attention to detail in the exercises;       5. Willingness and ability to learn with and from others in the class. SATISFACTORY/UNSATISFACTORY is the default assessment given for this course. * In the event that a student is ill or needs to miss a class session for any other reason, it is the studentâ€TMs responsibility to inform the Teaching Team prior to the anticipated absence. In the event of sudden illness, the student should send word to the Teaching Team as soon as possible. Multiple absences will compromise the learning experience and can lead to an Incomplete/Unsatisfactory grade. HGSE Policy on Plagiarism from the HGSE Student Handbook: All work submitted to meet course requirements is expected to be the studentâ€TMs own. In the preparation of all papers and other written work submitted to meet course requirements and dissertations, a student must be careful to distinguish between ideas that are his or her own and those that have been derived from other sources. Information and opinions drawn from all sources are to be attributed specifically to these sources. It is the studentâ€TMs responsibility to learn and use the proper forms of citation. Quotations must be properly placed within quotation marks and must be fully cited. All paraphrased material must also be fully cited. In all cases where ideas or material presented are derived from a studentâ€TMs reading and research, the source used must be indicated. Students who submit work either not their own or without clear attribution to the original source, for whatever reason, face sanctions up to and including dismissal and expulsion. HGSE Policy on Assistance in Course Work and Writing: Students occasionally work with others or receive assistance in various aspects of their course work. Students should be very clear about how they are working with others and what types of assistance, if any, they are receiving. Students should disclose to their professors any plans for outside professional assistance on editing, statistical work, or other matters central to completing their work. The student's professor will approve those kinds and levels of assistance that support, rather than supplant, the student's research, writing and learning. If assistance was approved, the student must specify what sort of assistance they received and from whom on the paper in question, upon submission. The goal of this oversight is to preserve the status of the work as the student's own genuine intellectual product. Students should remember that the Gutman Library Academic Writing Services (AWS) is available to assist them with assessing and editing their own work. AWS assistance has been sanctioned by HGSE. PLEASE NOTE: S301 has been structured to acknowledge both the practical and intellectual values of collaboration. To this end, it may be difficult to sort out, identify and â€œpreserve the status of the work as the student's own genuine intellectual productâ€​ in all situations. Nonetheless, students are expected to acknowledge the contributions of their peers as thoroughly as possible in the text of any papers, in footnotes, or in explanatory notes at the start of a paper. Assignments Required Readings All required readings will be available either in pdf form on the course website or online (available through URL links or posted on the course website). â€œRecommendedâ€​ readings may sometimes also be found on the course website or on reserve at the circulation desk of Gutman Library. Exercises There will be seven exercises assigned during the termâ€”one every other week. Five are my design; two will be of your design. They are: 1. Talking With Artists Who Teach--DUE: Friday, February 14 2. Making Implicit Learning Theories Explicitâ€”DUE: Friday, February 28 3. Images & Identities of Artists/Educatorsâ€”DUE: Friday, March 13 4. Self Care With/Through Artâ€”DUE: Friday, March 27 5. Create Your Own Exercise--DUE: Friday, April 10 6. Each One, Teach One--DUE: Friday, April 24 7. Final Syllabi--DUE: Monday, May 4 These exercises take a variety of forms and invite the use of diverse materials, including but not limited to words on paper. All will have artifacts that can be brought to class. In the case of large-form sculptural work, performances, or other materials that canâ€TMt be brought to class due to space and/or time issues, you are responsible for documentation of that work that can be shared in whole or in part. You must also    keep the productsâ€”or documentation of the productsâ€”of your exercises throughout the term. We provide GoogleDoc folders for this purpose. More detailed instructions for each exercise will be available in class and online when the exercises are introduced. *** S301--2020: Major Topics of the Course & Exercise Assignments--Week by Week CLASS 1--FRIDAY, JANUARY 31: Introduction to S301; the foundational questions of the course, and the â€ ̃exercisesâ€TM in reflective practice for artist/educators. Questions for and from artists who teach. CLASS 2â€”FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 7: Learning: Documentation of learning stories. Looking and listening as learning and teaching. CLASS 3--FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 14: Purposes/Identity/Responsibility: Why do we do what we do in the classroom? What do you teach--and why do you teach it? Micro-analysis of theory, practice, and purposes. EXERCISE #1: TALKING WITH ARTISTS WHO TEACH DUE CLASS 4--FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 21: Purposes: Learners Deciding to Learn. Relationships in the context of arts learning. Whatâ€TMs love got to do with it? CLASS 5--FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 28: Purposes/Values/Responsibility/Learning: Questions of qualityâ€”What constitutes quality in arts learning experiences? Part One: What is a culture of quality? EXERCISE #2: MAKING IMPLICIT LEARNING THEORIES EXPLICIT DUE CLASS 6--FRIDAY, MARCH 6: Purposes/Values/Responsibility/Learning: Questions of qualityâ€”What constitutes quality in arts learning experiences? (Part Two) CLASS 7--FRIDAY, MARCH 13: Responsibility/Learning: Contexts count--and we arenâ€TMt all aware of each otherâ€TMs contexts. Culturally responsive curriculum & whose culture has capital in the classroom EXERCISE #3: ARTIST/EDUCATOR IDENTITIES DUE SPRING BREAK: WEEK OF 3/16-3/20 CLASS 8--FRIDAY, MARCH 27: Learning: Reading The Poet X. How to teach a novel. How art works--the movement between interiority and exteriority--and how that aligns with learning. EXERCISE #4: SELF-CARE WITH/THROUGH ART DUE CLASS 9--FRIDAY, APRIL 4: Values/Learning: Responsibility/Learning: Our students and ourselvesâ€”What is our relationship? What are our images of each other? What do we need to know about each other? What do we need from each other? CLASS 10--FRIDAY, APRIL 10: Values/Learning: Responsibility/Learning: Our students and ourselvesâ€”What is our relationship? What are our images of each other? What do we need to know about each other? What do we need from each other? EXERCISE #5: CREATE YOUR OWN EXERCISE DUE CLASS 11â€”FRIDAY, APRIL 17: Purposes/Values/Responsibility/Learning: Teaching the arts in schools or other organizations/institutions CLASS 12â€”FRIDAY, APRIL 24: Identity/Purposes/Values/Responsibility/Learning: Revisiting, reconsidering, and reflecting. EXERCISE #6: EACH ONE TEACH ONE DUE --------------------------------------------------------------------------- EXERCISE #7: FUTURE SYLLABI DUE ON MONDAY, MAY 4

Exercises Just as there are exercises designed for pianists to develop and maintain their technical abilities, I believe there are exercises that artist/educators can learn and do throughout their careers. These exercises, however, are more reflective, analytic, interpretive, and philosophical than strictly technical. In each class session, we will introduce new exercises and/or discuss your experiences doing them, though the exercises themselves will be done outside of class. Sections All students are required to participate in a weekly, one-hour section meeting led by a member of the Teaching Team. Course Requirements: Each student will be expected to: 1. Be present at all class sessions and participate in all class activities and discussions*; 2. Keep up with all assigned course readings (assignments posted weekly); 3. Be present at and participate in weekly section meetings; 4. Complete all assigned work on time; 5. Make all reasonable efforts to support the work and learning of your classmates; 6. Respect and adhere to guidelines for participation in class, as established by the Teaching Team and the class during the term. Assessment of Student Performance: Students will be evaluated on the basis of: 1. Dedication to inquiry and exploration in all aspects of class work; 2. Organization and care in preparation for class; 3. Familiarity with and thoughtfulness about issues and readings as reflected through participation in class and section; 4. Depth and rigor of thought, structure, and attention to detail in the exercises; 5. Willingness and ability to learn with and from others in the class. SATISFACTORY UNSATISFACTORY is the default assessment given for this course. * In the event that a student is ill or needs to miss a class session for any other reason, it is the studentâ€TMs responsibility to inform the Teaching Team prior to the anticipated absence. In the event of sudden illness, the student should send word to the Teaching Team as soon as possible. Multiple absences will compromise the learning experience and can lead to an Incomplete/Unsatisfactory grade. HGSE Policy on Plagiarism from the HGSE Student Handbook: All work submitted to meet course requirements is expected to be the studentâ€TMs own. In the preparation of all papers and other written work submitted to meet course requirements and dissertations, a student must be careful to distinguish between ideas that are his or her own and those that have been derived from other sources. Information and opinions drawn from all sources are to be attributed specifically to these sources. It is the studentâ€TMs responsibility to learn and use the proper forms of citation. Quotations must be properly placed within quotation marks and must be fully cited. All paraphrased material must also be fully cited. In all cases where ideas or material presented are derived from a studentâ€TMs reading and research, the source used must be indicated. Students who submit work either not their own or without clear attribution to the original source, for whatever reason, face sanctions up to and including dismissal and expulsion. HGSE Policy on Assistance in Course Work and Writing: Students occasionally work with others or receive assistance in various aspects of their course work. Students should be very clear about how they are working with others and what types of assistance, if any, they are receiving. Students should disclose to their professors any plans for outside professional assistance on editing, statistical work, or other matters central to completing their work. The student's professor will approve those kinds and levels of assistance that support, rather than supplant, the student's research, writing and learning. If assistance was approved, the student must specify what sort of assistance they received and from whom on the paper in question, upon submission. The goal of this oversight is to preserve the status of the work as the student's own genuine intellectual product. Students should remember that the Gutman Library Academic Writing Services (AWS) is available to assist them with assessing and editing their own work. AWS assistance has been sanctioned by HGSE. PLEASE NOTE: S301 has been structured to acknowledge both the practical and intellectual values of collaboration. To this end, it may be difficult to sort out, identify and â€œpreserve the status of the work as the student's own genuine intellectual productâ€​ in all situations. Nonetheless, students are expected to acknowledge the contributions of their peers as thoroughly as possible in the text of any papers, in footnotes, or in explanatory notes at the start of a paper. Assignments Required Readings All required readings will be available either in pdf form on the course website or online (available through URL links or posted on the course website). â€œRecommendedâ€​ readings may sometimes also be found on the course website or on reserve at the circulation desk of Gutman Library. Exercises There will be seven exercises assigned during the termâ€”one every other week. Five are my design; two will be of your design. They are: 1. Talking With Artists Who Teach--DUE: Friday, February 14 2. Making Implicit Learning Theories Explicitâ€”DUE: Friday, February 28 3. Images & Identities of Artists/Educatorsâ€”DUE: Friday, March 13 4. Self Care With/Through Artâ€”DUE: Friday, March 27 5. Create Your Own Exercise--DUE: Friday, April 10 6. Each One, Teach One--DUE: Friday, April 24 7. Final Syllabi--DUE: Monday, May 4 These exercises take a variety of forms and invite the use of diverse materials, including but not limited to words on paper. All will have artifacts that can be brought to class. In the case of large-form sculptural work, performances, or other materials that canâ€TMt be brought to class due to space and/or time issues, you are responsible for documentation of that work that can be shared in whole or in part. You must also keep the productsâ€”or documentation of the productsâ€”of your exercises throughout the term. We provide GoogleDoc folders for this purpose. More detailed instructions for each exercise will be available in class and online when the exercises are introduced. *** S301--2020: Major Topics of the Course & Exercise Assignments--Week by Week CLASS 1--FRIDAY, JANUARY 31: Introduction to S301; the foundational questions of the course, and the â€ ̃exercisesâ€TM in reflective practice for artist educators. CLASS 5--FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 28: Purposes Values Responsibility Learning: Questions of qualityâ€”What constitutes quality in arts learning experiences? Part One: What is a culture of quality? EXERCISE #2: MAKING IMPLICIT LEARNING THEORIES EXPLICIT DUE CLASS 6--FRIDAY, MARCH 6: Purposes/Values/Responsibility/Learning: Questions of qualityâ€”What constitutes quality in arts learning experiences? (Part Two) CLASS 7--FRIDAY, MARCH 13: Responsibility/Learning: Contexts count--and we arenâ€TMt all aware of each otherâ€TMs contexts. Culturally responsive curriculum & whose culture has capital in the classroom EXERCISE #3: ARTIST/EDUCATOR IDENTITIES DUE SPRING BREAK: WEEK OF 3/16-3/20 CLASS 8--FRIDAY, MARCH 27: Learning: Reading The Poet X. How to teach a novel. How art works--the movement between interiority and exteriority--and how that aligns with learning. Pre-processed text 2: S-301 The Arts and Learning Spring, 2020 Fridays from 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. Room: 203 and 214 https://docs.google.com/document/d/1weChzNoZqRm7tw3PQstDLoxE6ZBh-5Btzip6MsQwh2Q/edit? usp=sharing Teaching Fellows: Office hours: By appointment Office hours: By appointment Course Description: This course is an inquiry into the nature of learning in and through the arts. It focuses on what happens in the interactions between students, teachers, works of art, and artistic processes in formal and informal spaces of arts learning. Issues related to learning theory, curriculum design, assessment, student-teacher relationships, and the ways in which artistic processes function as learning processes will be explored. At the heart of the course, though, are questions about the purposes of the arts in education and the nature of quality in arts learning experiences. In considering various purposes, we will investigate differences between teaching in the arts (teaching specific artistic practices) and teaching through the arts (the use of the arts to enrich the study of non-arts subject matter). We explore these topics through the study of readings, sharing stories of practice, dialogue with each other and with guest artists and educators, and through the practice of a series of reflective and analytic exercises. Learning and practicing these exercises will comprise a major portion of the course work. In some ways, S301 builds on S300 and AIE students are welcome and encouraged to take both, but they are designed to stand independently from each other. In both terms, we consider aspects of a series of core questions (below). In S301, we focus on these questions in relation to the ways in which teaching and learning happen in a wide range of settings. The questions are: 1) Identityâ€”How do I identify in this work? And in the world? 2) Purposesâ€”Why do I do what I do? 3) Valuesâ€”Why do I do what I do in the way I do it? What do I value and what does it mean to live and work in alignment with my values? 4) Responsibilityâ€” To whom and what am I responsible in my work and in the world? How do I understand my responsibility for imagining â€œthings as if they could be otherwise,â€​ as wrote, and for working to achieve what I imagine? What are the particular contributions that artists, educators, and artist/educators can make to address issues and conditions they believe need to be addressed? 5) Learningâ€”What does it mean to really learn something and what does it mean to teach? S301 is open to all HGSE Masterâ€TMs and Doctoral students. Students from other schools are welcome to apply to the instructor for permission to enroll in S301. Class sessions are videotaped for posting on the course website. These videos are accessible to all members of the S300 community, notably to provide documentation of class for those who have to miss a class session. Anyone missing class for any reason is expected to watch the posted videos from that session and discuss what happened during the session with several students and a Teaching Fellow or the course instructor. *** The Structure of this Course: Class Sessions Class meets on Fridays from 9:00 to noon. Each class session will include a check-in or warm-up, discussion of required readings, activities related to the focus of the week, work on our â€ ̃exercisesâ€TM, and a period for reflection on our â€ ̃learning stories.â€TM Readings There are required readings and/or videos each week and some weeks there are suggested readings as well. (Suggested readings may be referenced in class discussions, but students will not be held responsible for being prepared to discuss them. That said, please do the suggested readings whenever possible.) Required readings can be found on the S301 course website in Canvas. Respect and adhere to guidelines for participation in class, as established by the Teaching Team and the class during the term. Assessment of Student Performance: Students will be evaluated on the basis of: 1. Dedication to inquiry and exploration in all aspects of class work; 2. Organization and care in preparation for class; 3. Familiarity with and thoughtfulness about issues and readings as reflected through participation in class and section; 4. Depth and rigor of thought, structure, and attention to detail in the exercises; 5. Willingness and ability to learn with and from others in the class. Text: AFVS 76_syllabus.docx  Sign up for Office Hours appointments here: https://outlook.office365.com/owa/calendar/DavidJoselitOfficeHours@HU.onmicrosoft.com/bookings/ AFVS 76: The Language of Modern Art Fall 2022; Tu, Th; 1:30 - 2:30 pm; Carpenter Center B04 Instructor: David Joselit (djoselit@fas.harvard.edu) office hours Wednesdays, 4-6 in the Chair's office, Carpenter Center, or by appointment Teaching Fellow: Mahan Moalemi (mahanmoalemi@g.harvard.edu) ****** Course Description and Objectives: If the tradition of Western painting begins with the invention of perspective in the Renaissance, modern art also has its specific ways of seeing. Rather than creating the illusion of space, these modern grammars of form tend to stress duality and contradiction. This course will introduce students to the history of modern Western art from the late 19th century to the present, by considering a sequence of procedures or methods of producing art. This lexicon of modernism will be organized in a roughly chronological sequence, but also ordered according to three themes: "Grammars of the Human," which will investigate how modern geopolitics, in its simultaneous introduction of democracy and colonialism, revised what counts as a person; "Grammars of Industry," which will explore how industrial production served as a model for artmaking; and "Grammars of Information," which considers how the rise of the information era, in which virtually everything may be translated into data, has effected modern art. Each of these procedures is defined below in the syllabus and will be elaborated in lectures supplemented by readings. Together they will establish the elements of a language of modern art that is still in use today. Sections will stress direct encounter and analysis of art in Harvard's museum collections. The course is designed as an introduction and requires no previous acquaintance with modern or contemporary art. Course Policies and Expectations: It is expected that students attend all lectures and sections. Absences must be explained through a doctor's note or communication from a residential dean. Readings and Access: Required Text: Hal Foster et. al, American Art Since 1900, third edition vols 1 & 2 (London: Thames & Hudson, 2016); special link to the Harvard Coop here All readings, including the required text, are on reserve at the Fine Arts Library. All essays (excluding the required text) are also posted on the course Canvas site in pdf format in the "files" section. Assignments and Grading Procedures: Midterm Examination: The exam, on October 18th, will consist of essay questions covering assigned readings and works of art that have been discussed in the course. (30% of grade). Term Paper: A 7- to 10-page paper will be due during reading period. Students will be asked to reflect on one of the "keywords" covered since the midterm examination in light of works of art you have seen in person in Harvard or Boston museums (or in collections elsewhere if you are able to travel during the term). Topics must be approved in conversation with the instructor or TF, no later than November 17. (50% of grade). Participation: Students are expected to attend lectures and sections and to participate in discussion. (20 % of grade). Late Assignments: You must receive permission for an extension from the instructor before the due date. Otherwise, you will lose one-third of a letter grade for each day past the deadline. No extensions will be granted after the due date has passed.          Accommodations for Students with Disabilities: Students needing academic adjustments or accommodations because of a documented disability must present their Faculty Letter from the Accessible Education Office (AEO) and speak with the professor by the end of the second week of the term, 2/4/22. Failure to do so may result in the Course Head's inability to respond in a timely manner. All discussions will remain confidential, although Faculty are invited to contact AEO to discuss appropriate implementation. ***** GRAMMARS OF THE HUMAN 9/1: The Impression: A painterly mark that seeks to simultaneously register the temperament of an artist (their subjectivity) and an objective optical truth. Reading: Richard Shiff, CÃ©zanne and the End of Impressionism (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1984), 14-38. 9/6: Double Consciousness: This expression, drawn from the African American philosopher W.E.B. Du Bois' definition of looking at oneself through the eyes of others, indicates an aesthetic strategy for deploying and recoding stereotypes. Reading: Shawn Michelle Smith, â€œ'Looking at Oneâ€TMs Self Through the Eyes of Others': W.E.B. Du Boisâ€TMs Photographs for the 1900 Paris Exposition,â€​ African American Review (Winter 2000), pp. 581- 599. 9/8, 9/13: Disfiguration: The manipulation of human anatomies or natural form for expressive purposes. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 1: 1900a, pp. 64-68; 1903, pp. 76-81; 1906, pp. 82-89; 1907, pp. 90-96; 1930b, pp. 287-291. 9/15, 9/20, 9/22: Non-Objectivity: A practice of painting (and more rarely of sculpture and film) in which an autonomous visual system is invented without any reference to things in the world. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 1: 1908, pp. 97-101; 1913, pp. 130-136; 1915, pp. 142-146; 1917a, pp. 160-165. Anne Umland and Walburgia Krupp, "Sophie Taeuber-Arp: An Introduction," in Anne Umland and Walburgia Krupp with Charlotte Healy, eds., Sophie Taeuber-Arp; Living Abstraction (New York: The Museum of Modern Art; Basel: Kunstmuseum Basel, 2021), pp. 19-28. GRAMMARS OF INDUSTRY 9/27, 9/29, 10/4: Collage/Montage/Assemblage: Collage and assemblage incorporate heterogenous materials within an artwork, video, or film, ranging from works on paper to sculpture. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 1: 1912, pp. 124-129; 1920, pp. 186-191; 1921b, pp. 198-203. Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1959b, pp. 477-482. Kellie Jones, "Now Dig This! An Introduction," in Kellie Jones, Now Dig This! Art and Black Los Angeles 1960-1980 (Los Angeles: Hammer Museum, University of California; New York: DelMonico Books; Munich: Prestel, 2011), pp. 15-27. 10/6: Readymade: The strategy of using found objects, usually commodities, sometimes amended in simple or more elaborate ways, in the place of artworks. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 1: 1914, pp. 137-141 Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1960a, pp. 504-508 10/11, 10/13: Automatism: The generation of aesthetic content through unconscious procedures, such as automatic drawing or recording dreams.            Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 1: 1909, pp. 102-109; 1922, pp. 204-208; 1923, pp. 209-213; 1924, pp. 214-219 Juliet Koss, "Liubov Popova; Production Clothing for Actor No. 7, 1922," and Martino Stierli, "Alexandra Exter; Designs for a Mural in the Mechanical Engineering Pavilion at the All-Russian Exhibition of Agriculture and Home Industries, 1923," in Jodi Hauptman and Adrian Sudhalter, Engineer, Agitator, Constructor; The Artist Reinvented, 1918-1939; The Merrill C. Berman Collection (New York: The Museum of Modern Art, 2020), pp. 64-73 10/18: Midterm Examination GRAMMARS OF INFORMATION 10/20, 10/25: Double Consciousness 2: This expression, drawn from the African American philosopher W.E.B. Du Bois' definition of looking at oneself through the eyes of others, indicates an aesthetic strategy for deploying and recoding stereotypes. Reading: Sharon F. Patton, African-American Art (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1998), pp. 105-159. 10/27, 11/1, 11/3: Appropriation: The capture of found still or moving image content as material for art; closely related to the Readymade but expanding its practice beyond objects to images. Related also to practice of simulation defined as producing a copy without an original. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1960c, pp. 515-519; 1964b, pp. 562-567; 1977a, pp. 672-675; 1980, pp. 688-691. Bill Anthes, Edgar Heap of Birds (Durham: Duke University Press, 2015), pp. 117-161. 11/8: Score: The organization of an artwork, often composed of either possible or actual actions to be performed, in a form analogous to a musical score, but often adopting text or photography instead of musical notation. Scores are typically open to interpretation in different iterations or when adopted by different artists. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1953, pp. 430-434; 1962a, pp. 526-533. Aria Dean, "Worry the Image," Art in America, June/July 2017, pp. 41-44. 11/10, 11/15: Process: A principle of artmaking which is based on the behavior of materials when manipulated, as opposed to mimetic or abstract forms of representation. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1966b, pp. 576-580; 1969, pp. 610-613. Robert Morris, "Anti Form," Artforum, v. 6 (8) 1968, 33-35. 11/17, 11/22: Seriality: A mode of composition based on a replication of endless types or repetitions of aesthetic elements, as opposed to their composition according to any kind of closed design. Like the score, seriality is an open form of combining aesthetic elements rather than a closed figure. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1965, pp. 568-571; 1968a, pp. 597-602. David Joselit, Feedback: Television Against Democracy (Cambridge, MA: The MIT Press, 2007), pp. 1-41. 11/29, 12/1: Information: Art practices often labeled "Conceptual" that are rooted in discursive forms of knowledge such as statements, documentary photography, and archives. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1968b, pp. 603-609; 1972b, pp. 630-635; 1993c, pp. 741-746. Hal Foster, "An Archival Impulse," October n. 110 (Autumn 2004), pp. 3-22.

All essays (excluding the required text) are also posted on the course Canvas site in pdf format in the "files" section. Assignments and Grading Procedures: Midterm Examination: The exam, on October 18th, will consist of essay questions covering assigned readings and works of art that have been discussed in the course. (30% of grade). Term Paper: A 7- to 10-page paper will be due during reading period. Students will be asked to reflect on one of the "keywords" covered since the midterm examination in light of works of art you have seen in person in Harvard or Boston museums (or in collections elsewhere if you are able to travel during the term). Topics must be approved in conversation with the instructor or TF, no later than November 17. (50% of grade). Participation: Students are expected to attend lectures and sections and to participate in discussion. (20 % of grade). Late Assignments: You must receive permission for an extension from the instructor before the due date. Otherwise, you will lose one-third of a letter grade for each day past the deadline. No extensions will be granted after the due date has passed. Accommodations for Students with Disabilities: Students needing academic adjustments or accommodations because of a documented disability must present their Faculty Letter from the Accessible Education Office (AEO) and speak with the professor by the end of the second week of the term, 2/4/22. Failure to do so may result in the Course Head's inability to respond in a timely manner. All discussions will remain confidential, although Faculty are invited to contact AEO to discuss appropriate implementation. ***** GRAMMARS OF THE HUMAN 9/1: The Impression: A painterly mark that seeks to simultaneously register the temperament of an artist (their subjectivity) and an objective optical truth. Reading: Richard Shiff, CÃ©zanne and the End of Impressionism (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1984), 14-38. 9/6: Double Consciousness: This expression, drawn from the African American philosopher W.E.B. Du Bois' definition of looking at oneself through the eyes of others, indicates an aesthetic strategy for deploying and recoding stereotypes. Reading: Shawn Michelle Smith, â€œ'Looking at Oneâ€TMs Self Through the Eyes of Others': W.E.B. Du Boisâ€TMs Photographs for the 1900 Paris Exposition,â€​ African American Review (Winter 2000), pp. 581- 599. 9/8, 9/13: Disfiguration: The manipulation of human anatomies or natural form for expressive purposes. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 1: 1900a, pp. 64-68; 1903, pp. 76-81; 1906, pp. 82-89; 1907, pp. 90-96; 1930b, pp. 287-291. 9/15, 9/20, 9/22: Non-Objectivity: A practice of painting (and more rarely of sculpture and film) in which an autonomous visual system is invented without any reference to things in the world. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 1: 1908, pp. 97-101; 1913, pp. 130-136; 1915, pp. 142-146; 1917a, pp. 160-165. Anne Umland and Walburgia Krupp, "Sophie Taeuber-Arp: An Introduction," in Anne Umland and Walburgia Krupp with Charlotte Healy, eds., Sophie Taeuber-Arp; Living Abstraction (New York: The Museum of Modern Art; Basel: Kunstmuseum Basel, 2021), pp. 19-28. GRAMMARS OF INDUSTRY 9/27, 9/29, 10/4: Collage/Montage/Assemblage: Collage and assemblage incorporate heterogenous materials within an artwork, video, or film, ranging from works on paper to sculpture. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 1: 1912, pp. 124-129; 1920, pp. 186-191; 1921b, pp. 198-203. Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1959b, pp. 477-482. Kellie Jones, "Now Dig This! An Introduction," in Kellie Jones, Now Dig This! Art and Black Los Angeles 1960-1980 (Los Angeles: Hammer Museum, University of California; New York: DelMonico Books; Munich: Prestel, 2011), pp. 15-27. 10/6: Readymade: The strategy of using found objects, usually commodities, sometimes amended in simple or more elaborate ways, in the place of artworks. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 1: 1914, pp. 137-141 Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1960a, pp. 504-508 10/11, 10/13: Automatism: The generation of aesthetic content through unconscious procedures, such as automatic drawing or recording dreams. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 1: 1909, pp. 102-109; 1922, pp. 204-208; 1923, pp. 209-213; 1924, pp. 214-219 Juliet Koss, "Liubov Popova; Production Clothing for Actor No. 7, 1922," and Martino Stierli, "Alexandra Exter; Designs for a Mural in the Mechanical Engineering Pavilion at the All-Russian Exhibition of Agriculture and Home Industries, 1923," in Jodi Hauptman and Adrian Sudhalter, Engineer, Agitator, Constructor; The Artist Reinvented, 1918-1939; The Merrill C. Berman Collection (New York: The Museum of Modern Art, 2020), pp. 64-73 10/18: Midterm Examination GRAMMARS OF INFORMATION 10/20, 10/25: Double Consciousness 2: This expression, drawn from the African American philosopher W.E.B. Du Bois' definition of looking at oneself through the eyes of others, indicates an aesthetic strategy for deploying and recoding stereotypes. Reading: Sharon F. Patton, African-American Art (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1998), pp. 105-159. 10/27, 11/1, 11/3: Appropriation: The capture of found still or moving image content as material for art; closely related to the Readymade but expanding its practice beyond objects to images. Related also to practice of simulation defined as producing a copy without an original. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1960c, pp. 515-519; 1964b, pp. 562-567; 1977a, pp. 672-675; 1980, pp. 688-691. Bill Anthes, Edgar Heap of Birds (Durham: Duke University Press, 2015), pp. 117-161. 11/8: Score: The organization of an artwork, often composed of either possible or actual actions to be performed, in a form analogous to a musical score, but often adopting text or photography instead of musical notation. Scores are typically open to interpretation in different iterations or when adopted by different artists. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1953, pp. 430-434; 1962a, pp. 526-533. Aria Dean, "Worry the Image," Art in America, June/July 2017, pp. 41-44. 11/10, 11/15: Process: A principle of artmaking which is based on the behavior of materials when manipulated, as opposed to mimetic or abstract forms of representation. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1966b, pp. 576-580; 1969, pp. 610-613. Robert Morris, "Anti Form," Artforum, v. 6 (8) 1968, 33-35. 11/17, 11/22: Seriality: A mode of composition based on a replication of endless types or repetitions of aesthetic elements, as opposed to their composition according to any kind of closed design. Like the score, seriality is an open form of combining aesthetic elements rather than a closed figure. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1965, pp. 568-571; 1968a, pp. 597-602. David Joselit, Feedback: Television Against Democracy (Cambridge, MA: The MIT Press, 2007), pp. 1-41. 11/29, 12/1: Information: Art practices often labeled "Conceptual" that are rooted in discursive forms of knowledge such as statements, documentary photography, and archives. Reading: Art Since 1900, third edition v. 2: 1968b, pp. 603-609; 1972b, pp. 630-635; 1993c, pp. 741-746. Hal Foster, "An Archival Impulse," October n. 110 (Autumn 2004), pp. 3-22.
Pre-processed text 2: AFVS 76_syllabus.docx Sign up for Office Hours appointments here: AFVS 76: The Language of Modern Art Fall 2022; Tu, Th; 1:30 - 2:30 pm; Carpenter Center B04 Instructor: office hours Wednesdays, 4-6 in the Chair's office, Carpenter Center, or by appointment Teaching Fellow:  ****** Course Description and Objectives: If the tradition of Western painting begins with the invention of perspective in the Renaissance, modern art also has its specific ways of seeing. Rather than creating the illusion of space, these modern grammars of form tend to stress duality and contradiction. This course will introduce students to the history of modern Western art from the late 19th century to the present, by considering a sequence of procedures or methods of producing art. This lexicon of modernism will be organized in a roughly chronological sequence, but also ordered according to three themes: "Grammars of the Human," which will investigate how modern geopolitics, in its simultaneous introduction of democracy and colonialism, revised what counts as a person; "Grammars of Industry," which will explore how industrial production served as a model for artmaking; and "Grammars of Information," which considers how the rise of the information era, in which virtually everything may be translated into data, has effected modern art. Each of these procedures is defined below in the syllabus and will be elaborated in lectures supplemented by readings. Together they will establish the elements of a language of modern art that is still in use today. Sections will stress direct encounter and analysis of art in Harvard's museum collections. The course is designed as an introduction and requires no previous acquaintance with modern or contemporary art. Course Policies and Expectations: It is expected that students attend all lectures and sections. Absences must be explained through a doctor's note or communication from a residential dean. Readings and Access: Required Text: American Art Since 1900, third edition vols 1 & 2 special link to the Harvard Coop here All readings, including the required text, are on reserve at the Fine Arts Library. All essays (excluding the required text) are also posted on the course Canvas site in pdf format in the "files" section. Assignments and Grading Procedures: Midterm Examination: The exam, on October 18th, will consist of essay questions covering assigned readings and works of art that have been discussed in the course. (30% of grade). Term Paper: A 7- to 10-page paper will be due during reading period. Students will be asked to reflect on one of the "keywords" covered since the midterm examination in light of works of art you have seen in person in Harvard or Boston museums (or in collections elsewhere if you are able to travel during the term). Topics must be approved in conversation with the instructor or TF, no later than November 17. (50% of grade). Participation: Students are expected to attend lectures and sections and to participate in discussion. (20 % of grade). Late Assignments: You must receive permission for an extension from the instructor before the due date. Otherwise, you will lose one-third of a letter grade for each day past the deadline. No extensions will be granted after the due date has passed. Accommodations for Students with Disabilities: Students needing academic adjustments or accommodations because of a documented disability must present their Faculty Letter from the Accessible Education Office (AEO) and speak with the professor by the end of the second week of the term, 2/4/22. Failure to do so may result in the Course Head's inability to respond in a timely manner. All discussions will remain confidential, although Faculty are invited to contact AEO to discuss appropriate implementation. ***** GRAMMARS OF THE HUMAN 9/1: The Impression: A painterly mark that seeks to simultaneously register the temperament of an artist (their subjectivity) and an objective optical truth. Reading: Richard Shiff, CÃ©zanne and the End of Impressionism (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1984), 14-38. 9/6: Double Consciousness: This expression, drawn from the African American philosopher definition of looking at oneself through the eyes of others, indicates an aesthetic strategy for deploying and recoding stereotypes. Text: AFVS 179 POLITICAL CINEMA Fall 2021 Seminars: Monday, 3-5 pm, Carpenter Center 401 (except the first meeting, which will be on Wednesday, Sept 1) Screenings: Tuesday, 12-2:45 pm, Carpenter Center Lecture Hall Dennis Lim, dennislim@fas.harvard.edu Office hours by appointment Teaching fellow: Julia Sharpe, juliasharpe@g.harvard.edu Office hours by appointment Interested students are invited to a zoom shopping session Tuesday, August 24, 12â€“1 pm ET zoom link here and under the left side zoom tab. ***A note on enrollment: If you would like to enroll in this class, please complete this questionnaire by noon on August 25th. If there are more than 15 applicants, we will endeavor to create a balanced class while prioritizing students with concentrations in AFVS or FVS, seniors and juniors with a secondary field in AFVS, and those working on theses or dissertations related to politics and cinema." Overview This seminar surveys the landscape of global political cinema from the explosive 1960s to the unsettled present. Our central aims are to explore the relationship between cinema and politics, and to expand our understanding of the ways in which cinema can be political. Some questions we will ask: How can a film be political? Where do a filmâ€TMs politics reside? What does it mean to make films politically, and to read films politically? We will consider the connection between politics and form, the possibilities of cinema as politics, and cinemaâ€TMs representation of politics as well as cinemaâ€TMs politics of representation. We will trace a partial history of committed cinema and explore the role of film in revolutionary culture. The emancipatory movements of the 1960s and 1970s inevitably dominate such histories, and they occupy much of our attention in this class. But we will not treat the cinemas of resistance of yesteryear solely as a historical phenomenon; we will also ask how these works resonate today, in a very different political and cultural context, and how they might help us frame our present understanding of politics and cinema. Instead of adhering to a strict chronological or geographic progression, the class is structured in a way that allows us to bridge space and time â€” we will study classics of militant cinema alongside a diverse       array of recent and contemporary approaches to making political films. Viewing and reading Films will be screened every Tuesday in the Carpenter Center Lecture Hall as well as assigned to you to watch in your own time. Films assigned for home viewing will be made available as links or files on a shared drive, or can be found on various streaming sites (Criterion Channel, Ovid.TV, YouTube, iTunes, Netflix, Amazon, Kanopy). You are encouraged to take notes while watching films (or immediately after) â€” these will be useful for discussions and for your contributions to the class blog. Readings will be posted on the course site. Essays assigned for a given week should be read before that weekâ€TMs discussion. Screenings and readings, especially in later weeks, are subject to change, as we will likely adapt our viewing and reading lists based on the interests of the class. Please be aware that some of the films we will watch in this class may involve varying degrees of discomfort on the part of the viewer. This discomfort, which may be the result of violent or otherwise disturbing content or challenging formal strategy, is integral to the experience of political cinema and has the potential to act as a catalyst for productive and thoughtful discussion. Enrolling in this seminar brings with it the expectation that you are willing to engage with such material. If you have any questions about this, please write to either Dennis or Julia. Assignments and guidelines Discussion groups and class presentations: In addition to the weekly seminar, students will participate in smaller, rotating discussion groups to which you will be assigned. You may meet in person or on Zoom â€” try to set aside at least 45 minutes for each meeting. Each group will collectively submit at least three discussion questions ahead of the Monday class (due by Sunday 6 pm ET); you may also select a passage from an assigned film or text to present to the bigger group for closer analysis. Class blog: Write eight one-page (approx 400-5oo words) posts for the Canvas class blog. These can be responses to films on our viewing list (individual films, or pairings or groups thereof), or to othersâ€TM posts. Think of these short papers as opportunities to flesh out your reactions to various films; your analyses should be integrated with ideas drawn from class discussions, assigned readings, or your own research. This is an exercise you should be engaged in throughout the semester. The first four responses are due by October 25 and the rest by December 3. A written one-page proposal for your final project is due November 5. The project itself is due December 8. The final project can take one of the following forms: a written paper (10-12 pages) on a film, filmmaker, or theme of your choice, with some relevance to political cinema a written curatorial program, including a title, introductory essay (3-4 pages), and film notes (1 page each), for a themed screening series on some aspect of political cinema, consisting of at least 8 and no more than 12 films. The majority of your program should consist of films that were not discussed in class. a short film, video essay, or multimedia piece with some relevance to political cinema The success of any seminar depends on active and thoughtful participation from each member of the class. Please be prepared to discuss and engage with all assigned films and readings. We will be joined occasionally by guest filmmakers, scholars, or critics for brief discussions about their work. Grades: seminar attendance and participation (30%), discussion group assignments and class presentations (10%), class blog (25%), final project proposal (5%), final project (30%). Grace period and attendance: A total grace period of three days is allotted to each student for the semester. Late submissions beyond the grace period will affect your grade, as will more than one unexcused absence. Academic Integrity: Students are expected to adhere to Harvardâ€TMs Academic Integrity policies. Outside    of the small-group presentations, all work for this class, including the viewing log entries and final project, are to be completed independently. Please adhere to standard citation practices for all written work. Accommodations for Students With Disabilities: Harvard provides academic accommodations for students with disabilities. Please notify the professor as soon as possible if you expect to be receiving accommodations. WEEK 1, Sept 1 class Reading Films Politically READ Jane Gaines, â€œPolitical Mimesisâ€​ Serge Daney, â€œThe Tracking Shot in Kapoâ€​ Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick, â€œParanoid Reading and Reparative Readingâ€​ OPTIONAL James Baldwin, The Devil Finds Work [excerpt] Robin Wood, â€œResponsibilities of a Gay Film Criticâ€​ Erika Balsom, â€œIn Search of the Female Gazeâ€​ WEEK 2, Sept 7 screening/Sept 13 class Concerning Violence WATCH The Battle of Algiers (Gillo Pontecorvo, 1966, 121 min) Nocturama (Bertrand Bonello, 2016, 130 min) READ Frantz Fanon, â€œConcerning Violenceâ€​ Mark Fisher, Capitalist Realism [excerpts] WEEK 3, Sept 14 screening/Sept 20 class Politics and Form WATCH The Hour of the Furnaces Pt 1 (Octavio Getino and Fernando Solanas, 1968, 85 min) Sambizanga (Sarah Maldoror, 1972, 102 min) Handsworth Songs (John Akomfrah/Black Audio Film Collective, 1986, 61 min) READ Fernando Solanas and Octavio Getino, â€œToward a Third Cinemaâ€​ AimÃ© CÃ©saire, â€œDiscourse on Colonialismâ€​ Brett Story, â€œHow Does It End? Story and the Property Formâ€​ WEEK 4, Sept 21 screening/Sept 27 class Here and Elsewhere WATCH Ici et ailleurs (Dziga Vertov Group, 1976, 53 min) Silvered Water, Syria Self-Portrait (Ossama Mohammed and Wiam Simav Bedirxan, 2014, 92 min) Notturno (Gianfranco Rosi, 2020, 100 min) READ Jean-Luc Godard, â€œWhat Is To Be Done?â€​   Peter Wollen, â€œGodard and Counter-Cinemaâ€​ Susan Sontag, Regarding the Pain of Others [excerpts] WEEK 5, Sept 28 screening/Oct 4 class Then and Now WATCH Twenty Years Later (Eduardo Coutinho, 1984, 119 min) Martin Eden (Pietro Marcello, 2019, 128 min) La Commune (Paris, 1871) (Peter Watkins, 2000, 345 min) [excerpts] READ Mark Fisher, â€œWhat Is Hauntology?â€​ Avery Gordon, â€œSome Thoughts on Haunting and Futurityâ€​ WEEK 6, Oct 5 screening/no class Oct 11 Revisions and Reverberations: A Case Study WATCH La Chinoise (Jean-Luc Godard, 1967, 99 min) The Inheritance (Ephraim Asili, 2020, 102 min) Just a Movement (Vincent Meessen, 2021, 110 min) READ James S. Williams, â€œThe Politics of Violence and the End(s) of Art: Speaking (for) the Other in La Chinoiseâ€​ WEEK 7, Oct 12 screening/Oct 18 class Neoliberalism WATCH Rosetta (Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne, 1999, 93 min) Bamako (Abderrahmane Sissako, 2006, 117 min) READ Lauren Berlant, â€œNearly Utopian, Nearly Normal: Post-Fordist Affect in La Promesse and Rosettaâ€​ Tejumola Olaniyan, â€œOf Rations and Rationalities: The World Bank, African Hunger, and Abderrahmane Sissakoâ€TMs Bamakoâ€​ WEEK 8, Oct 19 screening/Oct 25 class Seeing the Present WATCH A Night of Knowing Nothing (Payal Kapadia, 2021, 90 min) Bad Luck Banging and Loony Porn (Radu Jude, 2021, 106 min) READ Giorgio Agamben, â€œWhat Is the Contemporary?â€​ Amos Vogel, Film as a Subversive Art [excerpts] WEEK 9, Oct 26 screening/Nov 1 class Futurist Dystopias   WATCH Ice (Robert Kramer, 1970, 130 min) Born in Flames (Lizzie Borden, 1983, 90 min) READ Fredric Jameson, â€œProgress versus Utopia; or, Can We Imagine the Future?â€​ WEEK 10, Nov 2 screening/Nov 8 class The Uses of Genre WATCH Antonio das Mortes (Glauber Rocha, 1969, 100 min) [excerpts] Sleep Dealer (Alex Rivera, 2008, 90 min) Bacurau (Kleber Mendonca Filho and Juliano Dornelles, 2019, 132 min) READ Glauber Rocha, On Cinema [excerpts including â€œAn Aesthetics of Hungerâ€​ and â€œAn Aesthetics of Dreamingâ€​] WEEK 11, Nov 9 screening/Nov 15 class After the Revolution WATCH Zabriskie Point (Michelangelo Antonioni, 1970, 114 min) The Devil Probably (Robert Bresson, 1977, 96 min) United Red Army (Koji Wakamatsu, 2007, 180 min) [excerpts] READ J. Halberstam, The Queer Art of Failure [excerpts] WEEK 12, Nov 16 screening/Nov 22 class The Sweep of History WATCH Lucia (Humberto Solas, 1968, 160 min) Platform (Jia Zhangke, 2000, 193 min) READ Paul A. Schroeder RodrÃ​guez, â€œThe Heresy of Cuban Cinemaâ€​ Zhang Zhen, â€œBearing Witness: Chinese Urban Cinema in the Age of â€ ̃Transformationâ€TMâ€​ WEEK 13, Nov 23 screening/Nov 29 class The Politics of the Everyday WATCH El Futuro (Luis LÃ3pez Carrasco, 2013, 68 min) Hale County This Morning This Evening (RaMell Ross, 2018, 76 min) Lovers Rock (Steve McQueen, 2020, 68 min) READ Kathleen Stewart, Ordinary Affects [excerpts] Nov 30: final screening TBD SHORTS  In addition to the mostly feature-length films listed in the weekly outlines above, we will also watch several short- and medium-length films, mostly drawn from the following list. These will be assigned occasionally as supplemental viewing or viewed together in class or during your discussion groups. The House Is Black (Forough Farrokhzad, 1962, 26 min) Now! (Santiago Alvarez, 1965, 6 min) A bientot jâ€TMespere (Chris Marker and Mario Marret, 1968, 55 min) I Am Somebody (Madeline Anderson, 1970, 28 min) Solidarity (Joyce Wieland, 1973, 11 min) This Lemon Tastes of Apple (Hiwa K, 2011, 13 min) Ears, Nose and Throat (Kevin Jerome Everson, 2016, 10 min) Foyer (Ismail Bahri, 2016, 32 min) Love Is the Message, the Message Is Death (Arthur Jafa, 2016, 8 min)

Think of these short papers as opportunities to flesh out your reactions to various films; your analyses should be integrated with ideas drawn from class discussions, assigned readings, or your own research. This is an exercise you should be engaged in throughout the semester. The first four responses are due by October 25 and the rest by December 3. A written one-page proposal for your final project is due November 5. The project itself is due December 8. The final project can take one of the following forms: a written paper (10-12 pages) on a film, filmmaker, or theme of your choice, with some relevance to political cinema a written curatorial program, including a title, introductory essay (3-4 pages), and film notes (1 page each), for a themed screening series on some aspect of political cinema, consisting of at least 8 and no more than 12 films. The majority of your program should consist of films that were not discussed in class. a short film, video essay, or multimedia piece with some relevance to political cinema The success of any seminar depends on active and thoughtful participation from each member of the class. Please be prepared to discuss and engage with all assigned films and readings. We will be joined occasionally by guest filmmakers, scholars, or critics for brief discussions about their work. Grades: seminar attendance and participation (30%), discussion group assignments and class presentations (10%), class blog (25%), final project proposal (5%), final project (30%). Grace period and attendance: A total grace period of three days is allotted to each student for the semester. Late submissions beyond the grace period will affect your grade, as will more than one unexcused absence. Academic Integrity: Students are expected to adhere to Harvardâ€TMs Academic Integrity policies. Outside of the small-group presentations, all work for this class, including the viewing log entries and final project, are to be completed independently. Please adhere to standard citation practices for all written work. Accommodations for Students With Disabilities: Harvard provides academic accommodations for students with disabilities. Please notify the professor as soon as possible if you expect to be receiving accommodations. Pre-processed text 2: AFVS 179 POLITICAL CINEMA Fall 2021 Seminars: Monday, 3-5 pm, Carpenter Center 401 (except the first meeting, which will be on Wednesday, Sept 1) Screenings: Tuesday, 12-2:45 pm, Carpenter Center Lecture Hall  Office hours by appointment Teaching fellow:  Office hours by appointment Interested students are invited to a zoom shopping session Tuesday, August 24, 12â€“1 pm ET zoom link here and under the left side zoom tab. ***A note on enrollment: If you would like to enroll in this class, please complete this questionnaire by noon on August 25th. If there are more than 15 applicants, we will endeavor to create a balanced class while prioritizing students with concentrations in AFVS or FVS, seniors and juniors with a secondary field in AFVS, and those working on theses or dissertations related to politics and cinema." Overview This seminar surveys the landscape of global political cinema from the explosive 1960s to the unsettled present. Our central aims are to explore the relationship between cinema and politics, and to expand our understanding of the ways in which cinema can be political. Some questions we will ask: How can a film be political? Where do a filmâ€TMs politics reside? What does it mean to make films politically, and to read films politically? We will consider the connection between politics and form, the possibilities of cinema as politics, and cinemaâ€TMs representation of politics as well as cinemaâ€TMs politics of representation. We will trace a partial history of committed cinema and explore the role of film in revolutionary culture. The emancipatory movements of the 1960s and 1970s inevitably dominate such histories, and they occupy much of our attention in this class. But we will not treat the cinemas of resistance of yesteryear solely as a historical phenomenon; we will also ask how these works resonate today, in a very different political and cultural context, and how they might help us frame our present understanding of politics and cinema. Instead of adhering to a strict chronological or geographic progression, the class is structured in a way that allows us to bridge space and time â€” we will study classics of militant cinema alongside a diverse array of recent and contemporary approaches to making political films. Viewing and reading Films will be screened every Tuesday in the Carpenter Center Lecture Hall as well as assigned to you to watch in your own time. Films assigned for home viewing will be made available as links or files on a shared drive, or can be found on various streaming sites (Criterion Channel, Ovid.TV, YouTube, iTunes, Netflix, Amazon, Kanopy). You are encouraged to take notes while watching films (or immediately after) â€” these will be useful for discussions and for your contributions to the class blog. Readings will be posted on the course site. Essays assigned for a given week should be read before that weekâ€TMs discussion. Screenings and readings, especially in later weeks, are subject to change, as we will likely adapt our viewing and reading lists based on the interests of the class. Please be aware that some of the films we will watch in this class may involve varying degrees of discomfort on the part of the viewer. This discomfort, which may be the result of violent or otherwise disturbing content or challenging formal strategy, is integral to the experience of political cinema and has the potential to act as a catalyst for productive and thoughtful discussion. Enrolling in this seminar brings with it the expectation that you are willing to engage with such material. If you have any questions about this, please write to either. Assignments and guidelines Discussion groups and class presentations: In addition to the weekly seminar, students will participate in smaller, rotating discussion groups to which you will be assigned. You may meet in person or on Zoom â€” try to set aside at least 45 minutes for each meeting. Each group will collectively submit at least three discussion questions ahead of the Monday class (due by Sunday 6 pm ET); you may also select a passage from an assigned film or text to present to the bigger group for closer analysis. Class blog: Write eight one-page (approx 400-5oo words) posts for the Canvas class blog. These can be responses to films on our viewing list (individual films, or pairings or groups thereof), or to othersâ€TM posts. Think of these short papers as opportunities to flesh out your reactions to various films; your analyses should be integrated with ideas drawn from class discussions, assigned readings, or your own research. This is an exercise you should be engaged in throughout the semester. The first four responses are due by October 25 and the rest by December 3. A written one-page proposal for your final project is due November 5. The project itself is due December 8. The final project can take one of the following forms: a written paper (10-12 pages) on a film, filmmaker, or theme of your choice, with some relevance to political cinema a written curatorial program, including a title, introductory essay (3-4 pages), and film notes (1 page each), for a themed screening series on some aspect of political cinema, consisting of at least 8 and no more than 12 films. The majority of your program should consist of films that were not discussed in class. a short film, video essay, or multimedia piece with some relevance to political cinema The success of any seminar depends on active and thoughtful participation from each member of the class. Please be prepared to discuss and engage with all assigned films and readings. We will be joined occasionally by guest filmmakers, scholars, or critics for brief discussions about their work. Grades: seminar attendance and participation (30%), discussion group assignments and class presentations (10%), class blog (25%), final project proposal (5%), final project (30%). Late submissions beyond the grace period will affect your grade, as will more than one unexcused absence. Academic Integrity: Students are expected to adhere to Harvardâ€TMs Academic Integrity policies. Outside of the small-group presentations, all work for this class, including the viewing log entries and final project, are to be completed independently. Please adhere to standard citation practices for all written work. Accommodations for Students With Disabilities: Harvard provides academic accommodations for students with disabilities.
