Cheating occurs when a student avails her/himself of an unfair or disallowed advantage which includes but is not limited to:
1. Theft of or unauthorized access to an exam, answer key or other graded work from previous course offerings.
2. Use of an alternate, stand-in or proxy during an examination.
3. Copying from the examination or work of another person or source.
4. Submission or use of falsified data.
5. Using false statements to obtain additional time or other accommodation.
6. Falsification of academic credentials.
Plagiarism is defined as the use of work or concepts contributed by other individuals without proper attribution or citation. Unique
ideas or materials taken from another source for either written or oral use must be fully acknowledged in academic work to be
graded. Examples of sources expected to be referenced include but are not limited to:
 Text, either written or spoken, quoted directly or paraphrased.
 Graphic elements.
 Passages of music, existing either as sound or as notation.
 Mathematical proofs.
 Scientific data.
 Concepts or material derived from the work, published or unpublished, of another person.
Unauthorized assistance refers to the use of sources of support that have not been specifically authorized in this policy statement or
by the course instructor(s) in the completion of academic work to be graded. Such sources of support may include but are not limited
to advice or help provided by another individual, published or unpublished written sources, and electronic sources. Examples of
unauthorized assistance include but are not limited to:
1. Collaboration on any assignment beyond the standards authorized by this policy statement and the course instructor(s).
2. Submission of work completed or edited in whole or in part by another person.
3. Supplying or communicating unauthorized information or materials, including graded work and answer keys from previous
course offerings, in any way to another student.
4. Use of unauthorized information or materials, including graded work and answer keys from previous course offerings.
5. Use of unauthorized devices.
6. Submission for credit of previously completed graded work in a second course without first obtaining permission from the
instructor(s) of the second course. In the case of concurrent courses, permission to submit the same work for credit in two courses
must be obtained from the instructors of both courses.
Procedures for dealing with allegations of these policy violations are detailed in the university’s Academic Disciplinary Action Procedures for Undergraduate Students and the Academic Disciplinary Action Procedures for Graduate Students, which are published
in The WORD student handbook. Periodic review of these procedures will be overseen by the Dean of Student Affairs or her/his
designee in consultation with Faculty Senate and the relevant student governing bodies. Any amendments to these procedures are
subject to the approval of Faculty Senate. Additional guidelines and procedures for graduate students may exist at the college/department/program level, in which case they are communicated in the college/department/program graduate student handbook.

This course is about communication. Specifically, we will use various media elements (text, graphics, animation, video and sound) to form communicative units. The purpose of a multimedia piece is to communicate your message to the audience. The goal of this course is to use type, color, illustrations, images,
sound, animation and video to produce professional materials. This course will teach a combination of
graphic design skills and software skills. Students will also learn the terminology, procedures and production requirement to effectively communicate with ad agencies, design firms and commercial printers.
Throughout the course students will learn the skills of the following applications:
• Adobe InDesign • Adobe Illustrator
• Adobe Photoshop • Adobe Audition
• Adobe After Effects • Adobe Premiere
Each of the above software programs will have one or two projects/assignments that will be completed
by the student. These applications are available in the classroom as well as several public clusters.
While the class offers a jump-start to these applications, students are expected to explore the higher
level features on their own.
Objectives
By the end of the class you will be able to...
• Create professional multi-media material using a variety of Adobe software.
• Be able to effectively communicate to your target audience using a variety of mutli-media programs.
• Become familiar with media design principles.
• Become familiar with graphic design/multi-media terminology.
• Be able to effectively communicate with clients, design firms and media content professionals.
Course Structure
• Class will usually consist of 3/4 lecture and 1/4 hands-on work with the software.
• Class attendance and participation is critical to learning in this class.
• I strongly suggest the purchasing of a USB - Jump - Flash portable storage device.
Cheating and Plagiarism
Students must do all of the assignments individually. Students may receive feedback on their work from
other students, but the final work must be their own. Students are subject to Carnegie Mellon University’s policies on academic integrity. Plagiarism is a serious offense that can result in the student failing
the course. Note that all academic integrity violations will be reported to the Associate Dean. Additional
penalties may be imposed.
Date Topics
August 31: Introduction to the Multi-media class.
 Multi-media Design Fundamentals: Type - Color - Images
September 7: Adobe InDesign Introduction: Tool Box - Palettes - Type
September 14: Adobe InDesign: Creating a Magazine cover and inside spread
September 21: Adobe Illustrator Introduction

September 28: Adobe Illustrator: Creating Logos and Infographics
October 5: Adobe Photoshop Introduction: Tools - Palettes - Features - Editing - Correcting
October 12: Adobe Photoshop: Creating a Movie Poster and Web Page

October 19: Fall Break - No Class
October 26: Adobe Audition: Introduction
November 2: Adobe Audition: Creating a Podcast
November 9: Adobe After Effects: Introduction, Text, Shapes, Images, Sound

November 16: Adobe After Effects: Creating Motion Graphics
November 23: Thanksgiving Break - No Class
November 30: Adobe Premiere Introduction: Editing video, music and images
December 7: Adobe Premiere: Creating and editing a 60 second video

Assessments
Tuesday, September 20: InDesign Magazine layout due
Tuesday, October 4: Illustrator Logo and Infographic designs due
Friday, October 14: Photoshop Movie Poster and web splash designs due
Tuesday, November 8: Adobe Audition Podcast due
Tuesday, November 22: Adobe After Effects motion graphic due
Tuesday, December 13: Adobe Premiere promotional video due
All assignments are due at 10:00 pm on the above dates.
The assignments will be turned in on Canvas.
Grading
Grading will be done with a rubric identifying specific requirements for each project.
• InDesign Magazine Project 100 points
• Illustrator Logo/Infographics Projects 200 points
• Photoshop Movie Poster/Web Projects 200 points
• Adobe Audition Podcast 100 points
• Adobe After Effects Motion Graphic 100 points
• Adobe Premiere Video 100 points
A+ 98-100%
A 92-98%
A- 87-92%
B+ 84-87%
B 80-84%
B- 75-80%
Carnegie Mellon University Policy on Academic Integrity
http://www.cmu.edu/policies/documents/Academic%20Integrity.htm
Students at Carnegie Mellon are engaged in intellectual activity consistent with the highest standards of the academy. The relationship between students and instructors and their shared commitment to overarching standards of respect, honor and transparency
determine the integrity of our community of scholars. The actions of our students, faculty and staff are a representation of our
university community and of the professional and personal communities that we lead. Therefore, a deep and abiding commitment
to academic integrity is fundamental to a Carnegie Mellon education. Honesty and good faith, clarity in the communication of core
values, professional conduct of work, mutual trust and respect, and fairness and exemplary behavior represent the expectations for
ethical behavior for all members of the Carnegie Mellon community.
Policy Statement
In any manner of presentation, it is the responsibility of each student to produce her/his own original academic work. Collaboration
or assistance on academic work to be graded is not permitted unless explicitly authorized by the course instructor(s). Students may
utilize the assistance provided by Academic Development, the Global Communication Center, and the Academic Resource Center
(CMU-Q) unless specifically prohibited by the course instructor(s). Any other sources of collaboration or assistance must be specifically authorized by the course instructor(s).
In all academic work to be graded, the citation of all sources is required. When collaboration or assistance is permitted by the course
instructor(s) or when a student utilizes the services provided by Academic Development, the Global Communication Center, and the
Academic Resource Center (CMU-Q), the acknowledgement of any collaboration or assistance is likewise required. This citation
and acknowledgement must be incorporated into the work submitted and not separately or at a later point in time. Failure to do so is
dishonest and is subject to disciplinary action.
Instructors have a duty to communicate their expectations including those specific to collaboration, assistance, citation and acknowledgement within each course. Students likewise have a duty to ensure that they understand and abide by the standards that apply in
any course or academic activity. In the absence of such understanding, it is the student’s responsibility to seek additional information
and clarification.
Policy Violations
Cheating occurs when a student avails her/himself of an unfair or disallowed advantage which includes but is not limited to:
1. Theft of or unauthorized access to an exam, answer key or other graded work from previous course offerings.
2. Use of an alternate, stand-in or proxy during an examination.
3. Copying from the examination or work of another person or source.
4. Submission or use of falsified data.
5. Using false statements to obtain additional time or other accommodation.
6. Falsification of academic credentials.
Plagiarism is defined as the use of work or concepts contributed by other individuals without proper attribution or citation. Unique
ideas or materials taken from another source for either written or oral use must be fully acknowledged in academic work to be
graded. Examples of sources expected to be referenced include but are not limited to:
 Text, either written or spoken, quoted directly or paraphrased.
 Graphic elements.
 Passages of music, existing either as sound or as notation.
 Mathematical proofs.
 Scientific data.
 Concepts or material derived from the work, published or unpublished, of another person.
Unauthorized assistance refers to the use of sources of support that have not been specifically authorized in this policy statement or
by the course instructor(s) in the completion of academic work to be graded. Such sources of support may include but are not limited
to advice or help provided by another individual, published or unpublished written sources, and electronic sources. Examples of
unauthorized assistance include but are not limited to:
1. Collaboration on any assignment beyond the standards authorized by this policy statement and the course instructor(s).
2. Submission of work completed or edited in whole or in part by another person.
3. Supplying or communicating unauthorized information or materials, including graded work and answer keys from previous
course offerings, in any way to another student.
4. Use of unauthorized information or materials, including graded work and answer keys from previous course offerings.
5. Use of unauthorized devices.
6. Submission for credit of previously completed graded work in a second course without first obtaining permission from the
instructor(s) of the second course. In the case of concurrent courses, permission to submit the same work for credit in two courses
must be obtained from the instructors of both courses.
Procedures for dealing with allegations of these policy violations are detailed in the university’s Academic Disciplinary Action Procedures for Undergraduate Students and the Academic Disciplinary Action Procedures for Graduate Students, which are published
in The WORD student handbook. Periodic review of these procedures will be overseen by the Dean of Student Affairs or her/his
designee in consultation with Faculty Senate and the relevant student governing bodies. Any amendments to these procedures are
subject to the approval of Faculty Senate. Additional guidelines and procedures for graduate students may exist at the college/department/program level, in which case they are communicated in the college/department/program graduate student handbook.

BU.131.601.T1| Business Leadership and Human Values | Milter | Page 1 of 5
BUSINESS LEADERSHIP AND HUMAN VALUES
2 Credits
BU.131.601.T1
Fridays 8:30 AM – 11:30 AM
10/19/18 - 12/14/18
DC Center – Room 207
Fall II 2018
Instructor
Richard G. Milter, PhD
Contact Information
milter@jhu.edu
410.234.9422
Teaching Assistant
Raman Mathur, rmathur4@jhu.edu
Office Hours
One hour before class and other times by appointment.
Required Texts and Learning Materials
This seminar course is a series of thematic conversations about human values and your
responsibilities as an emerging/aspiring business leader. There is no traditional textbook, but there is
much reading. You will find details about required learning materials in the syllabus (below) and on the
Blackboard Weekly Theme Briefs.
Required Workbook: Thompson, Lindsay. The Moral Compass Workbook. (Blackboard)
Note about Readings and Learning Resources
Readings, video/audio clips, websites, and other course materials are a starting point for inquiry and
discussion around each theme. All of the required learning materials are available via the internet or
Blackboard either in Course Documents or E-Reserves link to the Johns Hopkins libraries. Be sure
that your electronic access to Blackboard, libraries, and other Johns Hopkins websites is activated via
your computer and working effectively.
You are expected to read at least one mainstream business news source regularly. You will rely on
news sources to identify “live cases” that exemplify key ethical issues in business drawn from current
events and the observations and experiences you and your learning colleagues bring to class. You
should also be familiar with the range of business media, websites, and journals as a source of
intelligence and insight on business leadership and values. A list of these sources is provided under
Course Documents on Blackboard.
Course Description and Overview
This course explores ethical leadership as a framework for enterprise value creation in a complex
environment of competing value claims. Students examine the intrinsic ethical and moral challenges
of business and the concept of a moral compass as a foundation for conscientious leadership,
business practice, and value creation in a competitive global economy. You should read the Seminar
Preparation section in Blackboard prior to the first class. It will also be useful to learn more about the
learning theory underlying the design and implementation of this course. You are encouraged to read This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:43:12 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/39599774/131601ONSITESYLLABUS-TEMPLATE1docx/
BU.131.601.T1| Business Leadership and Human Values | Milter | Page 2 of 5
the two documents on transformational learning and constructive learning posted in the Course
Documents section of Blackboard.
Prerequisite(s) None
Learning Objectives
By the end of this course, you will be able to:
1. Explain the role of human values in business leadership.
2. Develop and justify an action plan to manage an ethical challenge.
3. Lead purposeful conversations about values and ethics.
4. Foster personal moral wellbeing.
To view the complete list of Carey Business School’s general learning goals and objectives, visit the
Carey website.
Course Policies
Throughout the seminar you will explore the architecture of human values from various dimensions:
personal, organizational, societal, cultural, and cross-cultural. The seminar provides the opportunity
for you to cultivate skills and dispositions of self-awareness, critical thinking, collaborative inquiry,
dialogue, discernment, and decision making that will foster your effectiveness as a values-empowered
leader.
Peer Learning and Class Participation
You are required to participate actively in building a peer learning community. Rather than learning
about values, the Business Leadership and Human Values seminar engages you with the Carey
Business Credo, Business with Humanity in Mind, challenging you to anchor value creation in
human values. You will be challenged by discussing these ideas and values with your classmates to
envision business leadership as a moral trust others place in you to manage assets, solve problems,
and lead people in creating sustainable wealth.
Note: If you have a question about the course, you should post it to the “Questions” forum on the Bb
discussion board. This is the primary medium for gaining clarity about course-related items. If you
have a question that is personal, you should contact the instructor or TA directly by email.
Assignments
Your grade will be based on your performance in the following equally weighted areas:
PERFORMANCE DELIVERABLE OR ASSIGNMENT

Grading
The grade of A is reserved for those who demonstrate extraordinarily excellent performance as
determined by the instructor. The grade of A- is awarded only for excellent performance. The grades
of B+, B, and B- are awarded for good performance. The grades of C+, C, and C- are awarded for
adequate but substandard performance. The grades of D+, D, and D- are not awarded at the
graduate level (undergraduate only). The grade of F indicates the student’s failure to satisfactorily
complete the course work.
Please note that for Core and Foundation courses, a maximum of 25% of students may be
awarded an A or A-; the grade point average of the class should not exceed 3.3. For Elective
courses, a maximum of 35% of students may be awarded an A or A-; the grade point average of
the class should not exceed 3.4. (For classes with 15 students or fewer, the class GPA cap is
waived.)
Grading Rubrics
Your performance in this course will be evaluated according to rubrics for each assignment. All of your
work in the course is graded on a 100-point scale. To earn a “B” you must perform consistently, in
every activity and on every assignment, at the level of 80 or above. To earn an “A-range” grade you
must perform, in every activity and on every assignment, at a level of 90. Rubric details for individual
assignments are posted in Blackboard.
90-100 points = A (Exemplary)
80-89 points = B (Proficient)
70-79 points = C (Needs Improvement)
<70 points = F
The Business Leadership and Human Values seminar experience is designed to foster personal
commitment to values. Acceptable performance (B or above) requires that you:
 Demonstrate authentic personal commitment to exploring and understanding the role of
human values in business, value creation, markets, and the economy.
 Prepare thoroughly and participate actively in the online discussion board and other
required learning activities.
 Complete all deliverables fully, in proper format, and on time.
 Work effectively with others.
 Demonstrate active engagement with course themes, content, and methods.

Carey Business School
Policies and General Information
Blackboard Site
A Blackboard course site is set up for this course. Each student is expected to check the site
throughout the semester as Blackboard will be the primary venue for outside classroom
communications between the instructors and the students. Students can access the course site at
https://blackboard.jhu.edu. Support for Blackboard is available at 1-866-669-6138.
Disability Support Services
All students with disabilities who require accommodations for this course should contact Disability
Support Services at their earliest convenience to discuss their specific needs. If you have a
documented disability, you must be registered with Disability Support Services
(carey.disability@jhu.edu or 410-234-9243) to receive accommodations. For more information, please
visit the Disability Support Services webpage.
Academic Ethics Policy
Carey expects graduates to be innovative business leaders and exemplary global citizens. The Carey
community believes that honesty, integrity, and community responsibility are qualities inherent in an
exemplary citizen. The objective of the Academic Ethics Policy (AEP) is to create an environment of
trust and respect among all members of the Carey academic community and hold Carey students
accountable to the highest standards of academic integrity and excellence.
It is the responsibility of every Carey student, faculty member, and staff member to familiarize
themselves with the AEP and its procedures. Failure to become acquainted with this information will
not excuse any student, faculty, or staff from the responsibility to abide by the AEP. Please contact the
Student Services office if you have any questions. For the full policy, please visit the Academic Ethics
Policy webpage.
Student Conduct Code
The fundamental purpose of the Johns Hopkins University’s regulation of student conduct is to
promote and to protect the health, safety, welfare, property, and rights of all members of the University
community as well as to promote the orderly operation of the University and to safeguard its property
and facilities. As members of the University community, students accept certain responsibilities which
support the educational mission and create an environment in which all students are afforded the
same opportunity to succeed academically. Please contact the Student Services office if you have any
questions. For the full policy, please visit the Student Conduct Code webpage.
Student Success Center
The Student Success Center offers free online and in-person one-on-one and group coaching in
writing, presenting, and quantitative courses. For more information or to book an appointment, please
visit the Student Success Center website.
Other Important Policies and Services
Students are strongly encouraged to consult the Carey Business School’s Student Handbook and
Academic Catalog and Student Resources for information regarding other policies and services.
Copyright Statement
Unless explicitly allowed by the instructor, course materials, class discussions, and examinations are
created for and expected to be used by class participants only. The recording and rebroadcasting of
such material, by any means, is forbidden. Violations are subject to sanctions under the Academic
Ethics Policy.

required learning activities.
 Complete all deliverables fully, in proper format, and on time.
 Work effectively with others.

Business Leadership and Human Values
BUSINESS LEADERSHIP AND HUMAN VALUES
One hour before class and other times by appointment.
Required Texts and Learning Materials
This seminar course is a series of thematic conversations about human values and your
responsibilities as an emerging/aspiring business leader. There is no traditional textbook, but there is
much reading. You will find details about required learning materials in the syllabus (below) and on the
Blackboard Weekly Theme Briefs.
The Moral Compass Workbook
Note about Readings and Learning Resources
Readings, video/audio clips, websites, and other course materials are a starting point for inquiry and
discussion around each theme. All of the required learning materials are available via the internet or
Blackboard either in Course Documents or E-Reserves link to the Johns Hopkins libraries. Be sure
that your electronic access to Blackboard, libraries, and other Johns Hopkins websites is activated via
your computer and working effectively.
You are expected to read at least one mainstream business news source regularly. You will rely on
news sources to identify “live cases” that exemplify key ethical issues in business drawn from current
events and the observations and experiences you and your learning colleagues bring to class. You
should also be familiar with the range of business media, websites, and journals as a source of
intelligence and insight on business leadership and values. A list of these sources is provided under
Course Documents on Blackboard.
Course Description and Overview
This course explores ethical leadership as a framework for enterprise value creation in a complex
environment of competing value claims. Students examine the intrinsic ethical and moral challenges
of business and the concept of a moral compass as a foundation for conscientious leadership,
business practice, and value creation in a competitive global economy. You should read the Seminar
Preparation section in Blackboard prior to the first class. It will also be useful to learn more about the
learning theory underlying the design and implementation of this course. You are encouraged to read BU.131.601.T1| Business Leadership and Human Values | Milter | Page 2 of 5
the two documents on transformational learning and constructive learning posted in the Course
Documents section of Blackboard.
Prerequisite(s) None
Learning Objectives
By the end of this course, you will be able to:
1. Explain the role of human values in business leadership.
2. Develop and justify an action plan to manage an ethical challenge.
3. Lead purposeful conversations about values and ethics.
4. Foster personal moral wellbeing.
To view the complete list of Carey Business School’s general learning goals and objectives, visit the
Carey website.
Course Policies
Throughout the seminar you will explore the architecture of human values from various dimensions:
personal, organizational, societal, cultural, and cross-cultural. The seminar provides the opportunity
for you to cultivate skills and dispositions of self-awareness, critical thinking, collaborative inquiry,
dialogue, discernment, and decision making that will foster your effectiveness as a values-empowered
leader.
Peer Learning and Class Participation
You are required to participate actively in building a peer learning community. Rather than learning
about values, the Business Leadership and Human Values seminar engages you with the Carey
Business Credo, Business with Humanity in Mind, challenging you to anchor value creation in
human values. You will be challenged by discussing these ideas and values with your classmates to
envision business leadership as a moral trust others place in you to manage assets, solve problems,
and lead people in creating sustainable wealth.
Note: If you have a question about the course, you should post it to the “Questions” forum on the Bb
discussion board. This is the primary medium for gaining clarity about course-related items. If you
have a question that is personal, you should contact the instructor or TA directly by email.
Assignments
Your grade will be based on your performance in the following equally weighted areas:
PERFORMANCE DELIVERABLE OR ASSIGNMENT
Details are listed for each assignment in Blackboard

Grading
The grade of A is reserved for those who demonstrate extraordinarily excellent performance as
determined by the instructor. The grade of A- is awarded only for excellent performance. The grades
of B+, B, and B- are awarded for good performance. The grades of C+, C, and C- are awarded for
adequate but substandard performance. The grades of D+, D, and D- are not awarded at the
graduate level (undergraduate only). The grade of F indicates the student’s failure to satisfactorily
complete the course work.
Please note that for Core and Foundation courses, a maximum of 25% of students may be
awarded an A or A-; the grade point average of the class should not exceed 3.3. For Elective
courses, a maximum of 35% of students may be awarded an A or A-; the grade point average of
the class should not exceed 3.4. (For classes with 15 students or fewer, the class GPA cap is
waived.)
Grading Rubrics
Your performance in this course will be evaluated according to rubrics for each assignment. All of your
work in the course is graded on a 100-point scale. To earn a “B” you must perform consistently, in
every activity and on every assignment, at the level of 80 or above. To earn an “A-range” grade you
must perform, in every activity and on every assignment, at a level of 90. Rubric details for individual
assignments are posted in Blackboard.
90-100 points = A (Exemplary)
80-89 points = B (Proficient)
70-79 points = C (Needs Improvement)
<70 points = F

required learning activities.

Text:
Sport & Exercise Psychology
 SED PE 375 A1
Fall 2017 CAS B25B
Tuesday/Thursday 11:00am – 12:15pm
ABOUT THE COURSE:
PE 375 provides an introduction to the many topics included in sport and
exercise psychology. Students will be exposed to research and theory, as well
as practical applications of this knowledge. While this class is primarily
geared towards sport, class discussions will also expand on how theories and
practical knowledge can be applied in various performance domains.
COURSE OBJECTIVES
 To explore and understand the overall field of sport and performance
psychology.
 To have opportunities to practice and apply basic sport and
performance psychology skills.
 To understand how to connect sport and performance psychology
concepts and theories to personal and professional contexts.
 To tap students curiosity and interest in the field and encourage further
exploration.
 To understand professional pathways and opportunities in sport and
performance psychology.
STUDENT OUTCOMES
 Students will be able to articulate basic understandings of sport and
performance theories.
 Students will be able to apply basic sport psychology skills in the
contexts of their choice.
 Students will be able to identify psychological concepts in sport and
performance.
 Students will be able to develop a theory based rational in support of
their stance regarding several issues throughout the field of sport and
performance psychology.
Required Texts
Weinberg, R. S. & Gould, D. (2014), Foundations of Sport and Exercise
Psychology. Champaign, IL: Human Kinetics.
Recommended Texts
Williams, J. M. E. (2010). Applied sport psychology: Personal growth to
peak performance (6th ed.). New York, NY: McGraw Hill.
Reserved Readings

There will be some reserved readings posted on Blackboard throughout
the semester outside of the textbook. These readings will be used to
provide more in depth perspectives on relevant topics.
Statement of Accommodations for Students with Disabilities
The School of Education at Boston University is committed to equal
access for students with disabilities. If you have a specific disability
and require accommodations in this class, please let me know early in
the semester so that appropriate accommodations can be made. You
must provide me with a letter of needed accommodations prepared by
the Office of Disability Services. Contact for that office is as follows:
(617) 353-3658 V/TTY or access@bu.edu. All discussions and written
materials will be kept confidential.
Academic Conduct
Academic integrity is the bedrock of any scholarly community. The
objective of Boston University in enforcing academic rules is to
promote a community atmosphere in which learning and the pursuit of
knowledge can best take place.
As articulated in the Academic Conduct Code “All students at Boston
University are expected to maintain high standards of academic
honesty and integrity. It is the responsibility of every student to be
aware of the Academic Conduct Code’s contents and to abide by its
provisions” (http://www.bu.edu/academics/policies/academic-conductcode/).
In general, academic misconduct is conduct by which a student
misrepresents his or her academic accomplishments, or impedes other
students’ opportunities of being judged fairly for their academic work.
Students should pay particular attention to the rules regarding
plagiarism, teamwork, submission of work to more than one course
without permission, and conduct in a professional field
assignment. Plagiarism, that is, failure to properly acknowledge
sources, written or electronic, used for verbatim quotations or ideas, is
a violation of academic integrity. Each student is responsible for
learning and using proper methods of paraphrasing and footnoting,
quotation, and other forms of citation, to ensure that the original
author, speaker, illustrator, or source of the material used is clearly
acknowledged. If students have any questions about academic
integrity or how it applies to the assignments in a specific course,
students should consult their instructor.
Incomplete Grade Policy

In the School of Education, students receiving a grade of Incomplete
must complete an “Incomplete Contract.” This contract should be filled
out by both the student and instructor to dictate the completion
deadline and circumstances of an Incomplete grade. Both student and
instructor will need to sign this form and the signed form should be
returned to the SED Student Records Office, Room 115, for processing.
Incomplete grades should not be awarded without this contract.
Students have one year to resolve the terms of the contract or the
grade will become the grade earned at the time the “I” grade was
issued.
Credit Hour Explanation
This course is a 4-credit course. It has a scheduled course
lecture/discussion time of 3 hours per week. Students are expected to
engage an additional 1-hour of course-related work each week during
the semester. This includes: student conferences with instructor,
teaching lessons in the field, writing reflections, participating in online
modules and discussion boards, viewing and analyzing films, meeting
in small peer groups, preparing group projects, and visiting local sites
related to course content.
COURSE EXPECATIONS
Attendance and Participation
Attendance to every class is important because it is heavily reliant on
participation. We aim to create an interactive culture and group work
during the semester, so the quality of the course depends on your
consistent attendance and participation. Should you find it difficult to
speak in front of a group, contact us by the second week of the
semester so that we can work out alternative ways for you to
participate. Missing any class time may impact your participation
grade. If you are going to miss a class, please let us know ahead of
time and contact a classmate for material missed during the session.
You will be required to turn in a 1-page reflection on each reading (i.e.,
1 page for each article of chapter). If you miss class and do not
turn in a 1-page summary for each article you be deducted 2
points in your attendance/participation grade. If you miss more
than three classes during the semester, you are at risk for failing the
course. Please talk to us regarding any exceptional circumstances.
Sick Policy
If you must miss a class due to illness please email us as soon as
possible. If we do not respond within 24 hours, it means we did not

receive your message. We will always respond to acknowledge that we
received any information regarding your health.
Email Policy
Please make sure you consult the course outline/syllabus, other
handouts, and/or Blackboard before submitting inquiries by email.
While I check email routinely during the day, if the matter is not time
sensitive, please note that at times it might take up to 24 hours before
you receive a response. While I do check email in evenings and over
the weekends, for emails sent after 8:00 PM, do not expect a response
until the following morning; for emails sent over the weekend, you can
usually expect a response within 24 hours. Please include Riley in
all emails.
Communication Policy
Communication and updates regarding the course will be sent via
email. Please note, I use Blackboard Learn to email the class – this
means that your BU email is how you will be contacted. If you are not
sure how to access your BU email, please contact IT services.
Behavior
The appropriate use of tablets and computers (or other technologies)
will be acceptable during class for note taking. However, our
preference is for you not to use a computer. Technology is not for
personal use during class time (i.e. social media, personal email, sports
websites). There will be certain points during every class where we will
ask you to put away your devices. It is expected that during group
discussion that all students remain attentive and respectful of each
other’s opinions.
Grading
Attendance/Participation: 20 points (10% of your grade)
Exam 1: 40 points (20% of your grade)
Exam 2: 40 points (20% of your grade)
Small Group Facilitator: 40 points (20% of your grade)
Paper: 10%
Facilitation: 10%
Final: 60 points (30% of your grade)
Final grades will be distributed as follows out of the total possible points:
A 93-100% C 73-76%
A- 90-93% C- 70-72%

note that no extensions will be granted for the final exam or the

Description of Small Group Facilitator: You will sign up for a topic to
write a 2 page paper and facilitate a small group discussion.
For the paper, you will find a written work (i.e., journal article or article
from a reputable media source) that is related to your topic and write a 2
page paper. The paper should include, 1) brief summary of the written work
(no more than 2 paragraphs), 2) how it relates to your topic, 3) personal
application (i.e., how could you use this information in the future?), and 4)
Three questions you plan to ask to facilitate the small group discussion.
Please submit your paper via email. The paper is due 5pm the day
before you are scheduled to lead the small group discussion (so if
you are scheduled to facilitate on 10/12, you must send the paper to
tcote@bu.edu and rfitz@bu.edu by 4:59pm on 10/11). For the facilitation,
you will lead a 10-minute small group discussion and use the questions you
wrote in your paper to guide the discussion).

Sport & Exercise Psychology
 SED PE 375 A1
Fall 2017 CAS B25B
Tuesday/Thursday 11:00am – 12:15pm
ABOUT THE COURSE:
PE 375 provides an introduction to the many topics included in sport and
exercise psychology. Students will be exposed to research and theory, as well
as practical applications of this knowledge. While this class is primarily
geared towards sport, class discussions will also expand on how theories and
practical knowledge can be applied in various performance domains.
COURSE OBJECTIVES
 To explore and understand the overall field of sport and performance
psychology.
 To have opportunities to practice and apply basic sport and
performance psychology skills.
 To understand how to connect sport and performance psychology
concepts and theories to personal and professional contexts.
 To tap students curiosity and interest in the field and encourage further
exploration.
 To understand professional pathways and opportunities in sport and
performance psychology.
STUDENT OUTCOMES
 Students will be able to articulate basic understandings of sport and
performance theories.
 Students will be able to apply basic sport psychology skills in the
contexts of their choice.
 Students will be able to identify psychological concepts in sport and
performance.
 Students will be able to develop a theory based rational in support of
their stance regarding several issues throughout the field of sport and
performance psychology.
Required Texts
Weinberg, R. S. & Gould, D. (2014), Foundations of Sport and Exercise
Psychology. Champaign, IL: Human Kinetics.
Recommended Texts
Williams, J. M. E. (2010). Applied sport psychology: Personal growth to
peak performance (6th ed.). New York, NY: McGraw Hill.
Reserved Readings

 SED PE 375 A1

There will be some reserved readings posted on Blackboard throughout
the semester outside of the textbook. These readings will be used to
provide more in depth perspectives on relevant topics.
Statement of Accommodations for Students with Disabilities
The School of Education at Boston University is committed to equal
access for students with disabilities. If you have a specific disability
and require accommodations in this class, please let me know early in
the semester so that appropriate accommodations can be made. You
must provide me with a letter of needed accommodations prepared by
the Office of Disability Services. Contact for that office is as follows:
All discussions and written
materials will be kept confidential.
Academic Conduct
Academic integrity is the bedrock of any scholarly community. The
objective of Boston University in enforcing academic rules is to
promote a community atmosphere in which learning and the pursuit of
knowledge can best take place.
As articulated in the Academic Conduct Code “All students at Boston
University are expected to maintain high standards of academic
honesty and integrity. It is the responsibility of every student to be
aware of the Academic Conduct Code’s contents and to abide by its
provisions” In general, academic misconduct is conduct by which a student
misrepresents his or her academic accomplishments, or impedes other
students’ opportunities of being judged fairly for their academic work.
Students should pay particular attention to the rules regarding
plagiarism, teamwork, submission of work to more than one course
without permission, and conduct in a professional field
assignment. Plagiarism, that is, failure to properly acknowledge
sources, written or electronic, used for verbatim quotations or ideas, is
a violation of academic integrity. Each student is responsible for
learning and using proper methods of paraphrasing and footnoting,
quotation, and other forms of citation, to ensure that the original
author, speaker, illustrator, or source of the material used is clearly
acknowledged. If students have any questions about academic
integrity or how it applies to the assignments in a specific course,
students should consult their instructor.
Incomplete Grade Policy
Sport & Exercise Psychology
 SED PE 375 A1
Fall 2017 CAS B25B
Tuesday/Thursday 11:00am – 12:15pm
In the School of Education, students receiving a grade of Incomplete
must complete an “Incomplete Contract.” This contract should be filled
out by both the student and instructor to dictate the completion
deadline and circumstances of an Incomplete grade. Both student and
instructor will need to sign this form and the signed form should be
returned to the SED Student Records Office, Room 115, for processing.
Incomplete grades should not be awarded without this contract.
Students have one year to resolve the terms of the contract or the
grade will become the grade earned at the time the “I” grade was
issued.
Credit Hour Explanation
This course is a 4-credit course. It has a scheduled course
lecture/discussion time of 3 hours per week. Students are expected to
engage an additional 1-hour of course-related work each week during
the semester. This includes: student conferences with instructor,
teaching lessons in the field, writing reflections, participating in online
modules and discussion boards, viewing and analyzing films, meeting
in small peer groups, preparing group projects, and visiting local sites
related to course content.
COURSE EXPECATIONS
Attendance and Participation
Attendance to every class is important because it is heavily reliant on
participation. We aim to create an interactive culture and group work
during the semester, so the quality of the course depends on your
consistent attendance and participation. Should you find it difficult to
speak in front of a group, contact us by the second week of the
semester so that we can work out alternative ways for you to
participate. Missing any class time may impact your participation
grade. If you are going to miss a class, please let us know ahead of
time and contact a classmate for material missed during the session.
You will be required to turn in a 1-page reflection on each reading (i.e.,
1 page for each article of chapter). If you miss class and do not
turn in a 1-page summary for each article you be deducted 2
points in your attendance/participation grade. If you miss more
than three classes during the semester, you are at risk for failing the
course. Please talk to us regarding any exceptional circumstances.
Sick Policy
If you must miss a class due to illness please email us as soon as
possible. If we do not respond within 24 hours, it means we did not
Sport & Exercise Psychology
 SED PE 375 A1

Tuesday/Thursday 11:00am – 12:15pm
receive your message. We will always respond to acknowledge that we
received any information regarding your health.
Email Policy
Please make sure you consult the course outline/syllabus, other
handouts, and/or Blackboard before submitting inquiries by email.
While I check email routinely during the day, if the matter is not time
sensitive, please note that at times it might take up to 24 hours before
you receive a response. While I do check email in evenings and over
the weekends, for emails sent after 8:00 PM, do not expect a response
until the following morning; for emails sent over the weekend, you can
usually expect a response within 24 hours. Please include Riley in
all emails.
Communication Policy
Communication and updates regarding the course will be sent via
email. Please note, I use Blackboard Learn to email the class – this
means that your BU email is how you will be contacted. If you are not
sure how to access your BU email, please contact IT services.
Behavior
The appropriate use of tablets and computers (or other technologies)
will be acceptable during class for note taking. However, our
preference is for you not to use a computer. Technology is not for
personal use during class time (i.e. social media, personal email, sports
websites). There will be certain points during every class where we will
ask you to put away your devices. It is expected that during group
discussion that all students remain attentive and respectful of each
other’s opinions.
Grading
Attendance/Participation: 20 points (10% of your grade)
Exam 1: 40 points (20% of your grade)
Exam 2: 40 points (20% of your grade)
Small Group Facilitator: 40 points (20% of your grade)
Paper: 10%
Facilitation: 10%
Final: 60 points (30% of your grade)
Final grades will be distributed as follows out of the total possible points:
A 93-100% C 73-76%
A- 90-93% C- 70-72%

accepted and a grade of 0 will be received for that assignment. Please
note that no extensions will be granted for the final exam or the

Description of Small Group Facilitator: You will sign up for a topic to
write a 2 page paper and facilitate a small group discussion.
For the paper, you will find a written work (i.e., journal article or article
from a reputable media source) that is related to your topic and write a 2
page paper. The paper should include, 1) brief summary of the written work
(no more than 2 paragraphs), 2) how it relates to your topic, 3) personal
application (i.e., how could you use this information in the future?), and 4)
Three questions you plan to ask to facilitate the small group discussion.
Please submit your paper via email. The paper is due 5pm the day
before you are scheduled to lead the small group discussion (so if
you are scheduled to facilitate on 10/12, you must send the paper to
by 4:59pm on 10/11). For the facilitation,
you will lead a 10-minute small group discussion and use the questions you
wrote in your paper to guide the discussion).

Text:
AC222 – Managerial Accounting Fall, 2020
Boston University Questrom School of Business
AC222 – Managerial Accounting
Instructor names: Ann Marie Asadoorian,
and Greg Sabin (course coordinator) version: 20200806
 [Please be sure to read this Syllabus thoroughly prior to your 1st class session!]
I. Course Administrative Details
 Coordinator/instructor: Gregory Sabin, 524A HAR, gsabin@bu.edu
 Office hours (virtual): Wednesday, 9:00am – 11:00am via Zoom
 pre-requisites: AC221, QM221, sophomore standing
 TAs contact info and schedule (TBD) for AC222 help room (HAR 343A)
o Ashley Li, Lead Teaching Assistant, ly1205@bu.edu
o Kristina Schuler, Wiley Plus Assistance, kschuler@bu.edu
o Lyli Barnette, lylib@bu.edu
o Jennah Santiago, jennahs@bu.edu
o Rebecca Sarkisian, rebsark@bu.edu
o Audrey Duffy, audreydu@bu.edu
o Sanoja Shah, sanojas@bu.edu
o
II. Course Description, Learning Goals, Structure, & Materials
II.1a. Course Description & Learning Goals
 Introduces the basic principles, methods, and challenges of modern managerial accounting.
Covers traditional topics such as job-order costing, cost-volume-profit analysis, budgeting,
variance analysis, profitability analysis, relevant costs for decision making, and cost-plus pricing,
as well as less traditional topics such as Activity-Based Cost (ABC) accounting and performance
measurement. The material is examined from the perspective of students preparing to use
accounting information as managers, to support decision making (such as pricing, product mix,
sourcing, technology and investment decisions) and short- and long-term planning, and to
measure, evaluate, and reward performance. Emphasizes the relationships between accounting
techniques and other organizational activities. 4 cr.
II.1b. Course Learning Objectives
 Learn terminology to describe, categorize, and analyze the costs of doing business
 Understand how costs behave in relation to changes in volume
 Distinguish between the direct and indirect costs of products and services, and learn benefits
and drawbacks of different methods of allocating indirect costs to the objectives those costs
help to achieve
 Prepare a master budget as well as each of its components and understand how to use it to
manage operations
 Learn to make strategic decisions, using financial and non-financial information
 Gain an understanding of the basics of performance measurement
 Become proficient in variance analysis
1 of 5
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:44:11 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/69255165/AC222-Syllabus-2020-Fall-20200820docx/
AC222 – Managerial Accounting Fall, 2020
II.2. Course Structure & Pedagogy
 Module 1 – Understand cost terms, definitions and concepts relating to the operations of a business.
Understand how those costs behave in relation to changes in volume and the implications of this
relationship on firm risk.
 Module 2 – Managerial analysis, learn a tool set to make better business decisions
 Module 3 – Learn to construct budgets and to use those to control/improve operations
 Module 4 – Learn how to assess the performance of a business
II.3. Course Materials:
III. Managerial Accounting, Davis and Davis, 4th edition. You will need this version, not a
previous, nor an international version. Available at Barnes & Noble or online through
Wiley. This version is bundled with WileyPlus access, which you will need for this course.
A used book will not come with WileyPlus access, so if you buy a used version, you will
need to purchase WileyPlus access separately. If you purchase WileyPlus access by itself,
you receive access to an e-book included in the price
IV. Course Policies
III.1. Attendance Policy and Contribution Score (valid only through exam 1, thereafter attendance
is no longer mandatory, but suggested)
 Attendance is expected and the easiest way to do well in the participation portion of the class. While
attendance alone does NOT ensure a good contribution score, it will be much harder to achieve a
good contribution score without attending class. Arriving on time is expected. Students who arrive
late disrupt the learning process of everyone who made it to class on time. Late arrivals will bear a
penalty to participation. I will not distinguish between “excused or unexcused absences”.
 BU policy and Massachusetts State Law consider absences for religious reasons to be “excused” but
as far as I am aware there are not more than 3 major religious holidays scheduled during this course,
and as such, no one should need to miss more than 3 classes.
 If you are not able to attend the live session of the class, you are expected to watch a video recording
of the lecture. In addition, you will need to participate in the online discussion forums. Failure to
participate in live class sessions as well as not participating in the online discussion forums and not
providing case feedback will be grounds for a 0 in the contribution portion of the class.
III.2. Academic accommodations for students with special needs:
 In keeping with University policy, any student with a disability who needs or thinks they need
academic accommodations must call the Office of Disability Services at 617-353-3658 or stop by 19
Deerfield Street to arrange a confidential appointment with a Disability Services staff member.
Accommodation letters must be delivered to your instructor in a timely fashion (not later than two
weeks before any major examination). Please note that accommodations will not be delivered
absent an official letter of accommodation.
III.3. Academic Integrity Policy
 The Questrom Academic Conduct Code is strictly observed in this course. Consider it to be an
addendum to this syllabus. I assume that if you continue in this course, you have read and
understood the Academic Conduct Code. Penalties for infractions range from a minimum of a zero
grade on the test or assignment, to an appearance before the Academic Conduct Committee, which
could result in suspension or expulsion from Boston University.
III.4. Diversity and Inclusion Statement
 In developing this course, I have aimed to be thoughtful about how identity, abilities, experiences
and culture impact the course content.
2 of 5
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:44:11 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/69255165/AC222-Syllabus-2020-Fall-20200820docx/
AC222 – Managerial Accounting Fall, 2020
 I invite you to share your personal experiences and perspective related to the course content. If there
are topics or conversations that you feel would benefit from incorporation of social context, a
differing perspective, or Questrom’s Office of Diversity & Inclusion, please inform me and I will
explore resources and opportunities for us to engage a wide variety of perspectives in our classroom.
V. Course Evaluation & Expectations
IV.1. Course Evaluation
 Grading: The relative weighting of assignments in your course grade is as follows:
 Evaluation Activity Fraction of Course Grade
Mid-Term Exam #1 20%
Mid-Term Exam #2 20%
Exit Questions 5%
Introductory Video 5%
Final Exam 25%
Class Contribution 5%
Individual WileyPlus homework submissions 5%
Case feedback scores 5%
Case #1 (Ethics Case) 5%
 Case #2 (Variance Analysis or Budgeting Case) 5%
 TOTAL 100%
 There will be absolutely no grade deflation in this course (There will also, however, not be any
grade inflation). Final course grades will be the result of a direct mathematical computation,
based on the formula above and the distribution below.
o Questrom’s grading guidelines for required UG courses:
25-35% of students can expect to receive A’s (for excellent work)
50-65% of students can expect to receive B’s (for good or very good work)
5-20% of students can expect to receive C’s or below (for adequate or poor work)
 If you have any questions about grades that you receive on particular assignments, you must raise
them within two weeks of receiving your grade on that assignment. Unless we have made
computational errors, we will be unable to alter grades after final grades have been determined.
If you have particular grade-related considerations that you think are important, please raise
these with your instructor as early as possible (during the first half of the semester at the latest!),
so that your instructor can help you approach the course in a way that will help you achieve your
best possible performance.
IV.2. Assignment Descriptions & Expectations
 WileyPlus homework: Each chapter in the book has a homework assignment associated with the
online system. Submissions are due one week after the associated material was covered in class. I
suggest you do not fall behind in these assignments as they are meant to be material to reinforce
what we did in lecture each day after completing each class. I will give a full score to anyone who
completes more than 90% of the material correctly. Scores below 90% will be graded as the
reported score multiplied by the number of points possible for the assignment.
 Case submissions: We will cover two cases in this course. The cases are a lot of fun and highly
interactive. Because they are so interactive, they are a great opportunity for you to gain a lot of
contribution points. In order to ensure that everyone comes to class prepared, you will be assigned a
1-page summary level response to a question about the case that will be posted at least one week
prior to the case being covered in class. These write ups should NOT exceed 1.5 pages, nor be less
than 0.5 pages, 12-point Times New Roman, double spaced. My goal with this assignment is to give
you an opportunity to simply show me how much you know about the topic and how it is applied to
the case in question. The majority of these submissions will receive 4/5. If your statements in the
case are logically inconsistent or incorrect, your grade will drop by .5 points for each error. If you
3 of 5
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:44:11 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/69255165/AC222-Syllabus-2020-Fall-20200820docx/
AC222 – Managerial Accounting Fall, 2020
make exceptionally insightful comments your grade will increase by .5 points per observation. Note
that you get to drop your lowest case score of the three.
 Case feedback: You will review the submission of 3 different classmates. You will be randomly
assigned the case submission of other students for which you will need to provide feedback and rate
their submission as either meets expectations, exceeds expectations or fails to meet expectations.
Your feedback will be scored by the recipient as to how helpful it is to the original author of the case
submission.
 Midterm exams: Each of the midterm exams is a 50-minute exam that may consist of multiple
choice, short answer and essay questions. The midterm exams each cover their respective portion of
the course and are not cumulative, however, much of the underlying course material is cumulative.
So, if you fall too far behind, you will be at a disadvantage on the exams. We will post a previous
version of the exam to use as a study guide for your review prior to the exam.
 Final exam: The final exam will last 120 minutes and contain a variety of question types. It is
cumulative. Roughly half of the test content comes from the material covered during the last
portion of the course, and the other half of the test questions will cover materials from the first 3
portions of the semester.
 Class contribution: see the attendance policy in section III.1 above.
 Exit questions: each class period there will be a low stakes question posted that you will need to
answer. This is intended both as a basic skills check, and to ensure that you are paying attention
during class. If you are not able to attend class, you will have 24 hours to watch the recorded
video and answer the exit question. After 24 hours you will no longer be allowed to turn in the
assignment.
 Introductory video: before the first class you must submit a link to a Youtube video that you
create introducing you to the class. Your introductory video, and the responses you post to other
people’s videos will count toward your contribution score for the course. You will post the link
to your video into a discussion board on Questromtools where we will each review the videos
and you will comment on at least 3 other people’s videos. You can critique them, or find
something you share in common with them, or just about any other constructive response to the
video you can think of. The video must be at least 30 seconds and not more than 1 minute. Your
video will be worth 2 points, and your comments in response to other’s videos will each be worth
1 up to 3, for a total of 5 points possible relating to the introductory videos. Your video should
include information such as:
 What is your name?
 What is your year?
 What is your concentration?
 Where you are from?
 What are your passions?
 Why you chose BU?
4 of 5

AC222 – Managerial Accounting Fall, 2020
Boston University Questrom School of Business
AC222 – Managerial Accounting
 [Please be sure to read this Syllabus thoroughly prior to your 1st class session!]
I. Course Administrative Details
 Coordinator/instructor:II. Course Description, Learning Goals, Structure, & Materials
II.1a. Course Description & Learning Goals
 Introduces the basic principles, methods, and challenges of modern managerial accounting.
Covers traditional topics such as job-order costing, cost-volume-profit analysis, budgeting,
variance analysis, profitability analysis, relevant costs for decision making, and cost-plus pricing,
as well as less traditional topics such as Activity-Based Cost (ABC) accounting and performance
measurement. The material is examined from the perspective of students preparing to use
accounting information as managers, to support decision making (such as pricing, product mix,
sourcing, technology and investment decisions) and short- and long-term planning, and to
measure, evaluate, and reward performance. Emphasizes the relationships between accounting
techniques and other organizational activities. 4 cr.
II.1b. Course Learning Objectives
 Learn terminology to describe, categorize, and analyze the costs of doing business
 Understand how costs behave in relation to changes in volume
 Distinguish between the direct and indirect costs of products and services, and learn benefits
and drawbacks of different methods of allocating indirect costs to the objectives those costs
help to achieve
 Prepare a master budget as well as each of its components and understand how to use it to
manage operations
 Learn to make strategic decisions, using financial and non-financial information
 Gain an understanding of the basics of performance measurement
 Become proficient in variance analysis
1 of 5
AC222 – Managerial Accounting Fall, 2020
II.2. Course Structure & Pedagogy
 Module 1 – Understand cost terms, definitions and concepts relating to the operations of a business.
Understand how those costs behave in relation to changes in volume and the implications of this
relationship on firm risk.
 Module 2 – Managerial analysis, learn a tool set to make better business decisions
 Module 3 – Learn to construct budgets and to use those to control/improve operations
 Module 4 – Learn how to assess the performance of a business

III. Managerial Accounting, 
IV. Course Policies
III.1. Attendance Policy and Contribution Score (valid only through exam 1, thereafter attendance
is no longer mandatory, but suggested)
 Attendance is expected and the easiest way to do well in the participation portion of the class. While
attendance alone does NOT ensure a good contribution score, it will be much harder to achieve a
good contribution score without attending class. Arriving on time is expected. Students who arrive
late disrupt the learning process of everyone who made it to class on time. Late arrivals will bear a
penalty to participation. I will not distinguish between “excused or unexcused absences”.
 BU policy and Massachusetts State Law consider absences for religious reasons to be “excused” but
as far as I am aware there are not more than 3 major religious holidays scheduled during this course,
and as such, no one should need to miss more than 3 classes.
 If you are not able to attend the live session of the class, you are expected to watch a video recording
of the lecture. In addition, you will need to participate in the online discussion forums. Failure to
participate in live class sessions as well as not participating in the online discussion forums and not
providing case feedback will be grounds for a 0 in the contribution portion of the class.
III.2. Academic accommodations for students with special needs:
 In keeping with University policy, any student with a disability who needs or thinks they need
academic accommodations must call the Office of Disability Services at 617-353-3658 or stop by 19
Deerfield Street to arrange a confidential appointment with a Disability Services staff member.
Accommodation letters must be delivered to your instructor in a timely fashion (not later than two
weeks before any major examination). Please note that accommodations will not be delivered
absent an official letter of accommodation.
III.3. Academic Integrity Policy
 The Questrom Academic Conduct Code is strictly observed in this course. Consider it to be an
addendum to this syllabus. I assume that if you continue in this course, you have read and
understood the Academic Conduct Code. Penalties for infractions range from a minimum of a zero
grade on the test or assignment, to an appearance before the Academic Conduct Committee, which
could result in suspension or expulsion from Boston University.
III.4. Diversity and Inclusion Statement
 In developing this course, I have aimed to be thoughtful about how identity, abilities, experiences
and culture impact the course content.

V. Course Evaluation & Expectations
IV.1. Course Evaluation
 Grading: The relative weighting of assignments in your course grade is as follows:

Mid-Term Exam #2 20%

 There will be absolutely no grade deflation in this course (There will also, however, not be any

o Questrom’s grading guidelines for required UG courses:
25-35% of students can expect to receive A’s (for excellent work)
50-65% of students can expect to receive B’s (for good or very good work)
5-20% of students can expect to receive C’s or below (for adequate or poor work)
 If you have any questions about grades that you receive on particular assignments, you must raise
them within two weeks of receiving your grade on that assignment. Unless we have made
computational errors, we will be unable to alter grades after final grades have been determined.
If you have particular grade-related considerations that you think are important, please raise
these with your instructor as early as possible (during the first half of the semester at the latest!),
so that your instructor can help you approach the course in a way that will help you achieve your
best possible performance.
IV.2. Assignment Descriptions & Expectations
 WileyPlus homework: Each chapter in the book has a homework assignment associated with the
online system. Submissions are due one week after the associated material was covered in class. I
suggest you do not fall behind in these assignments as they are meant to be material to reinforce
what we did in lecture each day after completing each class. I will give a full score to anyone who
completes more than 90% of the material correctly. Scores below 90% will be graded as the
reported score multiplied by the number of points possible for the assignment.
 Case submissions: We will cover two cases in this course. The cases are a lot of fun and highly
interactive. Because they are so interactive, they are a great opportunity for you to gain a lot of
contribution points. In order to ensure that everyone comes to class prepared, you will be assigned a
1-page summary level response to a question about the case that will be posted at least one week
prior to the case being covered in class. These write ups should NOT exceed 1.5 pages, nor be less
than 0.5 pages, 12-point Times New Roman, double spaced. My goal with this assignment is to give
you an opportunity to simply show me how much you know about the topic and how it is applied to
the case in question. The majority of these submissions will receive 4/5. If your statements in the
case are logically inconsistent or incorrect, your grade will drop by .5 points for each error. If you
3 of 5

make exceptionally insightful comments your grade will increase by .5 points per observation. Note
that you get to drop your lowest case score of the three.
 Case feedback: You will review the submission of 3 different classmates. You will be randomly
assigned the case submission of other students for which you will need to provide feedback and rate
their submission as either meets expectations, exceeds expectations or fails to meet expectations.
Your feedback will be scored by the recipient as to how helpful it is to the original author of the case
submission.
 Midterm exams: Each of the midterm exams is a 50-minute exam that may consist of multiple
choice, short answer and essay questions. The midterm exams each cover their respective portion of
the course and are not cumulative, however, much of the underlying course material is cumulative.
So, if you fall too far behind, you will be at a disadvantage on the exams. We will post a previous
version of the exam to use as a study guide for your review prior to the exam.
 Final exam: The final exam will last 120 minutes and contain a variety of question types. It is
cumulative. Roughly half of the test content comes from the material covered during the last
portion of the course, and the other half of the test questions will cover materials from the first 3
portions of the semester.
 Class contribution: see the attendance policy in section III.1 above.
 Exit questions: each class period there will be a low stakes question posted that you will need to
answer. This is intended both as a basic skills check, and to ensure that you are paying attention
during class. If you are not able to attend class, you will have 24 hours to watch the recorded
video and answer the exit question. After 24 hours you will no longer be allowed to turn in the
assignment.
 Introductory video: before the first class you must submit a link to a Youtube video that you
create introducing you to the class. Your introductory video, and the responses you post to other
people’s videos will count toward your contribution score for the course. You will post the link
to your video into a discussion board on Questromtools where we will each review the videos
and you will comment on at least 3 other people’s videos. You can critique them, or find
something you share in common with them, or just about any other constructive response to the
video you can think of. The video must be at least 30 seconds and not more than 1 minute. Your
video will be worth 2 points, and your comments in response to other’s videos will each be worth
1 up to 3, for a total of 5 points possible relating to the introductory videos. Your video should
include information such as:
 What is your name?
 What is your year?
 What is your concentration?
 Where you are from?
 What are your passions?
 Why you chose BU?

Course Materials:
Required Text: Chemistry for Today: General, Organic and Biochemistry, 9th Edition (ISBN:
978-1-337-59823-1). This is the most affordable textbook option that can be offered in the

Course Website and Correspondence:
The course website will be administered through Blackboard Learn (http://learn.bu.edu).
Course announcements and material will be posted on this site and/or sent via students’ BU
email addresses.
Course Description and Objectives:
This course provides a one-semester introduction to organic chemistry and biochemistry. By
the end of the course, you should understand and be able to:
i. Apply the concepts associated with the names, structures, reactivities and reactions of
the major classes of organic compounds and describe their chemical basis
ii. Describe and predict the chemical properties associated with carbohydrates, lipids,
proteins and nucleotides
iii. Describe the physical and chemical properties that contribute to the structure and function
of key biomolecules in living organisms.
iv. Describe the principles behind and relationships between the central pathways of
metabolism for carbohydrates, lipids, and amino acids.
v. Determine patterns in the structures and reactivities of biomolecules associated with their
function in living organisms.
vi. Approach and answer scientific questions related to organic and biochemistry, and learn
how these concepts relate to the life and medical sciences.
Grading and Exam Dates:
Exam 1 Friday, February 22, in class 11 %
Exam 2 Friday, March 29, in class 11 %
Exam 3 Monday, April 29, in class 11 %
Final Exam Tuesday, May 7, 9 – 11am 22 %
Quizzes, Homework & TopHat (each contributes equally) 20 %
Laboratory 25 %
The final and midterm exams are graded on a 100 percent basis and scaled to a 75 percent
class median by adding a maximum of 15 points to everybody’s raw scores. No points are
added if the class median is higher than 75 points. Only 15 points are added if the class median
is lower than 60 points.
Lecture Format, Preparation and Attendance:
CH172 consists of three hours of lectures per week, one hour of discussion, one hour of prelab lecture, and three hours of laboratory work. Your grade will be based on your performance
and contributions in all three aspects of the course. It is highly recommended that you attend
all lecture, discussion, and laboratory sessions. Announcements, which will be posted both in
lecture and on the course Blackboard Learn site, will include reading assignments, problems
and/or worksheets.

The lecture will start promptly at 10:10 AM. There is a great deal of material to cover and we
cannot afford using the first five minutes of each class to get everyone settled. In addition,
important information about up-coming examinations and other matters are often made at the
start of the lecture. For these reasons it is important that you are in your seat and ready to
begin at 10:10 AM.
Although attendance will not be graded, students are expected to attend all lectures. It is
strongly recommended that you read the relevant portions of the textbook before coming to
class. The majority of the time in lecture will be spent selectively explaining the more
challenging parts of the material and their chemical implications, rather than just regurgitating
the textbook. It’s therefore essential that you have a basic knowledge of the material, from
reading the textbook, before coming to the lecture. This approach will allow us to be efficient in
spending most of our class time discussing the more challenging concepts, and on trying to
achieve a deeper understanding of the material. It will also leave more time for us to have
discussions around student’s questions in lecture. Materials in the assigned readings and
materials presented in lectures may appear on quizzes or exams. Pop quizzes may be given
during lecture.
TopHat:
The TopHat audience response system will be used both in and outside of lecture, and will
sometimes be used for quizzes. Your final TopHat grade will be based both upon participation
and the number of correct answers. For in-class questions, you will generally receive 4/5th of
a point for submitting any answer and an additional 1/5th of a point for submitting the correct
answer. Questions used only for information or discussion purposes will earn you 1 point,
regardless of your answer. You will receive a point for quiz questions only if your answer is
correct. You must be in class to answer in-class TopHat questions. Answering in-class
questions from another location will result in you loosing the points for that day, and potentially
obtaining an overall TopHat grade of zero.
For homework questions, you will receive a 1/2 point for submitting any answer and an
additional 1/2 point for submitting the correct answer. Homework questions can be answered
from off-campus.
To receive full credit, you only need to get 90% of the TopHat points, so you can still earn full
credit with a number of incorrect answers and with excused absences. The grade will be
calculated using: [5% x points earned/(possible points * 0.9)].
Online homework:
One or more homework sets will be assigned for each Chapter covered through the Sapling
homework system. Students are expected to check the site after each lecture, to complete the
assignment before the due date, and to leave enough time to manage any computer or network
errors that might arise. Any score greater than 85% will receive full credit for the homework.
Practice Problems:
Students are expected to work assigned end of chapter problems. While these problems will
not be collected or graded, they provide good preparation for quizzes and exams.
