Discussion Sections:
Attendance at your discussion section is expected. Students should come to their Discussion
section with questions about the practice problems, assigned reading, and lecture material.
During discussion, Learning Assistants (LAs) will assist the discussion leaders in facilitating
practice problem-solving and addressing student questions.
Students should attend the discussion section for which they are registered. If discussion is
cancelled due to a school holiday, accommodations will be made. Graded exams will be
returned during discussion in the week following the exam.
Quizzes:
Quizzes will be given throughout the semester, at the beginning of many discussion sections.
Students who arrive late will not be given extra time to take the quiz, and will not be
allowed to take it at a later time than the other students. Quizzes will cover materials from
the previous discussion.
If you have a planned, excused absence (e.g. religious observance, BU athletic team trip), you
must submit a written request as soon as possible (minimum: 1 week in advance) to both your
discussion leader and Dr. Szymczyna, so that appropriate arrangements can be made. No
make-up quizzes will be given for unexcused absences, which will result in a quiz grade of
zero. The lowest quiz grade will be dropped.
Exams:
In-class exams will be administered during the regular lecture period on the following days:
February 22, March 29 and April 29. Examinations 2 and 3 will focus on materials covered
since the prior exam. If you have a planned, excused absence (e.g. religious observance, BU
athletic team trip), Dr. Szymczyna must be provided with a written request as soon as possible
(1 week in advance, minimum), and appropriate arrangements will be made. Unexcused
absences will result in a grade of zero for the exam. If an unplanned emergency (that
qualifies as an excused absence) arises, please contact Dr. Szymczyna as soon as possible
so that any necessary arrangements can be made.
If you believe your test/exam has not been graded correctly, a written re-evaluation request
may be submitted. All re-grade requests must be submitted to your discussion leader before
the end of the discussion period during which the exams are returned. Requests must be
submitted in writing, on a separate sheet, with a clear explanation of your concerns. Exams
that have been written on outside of the exam period will not be re-graded. If an exam is
submitted for re-grading, the entire exam (not just the problem in question) may be re-graded.
Final Exam:
The final exam is scheduled for Tuesday, May 7, 9 am – 11 am. The final exam is cumulative
and cannot be made-up or excused.
Other Important Dates:
Last day to add classes February 4
Last day to drop classes without a “W” grade February 26
Last day to drop classes with a “W” grade April 5

Withdrawals and Incompletes:
If it is in your best interest to drop CH 172, you will have no record of the course on your
transcript if you drop before on or before Tuesday, February 26. You may still drop the course
before Friday, April 5, but you will receive a grade of “W” (“withdrawn”) on your transcript. A
grade of “Incomplete” (I) is given in cases where a student with a good academic standing has
not completed specific work, and cannot be used to avoid receiving a poor grade. A grade of
“Incomplete” is only given in approved exceptional circumstances, as defined in the College of
Arts and Sciences (CAS) Undergraduate Programs Bulletin. Grades of “I” automatically convert
to “F” after one calendar year, if the basis of the Incomplete is not adequately addressed.
Incompletes based on your failing to satisfactorily complete the laboratory portion of the course
are left to the discretion of Dr. Rubio. If you believe that you may receive a “W” or “I” grade,
please see Dr. Szymczyna to discuss your status as soon as possible.
Disability Services:
Any student, whose disabilities fall within the Americans with Disabilities Act, should inform Dr.
Szymczyna as soon as possible of any special needs. Students with learning disabilities should
provide the instructor with a letter from the BU Disability Services office that outlines any
recommended accommodations, at least one week before the first exam. The extra time exam
will begin at 9:55 am on exam days, unless other instructions are provided. It is best if students
requiring extra time on exams are not be enrolled in the Friday morning laboratory section (C3).
Academic Conduct:
As a BU student, a high standard of academic honesty and integrity is expected. Every student
in the College of Arts and Sciences is responsible for understanding the content of Academic
Conduct Code and abiding by its provisions. By attending this class, it is assumed that you
have read and will abide by the Code, which can be found at:
http://www.bu.edu/academics/policies/academic-conduct-code/
Please note that we treat cheating - that is any infraction whatsoever of the Academic Conduct
Code - with ZERO TOLERANCE. Cheating is self-destructive, and is disrespectful to your
classmates who earn their grades honestly. At minimum, the consequences of cheating are
that the score for work on which cheating occurs counts as zero and that a letter detailing the
cheating is sent to the student’s advisor, the Dean of your college or program, and placed in
the student’s academic file. Possible further consequences are referral to the Academic
Conduct Committee and additional penalties, including possible expulsion from the University.
None of these consequences are at the discretion of the instructors, but rather are governed
by Boston University’s policies.
Work Together or Work Alone? In light of our strict observance of the Academic Conduct Code,
you may be wondering when it is or is not okay to receive help from a classmate or another
student on an assignment. The simple answer is: if the assignment is for credit (i.e. online
homework, lab report, quiz or exam), then the final written work product MUST reflect YOUR
OWN understanding of the material. In work that is not graded for credit, for example when
doing problems from the textbook, we encourage you to discuss them with your classmates
and within study groups as much as possible, as this is an important mechanism by which you
can come to understand the material better. Thus:

- It is okay, and strongly encouraged, to help each other with textbook problems.
- It is okay, and encouraged, to discuss with another student how to approach a certain type
of problem that you encounter in lecture or in lab.
- It is okay, and encouraged, help each other to review for quizzes and exams.
- It is NOT okay to communicate or collaborate with another student in any way during an
actual quiz or exam (see below for additional rules for taking exams)
- It is NOT okay to submit a lab report containing any section that you did not write entirely
by yourself.
- It is NOT okay to share any part of your lab report with another student before submission,
e.g. “just to see if we came to the same conclusions”.
Rules for Taking Examinations: We make every effort to conduct the examinations in a way
that discourages cheating. These precautionary measures include the following:
a) You are permitted to bring to examinations:
• A Scientific Calculator (unless told otherwise). Graphing calculators and PDAs (i.e. palm
pilots, iPhones or similar electronic devices) with a calculator “app” are not permitted
during examinations.
• A beverage in a colorless, transparent bottle with no label.
b) You may not bring to the examination:
• Any notes or other written or printed matter.
• Laptops, cell phones, mp3 players or any other electronic device.
• No wrapped food, including candy.
c) During the exam, you must sit as directed by the supervising faculty and TFs.
d) All personal belongings must be placed out of reach. Once the exam has started, you
may not access your possessions until the exam is over and you are ready to leave.
Make sure you have any permitted articles that you need for the exam prior to beginning.
e) Hats with visors are to be left with your personal belongings or turned backwards.
f) Once you enter the examination room and sit down, there is no talking to other students
or sharing of any materials, such as molecular models and calculators.
g) If you arrive late, you will not be given extra time to complete the exam. You will not be
allowed to take the exam if any student has handed in his or her work and left the room.
h) If you need to talk to me or to one of the other proctors, raise your hand.
i) If you need to go to the restroom, you must notify and may be accompanied by a
proctor.
j) Please do not fidget loudly, tap on the desk, or make other noises that might disrupt the
concentration of your classmates.
k) All other customary rules for taking exams are enforced.
l) Any serious infractions or suspected cheating will be immediately reported to the Dean’s
Office, who will then take the appropriate actions.

FAQ: How Does One Pass Principles of Organic and Biochemistry?
a) Attend every one of your lecture, discussion, pre-lab and laboratory sections!
b) Schedule enough time to learn the materials!!! For each 50 minutes of class time, you
should spend at least 3 hours reviewing/rewriting the materials. Material covered in later
classes is dependent upon the material learned in earlier classes.
• Read the corresponding sections or chapter before class and come to class with
questions and the answers to the TopHat questions.
• Take detailed notes during the lecture
• Rewrite class notes in your own words after class!!!
• Work though many problems every day. The more homework problems you do, the
better you will retain the material and perform on exams.
c) If a concept confuses you, please seek help as soon as possible by asking questions
during lecture, discussion sections or office hours. Later materials often build on earlier
materials, and not keeping up will lead to increased misunderstandings and difficulties.
d) Arrange study groups. Working on problems with your classmates and explaining what
you have learned to them will help solidify the materials in mind.
e) NEVER FALL BEHIND. Since later lectures build on previous lectures, falling even a
few days behind can put you at a disadvantage. Make time each day to work on
mastering course materials. ‘Cramming’ for exams will not be successful.

2
Course Website and Correspondence:
The course website will be administered through Blackboard Learn (http://learn.bu.edu).
Course announcements and material will be posted on this site and/or sent via students’ BU
email addresses.
Course Description and Objectives:
This course provides a one-semester introduction to organic chemistry and biochemistry. By
the end of the course, you should understand and be able to:
i. Apply the concepts associated with the names, structures, reactivities and reactions of
the major classes of organic compounds and describe their chemical basis
ii. Describe and predict the chemical properties associated with carbohydrates, lipids,
proteins and nucleotides
iii. Describe the physical and chemical properties that contribute to the structure and function
of key biomolecules in living organisms.
iv. Describe the principles behind and relationships between the central pathways of
metabolism for carbohydrates, lipids, and amino acids.
v. Determine patterns in the structures and reactivities of biomolecules associated with their
function in living organisms.
vi. Approach and answer scientific questions related to organic and biochemistry, and learn
how these concepts relate to the life and medical sciences.
Grading and Exam Dates:
Exam 1 Friday, February 22, in class 11 %
Exam 2 Friday, March 29, in class 11 %
Exam 3 Monday, April 29, in class 11 %
Final Exam Tuesday, May 7, 9 – 11am 22 %
Quizzes, Homework & TopHat (each contributes equally) 20 %
Laboratory 25 %
The final and midterm exams are graded on a 100 percent basis and scaled to a 75 percent
class median by adding a maximum of 15 points to everybody’s raw scores. No points are
added if the class median is higher than 75 points. Only 15 points are added if the class median
is lower than 60 points.
Lecture Format, Preparation and Attendance:
CH172 consists of three hours of lectures per week, one hour of discussion, one hour of prelab lecture, and three hours of laboratory work. Your grade will be based on your performance
and contributions in all three aspects of the course. It is highly recommended that you attend
all lecture, discussion, and laboratory sessions. Announcements, which will be posted both in
lecture and on the course Blackboard Learn site, will include reading assignments, problems
and/or worksheets.
Grade F D C- C C+ B- B B+ A- A
Min % 0 50 55 62.5 67.5 75 77.5 85 87.5 92.5

Tentative Syllabus for CH 172
3
The lecture will start promptly at 10:10 AM. There is a great deal of material to cover and we
cannot afford using the first five minutes of each class to get everyone settled. In addition,
important information about up-coming examinations and other matters are often made at the
start of the lecture. For these reasons it is important that you are in your seat and ready to
begin at 10:10 AM.
Although attendance will not be graded, students are expected to attend all lectures. It is
strongly recommended that you read the relevant portions of the textbook before coming to
class. The majority of the time in lecture will be spent selectively explaining the more
challenging parts of the material and their chemical implications, rather than just regurgitating
the textbook. It’s therefore essential that you have a basic knowledge of the material, from
reading the textbook, before coming to the lecture. This approach will allow us to be efficient in
spending most of our class time discussing the more challenging concepts, and on trying to
achieve a deeper understanding of the material. It will also leave more time for us to have
discussions around student’s questions in lecture. Materials in the assigned readings and
materials presented in lectures may appear on quizzes or exams. Pop quizzes may be given
during lecture.
TopHat:
The TopHat audience response system will be used both in and outside of lecture, and will
sometimes be used for quizzes. Your final TopHat grade will be based both upon participation
and the number of correct answers. For in-class questions, you will generally receive 4/5th of
a point for submitting any answer and an additional 1/5th of a point for submitting the correct
answer. Questions used only for information or discussion purposes will earn you 1 point,
regardless of your answer. You will receive a point for quiz questions only if your answer is
correct. You must be in class to answer in-class TopHat questions. Answering in-class
questions from another location will result in you loosing the points for that day, and potentially
obtaining an overall TopHat grade of zero.
For homework questions, you will receive a 1/2 point for submitting any answer and an
additional 1/2 point for submitting the correct answer. Homework questions can be answered
from off-campus.
To receive full credit, you only need to get 90% of the TopHat points, so you can still earn full
credit with a number of incorrect answers and with excused absences. The grade will be
calculated using: [5% x points earned/(possible points * 0.9)].
Online homework:
One or more homework sets will be assigned for each Chapter covered through the Sapling
homework system. Students are expected to check the site after each lecture, to complete the
assignment before the due date, and to leave enough time to manage any computer or network
errors that might arise. Any score greater than 85% will receive full credit for the homework.
Practice Problems:
Students are expected to work assigned end of chapter problems. While these problems will
not be collected or graded, they provide good preparation for quizzes and exams.

4
Discussion Sections:
Attendance at your discussion section is expected. Students should come to their Discussion
section with questions about the practice problems, assigned reading, and lecture material.
During discussion, Learning Assistants (LAs) will assist the discussion leaders in facilitating
practice problem-solving and addressing student questions.
Students should attend the discussion section for which they are registered. If discussion is
cancelled due to a school holiday, accommodations will be made. Graded exams will be
returned during discussion in the week following the exam.
Quizzes:
Quizzes will be given throughout the semester, at the beginning of many discussion sections.
Students who arrive late will not be given extra time to take the quiz, and will not be
allowed to take it at a later time than the other students. Quizzes will cover materials from
the previous discussion.
If you have a planned, excused absence (e.g. religious observance, BU athletic team trip), you
must submit a written request as soon as possible (minimum: 1 week in advance) to both your
discussion leader and so that appropriate arrangements can be made. No
make-up quizzes will be given for unexcused absences, which will result in a quiz grade of
zero. The lowest quiz grade will be dropped.
Exams:
In-class exams will be administered during the regular lecture period on the following days:
February 22, March 29 and April 29. Examinations 2 and 3 will focus on materials covered
since the prior exam. If you have a planned, excused absence (e.g. religious observance, BU
athletic team trip), must be provided with a written request as soon as possible
(1 week in advance, minimum), and appropriate arrangements will be made. Unexcused
absences will result in a grade of zero for the exam. If an unplanned emergency (that
qualifies as an excused absence) arises, please contact as soon as possible
so that any necessary arrangements can be made.
If you believe your test/exam has not been graded correctly, a written re-evaluation request
may be submitted. All re-grade requests must be submitted to your discussion leader before
the end of the discussion period during which the exams are returned. Requests must be
submitted in writing, on a separate sheet, with a clear explanation of your concerns. Exams
that have been written on outside of the exam period will not be re-graded. If an exam is
submitted for re-grading, the entire exam (not just the problem in question) may be re-graded.
Final Exam:
The final exam is scheduled for Tuesday, May 7, 9 am – 11 am. The final exam is cumulative
and cannot be made-up or excused.
Other Important Dates:
Last day to add classes February 4
Last day to drop classes without a “W” grade February 26
Last day to drop classes with a “W” grade April 5

5
Withdrawals and Incompletes:
If it is in your best interest to drop CH 172, you will have no record of the course on your
transcript if you drop before on or before Tuesday, February 26. You may still drop the course
before Friday, April 5, but you will receive a grade of “W” (“withdrawn”) on your transcript. A
grade of “Incomplete” (I) is given in cases where a student with a good academic standing has
not completed specific work, and cannot be used to avoid receiving a poor grade. A grade of
“Incomplete” is only given in approved exceptional circumstances, as defined in the College of
Arts and Sciences (CAS) Undergraduate Programs Bulletin. Grades of “I” automatically convert
to “F” after one calendar year, if the basis of the Incomplete is not adequately addressed.
Incompletes based on your failing to satisfactorily complete the laboratory portion of the course
are left to the discretion of If you believe that you may receive a “W” or “I” grade,
please see a to discuss your status as soon as possible.
Disability Services:
Any student, whose disabilities fall within the Americans with Disabilities Act, should informas soon as possible of any special needs. Students with learning disabilities should
provide the instructor with a letter from the BU Disability Services office that outlines any
recommended accommodations, at least one week before the first exam. The extra time exam
will begin at 9:55 am on exam days, unless other instructions are provided. It is best if students
requiring extra time on exams are not be enrolled in the Friday morning laboratory section (C3).
Academic Conduct:
As a BU student, a high standard of academic honesty and integrity is expected. Every student
in the College of Arts and Sciences is responsible for understanding the content of Academic
Conduct Code and abiding by its provisions. By attending this class, it is assumed that you
have read and will abide by the Code, which can be found at:
http://www.bu.edu/academics/policies/academic-conduct-code/
Please note that we treat cheating - that is any infraction whatsoever of the Academic Conduct
Code - with ZERO TOLERANCE. Cheating is self-destructive, and is disrespectful to your
classmates who earn their grades honestly. At minimum, the consequences of cheating are
that the score for work on which cheating occurs counts as zero and that a letter detailing the
cheating is sent to the student’s advisor, the Dean of your college or program, and placed in
the student’s academic file. Possible further consequences are referral to the Academic
Conduct Committee and additional penalties, including possible expulsion from the University.
None of these consequences are at the discretion of the instructors, but rather are governed
by Boston University’s policies.
Work Together or Work Alone? In light of our strict observance of the Academic Conduct Code,
you may be wondering when it is or is not okay to receive help from a classmate or another
student on an assignment. The simple answer is: if the assignment is for credit (i.e. online
homework, lab report, quiz or exam), then the final written work product MUST reflect YOUR
OWN understanding of the material. In work that is not graded for credit, for example when
doing problems from the textbook, we encourage you to discuss them with your classmates
and within study groups as much as possible, as this is an important mechanism by which you
can come to understand the material better. Thus:
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:44:41 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/52689680/Chemistry-172-Syllabus-Spring-2019-Tentativepdf/
Tentative Syllabus for CH 172
6
- It is okay, and strongly encouraged, to help each other with textbook problems.
- It is okay, and encouraged, to discuss with another student how to approach a certain type
of problem that you encounter in lecture or in lab.
- It is okay, and encouraged, help each other to review for quizzes and exams.
- It is NOT okay to communicate or collaborate with another student in any way during an
actual quiz or exam (see below for additional rules for taking exams)
- It is NOT okay to submit a lab report containing any section that you did not write entirely
by yourself.
- It is NOT okay to share any part of your lab report with another student before submission,
e.g. “just to see if we came to the same conclusions”.
Rules for Taking Examinations: We make every effort to conduct the examinations in a way
that discourages cheating. These precautionary measures include the following:
a) You are permitted to bring to examinations:
• A Scientific Calculator (unless told otherwise). Graphing calculators and PDAs (i.e. palm
pilots, iPhones or similar electronic devices) with a calculator “app” are not permitted
during examinations.
• A beverage in a colorless, transparent bottle with no label.
b) You may not bring to the examination:
• Any notes or other written or printed matter.
• Laptops, cell phones, mp3 players or any other electronic device.
• No wrapped food, including candy.
c) During the exam, you must sit as directed by the supervising faculty and TFs.
d) All personal belongings must be placed out of reach. Once the exam has started, you
may not access your possessions until the exam is over and you are ready to leave.
Make sure you have any permitted articles that you need for the exam prior to beginning.
e) Hats with visors are to be left with your personal belongings or turned backwards.
f) Once you enter the examination room and sit down, there is no talking to other students
or sharing of any materials, such as molecular models and calculators.
g) If you arrive late, you will not be given extra time to complete the exam. You will not be
allowed to take the exam if any student has handed in his or her work and left the room.
h) If you need to talk to me or to one of the other proctors, raise your hand.
i) If you need to go to the restroom, you must notify and may be accompanied by a
proctor.
j) Please do not fidget loudly, tap on the desk, or make other noises that might disrupt the
concentration of your classmates.
k) All other customary rules for taking exams are enforced.
l) Any serious infractions or suspected cheating will be immediately reported to the Dean’s
Office, who will then take the appropriate actions.

FAQ: How Does One Pass Principles of Organic and Biochemistry?
a) Attend every one of your lecture, discussion, pre-lab and laboratory sections!
b) Schedule enough time to learn the materials!!! For each 50 minutes of class time, you
should spend at least 3 hours reviewing/rewriting the materials. Material covered in later
classes is dependent upon the material learned in earlier classes.
• Read the corresponding sections or chapter before class and come to class with
questions and the answers to the TopHat questions.
• Take detailed notes during the lecture
• Rewrite class notes in your own words after class!!!
• Work though many problems every day. The more homework problems you do, the
better you will retain the material and perform on exams.
c) If a concept confuses you, please seek help as soon as possible by asking questions
during lecture, discussion sections or office hours. Later materials often build on earlier
materials, and not keeping up will lead to increased misunderstandings and difficulties.
d) Arrange study groups. Working on problems with your classmates and explaining what
you have learned to them will help solidify the materials in mind.
e) NEVER FALL BEHIND. Since later lectures build on previous lectures, falling even a
few days behind can put you at a disadvantage. Make time each day to work on
mastering course materials. ‘Cramming’ for exams will not be successful.
f) Use tutoring services, such as those offered by the Educational Resource Center (ERC)
or Chemia: The ERC focuses on helping students to become stronger learners through
several free programs and services designed to complement your experience in
class. Professional staff are available to help you craft a customized plan for academic
success and to help you get connected to the wide variety of resources available at
BU. In addition, free Peer Tutoring is available as another support for this course
(subject to availability). For more information on these and other services see
www.bu.edu/erc.

tutoring service twice a week. For additional details see their website, Facebook page
or Instagram page:

Course Website and Correspondence:
The course website will be administered through Blackboard Learn (http://learn.bu.edu).
Course announcements and material will be posted on this site and/or sent via students’ BU
email addresses.
Course Description and Objectives:
This course provides a one-semester introduction to organic chemistry and biochemistry. By
the end of the course, you should understand and be able to:
i. Apply the concepts associated with the names, structures, reactivities and reactions of
the major classes of organic compounds and describe their chemical basis
ii. Describe and predict the chemical properties associated with carbohydrates, lipids,
proteins and nucleotides
iii. Describe the physical and chemical properties that contribute to the structure and function
of key biomolecules in living organisms.
iv. Describe the principles behind and relationships between the central pathways of
metabolism for carbohydrates, lipids, and amino acids.
v. Determine patterns in the structures and reactivities of biomolecules associated with their
function in living organisms.
vi. Approach and answer scientific questions related to organic and biochemistry, and learn
how these concepts relate to the life and medical sciences.
Grading and Exam Dates:
Exam 1 Friday, February 22, in class 11 %
Exam 2 Friday, March 29, in class 11 %
Exam 3 Monday, April 29, in class 11 %
Final Exam Tuesday, May 7, 9 – 11am 22 %
Quizzes, Homework & TopHat (each contributes equally) 20 %
Laboratory 25 %
The final and midterm exams are graded on a 100 percent basis and scaled to a 75 percent
class median by adding a maximum of 15 points to everybody’s raw scores. No points are
added if the class median is higher than 75 points. Only 15 points are added if the class median
is lower than 60 points.
Lecture Format, Preparation and Attendance:
CH172 consists of three hours of lectures per week, one hour of discussion, one hour of prelab lecture, and three hours of laboratory work. Your grade will be based on your performance
and contributions in all three aspects of the course. It is highly recommended that you attend
all lecture, discussion, and laboratory sessions. Announcements, which will be posted both in
lecture and on the course Blackboard Learn site, will include reading assignments, problems
and/or worksheets.
Grade F D C- C C+ B- B B+ A- A
Min % 0 50 55 62.5 67.5 75 77.5 85 87.5 92.5



3
The lecture will start promptly at 10:10 AM. There is a great deal of material to cover and we
cannot afford using the first five minutes of each class to get everyone settled. In addition,
important information about up-coming examinations and other matters are often made at the
start of the lecture. For these reasons it is important that you are in your seat and ready to
begin at 10:10 AM.
Although attendance will not be graded, students are expected to attend all lectures. It is
strongly recommended that you read the relevant portions of the textbook before coming to
class. The majority of the time in lecture will be spent selectively explaining the more
challenging parts of the material and their chemical implications, rather than just regurgitating
the textbook. It’s therefore essential that you have a basic knowledge of the material, from
reading the textbook, before coming to the lecture. This approach will allow us to be efficient in
spending most of our class time discussing the more challenging concepts, and on trying to
achieve a deeper understanding of the material. It will also leave more time for us to have
discussions around student’s questions in lecture. Materials in the assigned readings and
materials presented in lectures may appear on quizzes or exams. Pop quizzes may be given
during lecture.
TopHat:
The TopHat audience response system will be used both in and outside of lecture, and will
sometimes be used for quizzes. Your final TopHat grade will be based both upon participation
and the number of correct answers. For in-class questions, you will generally receive 4/5th of
a point for submitting any answer and an additional 1/5th of a point for submitting the correct
answer. Questions used only for information or discussion purposes will earn you 1 point,
regardless of your answer. You will receive a point for quiz questions only if your answer is
correct. You must be in class to answer in-class TopHat questions. Answering in-class
questions from another location will result in you loosing the points for that day, and potentially
obtaining an overall TopHat grade of zero.
For homework questions, you will receive a 1/2 point for submitting any answer and an
additional 1/2 point for submitting the correct answer. Homework questions can be answered
from off-campus.
To receive full credit, you only need to get 90% of the TopHat points, so you can still earn full
credit with a number of incorrect answers and with excused absences. The grade will be
calculated using: [5% x points earned/(possible points * 0.9)].
Online homework:
One or more homework sets will be assigned for each Chapter covered through the Sapling
homework system. Students are expected to check the site after each lecture, to complete the
assignment before the due date, and to leave enough time to manage any computer or network
errors that might arise. Any score greater than 85% will receive full credit for the homework.
Practice Problems:
Students are expected to work assigned end of chapter problems. While these problems will
not be collected or graded, they provide good preparation for quizzes and exams.



4
Discussion Sections:
Attendance at your discussion section is expected. Students should come to their Discussion
section with questions about the practice problems, assigned reading, and lecture material.
During discussion, Learning Assistants (LAs) will assist the discussion leaders in facilitating
practice problem-solving and addressing student questions.
Students should attend the discussion section for which they are registered. If discussion is
cancelled due to a school holiday, accommodations will be made. Graded exams will be
returned during discussion in the week following the exam.
Quizzes:
Quizzes will be given throughout the semester, at the beginning of many discussion sections.
Students who arrive late will not be given extra time to take the quiz, and will not be
allowed to take it at a later time than the other students. Quizzes will cover materials from
the previous discussion.
If you have a planned, excused absence (e.g. religious observance, BU athletic team trip), you
must submit a written request as soon as possible (minimum: 1 week in advance) to both your
discussion leader and so that appropriate arrangements can be made. No
make-up quizzes will be given for unexcused absences, which will result in a quiz grade of
zero. The lowest quiz grade will be dropped.
Exams:
In-class exams will be administered during the regular lecture period on the following days:
February 22, March 29 and April 29. Examinations 2 and 3 will focus on materials covered
since the prior exam. If you have a planned, excused absence (e.g. religious observance, BU
athletic team trip), must be provided with a written request as soon as possible
(1 week in advance, minimum), and appropriate arrangements will be made. Unexcused
absences will result in a grade of zero for the exam. If an unplanned emergency (that
qualifies as an excused absence) arises, please contact as soon as possible
so that any necessary arrangements can be made.
If you believe your test/exam has not been graded correctly, a written re-evaluation request
may be submitted. All re-grade requests must be submitted to your discussion leader before
the end of the discussion period during which the exams are returned. Requests must be
submitted in writing, on a separate sheet, with a clear explanation of your concerns. Exams
that have been written on outside of the exam period will not be re-graded. If an exam is
submitted for re-grading, the entire exam (not just the problem in question) may be re-graded.
Final Exam:
The final exam is scheduled for Tuesday, May 7, 9 am – 11 am. The final exam is cumulative
and cannot be made-up or excused.
Other Important Dates:
Last day to add classes February 4
Last day to drop classes without a “W” grade February 26
Last day to drop classes with a “W” grade April 5



5
Withdrawals and Incompletes:
If it is in your best interest to drop CH 172, you will have no record of the course on your
transcript if you drop before on or before Tuesday, February 26. You may still drop the course
before Friday, April 5, but you will receive a grade of “W” (“withdrawn”) on your transcript. A
grade of “Incomplete” (I) is given in cases where a student with a good academic standing has
not completed specific work, and cannot be used to avoid receiving a poor grade. A grade of
“Incomplete” is only given in approved exceptional circumstances, as defined in the College of
Arts and Sciences (CAS) Undergraduate Programs Bulletin. Grades of “I” automatically convert
to “F” after one calendar year, if the basis of the Incomplete is not adequately addressed.
Incompletes based on your failing to satisfactorily complete the laboratory portion of the course
are left to the discretion of If you believe that you may receive a “W” or “I” grade,
please see a to discuss your status as soon as possible.
Disability Services:
Any student, whose disabilities fall within the Americans with Disabilities Act, should informas soon as possible of any special needs. Students with learning disabilities should
provide the instructor with a letter from the BU Disability Services office that outlines any
recommended accommodations, at least one week before the first exam. The extra time exam
will begin at 9:55 am on exam days, unless other instructions are provided. It is best if students
requiring extra time on exams are not be enrolled in the Friday morning laboratory section (C3).
Academic Conduct:
As a BU student, a high standard of academic honesty and integrity is expected. Every student
in the College of Arts and Sciences is responsible for understanding the content of Academic
Conduct Code and abiding by its provisions. By attending this class, it is assumed that you
have read and will abide by the Code, which can be found at:

Please note that we treat cheating - that is any infraction whatsoever of the Academic Conduct
Code - with ZERO TOLERANCE. Cheating is self-destructive, and is disrespectful to your
classmates who earn their grades honestly. At minimum, the consequences of cheating are
that the score for work on which cheating occurs counts as zero and that a letter detailing the
cheating is sent to the student’s advisor, the Dean of your college or program, and placed in
the student’s academic file. Possible further consequences are referral to the Academic
Conduct Committee and additional penalties, including possible expulsion from the University.
None of these consequences are at the discretion of the instructors, but rather are governed
by Boston University’s policies.
Work Together or Work Alone? In light of our strict observance of the Academic Conduct Code,
you may be wondering when it is or is not okay to receive help from a classmate or another
student on an assignment. The simple answer is: if the assignment is for credit (i.e. online
homework, lab report, quiz or exam), then the final written work product MUST reflect YOUR
OWN understanding of the material. In work that is not graded for credit, for example when
doing problems from the textbook, we encourage you to discuss them with your classmates
and within study groups as much as possible, as this is an important mechanism by which you
can come to understand the material better. Thus:



6
- It is okay, and strongly encouraged, to help each other with textbook problems.
- It is okay, and encouraged, to discuss with another student how to approach a certain type
of problem that you encounter in lecture or in lab.
- It is okay, and encouraged, help each other to review for quizzes and exams.
- It is NOT okay to communicate or collaborate with another student in any way during an
actual quiz or exam (see below for additional rules for taking exams)
- It is NOT okay to submit a lab report containing any section that you did not write entirely
by yourself.
- It is NOT okay to share any part of your lab report with another student before submission,
e.g. “just to see if we came to the same conclusions”.
Rules for Taking Examinations: We make every effort to conduct the examinations in a way
that discourages cheating. These precautionary measures include the following:
a) You are permitted to bring to examinations:
• A Scientific Calculator (unless told otherwise). Graphing calculators and PDAs (i.e. palm
pilots, iPhones or similar electronic devices) with a calculator “app” are not permitted
during examinations.
• A beverage in a colorless, transparent bottle with no label.
b) You may not bring to the examination:
• Any notes or other written or printed matter.
• Laptops, cell phones, mp3 players or any other electronic device.
• No wrapped food, including candy.
c) During the exam, you must sit as directed by the supervising faculty and TFs.
d) All personal belongings must be placed out of reach. Once the exam has started, you
may not access your possessions until the exam is over and you are ready to leave.
Make sure you have any permitted articles that you need for the exam prior to beginning.
e) Hats with visors are to be left with your personal belongings or turned backwards.
f) Once you enter the examination room and sit down, there is no talking to other students
or sharing of any materials, such as molecular models and calculators.
g) If you arrive late, you will not be given extra time to complete the exam. You will not be
allowed to take the exam if any student has handed in his or her work and left the room.
h) If you need to talk to me or to one of the other proctors, raise your hand.
i) If you need to go to the restroom, you must notify and may be accompanied by a
proctor.
j) Please do not fidget loudly, tap on the desk, or make other noises that might disrupt the
concentration of your classmates.
k) All other customary rules for taking exams are enforced.
l) Any serious infractions or suspected cheating will be immediately reported to the Dean’s
Office, who will then take the appropriate actions.



7
FAQ: How Does One Pass Principles of Organic and Biochemistry?
a) Attend every one of your lecture, discussion, pre-lab and laboratory sections!
b) Schedule enough time to learn the materials!!! For each 50 minutes of class time, you
should spend at least 3 hours reviewing/rewriting the materials. Material covered in later
classes is dependent upon the material learned in earlier classes.
• Read the corresponding sections or chapter before class and come to class with
questions and the answers to the TopHat questions.
• Take detailed notes during the lecture
• Rewrite class notes in your own words after class!!!
• Work though many problems every day. The more homework problems you do, the
better you will retain the material and perform on exams.
c) If a concept confuses you, please seek help as soon as possible by asking questions
during lecture, discussion sections or office hours. Later materials often build on earlier
materials, and not keeping up will lead to increased misunderstandings and difficulties.
d) Arrange study groups. Working on problems with your classmates and explaining what
you have learned to them will help solidify the materials in mind.
e) NEVER FALL BEHIND. Since later lectures build on previous lectures, falling even a
few days behind can put you at a disadvantage. Make time each day to work on
mastering course materials. ‘Cramming’ for exams will not be successful.
f) Use tutoring services, such as those offered by the Educational Resource Center (ERC)
or Chemia: The ERC focuses on helping students to become stronger learners through
several free programs and services designed to complement your experience in
class. Professional staff are available to help you craft a customized plan for academic
success and to help you get connected to the wide variety of resources available at
BU. In addition, free Peer Tutoring is available as another support for this course
(subject to availability). For more information on these and other services see
www.bu.edu/erc.
Chemia, the Undergraduate ACS affiliate of chemistry majors at BU, operates a free
tutoring service twice a week. For additional details see their website, Facebook page
or Instagram page:




8

Text:
AR 101: Introduction to Archaeology
Course Syllabus
Boston University
Spring, 2021
(last revised on 03/20/21)
COURSE INFORMATION
Professor: Dr. Mary Clarke
Lecture:
Tue. & Thurs. 9:30–10:45am
College of Arts and Sciences (CAS) Room 320
Zoom Meeting: LINK
Meeting ID: 968 1451 6967
Passcode: AR101–2021
Teaching Fellow: Ana Barun
Sections:
B3, Mon. 2:30–3:20
B4, Mon. 4:40–5:30
B1, Tue. 11:15–12:05
Stone Science Building
(STO) Room 253
Zoom Meetings: See Blackboard
CONTACT INFORMATION
Dr. Mary Clarke
Email: meclarke@bu.edu
Office: CAS, Room 354A
Office Hours: Tue. 12–3pm
Schedule Appts: LINK
Ana Barun
Email: aebarun@bu.edu
Office: CAS, Room 350
Office Hours: Fri. 10am – 12pm
COURSE DESCRIPTION
As social scientists that study the human past, archaeologists rely on field and laboratory methods for
locating, dating, and understanding the material remains of past human activities. We ask questions such
as: Where did we come from? How did cultures adapt to and elaborate on their surroundings? Why do
complex societies rise and fall? What lessons does the past have for us in the present? This course
provides an introduction to archaeological methods, theories, and topics of debate that allow
archaeologists to evaluate these questions and integrate the answers into contemporary society. The
semester builds from the “nuts and bolts” methods that archaeologists rely on in field and laboratory
settings, to the important research topics and theories archaeologists engage in as they endeavor to
explain social change.
COURSE OBJECTIVES
At the conclusion of this course, you will have developed a foundational understanding of archaeological
practice and reasoning. You will be able to evaluate the logic behind and merits of different
interpretations of what occurred in the human past. Through classroom lectures and discussions during
sections, you will gain an appreciation of the deep histories and cultural diversity of different parts of the
globe, and better your understanding of how people create and inhabit an ever-changing material world.
This is an introductory level course that fulfills the social-science distribution for the College of Arts and
Sciences and does not require prerequisites. It fulfills the Department of Archaeology area requirement, and
it satisfies two BU Hub Capacities: Historical Consciousness and Social Inquiry I. Course credit: 4.0.
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:47:07 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/102299047/AR-101-Spring-2021-Syllabuspdf/
For the BU Hub capacities, three Historical outcomes will be fulfilled in this course: 1) Students will
develop a foundational understanding of how to evaluate the deep history of humankind. Course content
covers millions of years of human history, including topics such as human evolution, the origins of
agriculture, early urbanism, the invention of writing, and the rise and development of early civilizations
and empires. 2) Students will discuss and demonstrate their understanding of the information presented
in the lectures, sections, and readings, especially in terms of how the human past is relevant in the
present, including the issues of protecting and preserving the cultural heritage worldwide, as well as how
societies in the past have coped with changing environments. 3) Course content includes an
understanding of forms of socio-political organization, from Paleolithic hunter-gatherers to the early
states and empires in both the Old and New Worlds. Changing modes of subsistence, especially with the
invention of agriculture, to state-level economies, are also covered. Content includes material
manifestations of social inequality, religious traditions and cosmology and how these were similar or
different during different periods of human history.
One Social outcome will be fulfilled by this course: Students learn and apply archaeological methods of
cross-cultural and diachronic comparison (change over time) to understand subsistence and technology as
well as political and religious systems.
Required Textbooks and Readings – We have two textbooks in this course. First, we’ll be using
Archaeology Essentials: Theories, Methods, and Practice by Colin Renfrew and Paul Bahn (2018), 4th edition
(although I will also list assigned readings for the 3rd edition in case that version is more accessible to
you). The second is Death by Theory: A Tale of Mystery and Archaeological Theory by Adrian
Praetzellis (2011). You can buy a copy of both through Boston University’s Barnes & Noble store or
online. Please email me if purchasing either textbook is an obstacle to your success in this class so that we
can make the appropriate arrangements. This includes those of you attending class remotely. There will
also be non-textbook readings, podcasts, and videos, all of which will be posted on the course website on
BU Learn (Blackboard): https://learn.bu.edu/
POLICIES
Make-up Exams – Traditionally, none are given except in the case of a documented illness, emergency, or
previously discussed circumstances (see the section on Equity below). However, current circumstances
allow for greater flexibility, so please do be in touch with the Professor.
CAS Academic Misconduct Code – This will be followed in the event that academic misconduct occurs.
Students should refer to the CAS policy on misconduct
(https://www.bu.edu/academics/policies/academic-conduct-code/ ).
Absences & LfA – As you are able to take this course in multiple modes, absences will not be counted for
this course. However, participation will be assessed based on either your lecture/section attendance OR
the completion of discussion questions that are posted on blackboard and reflect material covered in the
lecture/section recordings. Any prolonged absences or extenuating circumstances should be discussed
with Prof. Clarke.
In the Classroom – As a courtesy to the instructor and your fellow students, be on time to class and
refrain from engaging in distracting behavior. As many of you will be joining remotely, please do consider
keeping your video on (not a requirement, but it is nice to teach to people rather than black/blank
screens), muting yourself when not participating in conversation, and being in a place where you can
focus on the course. When you’re attending class in person, you’ll have the option to login to the Zoom
classroom to view the slides up close, utilize the chat/poll functions, and stay connected to your peers.
To prevent audio feedback, I’ll instruct those of us attending in person to turn off our computer audio
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:47:07 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/102299047/AR-101-Spring-2021-Syllabuspdf/
systems. We’ll go over more of this in class, but I’ll also direct you to blackboard where I’ve made a
content folder on Zoom etiquette.
Names and Pronouns – Everyone has the right to go by the name and pronouns (e.g. she/her/hers,
he/him/his, they/them/their) that they prefer. You may introduce yourself using whatever name you
wish to use. It would also be good for you all to edit or adjust your Zoom profiles so that they reflect
these identifiers (see links to instructions within the etiquette folder on blackboard).
Accommodations – If you are a student with a disability or believe you might have a disability that requires
accommodations, please contact the Office for Disability Services (ODS) at (617) 353-3658
(http://www.bu.edu/disability/) to coordinate any accommodation requests. I am typically notified by
ODS but would be happy to meet with you directly as well to ensure that the structure of your assessment
will lead to your success in this course. Those of you that are non-native speakers, first generation college
students, or non-traditional students (e.g., caregivers, full-time workers, etc.), please do set aside time to meet
with me so that we may discuss a flexible timeline that enables you to succeed in all your responsibilities.
Communication – Please check your email regularly for course announcements.
EXPECTATIONS
What you can expect from your instructors:
1) Transparency in the way we intend to assess your performance in this course
2) Empathy, respect, and fairness in our treatment of all students
3) An open ear to your ideas, thoughts, complaints, and solutions regarding instruction, course
content, and your assessment.
4) Confidentiality in personnel matters and individual conversations; transparency and consistency
in decision making, and prompt sharing of information as soon as practicable
5) A commitment to justice, equality/equity, and inclusivity in our curriculum, at our university, and
in our profession
What we expect from you:
1) Patience and tolerance: these are exceptional times for the university and our society. Please bear
with us as we navigate these situations as best as we are able.
2) Respect and professionalism: there are new modes of conduct that we’re all learning to integrate
into our daily lives, be it social distancing, wearing face masks, or hybrid learning/teaching
formats. We ask that you respect these codes of conduct for the safety of our community while
also maintaining a level of professionalism in your decorum.
3) Honesty and critique: if we make a decision with which you disagree, please share your concerns
with us. We will be integrating an equity assessment into this course so that we may grow and
confront any biases within our teaching and course content.
4) Academic integrity: we are interested in your thoughts and unique perspectives on the world.
Please lead with your view when approaching your work in this course.
EVALUATION SCHEME
15% Participation – Marks will be assigned in accordance with the level of participation and engagement
with reading materials and class discussions. For those of you that plan to attend asynchronously, you will
need to complete the four discussion questions posted on blackboard for each lecture and section
meeting. These questions will directly relate to the recordings and can be complete while watching this
material.
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:47:07 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/102299047/AR-101-Spring-2021-Syllabuspdf/
20% Sections – Sections are an important component of this course because they provide a more
intimate setting for questions, discussion, and lab activities aimed at introducing you to thinking like an
archaeologist. They are also structured so that they prepare you for your exams, which includes short, in
class quizzes. Sections offer you an opportunity to apply methods as well as discuss and debate topics
from lectures in a manner that is consistent with your exams.
20% Midterm Exam #1 – Covering material from the first unit: Archaeological Methods, this exam will
include multiple choice, matching, short answer questions, and short response questions. It will be given
as a take home and open note exam; however, the structure of assessment will emphasize evaluation,
discussion, and critique over recollection and pure memorization. You will have five days to complete
and submit your exam.
20% Midterm Exam #2 – Covering material from the second unit: Archaeology at Work, this exam will
include multiple choice, matching, short answer questions, short response question, and one essay
question. It will be given as a take home and open note exam; however, the structure of questions will
emphasize evaluation, discussion, and critique over recollection and pure memorization. You will have
five days to complete and submit your exam.
25% Cumulative Final Exam – Covering material from all units in this class (a 30% / 30% / 40%
distribution), this exam will include multiple choice, matching, short answer questions, and two essay
questions. It will be given as a take home and open note exam; however, the structure of questions will
emphasize evaluation, discussion, and critique over recollection and pure memorization. You will have
approximately one week to complete and submit your exam.
2–6% Extra Credit – In addition to extra credit questions on your exams, you also have the opportunity
to complete a total of three extra assignments, each worth 2% of your total grade. These options ask that
you engage with archaeology and related topics outside of the classroom, and then produce an engaging
short essay, podcast, or video outcome (See blackboard for examples). Notably, these may be completed
and submitted at any point in the semester.
GRADE DISTRIBUTIONS

A- 93–90
B+ 89–87
B 86–83
B- 82–80
C+ 79–77
C 76–73
C- 72–70
D+ 69–67
D 66–63
D- 62–60
F 59–0

Pre-processed text 1:
AR 101: Introduction to Archaeology
Course Syllabus
Boston University
Spring, 2021
(last revised on 03/20/21)
COURSE INFORMATION
COURSE DESCRIPTION
As social scientists that study the human past, archaeologists rely on field and laboratory methods for
locating, dating, and understanding the material remains of past human activities. We ask questions such
as: Where did we come from? How did cultures adapt to and elaborate on their surroundings? Why do
complex societies rise and fall? What lessons does the past have for us in the present? This course
provides an introduction to archaeological methods, theories, and topics of debate that allow
archaeologists to evaluate these questions and integrate the answers into contemporary society. The
semester builds from the “nuts and bolts” methods that archaeologists rely on in field and laboratory
settings, to the important research topics and theories archaeologists engage in as they endeavor to
explain social change.
COURSE OBJECTIVES
At the conclusion of this course, you will have developed a foundational understanding of archaeological
practice and reasoning. You will be able to evaluate the logic behind and merits of different
interpretations of what occurred in the human past. Through classroom lectures and discussions during
sections, you will gain an appreciation of the deep histories and cultural diversity of different parts of the
globe, and better your understanding of how people create and inhabit an ever-changing material world.
This is an introductory level course that fulfills the social-science distribution for the College of Arts and
Sciences and does not require prerequisites. It fulfills the Department of Archaeology area requirement, and
it satisfies two BU Hub Capacities: Historical Consciousness and Social Inquiry I. Course credit: 4.0.
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:47:07 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/102299047/AR-101-Spring-2021-Syllabuspdf/
For the BU Hub capacities, three Historical outcomes will be fulfilled in this course: 1) Students will
develop a foundational understanding of how to evaluate the deep history of humankind. Course content
covers millions of years of human history, including topics such as human evolution, the origins of
agriculture, early urbanism, the invention of writing, and the rise and development of early civilizations
and empires. 2) Students will discuss and demonstrate their understanding of the information presented
in the lectures, sections, and readings, especially in terms of how the human past is relevant in the
present, including the issues of protecting and preserving the cultural heritage worldwide, as well as how
societies in the past have coped with changing environments. 3) Course content includes an
understanding of forms of socio-political organization, from Paleolithic hunter-gatherers to the early
states and empires in both the Old and New Worlds. Changing modes of subsistence, especially with the
invention of agriculture, to state-level economies, are also covered. Content includes material
manifestations of social inequality, religious traditions and cosmology and how these were similar or
different during different periods of human history.
One Social outcome will be fulfilled by this course: Students learn and apply archaeological methods of
cross-cultural and diachronic comparison (change over time) to understand subsistence and technology as
well as political and religious systems.
Required Textbooks and Readings – We have two textbooks in this course. First, we’ll be using
Archaeology Essentials: Theories, Methods, and Practice by Colin Renfrew and Paul Bahn (2018), 4th edition
(although I will also list assigned readings for the 3rd edition in case that version is more accessible to
you). The second is Death by Theory: A Tale of Mystery and Archaeological Theory by Adrian
Praetzellis (2011). You can buy a copy of both through Boston University’s Barnes & Noble store or
online. Please email me if purchasing either textbook is an obstacle to your success in this class so that we
can make the appropriate arrangements. This includes those of you attending class remotely. There will
also be non-textbook readings, podcasts, and videos, all of which will be posted on the course website on
BU Learn (Blackboard): https://learn.bu.edu/
POLICIES
Make-up Exams – Traditionally, none are given except in the case of a documented illness, emergency, or
previously discussed circumstances (see the section on Equity below). However, current circumstances
allow for greater flexibility, so please do be in touch with the Professor.
CAS Academic Misconduct Code – This will be followed in the event that academic misconduct occurs.
Students should refer to the CAS policy on misconduct
(https://www.bu.edu/academics/policies/academic-conduct-code/ ).
Absences & LfA – As you are able to take this course in multiple modes, absences will not be counted for
this course. However, participation will be assessed based on either your lecture/section attendance OR
the completion of discussion questions that are posted on blackboard and reflect material covered in the
lecture/section recordings. Any prolonged absences or extenuating circumstances should be discussed
with Prof. Clarke.
In the Classroom – As a courtesy to the instructor and your fellow students, be on time to class and
refrain from engaging in distracting behavior. As many of you will be joining remotely, please do consider
keeping your video on (not a requirement, but it is nice to teach to people rather than black/blank
screens), muting yourself when not participating in conversation, and being in a place where you can
focus on the course. When you’re attending class in person, you’ll have the option to login to the Zoom
classroom to view the slides up close, utilize the chat/poll functions, and stay connected to your peers.
To prevent audio feedback, I’ll instruct those of us attending in person to turn off our computer audio
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:47:07 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/102299047/AR-101-Spring-2021-Syllabuspdf/
systems. We’ll go over more of this in class, but I’ll also direct you to blackboard where I’ve made a
content folder on Zoom etiquette.
Names and Pronouns – Everyone has the right to go by the name and pronouns (e.g. she/her/hers,
he/him/his, they/them/their) that they prefer. You may introduce yourself using whatever name you
wish to use. It would also be good for you all to edit or adjust your Zoom profiles so that they reflect
these identifiers (see links to instructions within the etiquette folder on blackboard).
Accommodations – If you are a student with a disability or believe you might have a disability that requires
accommodations, please contact the Office for Disability Services (ODS) at (617) 353-3658
(http://www.bu.edu/disability/) to coordinate any accommodation requests. I am typically notified by
ODS but would be happy to meet with you directly as well to ensure that the structure of your assessment
will lead to your success in this course. Those of you that are non-native speakers, first generation college
students, or non-traditional students (e.g., caregivers, full-time workers, etc.), please do set aside time to meet
with me so that we may discuss a flexible timeline that enables you to succeed in all your responsibilities.
Communication – Please check your email regularly for course announcements.
EXPECTATIONS
What you can expect from your instructors:
1) Transparency in the way we intend to assess your performance in this course
2) Empathy, respect, and fairness in our treatment of all students
3) An open ear to your ideas, thoughts, complaints, and solutions regarding instruction, course
content, and your assessment.
4) Confidentiality in personnel matters and individual conversations; transparency and consistency
in decision making, and prompt sharing of information as soon as practicable
5) A commitment to justice, equality/equity, and inclusivity in our curriculum, at our university, and
in our profession
What we expect from you:
1) Patience and tolerance: these are exceptional times for the university and our society. Please bear
with us as we navigate these situations as best as we are able.
2) Respect and professionalism: there are new modes of conduct that we’re all learning to integrate
into our daily lives, be it social distancing, wearing face masks, or hybrid learning/teaching
formats. We ask that you respect these codes of conduct for the safety of our community while
also maintaining a level of professionalism in your decorum.
3) Honesty and critique: if we make a decision with which you disagree, please share your concerns
with us. We will be integrating an equity assessment into this course so that we may grow and
confront any biases within our teaching and course content.
4) Academic integrity: we are interested in your thoughts and unique perspectives on the world.
Please lead with your view when approaching your work in this course.
EVALUATION SCHEME
15% Participation – Marks will be assigned in accordance with the level of participation and engagement
with reading materials and class discussions. For those of you that plan to attend asynchronously, you will
need to complete the four discussion questions posted on blackboard for each lecture and section
meeting. These questions will directly relate to the recordings and can be complete while watching this
material.
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:47:07 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/102299047/AR-101-Spring-2021-Syllabuspdf/
20% Sections – Sections are an important component of this course because they provide a more
intimate setting for questions, discussion, and lab activities aimed at introducing you to thinking like an
archaeologist. They are also structured so that they prepare you for your exams, which includes short, in
class quizzes. Sections offer you an opportunity to apply methods as well as discuss and debate topics
from lectures in a manner that is consistent with your exams.
20% Midterm Exam #1 – Covering material from the first unit: Archaeological Methods, this exam will
include multiple choice, matching, short answer questions, and short response questions. It will be given
as a take home and open note exam; however, the structure of assessment will emphasize evaluation,
discussion, and critique over recollection and pure memorization. You will have five days to complete
and submit your exam.
20% Midterm Exam #2 – Covering material from the second unit: Archaeology at Work, this exam will
include multiple choice, matching, short answer questions, short response question, and one essay
question. It will be given as a take home and open note exam; however, the structure of questions will
emphasize evaluation, discussion, and critique over recollection and pure memorization. You will have
five days to complete and submit your exam.
25% Cumulative Final Exam – Covering material from all units in this class (a 30% / 30% / 40%
distribution), this exam will include multiple choice, matching, short answer questions, and two essay
questions. It will be given as a take home and open note exam; however, the structure of questions will
emphasize evaluation, discussion, and critique over recollection and pure memorization. You will have
approximately one week to complete and submit your exam.
2–6% Extra Credit – In addition to extra credit questions on your exams, you also have the opportunity
to complete a total of three extra assignments, each worth 2% of your total grade. These options ask that
you engage with archaeology and related topics outside of the classroom, and then produce an engaging
short essay, podcast, or video outcome (See blackboard for examples). Notably, these may be completed
and submitted at any point in the semester.
GRADE DISTRIBUTIONS
A 100–94
A- 93–90
B+ 89–87
B 86–83
B- 82–80
C+ 79–77
C 76–73
C- 72–70
D+ 69–67
D 66–63
D- 62–60
F 59–0

- Readings: Arch Essen, Chapter 3, pp. 62–90
2/9, Tues. Archaeological Survey & Excavation

as a take home and open note exam; however, the structure of assessment will emphasize evaluation,
discussion, and critique over recollection and pure memorization. You will have five days to complete
and submit your exam.
20% Midterm Exam #2 – Covering material from the second unit: Archaeology at Work, this exam will
include multiple choice, matching, short answer questions, short response question, and one essay
question. It will be given as a take home and open note exam; however, the structure of questions will
emphasize evaluation, discussion, and critique over recollection and pure memorization. You will have
five days to complete and submit your exam.
25% Cumulative Final Exam – Covering material from all units in this class (a 30% / 30% / 40%
distribution), this exam will include multiple choice, matching, short answer questions, and two essay
questions. It will be given as a take home and open note exam; however, the structure of questions will
emphasize evaluation, discussion, and critique over recollection and pure memorization. You will have
approximately one week to complete and submit your exam.
2–6% Extra Credit – In addition to extra credit questions on your exams, you also have the opportunity
to complete a total of three extra assignments, each worth 2% of your total grade. These options ask that
you engage with archaeology and related topics outside of the classroom, and then produce an engaging
short essay, podcast, or video outcome (See blackboard for examples). Notably, these may be completed
and submitted at any point in the semester.
GRADE DISTRIBUTIONS

D+ 69–67

Text:
ANTH 250: Biological Anthropology Winter 2021
Dr. Nichole Fournier
nfournie@calpoly.edu
Office Hours: Monday and Wednesday 9:00-11:00am Pacific Time via Zoom
Course Description: This course is an introduction to biological anthropology, the subfield of
anthropology that focuses on human evolutionary history, behavior, and variation. We will cover
the theory of evolution, primate and human evolution, primate behavior, and modern human
variation. By the end of the course, students will have an understanding of what it means to be
human.
ANTH 250 Learning Objectives:
1. Understand biological evolution and the processes by which it occurs.
2. Be able to identify what human ancestors looked like, how they acted, and the
evolutionary relationships between them.
3. Understand modern human variation and investigate the causal forces behind this
variation.
4. Gain familiarity with the biology, ecology, and behavior of the various kinds of
nonhuman primates.
Anthropology Program Learning Objectives Met:
1. Understand and appreciate the cultural and physical attributes of major world regions,
key regional issues and linkages between regions, the processes that shape cultural
change and interaction, and international development issues.
2. Demonstrate an in-depth knowledge of human ecology with specific emphasis on the
ecological, demographic, genetic, developmental, and epidemiological dimensions of
modern human adaptations and their evolutionary foundations over time and space.
3. Apply scientific research methodology and design, including the ability to collect,
synthesize, and interpret qualitative and quantitative cultural and ecological data using a
variety of methods including the utilization of geospatial technologies (GIS, remote
sensing, and GPS).
4. Critically analyze issues from multiple perspectives and communicate results effectively.
Diversity Learning Objectives Met:
1. Understand the history of issues related to diversity, social and economic inequities, and
political power in the United States and across the world
2. Analyze the current social, political, artistic, and/or economic lives of historically
marginalized people in the United States and across the world.
3. Analyze the various institutions and structures that create and maintain social, economic,
and political inequality in the United States and across the world; and, identify those that
offer redress for these issues.
4. Define and describe the various issues related to diversity, equity, and inclusion in their
respective disciplines.
5. Critically examine their own personal beliefs, attitudes, and biases about historically
marginalized people and cultures in the United States and across the world.
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:48:15 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/127605848/Cal-Poly-Biological-Anthropology-Syllabus-Winter-2021pdf/
University Learning Objectives Met:
1. Think critically and creatively
2. Communicate effectively
3. Demonstrate expertise in a scholarly discipline and understand that discipline in relation
to the larger world of the arts, sciences and technology
4. Work productively as individuals and in groups
5. Use their knowledge and skills to make a positive contribution to society
6. Make reasoned decisions based on an understanding of ethics, a respect for diversity, and
an awareness of issues related to sustainability
7. And engage in lifelong learning
Required Text: Essentials of Physical Anthropology 4th edition by Clark Spencer Larsen.
Additional readings will be distributed electronically.
Classroom Policies: First and foremost, students will respect their instructor and each other. We
are here to learn from each other and in order for us to be most successful in this endeavor we
must feel comfortable in our environment to share and ask questions. Any words or actions that
threaten a comfortable environment will result in removal from the classroom, potentially from
the course if the behavior continues.
Email Policy: As your professor, it is reasonable to expect an email response from me within
24-48 hours of your email and I will try my very best to adhere to this. In terms of assignments,
my rule is as follows. Because this is a virtual course, all assignments will also be turned in
digitally. Technology is notoriously unreliable and therefore, I recommend that you do not wait
until right before the assignment is due to turn it in. Should you have problems turning anything
in, please email me right away so we can sort it out.
Academic Integrity: Students are required to maintain academic integrity throughout this
course. All work must be your own. Consequences for cheating, plagiarism, or facilitation in
another student’s academic misconduct will be a failing grade on that assignment or test. Further
consequences are at the discretion of the instructor and will be based on the severity of the
incident. NO AMOUNT of academic misconduct is acceptable. Be aware of how to cite the work
of others to avoid accidentally committing plagiarism. See the instructor if you have questions on
how to cite or if you need to. Rule of thumb- if you are unsure if you should or not, cite! For
further information https://osrr.calpoly.edu/academic-integrity.
Missed Exam Policy: Make-up exams will only be allowed with a valid excused absence and
must be completed within 1 week of the scheduled date unless prior arrangements are made with
the instructor. It is up to the student to contact the instructor THE DAY OF THE EXAM if an
exam is missed and to arrange a make-up within 1 week of the test date.
Late Assignment Policy: Missed assignments/exams are not accepted late without penalty,
unless the student contacts the instructor about the absence and requests a make-up, given a
sufficient reason for missing class.
