CAMPUS RESOURCES
Here are a few campus resources if you should have need of them:
• Campus Counseling Services: Cal Poly Counseling Services promotes the development of
holistic student emotional health. As mental health professionals, we serve the campus
community through advocacy and the provision of confidential, accessible services. Ph:
805-756-1211 Location: 27-135 Website: http://hcs.calpoly.edu/counseling
• SAFER: Cal Poly’s confidential advocacy, education and support resource for addressing
sexual assault, sexual misconduct, dating violence, domestic violence, and stalking. Ph:
756-2282 Location: UU217 Email: safer@calpoly.edu Website:
http://deanofstudents.calpoly.edu/content/safer/index. *As an employee of our university
I am a mandated reporter for sexual assaults.
• Undocumented Students Working Group: The Undocumented Student Working Group at
Cal Poly San Luis Obispo is comprised of faculty, staff, and administrators dedicated to
supporting the personal and professional development of undocumented students and
creating institutional change. Ph: 756-2418 Location: 25-121 Email:
undocu@calpoly.edu Website: http://undocu.calpoly.edu
• Cross-Cultural Centers UU-217
o Multicultural Center: The MultiCultural Center (MCC) supports and advocates
for underrepresented students by honoring cultural expression, building
community, and creating cross- cultural connections. The MCC provides a
welcoming space for the Cal Poly community to promote diversity and work
towards social justice. The MCC provides a safe space for studying, cultural
expression, identity exploration, finding resources, and meeting new people. Ph:
756.1405 Location: UU217 Email: mcc@calpoly.edu Website:
http://deanofstudents.calpoly.edu/content/multicultural/index
o Pride Center: The Pride Center supports and advocates for the unique academic
and social needs of lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans, queer or questioning, intersex,
asexual, and pansexual (LGBTQIAP) students to promote personal growth and
success. We empower and retain LGBTQIAP and allied communities on campus
by cultivating a culture of care and providing a welcoming and inclusive spaces
for all members of campus to explore issues related to sexual and gender identity.
Ph: 805- 756-7733 Location: UU209 Email: pride@calpoly.edu Website:
http://deanofstudents.calpoly.edu/content/pride/index  
o Gender Equity Center: The Gender Equity Center (GEC) supports and empowers
all women identifying students by creating a strong community, educating about
feminist, womanist, and mujerista based movements, exploring identities through
an intersectional lens, and striving for social justice. Ph: 756-2600 Email:
genderequitycenter@calpoly.edu Website:
http://deanofstudents.calpoly.edu/content/genderequitycenter/index
• Veterans’ Success Center: California Polytechnic State University Veterans Success Center
provides multi-faceted assistance to prospective and enrolled student veterans and dependents.
Most notably, the center assists students in accessing their GI benefits, completing the admission
application process, and registering for courses. The center also helps students’ access campus
resources, get involved in leadership activities, and transition into the civilian work world. Ph:
756-6838 Location: 52-E4. Email: veteranscenter@calpoly.edu

culture for all in its classrooms, work environments, and at campus events. For more information

Grading/Evaluation: Students will be evaluated through 3 examinations, 1 worksheet, and 1
writing assignment. The numerical breakdown for the point value is listed below. Students are
also presented with extra credit opportunities that they may complete throughout the course of
the quarter. Any extra credit points will be added to the total at the end of the quarter. Extra
credit assignments must be sufficiently completed in order to receive credit. See extra credit
section below for details on assignments.
Exam 1: Consists of everything from Week 1 through Week 4. Does NOT include primates. The
test will be available on Canvas from 9:00am-5:00pm on Monday Feb 6. It is TIMED, which
means that once you start it, it MUST be completed within 60 minutes. The test will kick you
out after 60 minutes.
Exam 2: Consists of the material on primates ONLY. The test will be available on Canvas from
9:00am-5:00pm on Monday Mar 1. It is TIMED, which means that once you start it, it MUST
be completed within 60 minutes. The test will kick you out after 60 minutes.
Exam 3: This is your final. Consists of all material after primates. You must take it on Monday
Mar 15 between 9:00am-5:00pm. If this conflicts with your synchronous classes, please let me
know ASAP. It is TIMED, which means that once you start it, it MUST be completed within 60
minutes. The test will kick you out after 60 minutes.

Late Assignment Policy: Assignments submitted past the due date and time will be subject to

1 day: 10%
2 days: 20%
Beyond 48 hours: NO CREDIT
Extra Credit Assignments: Point values listed represent the maximum amount that can be

ANTH 250: Biological Anthropology Winter 2021

Office Hours: Monday and Wednesday 9:00-11:00am Pacific Time via Zoom
Course Description: This course is an introduction to biological anthropology, the subfield of
anthropology that focuses on human evolutionary history, behavior, and variation. We will cover
the theory of evolution, primate and human evolution, primate behavior, and modern human
variation. By the end of the course, students will have an understanding of what it means to be
human.
ANTH 250 Learning Objectives:
1. Understand biological evolution and the processes by which it occurs.
2. Be able to identify what human ancestors looked like, how they acted, and the
evolutionary relationships between them.
3. Understand modern human variation and investigate the causal forces behind this
variation.
4. Gain familiarity with the biology, ecology, and behavior of the various kinds of
nonhuman primates.
Anthropology Program Learning Objectives Met:
1. Understand and appreciate the cultural and physical attributes of major world regions,
key regional issues and linkages between regions, the processes that shape cultural
change and interaction, and international development issues.
2. Demonstrate an in-depth knowledge of human ecology with specific emphasis on the
ecological, demographic, genetic, developmental, and epidemiological dimensions of
modern human adaptations and their evolutionary foundations over time and space.
3. Apply scientific research methodology and design, including the ability to collect,
synthesize, and interpret qualitative and quantitative cultural and ecological data using a
variety of methods including the utilization of geospatial technologies (GIS, remote
sensing, and GPS).
4. Critically analyze issues from multiple perspectives and communicate results effectively.
Diversity Learning Objectives Met:
1. Understand the history of issues related to diversity, social and economic inequities, and
political power in the United States and across the world
2. Analyze the current social, political, artistic, and/or economic lives of historically
marginalized people in the United States and across the world.
3. Analyze the various institutions and structures that create and maintain social, economic,
and political inequality in the United States and across the world; and, identify those that
offer redress for these issues.
4. Define and describe the various issues related to diversity, equity, and inclusion in their
respective disciplines.
5. Critically examine their own personal beliefs, attitudes, and biases about historically
marginalized people and cultures in the United States and across the world.


University Learning Objectives Met:
1. Think critically and creatively
2. Communicate effectively
3. Demonstrate expertise in a scholarly discipline and understand that discipline in relation
to the larger world of the arts, sciences and technology
4. Work productively as individuals and in groups
5. Use their knowledge and skills to make a positive contribution to society
6. Make reasoned decisions based on an understanding of ethics, a respect for diversity, and
an awareness of issues related to sustainability
7. And engage in lifelong learning
Required Text: Essentials of Physical Anthropology Additional readings will be distributed electronically.
Classroom Policies: First and foremost, students will respect their instructor and each other. We
are here to learn from each other and in order for us to be most successful in this endeavor we
must feel comfortable in our environment to share and ask questions. Any words or actions that
threaten a comfortable environment will result in removal from the classroom, potentially from
the course if the behavior continues.
Email Policy: As your professor, it is reasonable to expect an email response from me within
24-48 hours of your email and I will try my very best to adhere to this. In terms of assignments,
my rule is as follows. Because this is a virtual course, all assignments will also be turned in
digitally. Technology is notoriously unreliable and therefore, I recommend that you do not wait
until right before the assignment is due to turn it in. Should you have problems turning anything
in, please email me right away so we can sort it out.
Academic Integrity: Students are required to maintain academic integrity throughout this
course. All work must be your own. Consequences for cheating, plagiarism, or facilitation in
another student’s academic misconduct will be a failing grade on that assignment or test. Further
consequences are at the discretion of the instructor and will be based on the severity of the
incident. NO AMOUNT of academic misconduct is acceptable. Be aware of how to cite the work
of others to avoid accidentally committing plagiarism. See the instructor if you have questions on
how to cite or if you need to. Rule of thumb- if you are unsure if you should or not, cite! For
further information https://osrr.calpoly.edu/academic-integrity.
Missed Exam Policy: Make-up exams will only be allowed with a valid excused absence and
must be completed within 1 week of the scheduled date unless prior arrangements are made with
the instructor. It is up to the student to contact the instructor THE DAY OF THE EXAM if an
exam is missed and to arrange a make-up within 1 week of the test date.
Late Assignment Policy: Missed assignments/exams are not accepted late without penalty,
unless the student contacts the instructor about the absence and requests a make-up, given a
sufficient reason for missing class.


CAMPUS RESOURCES
Here are a few campus resources if you should have need of them:
• Campus Counseling Services: Cal Poly Counseling Services promotes the development of
holistic student emotional health. As mental health professionals, we serve the campus
community through advocacy and the provision of confidential, accessible services. Ph:
805-756-1211 Location: 27-135 Website: http://hcs.calpoly.edu/counseling
• SAFER: Cal Poly’s confidential advocacy, education and support resource for addressing
sexual assault, sexual misconduct, dating violence, domestic violence, and stalking. Ph:
756-2282 Location: UU217 Email: Website:
http://deanofstudents.calpoly.edu/content/safer/index. *As an employee of our university
I am a mandated reporter for sexual assaults.
• Undocumented Students Working Group: The Undocumented Student Working Group at
Cal Poly San Luis Obispo is comprised of faculty, staff, and administrators dedicated to
supporting the personal and professional development of undocumented students and
creating institutional change. Ph: 756-2418 Location: 25-121 Email:
• Cross-Cultural Centers UU-217
o Multicultural Center: The MultiCultural Center (MCC) supports and advocates
for underrepresented students by honoring cultural expression, building
community, and creating cross- cultural connections. The MCC provides a
welcoming space for the Cal Poly community to promote diversity and work
towards social justice. The MCC provides a safe space for studying, cultural
expression, identity exploration, finding resources, and meeting new people. Ph:
756.1405 Location: UU217 Email: o Pride Center: The Pride Center supports and advocates for the unique academic
and social needs of lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans, queer or questioning, intersex,
asexual, and pansexual (LGBTQIAP) students to promote personal growth and
success. We empower and retain LGBTQIAP and allied communities on campus
by cultivating a culture of care and providing a welcoming and inclusive spaces
for all members of campus to explore issues related to sexual and gender identity.
Ph: 805- 756-7733 Location: UU209 Email:o Gender Equity Center: The Gender Equity Center (GEC) supports and empowers
all women identifying students by creating a strong community, educating about
feminist, womanist, and mujerista based movements, exploring identities through
an intersectional lens, and striving for social justice. • Veterans’ Success Center: California Polytechnic State University Veterans Success Center
provides multi-faceted assistance to prospective and enrolled student veterans and dependents.
Most notably, the center assists students in accessing their GI benefits, completing the admission
application process, and registering for courses. The center also helps students’ access campus
resources, get involved in leadership activities, and transition into the civilian work world. Ph:
756-6838 Location: 52-E4.

culture for all in its classrooms, work environments, and at campus events. For more information

CALIFORNIA STATE POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY, POMONA
Psychology and Sociology Department
MEMORY AND AMNESIA/PSY 335
Course Syllabus
Fall 2017
CLASS MEETING INFO: INSTRUCTOR INFO:
Days: MWF Name: Valerie F Marino, PhD
 Time: 11:45am-12:50pm Email: vfmarino@cpp.edu
Place: 5-107 Office: 5-228 Cubicle B
Number: 74205, Section 1 Office Hours: M/W 10:45-11:30am
 T/Th 2:15-2:45pm
 Fri 9:30-11:30am
Catalog Description:
A survey of topics in the psychology of memory, including current theories of memory and forgetting, the
neurobiology of memory, memory models, metamemory, memory development across the lifespan,
organic and functional memory disorders, and applied issues such as eyewitness legal testimony,
children’s memory abilities, effects of drugs and alcohol on memory, and the repressed memory debate.
Prerequisites: PSY 202, PSY 210.
Required Texts:
Baddeley, A.D., Eysenck, M. W., & Anderson, M. C. (2014). Memory (2nd ed.). New York, NY, US:
Psychology Press. ISBN: 978-1848721845.
Schacter, D. L. (2001). The Seven sins of memory: How the mind forgets and remembers. New York:
Houghton Mifflin.
Student Learning Outcomes:
At the end of the course, all students should be able to:
1. Describe the interaction between memory and other cognitive processes including: attention,
concept formation, language, and learning.
2. Differentiate among the different types of memory.
3. Understand the research paradigms used to study memory.
4. Understand the changes in memory and metamemory occurring across the lifespan regarding
both normal and abnormal aging.
5. Describe the symptoms of amnesia and understand the distinction between organic and
functional memory disorders.
6. Understand the importance of memory to social issues, such as formation of identity,
accuracy of eyewitness testimony, recall of emotionally charged experiences (flashbulb
memory, repressed memory).

CLASS REQUIREMENTS:
You must complete each assignment and test on time. If you hand in an assignment late, the instructor
reserves the right to not accept the work unless you provide a documented medical excuse (or equivalent).
If late work is accepted, it will be penalized (5% each business day late).
Class Participation: During the quarter, you will be asked to complete unannounced assignments designed to
assess your understanding of course content. At the end of the quarter, you must earn 20 points of credit on
these assignments to receive full credit for class participation. You may be able to earn more than 20 points
and, therefore, will receive extra credit towards your final grade. This is the only extra credit available in the
course.
Exams: There will be a Midterm and a Final Exam based on the concepts from the course. These concepts
can come from the readings, lectures, discussions, assignments, and class activities. The tests will include
multiple choice, short answer, and essay questions. Students are responsible for bringing pencils and 100Q
Zipgrade forms to both exams. If there is cumulative material between the midterm and the final, the
instructor will make it clear what material is going to be cumulative.
Seven Sins of Memory Group Presentation: Students will be randomly assigned to a group of 6 or 7 and
assigned a chapter in the Seven Sins of Memory book. Each group will do an hour-long
presentation/discussion facilitation on their chapter. This should include a reading quiz the group should
give to the class. The group will score these quizzes and return the results to the course instructor by the
following class meeting. Finally, each group member will turn in a self-evaluation regarding what they
contributed to the presentation as well as an evaluation of each group member. Finally, each group needs
to read chapter 8 and include in their presentation how their group’s “sin” might be a virtue.
Seven Sins Quiz Scores: The five best quiz scores (each worth 10 pts) from the Seven Sins of Memory
reading quizzes will be counted toward your grade.
 GRADE CALCULATION:
Learning Assessments:
Assessment Points
Midterm 50 pts
Final Exam 50 pts
Seven Sins of Memory Group Presentation 50 pts
Seven Sins Quiz Scores 50 pts
Class participation 20 pts

You take your total points earned and divide the number by the class total possible. Note: All points will be
rounded to the closest whole point value when determining your final grade ( .5 rounded up; < .4 rounded
down). In percentages your letter grade would be assigned approximately as follows:
A = 93.34-100.0% B = 83.34-86.66% C = 73.34-76.66% D = 63.34-66.66%
A- = 90.00-93.33% B- = 80.00-83.33% C- = 70.00-73.33% D- = 60.00-63.33%
B+ = 86.67-89.99% C+ = 76.67-79.99% D+ = 66.67-69.99% F = 59.99% or below

Class POLICIES:
1) Electronics in the Classroom… Turn off your electronic devices! It is very disruptive if phones or hand-held
devices go off in class, so please show respect to your classmates and instructor and turn them off before
coming in to class. Additionally, laptop computers may ONLY be used in class as a note-taking strategy. Do not
use them for any other reason during class. If you use electronic devices for non-class related purposes, you
may be excused from class and have your grade reduced.
2) Drop Policy… It’s YOUR responsibility! Please be aware that the only time I will drop you is if you fail to
show up for the first week’s class sessions without notification (in which case you are probably not reading
this). I may drop you for excessive absences, but ultimately it is YOUR responsibility to drop the class. Do not
assume that I will drop you… ever. It is your responsibility.
IMPORTANT DATES
September 21 Classes Begin
September 27 Last day to drop classes without receiving a "W"
October 11 Last day to drop without petition
October 12 First day to withdraw by petition for serious and compelling reason
October 20 Last day to apply online for Fall 2017 graduation
November 10 Holiday - Campus Closed
November 23 - November 24 Holiday - Campus Closed
December 4 - December 8 Final Examinations
3) Class Conduct… Participate in class! Ask questions! (And always respect others). I never mind answering your
questions, and helping you to understand psychology is my JOB (and my pleasure!) –Please feel free to
contribute to the conversations! However, students are responsible for regulating their own conduct and for
respecting the rights and privileges of others.
4) Academic HONESTY…Cheating and other forms of dishonest behavior are destructive to the educational
process for all students, and will not be tolerated in this class. As a result, the following guidelines shall be
followed:
A. Students may not submit work that is not totally their own, and if you are not sure how to
recognize or define plagiarism, please go to the following helpful link to avoid plagiarism
www.plagiarism.org
B. Exams must be taken individually with no assistance of any kind.
If you do not comply with these testing conditions, please drop this class immediately.
Academic dishonesty may result in an “F” on all or part of an assignment and referral to the Dean.
5) Reasonable accommodations are available for those with a documented disability. Please notify me by the end
of the second week of class if you require accommodations. Late notification may delay any accommodations.
All accommodations must be approved by Disabled Student Services (869-3333).
6) Class attendance is strongly recommended because exams will cover material from class meetings and from the
text. Furthermore, you are responsible for all material presented in class, including any changes in the class
schedule (including exam dates). Absenteeism is detrimental to exam performance. I won’t provide handouts
missed because of unexcused absences; your best source of information is a fellow student's notes. Being
absent and borrowing notes is not the equivalent of attending class yourself. Please ask permission to bring
guests to class. Arriving late to class or leaving early is fine as long as it is done quietly and without disturbing
others.
7) Difficulty with the English language. You should have a good working knowledge of English to take this class.
However, if English is not your native language and you want to use a translation dictionary during the exam, or
if English is your native language and you need a dictionary, notify me by the end of the second week of class.

8) Academic Difficulty. If you study the text, take notes in class, work through the assignments, and still feel that
you do not understand the material, or if your exam performance is not up to your expectations, please let me
know. I will try to help you, and I may be able to suggest ways to improve your retention of the material in this
course. Some suggestions will also be offered in class, but I may be able to offer some advice unique to your
situation.
9) COME SEE ME IF YOU ARE HAVING ANY PROBLEMS!
 Don’t wait too long to come speak with me, email me, or discuss any difficulty. I am here to help!
Executive Order 1083:
Please note that there are two executive orders from the CSU’s Office of the Chancellor that limit what information
faculty members are able to keep confidential. These are Executive Order 1096 (which relates to reporting of
campus sexual assaults) and Executive Order 1083 (which relates to mandatory reporting of child abuse). What this
means is that CSU faculty members are what is called “mandatory reporters,” which means that once we are
apprised of such incidents, we are required to report the incident to our Title IX officer on campus, regardless if the
student wants this information reported or not.
Campus RESOURCES:
There are a wide variety of services that you are entitled to as tuition-paying students at Cal Poly Pomona. Some of
them may be important to you as they relate to this course.
Academic and Psychological Counseling:
https://www.cpp.edu/~healthcounseling/counseling/index.shtml
Counseling services at CPP exist to help students with their academic, career, and personal concerns. The counseling
faculty helps students clarify their needs, make decisions, set goals, and deal effectively with personal obstacles. The
relationship between student and counselor is confidential. They offer academic planning, career exploration, and
personal counseling.
Health and Wellness Center:
https://www.cpp.edu/~healthcounseling/health/index.shtml Health and Wellness Center offers free medical services
to any student who has paid their health fee and is currently attending classes. These include psychological services,
which are provided by counseling interns under the supervision of a licensed psychologist. Services provided
include addressing the following issues: Stress, Anxiety, Depression, Family issues, Difficulty adjusting to school
environment, Drug or alcohol abuse, Difficulty focusing, Grief, Relationship issues, and Acculturation issues. Again,
these services are FREE!
Learning Resource Center:
https://www.cpp.edu/~lrc/ foundational practices that support student academic achievement.
Accommodations for Disabilities:
https://www.cpp.edu/~drc/index.shtml Students with disabilities who want to request academic accommodations are
responsible for informing their instructors and Disability Resource Center as early in the quarter as possible, or at
least two weeks before the accommodation is needed.
Library Hours of Operation:
Mon-Thurs 7:30am-11:30pm
Friday 7:30am-5:00pm
Saturday 10:00am-7:00pm
Sun 12 noon-9:00pm
Campus Police: (909) 869-3070 Please call them for any emergency that you might encounter on campus. In
addition, Campus Police Officers will provide assistance in starting vehicles with dead batteries and help on-campus
motorists in obtaining lockout or other assistance. Further, they offer escort services 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

CALIFORNIA STATE POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY, POMONA
Psychology and Sociology Department
MEMORY AND AMNESIA/PSY 335
Course Syllabus
Fall 2017

Catalog Description:
A survey of topics in the psychology of memory, including current theories of memory and forgetting, the
neurobiology of memory, memory models, metamemory, memory development across the lifespan,
organic and functional memory disorders, and applied issues such as eyewitness legal testimony,
children’s memory abilities, effects of drugs and alcohol on memory, and the repressed memory debate.
Prerequisites: PSY 202, PSY 210.
Required Texts:
Baddeley, A.D., Eysenck, M. W., & Anderson, M. C. (2014). Memory (2nd ed.). New York, NY, US:
Psychology Press. ISBN: 978-1848721845.
Schacter, D. L. (2001). The Seven sins of memory: How the mind forgets and remembers. New York:
Houghton Mifflin.
Student Learning Outcomes:
At the end of the course, all students should be able to:
1. Describe the interaction between memory and other cognitive processes including: attention,
concept formation, language, and learning.
2. Differentiate among the different types of memory.
3. Understand the research paradigms used to study memory.
4. Understand the changes in memory and metamemory occurring across the lifespan regarding
both normal and abnormal aging.
5. Describe the symptoms of amnesia and understand the distinction between organic and
functional memory disorders.
6. Understand the importance of memory to social issues, such as formation of identity,
accuracy of eyewitness testimony, recall of emotionally charged experiences (flashbulb
memory, repressed memory).

CLASS REQUIREMENTS:
You must complete each assignment and test on time. If you hand in an assignment late, the instructor
reserves the right to not accept the work unless you provide a documented medical excuse (or equivalent).
If late work is accepted, it will be penalized (5% each business day late).
Class Participation: During the quarter, you will be asked to complete unannounced assignments designed to
assess your understanding of course content. At the end of the quarter, you must earn 20 points of credit on
these assignments to receive full credit for class participation. You may be able to earn more than 20 points
and, therefore, will receive extra credit towards your final grade. This is the only extra credit available in the
course.
Exams: There will be a Midterm and a Final Exam based on the concepts from the course. These concepts
can come from the readings, lectures, discussions, assignments, and class activities. The tests will include
multiple choice, short answer, and essay questions. Students are responsible for bringing pencils and 100Q
Zipgrade forms to both exams. If there is cumulative material between the midterm and the final, the
instructor will make it clear what material is going to be cumulative.
Seven Sins of Memory Group Presentation: Students will be randomly assigned to a group of 6 or 7 and
assigned a chapter in the Seven Sins of Memory book. Each group will do an hour-long
presentation/discussion facilitation on their chapter. This should include a reading quiz the group should
give to the class. The group will score these quizzes and return the results to the course instructor by the
following class meeting. Finally, each group member will turn in a self-evaluation regarding what they
contributed to the presentation as well as an evaluation of each group member. Finally, each group needs
to read chapter 8 and include in their presentation how their group’s “sin” might be a virtue.
Seven Sins Quiz Scores: The five best quiz scores (each worth 10 pts) from the Seven Sins of Memory
reading quizzes will be counted toward your grade.
 GRADE CALCULATION:
Learning Assessments:
Assessment Points
Midterm 50 pts
Final Exam 50 pts
Seven Sins of Memory Group Presentation 50 pts
Seven Sins Quiz Scores 50 pts
Class participation 20 pts

You take your total points earned and divide the number by the class total possible. Note: All points will be
rounded to the closest whole point value when determining your final grade ( .5 rounded up; < .4 rounded
down). In percentages your letter grade would be assigned approximately as follows:
A = 93.34-100.0% B = 83.34-86.66% C = 73.34-76.66% D = 63.34-66.66%
A- = 90.00-93.33% B- = 80.00-83.33% C- = 70.00-73.33% D- = 60.00-63.33%
B+ = 86.67-89.99% C+ = 76.67-79.99% D+ = 66.67-69.99% F = 59.99% or below

Class POLICIES:
1) Electronics in the Classroom… Turn off your electronic devices! It is very disruptive if phones or hand-held
devices go off in class, so please show respect to your classmates and instructor and turn them off before
coming in to class. Additionally, laptop computers may ONLY be used in class as a note-taking strategy. Do not
use them for any other reason during class. If you use electronic devices for non-class related purposes, you
may be excused from class and have your grade reduced.
2) Drop Policy… It’s YOUR responsibility! Please be aware that the only time I will drop you is if you fail to
show up for the first week’s class sessions without notification (in which case you are probably not reading
this). I may drop you for excessive absences, but ultimately it is YOUR responsibility to drop the class. Do not
assume that I will drop you… ever. It is your responsibility.
IMPORTANT DATES
September 21 Classes Begin
September 27 Last day to drop classes without receiving a "W"
October 11 Last day to drop without petition
October 12 First day to withdraw by petition for serious and compelling reason
October 20 Last day to apply online for Fall 2017 graduation
November 10 Holiday - Campus Closed
November 23 - November 24 Holiday - Campus Closed
December 4 - December 8 Final Examinations
3) Class Conduct… Participate in class! Ask questions! (And always respect others). I never mind answering your
questions, and helping you to understand psychology is my JOB (and my pleasure!) –Please feel free to
contribute to the conversations! However, students are responsible for regulating their own conduct and for
respecting the rights and privileges of others.
4) Academic HONESTY…Cheating and other forms of dishonest behavior are destructive to the educational
process for all students, and will not be tolerated in this class. As a result, the following guidelines shall be
followed:
A. Students may not submit work that is not totally their own, and if you are not sure how to
recognize or define plagiarism, please go to the following helpful link to avoid plagiarism
www.plagiarism.org
B. Exams must be taken individually with no assistance of any kind.
If you do not comply with these testing conditions, please drop this class immediately.
Academic dishonesty may result in an “F” on all or part of an assignment and referral to the Dean.
5) Reasonable accommodations are available for those with a documented disability. Please notify me by the end
of the second week of class if you require accommodations. Late notification may delay any accommodations.
All accommodations must be approved by Disabled Student Services (869-3333).
6) Class attendance is strongly recommended because exams will cover material from class meetings and from the
text. Furthermore, you are responsible for all material presented in class, including any changes in the class
schedule (including exam dates). Absenteeism is detrimental to exam performance. I won’t provide handouts
missed because of unexcused absences; your best source of information is a fellow student's notes. Being
absent and borrowing notes is not the equivalent of attending class yourself. Please ask permission to bring
guests to class. Arriving late to class or leaving early is fine as long as it is done quietly and without disturbing
others.
7) Difficulty with the English language. You should have a good working knowledge of English to take this class.
However, if English is not your native language and you want to use a translation dictionary during the exam, or
if English is your native language and you need a dictionary, notify me by the end of the second week of class.

https://www.coursehero.com/file/27719994/PSY335-Syllabus-Fall-20171docx/
8) Academic Difficulty. If you study the text, take notes in class, work through the assignments, and still feel that
you do not understand the material, or if your exam performance is not up to your expectations, please let me
know. I will try to help you, and I may be able to suggest ways to improve your retention of the material in this
course. Some suggestions will also be offered in class, but I may be able to offer some advice unique to your
situation.
9) COME SEE ME IF YOU ARE HAVING ANY PROBLEMS!
 Don’t wait too long to come speak with me, email me, or discuss any difficulty. I am here to help!
Executive Order 1083:
Please note that there are two executive orders from the CSU’s Office of the Chancellor that limit what information
faculty members are able to keep confidential. These are Executive Order 1096 (which relates to reporting of
campus sexual assaults) and Executive Order 1083 (which relates to mandatory reporting of child abuse). What this
means is that CSU faculty members are what is called “mandatory reporters,” which means that once we are
apprised of such incidents, we are required to report the incident to our Title IX officer on campus, regardless if the
student wants this information reported or not.
Campus RESOURCES:
There are a wide variety of services that you are entitled to as tuition-paying students at Cal Poly Pomona. Some of
them may be important to you as they relate to this course.
Academic and Psychological Counseling:
https://www.cpp.edu/~healthcounseling/counseling/index.shtml
Counseling services at CPP exist to help students with their academic, career, and personal concerns. The counseling
faculty helps students clarify their needs, make decisions, set goals, and deal effectively with personal obstacles. The
relationship between student and counselor is confidential. They offer academic planning, career exploration, and
personal counseling.
Health and Wellness Center:
https://www.cpp.edu/~healthcounseling/health/index.shtml Health and Wellness Center offers free medical services
to any student who has paid their health fee and is currently attending classes. These include psychological services,
which are provided by counseling interns under the supervision of a licensed psychologist. Services provided
include addressing the following issues: Stress, Anxiety, Depression, Family issues, Difficulty adjusting to school
environment, Drug or alcohol abuse, Difficulty focusing, Grief, Relationship issues, and Acculturation issues. Again,
these services are FREE!
Learning Resource Center:
https://www.cpp.edu/~lrc/ foundational practices that support student academic achievement.
Accommodations for Disabilities:
https://www.cpp.edu/~drc/index.shtml Students with disabilities who want to request academic accommodations are
responsible for informing their instructors and Disability Resource Center as early in the quarter as possible, or at
least two weeks before the accommodation is needed.
Library Hours of Operation:
Mon-Thurs 7:30am-11:30pm
Friday 7:30am-5:00pm
Saturday 10:00am-7:00pm
Sun 12 noon-9:00pm
Campus Police: (909) 869-3070 Please call them for any emergency that you might encounter on campus. In
addition, Campus Police Officers will provide assistance in starting vehicles with dead batteries and help on-campus
motorists in obtaining lockout or other assistance. Further, they offer escort services 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

English 231-03 syllabus
English 231: British literature 1800-present David Hennessee
Winter 2009 Office: 47-22-H, 756-6136
Section 03: TTH 4:10-6, 22-312 dhenness@calpoly.edu
Office hours: MTWF 1-2. Also available by email, phone, and appointment
Texts
Jane Austen, Pride and Prejudice
Goethe, The Sorrows of Young Werther
James Joyce, Dubliners
Jeanette Winterson, Oranges are not the only fruit
Helen Fielding, Bridget Jones’s Diary
Course description
"And they lived happily ever after." "They" more likely than not got married. As a device of narrative
closure, marriage is ubiquitous, and to sustain interest until the happy event occurs, literary texts often
describe obstacles to nuptial bliss. In this course, we will examine love and the marriage plot under
stress. We will read (and view) texts that question and probe the nature of love, and that complicate,
evade or even thwart the marriage plot.
In doing so, we will have three goals:
1.) to understand the socio-historical conditioning of (what might seem) timeless, natural dynamics of
love, sex, heterosexuality, and marriage;
2.) to examine how different literary forms shape ideas of love and the marriage;
3.) to use the marriage plot as a window through which to view cultural changes in British society and
formal changes in British literature, 1800-present.
More generally, the course offers a survey of some important texts in British literature of the last 200
years, whose often bizarre plots will hopefully prove enjoyable. Some lecture on historical context, a
few in-class screenings of film adaptations, more discussion.
Course requirements
1.Take-home Midterm (100 points): directed topics on Austen or Goethe. 4-5 pp. essay. Due week 5.
2. Take-home Final (100 points): directed topics on texts from weeks 5-10. 4-5 pp. essay. Due during
finals week.
3. Quizzes (100 points). Nine quizzes. Factual in nature, true/false, multiple choice, short answer and
short essay. Will cover the readings for the current week and lectures and discussions of the previous
week. No make-up quizzes given, except on cases of medical and family emergencies.
4. Participation (30 points). Attendance, contributions to class discussions and activities, various
informal writings (study questions, freewrites, etc.). 3 excused absences. One point deducted for each
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:48:59 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/1317312/Syllabus/
additional absence. Positive class participation includes doing the reading, contributing regularly and
thoughtfully to class discussions, participating actively in small group work, and asking informed
questions. Negative participation includes lack of preparation, inattention, sleeping, reading the paper,
working on other course assignments, leaving early, text messaging, and disrespecting other members
of the class.
Policies
-- Please bring your copy of current readings to class.
-- Late essays will be penalized 5 points per day late.
--Plagiarism is a serious breach of academic ethics and will not be tolerated. Suspected cases will be
reported to university authorities and may result in failing the assignment or the class.
-- Please do not send essays or other written work over email. Only hardcopies will be accepted,
except in emergency cases.
-- I will not download essay drafts. I will comment on introductions and thesis statements, if sent in
the text of an email. If you would like advice on a midterm or final draft, come to office hours.
-- If you have a disability for which you are or may be requesting an accommodation, you are
encouraged to contact both the instructor and the Disability Resource Center, Building 124, Room
119, (805) 756-1395, as early as possible.
--Directions to 47/34G. Building 47 is on North Perimeter Road. It has three sections. Find section 3,
the one closest to the “P” on the hill. As you face the building, the “P” will be on your left, and a big
“3” on your right. Go to the “3.” You will pass the CLA dean’s office. Find room 32, the English
department office. Across from 32 is a stairway leading down. Go down this stairway to 22-H.
-- Please turn off cell phones during class.
-- Grading scale:
a. A 306-330
b. A- 297-305
c. B+ 287-296
d. B 273-286
e. B- 264-272
f. C+ 254-263
g. C 240-253
h. C- 231-239
i. D+ 221-230
C1 - C3: Lower-Division Educational Objectives
EO 1 understand the possibilities and limitations of language as a symbolic and expressive medium;
differentiate between formal and metaphorical language;

https://www.coursehero.com/file/1317312/Syllabus/
EO 2 read with insight, engagement, detachment, and discrimination; sustain an extended line of
reasoning through both narrative and thematic development;
EO 3 recognize crucial historical developments within the arts and humanities; appreciate the significance
of major literary, philosophic, and artistic works;
EO 4 understand the historical development of issues in the humanities in significant periods prior to and
including the twentieth century; understand the ways that historical context can illuminate current
problems and concerns;
EO 5 grasp relevant aspects of the relationship of the arts and humanities to science and technology;
EO appreciate non-verbal forms of understanding and expression; appreciate the aesthetic and historical
development of one or more of the visual or performing arts; understand the relationship between form
and content;
EO 7 understand currently accepted critical standards; understand the advantages and limitations of
various schools of reasoning;
EO 8 appreciate the relative cultural significance of canonical and non-canonical works of literature,
philosophy, and the arts.

Text:
Department of Political Science
California Polytechnic University, San Luis Obispo
1
POLITICAL SCIENCE 112
AMERICAN GOVERNMENT
Winter 2014
SYLLABUS
COURSE INFORMATION
Introduction & Description:
We will explore the United States political system, which will be broadly defined as
including the formal institutions of government as well as the ancillary and informal
avenues of power and influence used to shape political outcomes. By the end of the course
you should have available to you the tools necessary to practically evaluate the political
information you receive from media sources, political leaders, friends, and family alike.
Hopefully you will improve your writing and your ability to apply Political Science to
practical problems more generally. As most of my career has been spent working in
government, it is my hope that we can approach this academic subject with the objective of
making it practical and helpful in your future careers.
Days, Time & Location of Lectures
Days and Time: Mon & Wed 4:00 - 6:00 p.m. 6:00-8:00 p.m.
Location: Bldg. 180 Bldg. 33
Room 0101 Room 286
Instructor Contact:
Dr. Scott Englund
Email: senglund@calpoly.edu
Office: Bldg. 20, Room 133, Cube C
Hours: MW 3:00 – 4:00 p.m. & Thursday 8:00 – 10:00 a.m.
Course Materials:
Lowi, Theodore J., Benjamin Ginspbert, Kenneth A. Shepsle, and Stephen Ansolabehere.
2013. American Government: Power and Purpose, 13th Edition Core Edition. New
York: WW. Norton & Company Inc.
Canon, David T., John J. Coleman, and Kenneth R. Mayer. 2013. The Enduring Debate:
Classic and Contemporary Readings in American Politics, 7th Edition. New York:
W.W. Norton & Company Inc.
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:49:21 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/39832835/Syllabus-Pol-112-Winter-pdf/
2
Evaluation of Learning:
Two In-Class Multiple Choice Mid-Term Exams, 15% each
One Final Exam, 20 %
Bi-Weekly Team Projects, 30%
In-Class quizzes, 20%
Behavioral Expectations:
You should have read all material assigned prior to the week and day when it will be
discussed. You should come prepared to take notes, participate in discussion, and will be
required to treat your colleagues and instructors with respect. One should expect that as
sensitive issues may be raised, emotions might carry one away. At no time will abusive,
threatening or demeaning language be tolerated.
I will come to class prepared to lecture on the topics as scheduled, unless a change has
been made in advance. I will also prepare assignments on schedule, and make every effort
to ensure your work-product is evaluated in an unbiased and timely manner. I will hold
scheduled office hours and be available to meet by appointment; all discussions in office
hours will be confidential except where required by the university. I will respond to all email enquires within twenty-four hours of my receiving them.
Plagiarism:
Plagiarism is using other people’s work without giving them credit. This can include the
following: using a quote without citation, paraphrasing a quote without citation, presenting
the findings, conclusions, or theoretical elements of someone else without citation, using a
friend’s paper, in whole or in part, in your assignments, buying a paper, essay, et cetera,
from any source, and presenting it as your own, “cutting and pasting” from a Wikipedia
article or any other on-line source, copying another student’s work without their
knowledge, or providing your work to someone else with the intent of having that person
fraudulently presenting your work as his or her own. The University has extremely strict
penalties for plagiarism or “cheating,” to include suspension and permanent expulsion
without credit. To protect the legitimate efforts of its students, the Department of Political
Science takes every effort to detect plagiarism and punish those who plagiarize.
Student Resources & Students With Disabilities
Please advise me early on of any special accommodations you require and coordinate these
requests through the Disability Resource Center.
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:49:21 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/39832835/Syllabus-Pol-112-Winter-pdf/
3
The pace of a ten-week quarter can be stressful. All students have access to professional
counseling free of charge through Health and Counseling Services. You can find
information about their services at:
http://www.hcs.calpoly.edu/content/counseling/counseling-home
Or by calling 805-756-2511, or simply drop in at their offices in Building 27, Room 135,
near the Rec Center.
SCHEDULE OF TOPICS & ASSIGNMENTS:
Below is a schedule of topics with associated reading assignments. You should expect
additional reading to be assigned as the quarter progresses and current events present
opportunities to apply what we have been studying.
“AG” refers to the American Government: Power and Purpose text.
“ED” refers to the Enduring Debate: Classic and Contemporary Readings in American
Politics text.
You’ll find that mostly the chapters of AG and ED are parallel, but don’t make this
assumption. Each chapter in ED is divided into two big sections that contain more than
one article; you can assume that you should concentrate on the first section. The pace of a
ten-week quarter is relentless; it will be easy to fall behind on your reading assignments.
The chapter numbers listed below correspond to the most current edition of these texts.
Older texts are acceptable, please note that there will be a slight difference in the chapter
numbers (usually only off by one) in very recent previous editions.
Week 1: 6-10 January
6 January; Introduction & Course Overview
Pre-Test & Survey
AG: Ch. 1 & Appendix A13: The Constitution of the United States of
America
8 January; The Structure of Democracy in the U.S.
AG: Ch. 2; ED: Ch. 2

https://www.coursehero.com/file/39832835/Syllabus-Pol-112-Winter-pdf/
4
Week 2: 13-17 January
13 January; Federalism
AG: Ch. 3; ED: Ch 3
15 January; Civil Liberties & Civil Rights
AG: Ch. 4&5; ED: Ch. 4 (First three articles only, Nos. 18-20)
Week 3: 22 January
Monday, 20 January: Martin Luther King Jr. Holiday, No Meeting
22 January: Review & 1st Mid-Term Exam (Scantron)
Week 4: 27-31 January
27-29 January: Congress
AG: Ch. 6; ED: Ch. 5
Week 5: 3-7 February
3-7 February: Presidency
AG: Chs. 7; ED: Ch. 6
Week 6: 10-14 February
10-12 February: The Bureaucracy
AG: Ch. 8; ED: Ch. 7
Week 7: 17-21 February
Monday, 17 February: Presidents’ Day Holiday, No Meeting
19 February: The Judiciary
AG: Ch. 9; ED: Ch. 8
2nd Mid-Term Exam (Scantron)
This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:49:21 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/39832835/Syllabus-Pol-112-Winter-pdf/
5
Week 8: 24-28 February
24 February: Political Parties
AG Ch. 12; ED: Ch. 11
26 February: Interest Groups
AG: Chs. 13; ED: Ch. 12
Week 9: 3-7 March
3 March: The Media
AG: Ch. 14 (read ahead relevant articles from ED Ch. 9)
5 March: Public Opinion
AG: Ch. 9; ED: Ch. 9
Week 10: 10-14 March
10 March: Government Reform

Department of Political Science
California Polytechnic University, San Luis Obispo
1
POLITICAL SCIENCE 112
AMERICAN GOVERNMENT
Winter 2014
SYLLABUS
COURSE INFORMATION
Introduction & Description:
We will explore the United States political system, which will be broadly defined as
including the formal institutions of government as well as the ancillary and informal
avenues of power and influence used to shape political outcomes. By the end of the course
you should have available to you the tools necessary to practically evaluate the political
information you receive from media sources, political leaders, friends, and family alike.
Hopefully you will improve your writing and your ability to apply Political Science to
practical problems more generally. As most of my career has been spent working in
government, it is my hope that we can approach this academic subject with the objective of
making it practical and helpful in your future careers.
Course Materials:
Lowi, Theodore J., Benjamin Ginspbert, Kenneth A. Shepsle, and Stephen Ansolabehere.
2013. American Government: Power and Purpose, 13th Edition Core Edition. New
York: WW. Norton & Company Inc.
Canon, David T., John J. Coleman, and Kenneth R. Mayer. 2013. The Enduring Debate:
Classic and Contemporary Readings in American Politics, 7th Edition. New York:
W.W. Norton & Company Inc.


2
Evaluation of Learning:
Two In-Class Multiple Choice Mid-Term Exams, 15% each
One Final Exam, 20 %
Bi-Weekly Team Projects, 30%
In-Class quizzes, 20%
Behavioral Expectations:
You should have read all material assigned prior to the week and day when it will be
discussed. You should come prepared to take notes, participate in discussion, and will be
required to treat your colleagues and instructors with respect. One should expect that as
sensitive issues may be raised, emotions might carry one away. At no time will abusive,
threatening or demeaning language be tolerated.
I will come to class prepared to lecture on the topics as scheduled, unless a change has
been made in advance. I will also prepare assignments on schedule, and make every effort
to ensure your work-product is evaluated in an unbiased and timely manner. I will hold
scheduled office hours and be available to meet by appointment; all discussions in office
hours will be confidential except where required by the university. I will respond to all email enquires within twenty-four hours of my receiving them.
Plagiarism:
Plagiarism is using other people’s work without giving them credit. This can include the
following: using a quote without citation, paraphrasing a quote without citation, presenting
the findings, conclusions, or theoretical elements of someone else without citation, using a
friend’s paper, in whole or in part, in your assignments, buying a paper, essay, et cetera,
from any source, and presenting it as your own, “cutting and pasting” from a Wikipedia
article or any other on-line source, copying another student’s work without their
knowledge, or providing your work to someone else with the intent of having that person
fraudulently presenting your work as his or her own. The University has extremely strict
penalties for plagiarism or “cheating,” to include suspension and permanent expulsion
without credit. To protect the legitimate efforts of its students, the Department of Political
Science takes every effort to detect plagiarism and punish those who plagiarize.
Student Resources & Students With Disabilities
Please advise me early on of any special accommodations you require and coordinate these
requests through the Disability Resource Center.


3
The pace of a ten-week quarter can be stressful. All students have access to professional
counseling free of charge through Health and Counseling Services. You can find
information about their services at:
http://www.hcs.calpoly.edu/content/counseling/counseling-home
Or by calling 805-756-2511, or simply drop in at their offices in Building 27, Room 135,
near the Rec Center.
SCHEDULE OF TOPICS & ASSIGNMENTS:
Below is a schedule of topics with associated reading assignments. You should expect
additional reading to be assigned as the quarter progresses and current events present
opportunities to apply what we have been studying.
“AG” refers to the American Government: Power and Purpose text.
“ED” refers to the Enduring Debate: Classic and Contemporary Readings in American
Politics text.
You’ll find that mostly the chapters of AG and ED are parallel, but don’t make this
assumption. Each chapter in ED is divided into two big sections that contain more than
one article; you can assume that you should concentrate on the first section. The pace of a
ten-week quarter is relentless; it will be easy to fall behind on your reading assignments.
The chapter numbers listed below correspond to the most current edition of these texts.
Older texts are acceptable, please note that there will be a slight difference in the chapter
numbers (usually only off by one) in very recent previous editions.
Week 1: 6-10 January
6 January; Introduction & Course Overview
Pre-Test & Survey
AG: Ch. 1 & Appendix A13: The Constitution of the United States of
America
8 January; The Structure of Democracy in the U.S.
AG: Ch. 2; ED: Ch. 2


4
Week 2: 13-17 January
13 January; Federalism
AG: Ch. 3; ED: Ch 3
15 January; Civil Liberties & Civil Rights
AG: Ch. 4&5; ED: Ch. 4 (First three articles only, Nos. 18-20)
Week 3: 22 January
Monday, 20 January: Martin Luther King Jr. Holiday, No Meeting
22 January: Review & 1st Mid-Term Exam (Scantron)
Week 4: 27-31 January
27-29 January: Congress
AG: Ch. 6; ED: Ch. 5
Week 5: 3-7 February
3-7 February: Presidency
AG: Chs. 7; ED: Ch. 6
Week 6: 10-14 February
10-12 February: The Bureaucracy
AG: Ch. 8; ED: Ch. 7
Week 7: 17-21 February
Monday, 17 February: Presidents’ Day Holiday, No Meeting
19 February: The Judiciary
AG: Ch. 9; ED: Ch. 8
2nd Mid-Term Exam (Scantron)


5
Week 8: 24-28 February
24 February: Political Parties
AG Ch. 12; ED: Ch. 11
26 February: Interest Groups
AG: Chs. 13; ED: Ch. 12
Week 9: 3-7 March
3 March: The Media
AG: Ch. 14 (read ahead relevant articles from ED Ch. 9)
5 March: Public Opinion
AG: Ch. 9; ED: Ch. 9
Week 10: 10-14 March
10 March: Government Reform
AG: Appendix A34 &A 39, The Federalist Papers 10 & 51
ED: Ch. 14
12 March: Conclusion

Text:
CLEVELAND STATE UNIVERSITY
Monte Ahuja College of Business Administration
Marketing Department
Fall 2021
Course Title: Marketing Strategy
Course Credit: (3-0-3) Faculty: Dr. Ashutosh Dixit
Course Section: 51 or 52 Office: Ahuja Hall, BU 458
Class Meetings: 6pm-8:50 pm Office Hours: T 2-5 pm
Classroom: BU 0108 (51), BU 0206 (52) Office Phone:
Course Prerequisite: MKT 501 or equivalent Fax:
LAST DAY TO add: August 29 LAST DAY TO drop: Sept 03
E-mail:
TEXTBOOK: Coursepack: https://hbsp.harvard.edu/import/857015 (Tuesday Class) or
https://hbsp.harvard.edu/import/857018 (Wednesday Class)

COURSE CATALOGUE DESCRIPTION:
Explores advanced theories, concepts, and techniques for formulating strategic marketing plans
for business and non-business organizations in U.S. and global environments. Topics include
environmental analysis, market opportunity analysis, segmentation and positioning, marketingmix decisions, and formulating action plans.
COURSE OBJECTIVES:
As part of the MBA core, MKT 601 explores the process of formulating marketing strategies and
plans for business and nonprofit organizations operating in domestic as well as global markets.
Specific objectives include the following:
1. To identify and diagnose marketing problems in a variety of situations and industries, both
domestic, and international, and to apply marketing and strategic market planning concepts,
theories, and techniques to their analysis.
2. To sharpen analytical skills in solving marketing problems by working with quantitative as well
as qualitative data, and by utilizing quantitative tools and computer software for analyzing
decision options.
3. To identify strategic options, evaluate tradeoffs, examine the ethical consequences of
management decisions, and propose defensible recommendations, backed by realistic and
creative implementation plans.
4. To refine managerial communication skills by preparing written marketing plans and making
professional oral presentations.
Page 1 of 5 This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:49:48 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/106172296/Mktstgy-Fall21-Syllabus-1docx/
TOPICS COVERED:
A wide array of managerial decision-making topics is covered by the cases selected for analysis.
Lectures focus on decision-making skills that relate to specific cases. Specific topics include:
market segmentation, market selection, positioning, interpreting marketing research data, sales
forecasting, financial analysis, and formulating strategic and tactical marketing plans for domestic
and international firms in many business sectors.
COMMON BODY OF KNOWLEDGE:
Areas covered include: written communications, oral communications, computer usage,
quantitative analysis, financial reporting, human behavior, global, ethical, political & social, legal
& regulatory, environmental & technological, and demographic diversity.
SPECIFIC KNOWLEDGE AREAS:
Students will develop skills in: identifying and analyzing marketing issues, problems, and
challenges that a firm faces; applying behavioral and economic tolls for analysis; developing
feasible marketing strategies, incorporating decisions in selecting markets, managing products and
services, pricing, marketing communications, and distribution; and understanding the integrative
nature of decision making.
METHOD OF INSTRUCTION:
The case method of instruction, which is used throughout the course, depends upon extensive
prior preparation. Analyses of marketing cases are conducted with bb discussions and written
case presentations. A substantial portion of the final grade is assigned for classroom performance.
Consistent classroom participation is required. Quality of participation, rather than quantity, is
more important. Students and groups of students are encouraged to use a management style that
they feel will be most effective for them in the situation in which they find themselves. Students,
in the role of participants, should be completely prepared as if they were on a management team
with other class members.
DO NOT LET ONE ANOTHER DOWN; WE ARE ALL IN THIS TOGETHER!
The instructor will serve as a resource person to help you, but not to tell you what to do. You
have the opportunity to develop your own style as you must do if you are to learn and succeed.
PERFORMANCE EXPECTATIONS:
Students are expected to demonstrate knowledge and proficiency in the use of marketing
management concepts and decision-making tools. Class discussion of cases is a vital part of this
course. Hence, you are expected to be well prepared for the discussion of all cases and to
present your independent analyses and solutions for the marketing problems described. The
classroom performance grade will include the instructor’s evaluation of the student’s contribution
to the goals of the class. It is recognized that this type of evaluation may not commonly be used
in the educational environment. However, it is the one generally used in the business world. Your
supervisor’s opinion of your attitude, cooperation, motivation, and initiative, all of which
contribute to the success of the enterprise in which you are mutually engaged, is generally the
basis of your promotions and salary increases, or both. This subjective judgment will be based on
the aforementioned factors that are under your control.
Page 2 of 5 This study source was downloaded by 100000853212041 from CourseHero.com on 10-27-2022 12:49:48 GMT -05:00
https://www.coursehero.com/file/106172296/Mktstgy-Fall21-Syllabus-1docx/
ASSIGNMENTS:
Assignment is detailed in the course schedule. Cases and readings are required preparation for
each class. Each student/group is to write an analysis for cases as requested, be prepared to
contribute to the discussion of cases, and be ready to answer questions, take a quiz on your
analysis, or hand in your analysis at unannounced times.
Students will be assigned into groups to prepare cases for write-up.
GRADING:
Final grades (with + or -) will be computed according to the following weights:
Group Case presentations and write-ups (4) 40%
Marketing Simulation 30%
Final exam 30 % __
Total 100%
RETENTION OF STUDENT WORK FOR PORTFOLIOS:
The professor reserves the right to retain for pedagogical reasons the original, or a copy, of a
student’s test, written assignment, paper, video, or similar work (including individual and group
projects) submitted by the student for this class. Students’ names will be deleted from any
retained items.

CLEVELAND STATE UNIVERSITY
Monte Ahuja College of Business Administration
Marketing Department
Fall 2021
Course Title: Marketing Strategy
Course Credit: (3-0-3) 
TEXTBOOK: 
COURSE CATALOGUE DESCRIPTION:
Explores advanced theories, concepts, and techniques for formulating strategic marketing plans
for business and non-business organizations in U.S. and global environments. Topics include
environmental analysis, market opportunity analysis, segmentation and positioning, marketing mix decisions, and formulating action plans.
COURSE OBJECTIVES:
As part of the MBA core, MKT 601 explores the process of formulating marketing strategies and
plans for business and nonprofit organizations operating in domestic as well as global markets.
Specific objectives include the following:
1. To identify and diagnose marketing problems in a variety of situations and industries, both
domestic, and international, and to apply marketing and strategic market planning concepts,
theories, and techniques to their analysis.
2. To sharpen analytical skills in solving marketing problems by working with quantitative as well
as qualitative data, and by utilizing quantitative tools and computer software for analyzing
decision options.
3. To identify strategic options, evaluate tradeoffs, examine the ethical consequences of
management decisions, and propose defensible recommendations, backed by realistic and
creative implementation plans.
4. To refine managerial communication skills by preparing written marketing plans and making
professional oral presentations.


TOPICS COVERED:
A wide array of managerial decision-making topics is covered by the cases selected for analysis.
Lectures focus on decision-making skills that relate to specific cases. Specific topics include:
market segmentation, market selection, positioning, interpreting marketing research data, sales
forecasting, financial analysis, and formulating strategic and tactical marketing plans for domestic
and international firms in many business sectors.
COMMON BODY OF KNOWLEDGE:
Areas covered include: written communications, oral communications, computer usage,
quantitative analysis, financial reporting, human behavior, global, ethical, political & social, legal
& regulatory, environmental & technological, and demographic diversity.
SPECIFIC KNOWLEDGE AREAS:
Students will develop skills in: identifying and analyzing marketing issues, problems, and
challenges that a firm faces; applying behavioral and economic tolls for analysis; developing
feasible marketing strategies, incorporating decisions in selecting markets, managing products and
services, pricing, marketing communications, and distribution; and understanding the integrative
nature of decision making.
METHOD OF INSTRUCTION:
The case method of instruction, which is used throughout the course, depends upon extensive
prior preparation. Analyses of marketing cases are conducted with bb discussions and written
case presentations. A substantial portion of the final grade is assigned for classroom performance.
Consistent classroom participation is required. Quality of participation, rather than quantity, is
more important. Students and groups of students are encouraged to use a management style that
they feel will be most effective for them in the situation in which they find themselves. Students,
in the role of participants, should be completely prepared as if they were on a management team
with other class members.
DO NOT LET ONE ANOTHER DOWN; WE ARE ALL IN THIS TOGETHER!
The instructor will serve as a resource person to help you, but not to tell you what to do. You
have the opportunity to develop your own style as you must do if you are to learn and succeed.
PERFORMANCE EXPECTATIONS:
Students are expected to demonstrate knowledge and proficiency in the use of marketing
management concepts and decision-making tools. Class discussion of cases is a vital part of this
course. Hence, you are expected to be well prepared for the discussion of all cases and to
present your independent analyses and solutions for the marketing problems described. The
classroom performance grade will include the instructor’s evaluation of the student’s contribution
to the goals of the class. It is recognized that this type of evaluation may not commonly be used
in the educational environment. However, it is the one generally used in the business world. Your
supervisor’s opinion of your attitude, cooperation, motivation, and initiative, all of which
contribute to the success of the enterprise in which you are mutually engaged, is generally the
basis of your promotions and salary increases, or both. This subjective judgment will be based on
the aforementioned factors that are under your control.
Page 2 of 5 

ASSIGNMENTS:
Assignment is detailed in the course schedule. Cases and readings are required preparation for
each class. Each student/group is to write an analysis for cases as requested, be prepared to
contribute to the discussion of cases, and be ready to answer questions, take a quiz on your
analysis, or hand in your analysis at unannounced times.
Students will be assigned into groups to prepare cases for write-up.
GRADING:
Final grades (with + or -) will be computed according to the following weights:
Group Case presentations and write-ups (4) 40%
Marketing Simulation 30%
Final exam 30 % __
Total 100%
RETENTION OF STUDENT WORK FOR PORTFOLIOS:
The professor reserves the right to retain for pedagogical reasons the original, or a copy, of a
student’s test, written assignment, paper, video, or similar work (including individual and group
projects) submitted by the student for this class. Students’ names will be deleted from any
retained items.

ask/respond to questions on general discussion board as needed.
