GEO420K Intro. To Field and Stratigraphic Methods – Lab & Lecture Manual
COURSE OBJECTIVES
Why a class in geological field methods? Geology is first and foremost a field science. Field geology and
field geologists provide literally the ground truth for geologic concepts and theories of how the earth
works. The degree to which we, as geologists, are successful observers and interpreters of rocks in the
field depends in large measure on what we are prepared to see and record. The old adage “I wouldn’t
have believed it if I hadn’t seen it” is, in the case of field geology, more truthfully “I wouldn’t have seen
it if I hadn’t believed it”. We explore. We discover. Unfortunately, without sufficient experience and
preparation we can’t attach meaning to (and thus frequently ignore) what we don’t recognized or
understand. Discovery is, in part, “…seeing what everybody has seen, and thinking what nobody has
thought." (A. Szent-Györgyi). From our vantage point, this requires a perspective acquired largely from
field experiences.
Paradoxically, we must also learn what to ignore; “Wisdom is learning what to overlook...” (W. James).
There is rarely, if ever, sufficient time for exhaustive field data collecting. As time permits, we thus
typically focus on a relatively few key aspects at a field site, paying less or no attention to the rest.
Anthropologists term this ability to recognize and sort the significant from the insignificant “professional
vision”. It is a crucial field skill that comes mostly from practical experience. You will begin to develop
your professional vision in this class.
Field proficiency has long been a distinguishing characteristic of our science. As a geoscientist, you are
expected to be a proficient scientific observer and recorder. Your unique skills and training in this area
separate you from lawyers, engineers, chemists and other professionals with whom you might one day
work. Without proper preparation, including a strong grounding in field methods, we would be little
better than rock hounds out for a day of casual collecting. Field geology is not merely collecting data
and samples; it is about making sense of the geology around you, about making geologic interpretations.
Landscapes are histories, with time marked by boundaries in the rocks, soil and sediment. A geologic
map or a measured section is the articulation of that history, with each line marking a before and after,
a hiatus that might last a second or a billion years. Through our maps and graphical logs, we represent
time as space. The ability to create, read and interpret such product is best developed from training and
practice in a field setting. It all begins by making and recording observations. An accurate record in the
form of a map, measured section, photograph, sketch, a carefully documented sample, field notes, etc.
provides a permanent, solid basis upon which to develop testable ideas and interpretations – the plot of
the story. Without such evidence, interpretations are fanciful fables; there is no scientific basis to
objectively evaluate them.

Successful field work depends greatly on how well we can formulate and test ideas while in the field.
Geology is rooted in the scientific method. The process of formulating and testing multiple working
hypotheses during field work is a distinctive, unique, vital aspect of our profession, one that can only be
taught and practiced while in the field.
LEARNING OUTCOMES
As suggested by the course name, this class contains two main components. This semester our principal
objectives are to: 1) learn and apply geologic field methods to describe, measure, map, sample and
report on rocks in the field and in the laboratory; 2) acquire an understanding of and learn how to apply
the elements of stratigraphy (e.g. what is a Formation? what are lithostratigraphic, biostratigraphic and
chronostratigraphic units? what is a type section? how are rock units correlated?) and the field methods
upon which they are based. Like all sciences, geology has its own vocabulary. There is no better way to
learn a language than to be immersed in it, and field experiences, however brief, provide that
immersion.
GEO420K Intro. To Field and Stratigraphic Methods – Lab & Lecture Manual
It is often said “The best geologist is the one who has seen the most rocks” and there is much truth to it.
Four weekend field trips and a semester of labs will provide an introduction, the beginnings of a mental
catalog of rocks and field relationships that can provide a framework to build upon in future classes,
later field work and a future career in the geosciences.
TEACHING MODALITIES, PANDEMIC CONSIDERATIONS
As dictated by recent University policy, classes during the first two weeks of the semester this year
(January 18-28) will be taught remotely through Zoom. A link for these lectures is provided in Canvas, and
recordings of these and other MW lectures will be provided through the Canvas “Online Lectures” feature.
This is otherwise an in-person class only, with required attendance for all labs, lectures and field trips.
Disposable Nitril gloves, hand sanitizer and spray sanitizer will be available for use in all labs, some of
which require handling shared rock specimens and equipment. All lab and lecture rooms are large enough
to allow social distancing – please do so and wear a mask while indoors.

M408C: DIFFERENTIAL AND INTEGRAL CALCULUS Fall 2012
Under the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, have you persuaded yourself that
there are knowledges and truths beyond your grasp, things that you simply cannot learn?
Have you allowed adverse evidence to pile up and force you to conclude that you are not
mathematical, not linguistic, not poetic, not scientific, not philosophical? If you have
allowed this to happen, you have arbitrarily imposed limits on your intellectual freedom,
and you have smothered the fires from which all other freedoms arise.
—Scott Buchanan, Dean, St. John’s College, 1937–1946

Prerequisites:
Prerequisite and degree relevance: Either a 560 on the Mathematics IC Test or 560 on
Mathematics Level IIC, or a grade of at least C in M304E or M305G.
Note: Students who score less than 600 on the Mathematics Level IC Test should be aware that
studies show taking M305G first is likely to improve their grade in M408C.
Only one of the following may be counted: M 403K, 408C, 408K, 308K. 
M408C Treisman Fall 2012 2
M408C and M408D (or the equivalent sequence M408K, M408L, M408M) are required of
mathematics majors, and mathematics majors are required to make grades of C or better in these
courses. Any student who does not have the prerequisites for this course, or who has received
credit for any of the courses listed above, must see an advisor as soon as possible.
Students enter Math 408C with a great diversity of mathematics backgrounds. Many have taken
four years of mathematics plus Advanced Placement Calculus in high school; others may have
only taken two years of high school algebra and one year of high school geometry. Still others
will have taken Precalculus (Mathematics 305G) at UT Austin or at a community college. And,
some will be repeating M408C for a second or third time. Our sections require only that you
have met the official prerequisites for the course. Our aim is to help every one of you to
excel and to develop both the desire and the necessary skills to successfully continue your study
of mathematics and mathematics-dependent subjects. Professor Treisman will arrange extra
sessions for students who have had no prior exposure to Calculus. These students should make it
a special priority to attend Prof T’s office hours and his many extra review sessions. Finally,
students with no prior coursework in Calculus will have extra opportunities to earn points toward
their final grade.
Quantitative Reasoning Flag Course:
This course carries the Quantitative Reasoning flag. Quantitative Reasoning courses are designed
to equip you with skills that are necessary for understanding the types of quantitative arguments
you will regularly encounter in your adult and professional life. You should therefore expect a
substantial portion of your grade to come from your use of quantitative skills to analyze real- world problems.
Course Description:
M408C is the first semester of our standard first-year calculus sequence. It is designed for
students with interests in the mathematical, natural, and social sciences as well as for prospective
engineers and architects. This section of M408C is designed to help students develop:
(1) a conceptual understanding of the major ideas of differential and integral calculus,
(2) technical facility with its techniques and theorems, and
(3) the ability to use these techniques and theorems to solve a variety of standard and nonstandard problems.
The focus of this first calculus course is not on theory. However, because proof is so central to
later mathematical work, we will take a rigorous approach to the theory of limits and you will
learn how to prove the basic theorems that underlie important computational techniques.
Students will also learn to use the main course theorems to prove their important corollaries.
Calculus is a beautiful and venerable subject that provides powerful tools for analyzing the
behavior of functions—that is, the ways that changes in certain quantities affect changes in one
or more other quantities. These tools—developed in the seventeenth century and refined over
the next quarter of a millennium—represent one of civilization’s greatest intellectual
achievements. Calculus makes possible a concise and accurate description of the motion of
heavenly bodies, of basic economic principles, and of countless other phenomena in which
change and interdependence are central.
Calculus often allows us to compute the past and future states of a system, and here lies one
source of its power. It allows us to find desirable states of systems such as when one important
quantity takes its largest or smallest value, or moves at its greatest velocity, or just plain stops
changing for a spell. Often, when using the tools of calculus, one discovers that two systems or
phenomena, which appear at first to be completely unrelated, have exactly the same underlying
structure so that intuition in one domain allows us to better understand the other. This discovery 
M408C Treisman Fall 2012 3
of surprising similarities, that by looking through the lens of mathematics one can often see
unity, is one of the special pleasures of our subject and one of the reasons that drive some to
choose mathematics as their profession. We hope that, at semester’s end, you will have a sense
of the power of The Calculus and a growing appreciation for its beauty. Welcome to the
community of mathematicians.

M408C Treisman Fall 2012 4
Learning Calculus and the Role of the Professor and Teaching Assistant:
I was unable to find flaws in my 'proof' for quite a while, even though the error is very
obvious. It was a psychological problem, a blindness, an excitement, an inhibition of
reasoning by an underlying fear of being wrong. Techniques leading to the abandonment
of such inhibitions should be cultivated by every honest mathematician.
— John Stallings, one of my math professors at UC Berkeley, in an article on how he
failed to prove the Poincaré conjecture
Experience has taught us that mastering the content of M408C requires that students spend
many, many hours solving calculus problems and studying the textbook. We strongly
recommend getting to know some of your classmates and spending lots of time with them
working through hard problems, comparing notes on homework, and studying for examinations.
You should also make good use of our office hours, of the online Dana Center/Agile Mind
resources, and of the many other resources available on campus. We estimate that “A” students
will spend at least 15 hours a week studying for this course in addition to the time spent in
lecture and section. Of special importance is making sure you do not fall behind. The pace of
M408C is brisk; it’s hard to catch up. If you feel that your performance is slipping, come and
see us as soon as possible. If the professor or teaching assistant thinks that your performance is
slipping, one of us will hunt you down. Our goal is to help you all excel in this course. We need
your cooperation.
In lecture, we will not cover everything in the textbook, but rather, will spend most of the time
exploring difficult points and interesting problems, and working together on exercises that will
help us help you learn calculus. Do not expect a 75-minute lecture; they will rarely be given. Typically, the content covered in a lecture will be useful to completing a subsequent homework
assignment. But, occasionally, I will assign homework problems on material not yet covered in
lecture. This is one among many signals to you that the course syllabus has been specified and
that you are largely responsible for learning the basic material on your own and in collaboration
with your peers and teaching assistants. As the course progresses you will be responsible for
learning more and more of the basic material independently, but fear not—the teaching assistants
and I will be there to support you whenever you have trouble.
I expect many of you to be regulars at my office hours—that’s where we get to work on
problems in depth and where I can be responsive to your individual needs. Besides, as you’ll
discover, I’m quite witty and charming—and humble too!
The purpose of discussion sections is not only to respond to your individual questions, but also to
afford you an opportunity to work with your peers on the kinds of problems that will appear on
the course examinations. You’ll find your teaching assistant to be an invaluable resource for
helping you to excel in the course.
We expect you to come to every lecture and discussion section prepared to do mathematics.
Your running point total (as described below) will be posted on a secure part of the course
website. You’ll need to sign in with your UT EID and password to access your scores. No other
student can access your scores.
M408C Treisman Fall 2012 5

toward your final point total. Nota bene: Even if you earn 1,200 points only 1,000 will be
counted toward your final point total.
You can earn up to 300 points on the final exam and these will count toward your final point
total.
In other words, you cannot earn an A- or A in the course if you do not take the final exam.
It will be near impossible to earn an A without doing lots of extra credit work.
Note that you are not competing with your classmates. I’ve designed the grading system—an
absolute scale—explicitly to promote collaboration in learning calculus.
Exams will be challenging, but there will be few surprises, and conscientious studying should
produce A-level work. I gladly give partial credit for work that is partially correct. Midterms
and the final exam must be written in 8 x 10” bluebooks available at many on- and off-campus
stores. Be a sport and bring an extra one to exams for those who forget.
BANKRUPT YOUR PROFESSOR
How badly do I want you to excel in this course? If all the students in any section earn an A in
the course, that is, earn 1100 points or more, the students in that section can pick any restaurant
in Austin for a celebration—and dinner is on me. This has happened three times since I began
teaching at UT in fall 1991.
M408C Treisman Fall 2012 6
Class Leadership Team:
By week three of the course, each section must elect a student section leader. The student
section leaders will meet with me 4 times throughout the semester to give me advice on
improving the course. They will survey their fellow students and otherwise engage in activities
to surface class problems and opportunities. I will provide lunch, snacks of whatever form of
bribery is necessary to help you help me to make this a great semester.
Earning Points and Grading Policies
In-lecture spot quizzes (100 points):
Thirteen times in lecture I will give a two-minute quiz designed to be very easy for those who
have prepared for class by reading the assigned material—and designed to be very challenging
for those who did not do so. Each quiz will be worth up to ten points with partial credit given.
Most of these one-item quizzes will ask you to state a definition or theorem in the required
reading or, perhaps, to solve an elementary problem worked out in the assigned section of text.
The ten highest scores will be added to determine your score in this category. Since there will be
13 quizzes and only the top ten count, there will be no quiz makeups. Again, no make-ups will
be offered for this point-earning category. Occasionally, the class assistant will grant you more
than 10 points for superior work on your quiz, but your maximum total in this grading category
remains 100 points.
Homework (up to 100 points for book problems and up to 100 points for Quest problems):
Learning calculus requires developing computational fluency with important algorithms,
developing a deep conceptual understanding of a beautiful set of ideas, and learning to apply
these ideas and algorithms to both classical and novel problems. You can only achieve this
through lots of practice, made with pencil (and, often, graphing calculator) in hand. One way to
organize this necessary work is by being diligent at doing homework. There’s lots of it; ain’t no
way around that. There will be approximately 27 homework assignments, each of which will
require approximately five hours of work.
Each homework assignment will consist of the following:
 3–6 difficult problems assigned from the textbook. Your work must be submitted on
8 ½ x 11” paper, stapled in the upper left corner. Be sure to include your name and
section number on each page. This makes it easier for us to keep track of 130+
students’ work.
 Approximately 10–20 additional problems administered through the Quest Learning and
Assessment System. The Quest website is available at http://quest.cns.utexas.edu.
Required Notice Regarding Quest: This course makes use of the web-based Quest
content delivery and homework server system maintained by the College of Natural
Sciences at The University of Texas at Austin. This homework service will require a $25
charge per student for its use, which goes toward the maintenance and operation of the
resource. Please go to http://quest.cns.utexas.edu to log in to the Quest system for this
class. At some point during the second or third week, when you log into Quest, you will
be asked to pay via credit card on a secure payment site. You have the option to wait up
to 15 days to pay while still continuing to use Quest for your assignments. If you are
taking more than one course using Quest, you will not be charged more than
$50/semester. Quest provides mandatory instructional material for this course, just as is
your textbook, etc. For payment questions, email quest.billing@cns.utexas.edu.
Write neatly!!! Reading homework assignments is painstakingly hard work. Be kind to the
grader and to your professor, who will occasionally read a sample of homework papers. The
grader has the authority to give zero points to illegible homework assignments.
M408C Treisman Fall 2012 7
Nota Bene: On each assignment from the textbook only one problem will be graded. You will
not know which one it is in advance. Credit is given for the solution to a problem, not for the
answer, which you will often be able to find in the back of the textbook.
Each homework assignment on Quest is worth up to 5 points. If you score 100%, then you will
earn 5 points. If you score 50%, then you will earn 2.5 points, etc..
Your final homework score is the sum of your 20 highest homework grades from the textbook
plus your 20 highest homework grades from Quest (maximum of 200 points).
Chapter 2 Quiz (up to 100 points):
This quiz will test your knowledge of the material on chapter 2.
Midterm I: (up to 250 points):
This midterm will consist of four questions on the material in Topics I and II.
 Question 1 (4 parts, each worth 20 points, for a total of 80 points) will test your
computational skills.
 Question 2 (60 points) will be a modified version of an assigned (challenging)
homework problem.
 Question 3 (60 points) will be a modified version of a problem worked out in the
assigned sections of the text.
 Question 4 (50 points) A wild card!
Midterm II: (up to 250 points):
This midterm will consist of five questions on the material in Topics III, IV, inverse functions,
and logarithms.
 Question 1 (4 parts each worth 20 points for a total of 80 points). This question will test
your computational skills.
 Question 2 (40 points) will be a modified version of an assigned (challenging)
homework problem.
 Question 3 (40 points) will be a modified version of a problem worked out in the
assigned sections of the text.
 Question 4 (40 points) will be a modified version of a problem chosen from a list of 15
hard problems that will be distributed two weeks before the examination.
 Question 5 (50 points) A wild card!
Final Examination (up to 300 points):
The structure of the comprehensive final exam will be discussed in class.
Exam Make-Up policy:
Midterm I: If, for documented health reasons, a student misses Midterm I, then a make-up exam
will be provided at a time convenient to both student and professor.
Midterm II: If, for documented health reasons, a student misses Midterm II, then a make-up
exam will be provided at a time convenient to both student and professor.
Final Exam: If, for documented health reasons, a student misses the Final Exam, the student will
receive an Incomplete in the course. The grade will be determined after the student completes a
make-up final at a time convenient to both student and professor.
Make-up examinations will be taken in Professor Treisman’s Dana Center office at
1616 Guadalupe, Room 3.206 (UTA bldg) and will be proctored by Professor Treisman’s staff.
Nota bene: No make-ups for in-class spot quizzes or for homeworks.
M408C Treisman Fall 2012 8
Discussion Section (up to 100 points):
Your discussion section instructor will evaluate the quality of your participation in section. We
expect you to come prepared to work on problems from the assigned reading, to collaborate with
your classmates on hard problems, and to seek our help and extra challenges when needed. They
may choose to give you quizzes or special assignments on which they base the number of points
you earn in this category. These points, if any, will be awarded at the end of the semester.
Earning Extra Credit (up to 200 points):
Agile Mind (up to 100 points of extra credit): Students will be given passwords to this online
support system for learning calculus developed by Prof Treisman and his colleagues. The
service consists of more than 25 units on the main course topics together with helpful
animations, simulations, and problem sets. The service keeps track of your work and allows the
professor and TA to view your progress as well as the time spent on each task. We will
demonstrate the service in class and will distribute a sheet describing how to earn extra credit.
Students can earn up to 4 extra credit points for each online unit completed (up to a maximum of
100 points), if the unit is completed by the announced deadline. A completed unit represents
approx. 40–90 minutes of work. More information will be provided when the online system is
demonstrated in class. Your work will be graded by the course Famulus minor and her decisions
are final!
Special Sessions: The UT Sanger Learning Center offers review classes that are often excellent.
Every student is provided five free one-on-one tutoring sessions. It would be foolish not to use
them. I will grant extra credit for attending some of these. I will also grant extra credit for
attending some of my extra evening and weekend study sessions. Details to be given in lecture.
Classroom Participation: To encourage you to participate in class, I will often give students extra
credit points for astute comments made in class.
Special Extra Credit Projects: There will be three special opportunities to earn extra credit, each
of which will be worth up to 15 points for exceptional work. Details and a schedule will be
provided in lecture.
1. Laboratory Project on page 256.
2. With a group of 4–6 classmates, go to a cultural event on campus that you would not
ordinarily attend. Write a group essay on your experience. Choose classmates that you do
not know well. As a matter of respect, you may not chose a religious event.
3. Every year I write letters to high school teachers who have been identified by my students as
having a powerful effect on their mathematical knowledge and affection for the subject.
Write a two-page letter nominating one of your high school teachers for this honor.
Attendance Policy:
Attending lectures in a University requirement. I understand that there are legitimate reasons for
occasionally missing a class or a discussion session. I expect you to email me in advance of any
anticipated class absences. I do worry about you all and want to ensure you’re OK. It is
unimaginable that you could pass this course without near perfect attendance.
Religious Holidays:
I respect your religious beliefs and practices and will make accommodations for students who
choose to miss a class in observance of a holiday. You need to inform me by email at least two
days in advance if you will miss class for religious reasons, so that I can arrange appropriate
accommodations, make-up quizzes, etc.
M408C Treisman Fall 2012 9
Special Accommodations:
Students with special challenges or disabilities should notify the professor and the TA at the
beginning of the semester, so that we can work together to create the conditions that allow you to
excel in this class. The UT campus has an excellent office that provides services and special
accommodations for students with disabilities. You can contact this office at 471-6259 or
videophone at 866-327-8877 (then dial 512-232-2937).
Athletes: Please let me know as soon as possible when you will miss class. Hook‘em Horns.
Academic Integrity:
I have organized this class to encourage students to work together and to help each learn
calculus. I especially encourage students to work together on their homework and to check each
other’s work before handing in assignments. With this exception, I expect that all written work
submitted to the professor or the TA to be each student’s own work. I tolerate no cheating on
examinations. Students should read the University rules on scholastic dishonesty, which can be
found on the Student Judicial Services website at http://deanofstudents.utexas.edu/sjs/.

M408C: DIFFERENTIAL AND INTEGRAL CALCULUS Fall 2012
 Under the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, have you persuaded yourself that
 there are knowledges and truths beyond your grasp, things that you simply cannot learn?
 Have you allowed adverse evidence to pile up and force you to conclude that you are not
 mathematical, not linguistic, not poetic, not scientific, not philosophical? If you have
 allowed this to happen, you have arbitrarily imposed limits on your intellectual freedom,
 and you have smothered the fires from which all other freedoms arise.
 —Scott Buchanan, Dean, St. John’s College, 1937–1946

 The course website is available at https://courses.utexas.edu and requires your UT EID and
 password for access. Homework assignments, extra credit opportunities, and other important
 class information will be posted on this site. Check it regularly.
 Prerequisites:
 Prerequisite and degree relevance: Either a 560 on the Mathematics IC Test or 560 on
 Mathematics Level IIC, or a grade of at least C in M304E or M305G.
 Note: Students who score less than 600 on the Mathematics Level IC Test should be aware that
 studies show taking M305G first is likely to improve their grade in M408C.
 Only one of the following may be counted: M 403K, 408C, 408K, 308K. 
 M408C Treisman Fall 2012 2
 M408C and M408D (or the equivalent sequence M408K, M408L, M408M) are required of
 mathematics majors, and mathematics majors are required to make grades of C or better in these
 courses. Any student who does not have the prerequisites for this course, or who has received
 credit for any of the courses listed above, must see an advisor as soon as possible.
 Students enter Math 408C with a great diversity of mathematics backgrounds. Many have taken
 four years of mathematics plus Advanced Placement Calculus in high school; others may have
 only taken two years of high school algebra and one year of high school geometry. Still others
 will have taken Precalculus (Mathematics 305G) at UT Austin or at a community college. And,
 some will be repeating M408C for a second or third time. Our sections require only that you
 have met the official prerequisites for the course. Our aim is to help every one of you to
 excel and to develop both the desire and the necessary skills to successfully continue your study
 of mathematics and mathematics-dependent subjects. Professor Treisman will arrange extra
 sessions for students who have had no prior exposure to Calculus. These students should make it
 a special priority to attend Prof T’s office hours and his many extra review sessions. Finally,
 students with no prior coursework in Calculus will have extra opportunities to earn points toward
 their final grade.
 Quantitative Reasoning Flag Course:
 This course carries the Quantitative Reasoning flag. Quantitative Reasoning courses are designed
 to equip you with skills that are necessary for understanding the types of quantitative arguments
 you will regularly encounter in your adult and professional life. You should therefore expect a
 substantial portion of your grade to come from your use of quantitative skills to analyze real- world problems.
 Course Description:
 M408C is the first semester of our standard first-year calculus sequence. It is designed for
 students with interests in the mathematical, natural, and social sciences as well as for prospective
 engineers and architects. This section of M408C is designed to help students develop:
 (1) a conceptual understanding of the major ideas of differential and integral calculus,
 (2) technical facility with its techniques and theorems, and
 (3) the ability to use these techniques and theorems to solve a variety of standard and nonstandard problems.
 The focus of this first calculus course is not on theory. However, because proof is so central to
 later mathematical work, we will take a rigorous approach to the theory of limits and you will
 learn how to prove the basic theorems that underlie important computational techniques.
 Students will also learn to use the main course theorems to prove their important corollaries.
 Calculus is a beautiful and venerable subject that provides powerful tools for analyzing the
 behavior of functions—that is, the ways that changes in certain quantities affect changes in one
 or more other quantities. These tools—developed in the seventeenth century and refined over
 the next quarter of a millennium—represent one of civilization’s greatest intellectual
 achievements. Calculus makes possible a concise and accurate description of the motion of
 heavenly bodies, of basic economic principles, and of countless other phenomena in which
 change and interdependence are central.
 Calculus often allows us to compute the past and future states of a system, and here lies one
 source of its power. It allows us to find desirable states of systems such as when one important
 quantity takes its largest or smallest value, or moves at its greatest velocity, or just plain stops
 changing for a spell. Often, when using the tools of calculus, one discovers that two systems or
 phenomena, which appear at first to be completely unrelated, have exactly the same underlying
 structure so that intuition in one domain allows us to better understand the other. This discovery 
 M408C Treisman Fall 2012 3
 of surprising similarities, that by looking through the lens of mathematics one can often see
 unity, is one of the special pleasures of our subject and one of the reasons that drive some to
 choose mathematics as their profession. We hope that, at semester’s end, you will have a sense
 of the power of The Calculus and a growing appreciation for its beauty. Welcome to the
 community of mathematicians.
 Course Outline:
 Topic I: Limits and Continuity [Four lectures]
 Required Reading: Sections 2.1–2.6
 Agile Mind units: 1–6
 Chapter 2 Quiz (Topic I) (30 minutes at the beginning of class) -Tuesday, September 18
 Topic II: Differentiation [Six lectures]
 Required Reading: Sections 2.7, 2.8, 3.1–3.6, 3.8, 3.9
 Agile Mind units: 7–12, 17, 19, 32, 36
 Midterm I on Topics I and II (in class) –Thursday, October 4
 Topic III: Applications of the Derivative [Five lectures]
 Required Reading: Sections 4.1–4.7
 Agile Mind units: 13–16, 18, 20
 Topic IV: Integrals and their Applications [Six lectures]
 Required Reading: Section 4.9, 5.1–5.5, 6.1–6.3
 Agile Mind units: 21–27, 30
 Midterm II on Topics III and IV, Inverse Functions, and Logarithms -Thursday, November 15
 Topic V: Techniques of Integration [Five lectures]
 Required Reading: Sections 7.1–7.5
 FINAL EXAM (Comprehensive) -date and location to be announced
 M408C Treisman Fall 2012 4
 Learning Calculus and the Role of the Professor and Teaching Assistant:
 I was unable to find flaws in my 'proof' for quite a while, even though the error is very
 obvious. It was a psychological problem, a blindness, an excitement, an inhibition of
 reasoning by an underlying fear of being wrong. Techniques leading to the abandonment
 of such inhibitions should be cultivated by every honest mathematician.
 —  , one of my math professors at UC Berkeley, in an article on how he
 failed to prove the Poincaré conjecture
 Experience has taught us that mastering the content of M408C requires that students spend
 many, many hours solving calculus problems and studying the textbook. We strongly
 recommend getting to know some of your classmates and spending lots of time with them
 working through hard problems, comparing notes on homework, and studying for examinations.
 You should also make good use of our office hours, of the online Dana Center/Agile Mind
 resources, and of the many other resources available on campus. We estimate that “A” students
 will spend at least 15 hours a week studying for this course in addition to the time spent in
 lecture and section. Of special importance is making sure you do not fall behind. The pace of
 M408C is brisk; it’s hard to catch up. If you feel that your performance is slipping, come and
 see us as soon as possible. If the professor or teaching assistant thinks that your performance is
 slipping, one of us will hunt you down. Our goal is to help you all excel in this course. We need
 your cooperation.
 In lecture, we will not cover everything in the textbook, but rather, will spend most of the time
 exploring difficult points and interesting problems, and working together on exercises that will
 help us help you learn calculus. Do not expect a 75-minute lecture; they will rarely be given. Typically, the content covered in a lecture will be useful to completing a subsequent homework
 assignment. But, occasionally, I will assign homework problems on material not yet covered in
 lecture. This is one among many signals to you that the course syllabus has been specified and
 that you are largely responsible for learning the basic material on your own and in collaboration
 with your peers and teaching assistants. As the course progresses you will be responsible for
 learning more and more of the basic material independently, but fear not—the teaching assistants
 and I will be there to support you whenever you have trouble.
 I expect many of you to be regulars at my office hours—that’s where we get to work on
 problems in depth and where I can be responsive to your individual needs. Besides, as you’ll
 discover, I’m quite witty and charming—and humble too!
 The purpose of discussion sections is not only to respond to your individual questions, but also to
 afford you an opportunity to work with your peers on the kinds of problems that will appear on
 the course examinations. You’ll find your teaching assistant to be an invaluable resource for
 helping you to excel in the course.
 We expect you to come to every lecture and discussion section prepared to do mathematics.
 Your running point total (as described below) will be posted on a secure part of the course
 website. You’ll need to sign in with your UT EID and password to access your scores. No other
 student can access your scores.

 Special Sessions: The UT Sanger Learning Center offers review classes that are often excellent.
 Every student is provided five free one-on-one tutoring sessions. It would be foolish not to use
 them. I will grant extra credit for attending some of these. I will also grant extra credit for
 attending some of my extra evening and weekend study sessions. Details to be given in lecture.
 Classroom Participation: To encourage you to participate in class, I will often give students extra
 credit points for astute comments made in class.
 Special Extra Credit Projects: There will be three special opportunities to earn extra credit, each
 of which will be worth up to 15 points for exceptional work. Details and a schedule will be
 provided in lecture.
 1. Laboratory Project on page 256.
 2. With a group of 4–6 classmates, go to a cultural event on campus that you would not
 ordinarily attend. Write a group essay on your experience. Choose classmates that you do
 not know well. As a matter of respect, you may not chose a religious event.
 3. Every year I write letters to high school teachers who have been identified by my students as
 having a powerful effect on their mathematical knowledge and affection for the subject.
 Write a two-page letter nominating one of your high school teachers for this honor.
 Attendance Policy:
 Attending lectures in a University requirement. I understand that there are legitimate reasons for
 occasionally missing a class or a discussion session. I expect you to email me in advance of any
 anticipated class absences. I do worry about you all and want to ensure you’re OK. It is
 unimaginable that you could pass this course without near perfect attendance.
 Religious Holidays:
 I respect your religious beliefs and practices and will make accommodations for students who
 choose to miss a class in observance of a holiday. You need to inform me by email at least two
 days in advance if you will miss class for religious reasons, so that I can arrange appropriate
 accommodations, make-up quizzes, etc.
 M408C Treisman Fall 2012 9
 Special Accommodations:
 Students with special challenges or disabilities should notify the professor and the TA at the
 beginning of the semester, so that we can work together to create the conditions that allow you to
 excel in this class. The UT campus has an excellent office that provides services and special
 accommodations for students with disabilities. You can contact this office at 471-6259 or
 videophone at 866-327-8877 (then dial 512-232-2937).
 Athletes: Please let me know as soon as possible when you will miss class. Hook‘em Horns.
 Academic Integrity:
 I have organized this class to encourage students to work together and to help each learn
 calculus. I especially encourage students to work together on their homework and to check each
 other’s work before handing in assignments. With this exception, I expect that all written work
 submitted to the professor or the TA to be each student’s own work. I tolerate no cheating on
 examinations. Students should read the University rules on scholastic dishonesty, which can be
 found on the Student Judicial Services website at http://deanofstudents.utexas.edu/sjs/.
Pre-processed text 2:
M408C: DIFFERENTIAL AND INTEGRAL CALCULUS Fall 2012
 Under the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, have you persuaded yourself that
 there are knowledges and truths beyond your grasp, things that you simply cannot learn?
 Have you allowed adverse evidence to pile up and force you to conclude that you are not
 mathematical, not linguistic, not poetic, not scientific, not philosophical? If you have
 allowed this to happen, you have arbitrarily imposed limits on your intellectual freedom,
 and you have smothered the fires from which all other freedoms arise.
 —Scott Buchanan, Dean, St. John’s College, 1937–1946
 Course Overview:
 Instructor:
 Professor
 Office: RLM 10.162
 Office hours: announced in class
 (and by appointment)
 Phone: 232-2271
 Email: Assistant Instructor:
 
 Office:
 Office
 Email: Teaching Assistant:

 Office:
 Office hours:
 Email: Class Assistant / Famulus Minor /
 Queen of Grades:

 Email: Grader:

 Email: Required Text: Calculus 7E Early Transcendentals by James Stewart (Seventh Edition)
 Supplementary Resources: Agile Mind online services (url and passwords to be provided in section)
 Meeting Times:
 TTh 2:00–3:30 PM CPE 2.214 Sections 55170, 55175, 55180
 
 MW 8:00–9:00 AM RLM 7.124
 
 Section 55170
 MW 2:00–3:00 PM RLM 6.118 Section 55175
 MW 4:00–5:00 PM CPE 2.204 Section 55180
 
 The course website is available at https://courses.utexas.edu and requires your UT EID and
 password for access. Homework assignments, extra credit opportunities, and other important
 class information will be posted on this site. Check it regularly.
 Prerequisites:
 Prerequisite and degree relevance: Either a 560 on the Mathematics IC Test or 560 on
 Mathematics Level IIC, or a grade of at least C in M304E or M305G.
 Note: Students who score less than 600 on the Mathematics Level IC Test should be aware that
 studies show taking M305G first is likely to improve their grade in M408C.
 Only one of the following may be counted: M 403K, 408C, 408K, 308K. 
 M408C Treisman Fall 2012 2
 M408C and M408D (or the equivalent sequence M408K, M408L, M408M) are required of
 mathematics majors, and mathematics majors are required to make grades of C or better in these
 courses. Any student who does not have the prerequisites for this course, or who has received
 credit for any of the courses listed above, must see an advisor as soon as possible.
 Students enter Math 408C with a great diversity of mathematics backgrounds. Many have taken
 four years of mathematics plus Advanced Placement Calculus in high school; others may have
 only taken two years of high school algebra and one year of high school geometry. Still others
 will have taken Precalculus (Mathematics 305G) at UT Austin or at a community college. And,
 some will be repeating M408C for a second or third time. Our sections require only that you
 have met the official prerequisites for the course. Our aim is to help every one of you to
 excel and to develop both the desire and the necessary skills to successfully continue your study
 of mathematics and mathematics-dependent subjects. Professor Treisman will arrange extra
 sessions for students who have had no prior exposure to Calculus. These students should make it
 a special priority to attend Prof T’s office hours and his many extra review sessions. Finally,
 students with no prior coursework in Calculus will have extra opportunities to earn points toward
 their final grade.
 Quantitative Reasoning Flag Course:
 This course carries the Quantitative Reasoning flag. Quantitative Reasoning courses are designed
 to equip you with skills that are necessary for understanding the types of quantitative arguments
 you will regularly encounter in your adult and professional life. You should therefore expect a
 substantial portion of your grade to come from your use of quantitative skills to analyze real- world problems.
 Course Description:
 M408C is the first semester of our standard first-year calculus sequence. It is designed for
 students with interests in the mathematical, natural, and social sciences as well as for prospective
 engineers and architects. This section of M408C is designed to help students develop:
 (1) a conceptual understanding of the major ideas of differential and integral calculus,
 (2) technical facility with its techniques and theorems, and
 (3) the ability to use these techniques and theorems to solve a variety of standard and nonstandard problems.
 The focus of this first calculus course is not on theory. However, because proof is so central to
 later mathematical work, we will take a rigorous approach to the theory of limits and you will
 learn how to prove the basic theorems that underlie important computational techniques.
 Students will also learn to use the main course theorems to prove their important corollaries.
 Calculus is a beautiful and venerable subject that provides powerful tools for analyzing the
 behavior of functions—that is, the ways that changes in certain quantities affect changes in one
 or more other quantities. These tools—developed in the seventeenth century and refined over
 the next quarter of a millennium—represent one of civilization’s greatest intellectual
 achievements. Calculus makes possible a concise and accurate description of the motion of
 heavenly bodies, of basic economic principles, and of countless other phenomena in which
 change and interdependence are central.
 Calculus often allows us to compute the past and future states of a system, and here lies one
 source of its power. It allows us to find desirable states of systems such as when one important
 quantity takes its largest or smallest value, or moves at its greatest velocity, or just plain stops
 changing for a spell. Often, when using the tools of calculus, one discovers that two systems or
 phenomena, which appear at first to be completely unrelated, have exactly the same underlying
 structure so that intuition in one domain allows us to better understand the other. This discovery 
 M408C Treisman Fall 2012 3
 of surprising similarities, that by looking through the lens of mathematics one can often see
 unity, is one of the special pleasures of our subject and one of the reasons that drive some to
 choose mathematics as their profession. We hope that, at semester’s end, you will have a sense
 of the power of The Calculus and a growing appreciation for its beauty. Welcome to the
 community of mathematicians.
 Course Outline:
 Topic I: Limits and Continuity [Four lectures]
 Required Reading: Sections 2.1–2.6
 Agile Mind units: 1–6
 Chapter 2 Quiz (Topic I) (30 minutes at the beginning of class) -Tuesday, September 18
 Topic II: Differentiation [Six lectures]
 Required Reading: Sections 2.7, 2.8, 3.1–3.6, 3.8, 3.9
 Agile Mind units: 7–12, 17, 19, 32, 36
 Midterm I on Topics I and II (in class) –Thursday, October 4
 Topic III: Applications of the Derivative [Five lectures]
 Required Reading: Sections 4.1–4.7
 Agile Mind units: 13–16, 18, 20
 Topic IV: Integrals and their Applications [Six lectures]
 Required Reading: Section 4.9, 5.1–5.5, 6.1–6.3
 Agile Mind units: 21–27, 30
 Midterm II on Topics III and IV, Inverse Functions, and Logarithms -Thursday, November 15
 Topic V: Techniques of Integration [Five lectures]
 Required Reading: Sections 7.1–7.5
 FINAL EXAM (Comprehensive) -date and location to be announced
 M408C Treisman Fall 2012 4
 Learning Calculus and the Role of the Professor and Teaching Assistant:
 I was unable to find flaws in my 'proof' for quite a while, even though the error is very
 obvious. It was a psychological problem, a blindness, an excitement, an inhibition of
 reasoning by an underlying fear of being wrong. Techniques leading to the abandonment
 of such inhibitions should be cultivated by every honest mathematician.
 —  , one of my math professors at UC Berkeley, in an article on how he
 failed to prove the Poincaré conjecture
 Experience has taught us that mastering the content of M408C requires that students spend
 many, many hours solving calculus problems and studying the textbook. We strongly
 recommend getting to know some of your classmates and spending lots of time with them
 working through hard problems, comparing notes on homework, and studying for examinations.
 You should also make good use of our office hours, of the online Dana Center/Agile Mind
 resources, and of the many other resources available on campus. We estimate that “A” students
 will spend at least 15 hours a week studying for this course in addition to the time spent in
 lecture and section. Of special importance is making sure you do not fall behind. The pace of
 M408C is brisk; it’s hard to catch up. If you feel that your performance is slipping, come and
 see us as soon as possible. If the professor or teaching assistant thinks that your performance is
 slipping, one of us will hunt you down. Our goal is to help you all excel in this course. We need
 your cooperation.
 In lecture, we will not cover everything in the textbook, but rather, will spend most of the time
 exploring difficult points and interesting problems, and working together on exercises that will
 help us help you learn calculus. Do not expect a 75-minute lecture; they will rarely be given. Typically, the content covered in a lecture will be useful to completing a subsequent homework
 assignment. But, occasionally, I will assign homework problems on material not yet covered in
 lecture. This is one among many signals to you that the course syllabus has been specified and
 that you are largely responsible for learning the basic material on your own and in collaboration
 with your peers and teaching assistants. As the course progresses you will be responsible for
 learning more and more of the basic material independently, but fear not—the teaching assistants
 and I will be there to support you whenever you have trouble.
 I expect many of you to be regulars at my office hours—that’s where we get to work on
 problems in depth and where I can be responsive to your individual needs. Besides, as you’ll
 discover, I’m quite witty and charming—and humble too!
 The purpose of discussion sections is not only to respond to your individual questions, but also to
 afford you an opportunity to work with your peers on the kinds of problems that will appear on
 the course examinations. You’ll find your teaching assistant to be an invaluable resource for
 helping you to excel in the course.
 We expect you to come to every lecture and discussion section prepared to do mathematics.
 Your running point total (as described below) will be posted on a secure part of the course
 website. You’ll need to sign in with your UT EID and password to access your scores. No other
 student can access your scores.
 M408C Treisman Fall 2012 5
 Grading Scheme:
 Your final grade in M408C will be determined by the number of points you earn on the
 following scale:
 A 1100 or higher
 A– 1025 to 1099
 B+ 975 to 1024
 B 900 to 974
 B– 850 to 899
 C+ 800 to 849
 C 750 to 799
 C– 700 to 749
 D+ 650 to 699
 D 600 to 649
 F below 600
 During the 15 weeks of instruction, points can be earned in many ways:
 up to 100 points on in-lecture spot quizzes,
 up to 200 points on homework,
 up to 100 points on Chapter 2 Quiz,
 up to 250 points on Midterm I,
 up to 250 points on Midterm II,
 up to 100 points for high quality participation and engagement in your discussion section,
 In addition, there are many ways to earn up to as many as 200 extra credit points.
 However, only up to 1,000 points earned during the 15 weeks of instruction will be counted
 toward your final point total. Nota bene: Even if you earn 1,200 points only 1,000 will be
 counted toward your final point total.
 You can earn up to 300 points on the final exam and these will count toward your final point
 total.
 In other words, you cannot earn an A- or A in the course if you do not take the final exam.
 It will be near impossible to earn an A without doing lots of extra credit work.
 Note that you are not competing with your classmates. I’ve designed the grading system—an
 absolute scale—explicitly to promote collaboration in learning calculus.
 Exams will be challenging, but there will be few surprises, and conscientious studying should
 produce A-level work. I gladly give partial credit for work that is partially correct. Midterms
 and the final exam must be written in 8 x 10” bluebooks available at many on- and off-campus
 stores. Be a sport and bring an extra one to exams for those who forget.
 BANKRUPT YOUR PROFESSOR
 How badly do I want you to excel in this course? If all the students in any section earn an A in
 the course, that is, earn 1100 points or more, the students in that section can pick any restaurant
 in Austin for a celebration—and dinner is on me. This has happened three times since I began
 teaching at UT in fall 1991.
 M408C Treisman Fall 2012 6
 Class Leadership Team:
 By week three of the course, each section must elect a student section leader. The student
 section leaders will meet with me 4 times throughout the semester to give me advice on
 improving the course. They will survey their fellow students and otherwise engage in activities
 to surface class problems and opportunities. I will provide lunch, snacks of whatever form of
 bribery is necessary to help you help me to make this a great semester.
 Earning Points and Grading Policies
 In-lecture spot quizzes (100 points):
 Thirteen times in lecture I will give a two-minute quiz designed to be very easy for those who
 have prepared for class by reading the assigned material—and designed to be very challenging
 for those who did not do so. Each quiz will be worth up to ten points with partial credit given.
 Most of these one-item quizzes will ask you to state a definition or theorem in the required
 reading or, perhaps, to solve an elementary problem worked out in the assigned section of text.
 The ten highest scores will be added to determine your score in this category. Since there will be
 13 quizzes and only the top ten count, there will be no quiz makeups. Again, no make-ups will
 be offered for this point-earning category. Occasionally, the class assistant will grant you more
 than 10 points for superior work on your quiz, but your maximum total in this grading category
 remains 100 points.
 Homework (up to 100 points for book problems and up to 100 points for Quest problems):
 Learning calculus requires developing computational fluency with important algorithms,
 developing a deep conceptual understanding of a beautiful set of ideas, and learning to apply
 these ideas and algorithms to both classical and novel problems. You can only achieve this
 through lots of practice, made with pencil (and, often, graphing calculator) in hand. One way to
 organize this necessary work is by being diligent at doing homework. There’s lots of it; ain’t no
 way around that. There will be approximately 27 homework assignments, each of which will
 require approximately five hours of work.
 Each homework assignment will consist of the following:
 § 3–6 difficult problems assigned from the textbook. Your work must be submitted on
 8 ½ x 11” paper, stapled in the upper left corner. Be sure to include your name and
 section number on each page. This makes it easier for us to keep track of 130+
 students’ work.
 § Approximately 10–20 additional problems administered through the Quest Learning and
 Assessment System. The Quest website is available at http://quest.cns.utexas.edu.
 Required Notice Regarding Quest: This course makes use of the web-based Quest
 content delivery and homework server system maintained by the College of Natural
 Sciences at The University of Texas at Austin. This homework service will require a $25
 charge per student for its use, which goes toward the maintenance and operation of the
 resource. Please go to http://quest.cns.utexas.edu to log in to the Quest system for this
 class. At some point during the second or third week, when you log into Quest, you will
 be asked to pay via credit card on a secure payment site. You have the option to wait up
 to 15 days to pay while still continuing to use Quest for your assignments. If you are
 taking more than one course using Quest, you will not be charged more than
 $50/semester. Quest provides mandatory instructional material for this course, just as is
 your textbook, etc. For payment questions, email Write neatly!!! Reading homework assignments is painstakingly hard work. Be kind to the
 grader and to your professor, who will occasionally read a sample of homework papers. The
 grader has the authority to give zero points to illegible homework assignments.
 M408C Treisman Fall 2012 7
 Nota Bene: On each assignment from the textbook only one problem will be graded. You will
 not know which one it is in advance. Credit is given for the solution to a problem, not for the
 answer, which you will often be able to find in the back of the textbook.
 Each homework assignment on Quest is worth up to 5 points. If you score 100%, then you will
 earn 5 points. If you score 50%, then you will earn 2.5 points, etc..
 Your final homework score is the sum of your 20 highest homework grades from the textbook
 plus your 20 highest homework grades from Quest (maximum of 200 points).
 Chapter 2 Quiz (up to 100 points):
 This quiz will test your knowledge of the material on chapter 2.
 Midterm I: (up to 250 points):
 This midterm will consist of four questions on the material in Topics I and II.
 § Question 1 (4 parts, each worth 20 points, for a total of 80 points) will test your
 computational skills.
 § Question 2 (60 points) will be a modified version of an assigned (challenging)
 homework problem.
 § Question 3 (60 points) will be a modified version of a problem worked out in the
 assigned sections of the text.
 § Question 4 (50 points) A wild card!
 Midterm II: (up to 250 points):
 This midterm will consist of five questions on the material in Topics III, IV, inverse functions,
 and logarithms.
 § Question 1 (4 parts each worth 20 points for a total of 80 points). This question will test
 your computational skills.
 § Question 2 (40 points) will be a modified version of an assigned (challenging)
 homework problem.
 § Question 3 (40 points) will be a modified version of a problem worked out in the
 assigned sections of the text.
 § Question 4 (40 points) will be a modified version of a problem chosen from a list of 15
 hard problems that will be distributed two weeks before the examination.
 § Question 5 (50 points) A wild card!
 Final Examination (up to 300 points):
 The structure of the comprehensive final exam will be discussed in class.
 Exam Make-Up policy:
 Midterm I: If, for documented health reasons, a student misses Midterm I, then a make-up exam
 will be provided at a time convenient to both student and professor.
 Midterm II: If, for documented health reasons, a student misses Midterm II, then a make-up
 exam will be provided at a time convenient to both student and professor.
 Final Exam: If, for documented health reasons, a student misses the Final Exam, the student will
 receive an Incomplete in the course. The grade will be determined after the student completes a
 make-up final at a time convenient to both student and professor.
 Make-up examinations will be taken in Professor Treisman’s Dana Center office at
 1616 Guadalupe, Room 3.206 (UTA bldg) and will be proctored by Professor Treisman’s staff.
 Nota bene: No make-ups for in-class spot quizzes or for homeworks.
 M408C Treisman Fall 2012 8
 Discussion Section (up to 100 points):
 Your discussion section instructor will evaluate the quality of your participation in section. We
 expect you to come prepared to work on problems from the assigned reading, to collaborate with
 your classmates on hard problems, and to seek our help and extra challenges when needed. They
 may choose to give you quizzes or special assignments on which they base the number of points
 you earn in this category. These points, if any, will be awarded at the end of the semester.

 Agile Mind (up to 100 points of extra credit): Students will be given passwords to this online

 Students can earn up to 4 extra credit points for each online unit completed (up to a maximum of
 100 points), if the unit is completed by the announced deadline. A completed unit represents
 approx. 40–90 minutes of work. More information will be provided when the online system is
 demonstrated in class. Your work will be graded by the course Famulus minor and her decisions
