We expect these responses to be very short: 2-3 sentences should be more than adequate. Each item is worth 6 points, so that this section of the midterm is worth 30 points total.  Short Essays We will offer two or three potential essay prompts, from which you will write one essay. You should answer all elements of the prompt. We do not anticipate that you will need to write more than 4-5 paragraphs.  In General These exams are NOT cumulative.  The first exam will cover the reading and lecture material from the first day of class until the class immediately prior to the exam.  The last two exams will cover the material from the class immediately after the prior exam up until the class immediately before the scheduled exam.   Please note the dates and times of these exams and make sure that you are able to complete all exams. We will  consider  make-up  exams  for  students  with  compelling  (that  is,  university-sanctioned)  medical, educational,  or  personal  circumstances.  Please  be  prepared  to  offer  appropriate  documentation.  Also, please consult university guidelines on these matters, as standards and expectations are shifting in light of COVID-19.  Note also that we do NOT offer make-up exams simply because a particular exam time is inconvenient. Given the number of students enrolled in the course, this would be unfair as well as a logistical nightmare. Please contact us as soon as possible if there is a conflict.  
 6 Remember, the exam starts at 7:00 pm Central Time.  Please set up no later than 6:50 pm to insure that you have no technical issues. The exam ends promptly at 9:00 pm Central Time. We conduct the midterm exams online. We use the Proctorio test-taking tool, which requires that you use a Chrome browser AND that you install the Proctorio Chrome browser extension. Please see the following site for more information: https://wikis.utexas.edu/display/option3/Using+Proctorio+in+Canvas Students WILL be able to access the lecture outlines (PowerPoint slides) and their notes for the exams.  Students will NOT be able to access the lecture modules, webtext chapters, outside internet sites, or Google docs for the exams.  Weekly Update/In the News Quizzes As noted above, we will post a Weekly Update/In the News video most every Monday (beginning on Week 2; no video will be posted during the week of Spring Break). We will ask you to complete a brief quiz based on each of these videos. The quizzes consist of ten questions, and are worth a total of 10 points each. You will not be able to re-take the quiz; unlike the “Get the Gist” quizzes, your initial submitted response is your official answer. Your top 10 scores will determine your point total for this element of the course. Each quiz must be completed by 5:00 pm Central Time on the due date (Friday of the given week). Since you can drop your four low scores, we will not consider exceptions to these deadlines. If you cannot take the quiz due to extenuating circumstances, just use one of your “drop” scores.  Webtext Assignments The webtext will offer study questions and response boards that students will be asked to complete. Each chapter will be worth 10 points, with your top 10 chapter scores contributing to your point total for this element of the course. You must answer these “Get the Gist” questions correctly to receive credit. You may reset the answers to all the questions on a page if you answer any of them incorrectly, but you will only have 3 total attempts to answer each set of questions correctly. A numerical score based on the percentage of total questions answered correctly will constitute your Texas Politics reading grade. Each assignment must be submitted by 5:00 pm Central Time on the due date (Friday of the given week). Once again, since you can drop your four low scores, we will not consider exceptions to these deadlines. If you cannot do the webtext assignment due to extenuating circumstances, just use one of your “drop” scores.  The Grading Scale The grading scale is as follows:  Points Letter  Grade Points Letter  Grade Points Letter Grade 465-500 A 385-399.99 C+ 335-349.99 D+ 450-464.99 A- 365-384.99 C 315-334.99 D 435-449.99 B+ 350-364.99 C- 300-314.99 D- 415-434.99 B   0-299.99 F 400-414.99 B-      Please note that your grade is determined by your overall point total; percentages are used to determine the  cut-points,  but  are  otherwise  irrelevant  for  your  grade.  This  can  be  somewhat  confusing,  because Canvas automatically produces percentages in their grade scoring algorithms.  With respect to rounding, we typically round down when determining the cut-points. However, we do NOT then go ahead and round student point totals up. We can only take charity so far. In light of this, please refrain from asking us to “round up” your grade at the  end of the semester. We cannot do this without 

 7 offering the same to everyone else, and we are not prepared to thus destroy the integrity of the evaluative process.  Finally, we reserve the right to use a curve, which would take the top score in the course and “percentage” off of that number to determine cut-points. For example, say the top score were 495. We might then take 93% of this to set the A range at 460-500, the A- range at 445-459.99 (90% * 495), etc. We emphasize that students should NOT expect a curve; it is something that we occasionally use if we think it appropriate given the overall distribution of scores.  More information on this will come later in the class, if necessary.   Important Notes on Requirements and Evaluations • There is no final exam associated with this class. Final grades will be posted 48 hours prior to the official deadline from the College of Liberal Arts. • PLEASE NOTE: To receive credit for this course, students will need to…  o Complete all three midterm assignments, and  o Complete at least 7 Weekly Update/In the News quizzes, and   o Complete at least 7 webtext chapter assignments. These requirements are critical: Even if you have enough points for, say, a C in the course, you need to complete these assignments to pass. Failure to do so will result in a failing grade. • The readings, lectures, and short essay assignments are all designed to prepare you for the exams. There should be no surprises and you should do well if you do the readings, watch the videos, take notes, complete all short essay assignments, and pay attention to where you may need to allocate resources to studying.  Procedures for Dealing with Grade Concerns While we are always happy to discuss substantive issues and how to improve your performance in the class, we insist on a more formal process if you wish us to re-grade your work. There are only two legitimate reasons  for  a  re-grade  request.  First,  if you  wrote  something  that  was  correct  and  we  identified  it as incorrect. Second, if you wrote something that was clearly mischaracterized by us during evaluation. If you believe one or both of these situations pertains to your work, you can formally request that we re-grade a specific exam. Such a request must adhere to the following procedure: • The first step is to visit the TA who graded the assignment in office hours. A simple “face-to-face” may alleviate your questions or concerns.  • If you still think one or both of the two situations described above pertains, then you should proceed to a written request. All grade complaints must be TYPED and must clearly express the student’s specific  concerns.   These  written statements  must  be accompanied by citations  of  support  from course materials, i.e. readings, textbook, and/or lecture notes, in order to ensure accuracy. Please limit this statement  to one page.  These statements should be  submitted to Prof. Shaw and Prof. McDaniel. • Written  statements  may be  submitted  for  consideration AFTER one  week  has  passed  since  the assignment was returned to students. This allows the student time to re-read his/her answers and think carefully about what improvements could have been made. • Grade  complaints  will  not be considered once two  weeks have passed after the grade  has  been given.   For  example,  if we  return  a  graded  assignment  on  March  1st,  students  must  submit  a complaint BEFORE 5:00  PM  Central  Time  on  March  15th.   After  that  day,  no  complaints  will  be considered for that assignment. • Finally, submitting a grade grievance will result in a complete re-grade of the assignment. In other words, you cannot cherry-pick what we review. We will re-grade all responses. Just as we may have erred to your detriment on one item, we might have erred in your favor on another.  POLICY & PROCEDURES Thank You for Not... 1. Using profanity or any euphemisms for profanity; 
 8 2. Personally attacking other students; 3. Baiting other students; 4. Arguing for the sake of arguing; 5. Using hyperbole when something less will suffice; 6. Using sarcasm in a way that can be misinterpreted negatively; 7. Making the same point over and over again; 8. Typing "no-hitter" or "perfect game" to describe either in progress; 9. Being annoyed by the existence of this list; 10. Claiming your opinion isn't allowed when it's just being disagreed with; 11. Transmitting,  copying,  or  otherwise  distributing  lecture  material  without  our  expressed written consent.    STUDENTS WITH DISABILITIES Students  with  disabilities  may  request  appropriate  academic  accommodations  from  the  Division  of Diversity and Community Engagement, Services for Students with Disabilities at 471-6259 (voice) or 232-2937 (video phone) or http://diversity.utexas.edu/disability/.   ACADEMIC HONESTY The online course format allows us to monitor and detect issues involving identity verification, collusion, collaboration  and  plagiarism.  A  violation  of  the  course  policy  may  include  (but  is  not  limited  to)  the following: • Providing your UT EID to another person; • Collaborating  or  sharing  information  with  another  person  on  a  quiz,  writing  assignment,  or exercise;  • Recording any quiz, assessment or assignment material in any format; • Failing to properly cite ideas, data, or arguments that are not originally yours.  The University of Texas at Austin Academic Integrity Principles call for students to avoid engaging in any form of academic dishonesty on behalf of yourself or another student: http://deanofstudents.utexas.edu/conduct/index.php  Grade-related penalties are routinely assessed ("F" in the course is not uncommon), but students can also be suspended or even permanently expelled from the University for scholastic dishonesty: http://deanofstudents.utexas.edu/conduct/academicintegrity.php   Honor system for quizzes and assignments. By taking this class, you agree to abide by the University of Texas regulations concerning cheating.  While working on your activities, you  cannot receive help from others or discuss your short essay assignments with other students.  If you observe others cheating, you are honor bound to contact the teaching team.  TITLE IX REPORTING Title  IX is  a  federal  law  that  protects  against  sex  and  gender-based  discrimination,  sexual  harassment, sexual assault, sexual misconduct, dating/domestic violence and stalking at federally funded educational institutions.  UT  Austin  is  committed  to  fostering  a  learning  and  working  environment  free  from discrimination in all its forms. When sexual misconduct occurs in our community, the university can: 1. Intervene to prevent harmful behavior from continuing or escalating. 2. Provide  support  and  remedies  to  students  and  employees  who  have experienced  harm or have become involved in a Title IX investigation. 3. Investigate and discipline violations of the university’s relevant policies.   Faculty  members  and  certain  staff  members  are  considered  “Responsible Employees” or “Mandatory Reporters,”  which  means  that  they  are  required  to  report  violations  of  Title  IX to the  Title  IX Coordinator. We are Responsible Employees and must report any Title IX related incidents that are 

 9 disclosed in writing, discussion, or one-on-one. Before talking with us, or with any faculty or staff member about a Title IX related incident, be sure to ask whether they are a responsible employee. If you want to speak  with  someone  for  support  or  remedies  without  making  an  official  report  to the  university, . For  more  information  about  reporting  options  and  resources, visit titleix.utexas.edu or contact the Title IX Office at NTERNET RESOURCES  If you want to use the Internet to keep abreast of what’s happening in politics, we recommend the following sites:  Political News Sites Issues and the Basics cnn.com vote-smart.org nytimes.com archives.gov washingtonpost.com  latimes.com For the More Adventurous… onlinewsj.com fivethirtyeight.com realclearpolitics.com washingtonpost.com/blogs/monkey-cage/ politico.com pollingreport.com nationaljournal.com fec.gov texastribune.com      
 10 COURSE SCHEDULE*  Week  Dates Subject Assigned Readings/Videos/Podcasts Introduction Pre-Constitutional Government   The Constitution  The Constitution Texas: The Texas Constitution  Federalism  Federalism Texas: Federalism  Texas: Local Government Civil Liberties & Civil Rights  Civil Liberties & Civil Rights Stuff you Missed in History Class:  Texas Interest Groups  Interest Groups Texas: Interest Groups  FIRST MIDTERM EXAM Monday, The News Media   The News Media Media Business Matters Podcast: Local Media a Conversation with Texas Tribune CEO Evan Smith  Political Parties   Political Parties    Texas: Political Parties  Stuff You Missed in History Class: Alabama Governor George Wallace  

The Presidency  The Presidency & Bureaucracy Texas: The Governor  Texas: The Executive Branch The Courts Texas: The Judicial System  Texas: The Criminal Justice System   More Perfect: The Heist Whistlestop: The Bidding of Biden to Boo Bork Domestic Policy  Economic Policy Texas: Public Policy  : “We Let Our Readers Practice International Trade. They Started A Bunch of Trade Wars”.  Foreign Policy  THIRD MIDTERM EXAM Monday, *The webtext assignments for each week must be submitted by 5:00 PM CDT on the Friday.

Text:
HIST 2559, Fascism: A Global History
UVA, Spring 2021, MW 10:00-10:50AM (EST)
Co-Instructor: Co-Instructor: Teaching Assistant:
Manuela Achilles
ma6cq@virginia.edu
Office Hours: Tue, 9-11AM
Click here to schedule
Kyrill Kunakhovich
kmk5ss@virginia.edu
Office Hours: W 11-1
Click here to schedule
Lily van Diepen
lwv2wd@virginia.edu
Office Hours:
Click here to schedule
Course Description
This class investigates fascism as an ideology, movement, and regime in a global
framework. We will start our investigation with the cases of Mussolini’s Italy and Hitler’s
Germany before broadening our perspective to Francoist Spain, Shōwa Statism in
Japan, and more recent manifestations of (post-)fascism in Latin America, Europe, and
across the world. As we expand our understanding of the phenomenon, we will explore
the regional inflections of fascism (such as the genocidal antisemitism of German
National Socialism) and common characteristics (such fascism’s embrace of violence as
a means of politics). Thematic perspectives include: the origins and theories of fascism,
key terms in the fascist lexicon, motives that brought people to fascism, fascism as an
aesthetics and lived experience, and the role of women in fascism. We will also study
the historical articulations of antifascism, i.e. those groups and individuals who have
fought against fascism over the years.
Throughout this course, we will interrogate the term “fascism,” asking what it means -
and what it means for us to use it. Today, politicians of all stripes deride their opponents
as “fascists.” Is it possible to apply this term productively? How can we define fascism,
and what are the stakes of using such language? Is there a difference between fascist,
fascistic, and fascistoid? To paraphrase Gertrude Stein, is there a there there?
Upon successful completion of this course students will be able to:
 Identify and historicize fascism’s intellectual and sociopolitical origins, as well as
its major characteristics;
 Compare and contrast fascist ideologies and movements from the 19th century to
the present in a global framework;
 Recognize and analyze different interpretations of and approaches to fascism;
 Make connections between past and present, using history to inform our
understanding of current events;
 Complete writing exercises for different academic and professional purposes,
including (but not limited to) op-eds, think pieces, and research essays.
1
Mode of Instruction
This course will take place entirely online. All class meetings, discussion sections, and
office hours will be held via Zoom. If there is anything that makes it difficult for you to
participate – technology trouble, internet access, time zones – please talk to us as soon
as possible.
Most of our Monday meetings will consist of recorded lectures, though some that
feature guest speakers will be held synchronously. Please refer to the syllabus for
details and watch our Collab page for updates. Our Wednesday meetings are
synchronous and attendance is mandatory. Recordings will be available upon request to
students who have a valid excuse for missing a class.
To facilitate a safe environment that encourages the free exchange of ideas, smallgroup discussions and sections will not be recorded. If you have to miss a section,
please contact your teaching assistant to schedule a make-up assignment.
A Note on Online Education
In a traditional face-to-face class, you are expected to read the assigned materials
before coming to class. While in the classroom (about three hours a week), you listen to
lectures, participate in discussions and activities, interact with your peers, and take
quizzes/exams. You have several larger out-of-class assignments on top of that.
Online classes are as demanding as face-to-face classes: after all, they teach
equivalent content. This class, therefore, also requires you to read first. Then for about
three hours a week you attend synchronous and asynchronous online lectures,
participate in virtual discussions, and complete online mini assignments. You also have
several larger out-of-class assignments on top of that.
It will be up to you, the students, to manage your time effectively, and to make sure that
you are setting aside the time each week to complete the readings and assignments on
time. We, your teaching team, will support you every step along the way. Please do not
hesitate to contact us if you have questions, need special accommodations, or would
like to chat about class topics.
All our class materials, with the exception of the required books, are available through
Collab. Collab is also where we will post updates, extra credit opportunities, and
potential tweaks to the syllabus - so watch the space closely.
This course covers war and genocide, as well as other violent historical events and
practices. We ask all students to help create an atmosphere of mutual respect and
sensitivity. When using our virtual classroom spaces, please adhere to the following
expectations for classroom conduct:
2
 Come prepared: do the readings, pay attention, and participate. Encourage
others to do the same.
 Listen: keep an open mind and let others present their reasoning and opinions.
Contribute to the discussion at hand, rather than taking the conversation off topic.
 Debate: share your point of view and encourage different perspectives. Tackle
the idea instead of the person.
 Respect diversity: use respectful language and avoid personal attacks and
assumptions about peoples’ backgrounds. Give others the benefit of the doubt by
not taking different opinions personally.
 Question: encourage debate and try to see things from different perspectives.
There is no such thing as a bad question.
This year more than ever, our class depends on your full participation. While on Zoom,
please refrain from using your computer for anything other than academic work. This
includes emailing, messaging, texting, txtng, skyping, google-earthing, facebooking,
myspacing, yourspacing, just spacing out, blogging, vlogging, twittering, tweeting,
surfing, turfing, yahooing, googling, giggling (might be okay in some circumstances),
snapchatting, pin-ing, pinteresting, tumblering, linking-in, linking-out, selfie-ing, and any
other social media-ting that we don’t yet know about. We’ll be watching!
If you feel comfortable, please leave the camera on during our course sessions. So
much of community is built in how we react to each other. Zoom is no substitute for
physical interaction, but at least with the video feature it doesn’t feel as though you are
speaking into a void.
Assignments and Grading
This class emphasizes continuous engagement with the weekly readings, discussions,
and lectures. There are six primary elements to the course requirements and
expectations.
15% Class engagement (attendance, participation, presentation, posts; graded
holistically)
5% Map quiz
25% Weekly responses (to be collected in an electronic learning portfolio)
15% Reflections on the portfolio (two-page midterm; thee-page final)
15% Take-home midterm exam (essay with a prompt or source analysis)
25% Final essay/op-ed (students taking the class C/NC can take the final exam
instead)
[25%] Optional final exam
Attendance: You should come to every class and section, read all assigned materials,
and watch any films or recorded lectures ahead of time. While we recognize the
volatility of our lives in these complicated times, we ask you to arrive to synchronous
meetings on time. Switch on your camera if you can. Please notify us of any technical
3
issues or changes in your health and environment that may make staying connected
difficult. We are here to support you!
Participation: This class depends on your active participation. Your contributions are
productive when you listen with an open mind, ask thoughtful questions, offer insightful
comments, note relevant passages in texts or films, and point out connections between
ideas.
Presentation: Once during the semester, you will be asked to make an oral presentation
in section. This will involve introducing a brief text and raising questions for discussion.
Your presentation should last about five minutes and will be integrated into our Zoom
meetings. Alternatively, you may submit your presentation in the form of a nonsynchronous PowerPoint video. Click here for instructions on how to convert
PowerPoint presentations into videos (it’s easy): https://www.youtube.com/watch?
 v=AGSk_ynrvTA.
Discussion Board: An online discussion board is one more way for you to contribute to
our class discussions. You can use it to raise a question; to make a comment on the
lecture or in-class conversation; or to post a link to a relevant news article. You can also
respond to your classmates’ posts, not just with “likes” but with substantive comments.
You should visit the discussion board at least once a week, and ideally more;
participation in this virtual space is a key aspect of our class discussion. Please
remember to be as courteous and respectful online as you are in the classroom.
Map Quiz: in section on Thursday, February 18, you will have a brief map quiz (20
minutes) on the geography of Europe and the world. You will be given a list of countries,
cities, and natural features that are important to the subject of this course, and you’ll be
asked to identify these on a blank map.
Weekly Responses: each week, you will submit a one-page (300-450 words) written
response to that week’s readings, lectures, and discussions. Your response should not
summarize these materials, but rather connect them to the main themes of the class.
How do each week’s materials shape your understanding of fascism? What new
aspects and/or experiences of fascism do they illuminate? What lessons can we draw
from them?
Your responses will receive check marks, indicating whether they did (or did not) fulfill
expectations. To receive full credit for this assignment, each response should:
 identify and develop at least one idea or theme,
 directly connect to the weekly course readings and discussions,
 demonstrate critical reflection and original thought.
Your weekly responses must be posted under the “Assignments” tab on Collab by the
end of the day (11:59 PM EST) on Wednesdays. Collab will not accept late responses.
Please contact your TA if you experience any problems with this assignment.
4
Portfolio: Over the course of the semester, you will write ten weekly responses in all. At
two points, we will ask you to re-read all the entries you’ve written and compile them
into a portfolio with a short (2-3 page) introduction. This portfolio will allow you to reflect
on the evolution of your own thinking and flesh out your understanding of what fascism
is and does. Your midterm portfolio is due on Wednesday, March 10, at 11:59PM (EST);
the final version is due on Wednesday, May 5, at 11:59PM (EST). As with all
assignments for this class, this is not the place for flattery or arguments you don’t
believe in.
Midterm Exam: You will have a take-home final exam due on Thursday, April 1, at
11:59PM (EST). It will consist of short answer and essay questions covering all the
material we’ve studied by that point in the course.
Final paper: Your final paper in this course is an opinion piece, or op-ed, that draws on
everything you’ve learned in this class to make an argument about current events. It is
due on Thursday, May 13, at 11:59PM (EST). Students who are taking this class on a
Credit/No Credit basis have the option of taking a final exam instead of the final paper.
Final Exam (optional): The final exam will include multiple-choice questions,
identifications, and short essay prompts. Its main purpose is to give credit/no credit
students the option to conclude the class with an alternative assignment. Students who
are taking this class for a letter grade are welcome to take the final exam, but they must
still submit a final paper. If you choose to complete both a final paper and a final exam,
the average of those two grades will account for 25% of the total.
Extra Credit: There will be several opportunities to earn extra credit over the course of
the semester, by attending (virtual) events or watching extra films and lectures - and
then writing brief responses to them. Stay tuned for more information. You can improve
your final grade by at most three percent (3%) through three extra credits (1% for each
extra credit activity), i.e. B → B+ or B+ → A-. To receive the maximum extra credit of
three percent (3%), you need to hand in three individual short assignments.
Rules and Policies
Grading Policy: Your written work will be assessed for clarity, originality, organization,
and the effective use of evidence from the readings, films, lectures and discussions. The
penalty for late papers is 1/3 of a letter grade for each 24 hours the work is overdue.
Late weekly responses will not be accepted without a valid excuse, but they can be
included in your learning portfolio for partial credit. Exceptions will be granted on the
grounds of documented illness or personal emergency.
If you are concerned about meeting any of the deadlines, please notify us well ahead of
time or as soon as you can. You will receive more information on all assignments as we
get closer to their due dates.
Academic Integrity: We trust that all work turned in for this class was composed
exclusively for this class, and that all wording and ideas presented in any written work
5
are your own. Always cite any sources and resources you use and be sure to use
bibliographic citations. Plagiarism is a serious academic offence. Definitions of what it is
and how to avoid it can be found at: https://guides.lib.virginia.edu/c.php?
g=535505&p=3663691.
When collaborating with other students, do not copy their answers. Always acknowledge
the individuals you consulted to complete an assignment and detail the nature of their
input. If you have a question about what is or is not permitted on an assignment, you
should clarify your question with your instructors prior to doing the work.
The Bylaws of the Honor Committee define an Honor offense as “a Significant Act of
Lying, Cheating or Stealing, which Act is committed with Knowledge.” By enrolling into
this class, you pledge to adhere to UVa’s Honor Code. If you believe you may have
committed an Honor Offense, you may wish to file a Conscientious Retraction (“CR”) by
calling the Honor Offices at (434) 924-7602. For your retraction to be considered valid, it
must, among other things, be filed with the Honor Committee before you are aware that
the act in question has come under suspicion by anyone. More information about UVa’s
Honor Code can be found at: https://honor.virginia.edu/.
Copyright: You may not record, download, alter, and/or distribute class lectures, lecture
slides, or any other element of this class. We will consider violations of this policy a
“significant act of stealing” and thus an honor offence. Violations of these terms may
also be subject to disciplinary action under the University’s Standards of Conduct; for
details, see https://ujc.virginia.edu/.
Your Safety and Wellbeing
We are living through the greatest public health emergency this country has seen in
over a century. Please stay safe and do your part to slow the rate of transmission. This
involves complying with all state and local regulations; following university policies; and
being courteous, considerate, and compassionate towards others.
It also means that little about this semester will be “normal.” Learning online is still a
fairly new experience for all of us, and it will require some trial and error. Lecture
formats, readings, and even assignments may all change as we go along; we’ll give you
as much notice as we can, and hope that you’ll bear with us. We also ask for your
feedback: what’s working, what’s not, and what we can do better. Feel free to email us,
or use the Anonymous Feedback tab on Collab.
We recognize that this semester brings new challenges and stresses. Here are a
number of ways to get help:
Instructor Support: Feel free to schedule individual Zoom or Skype sessions with us to
discuss drafts, ideas, and our comments on your work. We also understand that
personal circumstances or unforeseen events can interfere with your academic
responsibilities. We can meet during office hours or by appointment to discuss any
6
aspect of the course, difficulties you may be experiencing, or suggestions for making
the course more accessible.
The Writing Center offers online appointments in non-synchronous mode. Good writers
know that another pair of eyes on their work is always helpful.
The Student Disability Access Center offers a range of remote services including
assessments, consultations, and support with accommodations. We always make
accommodations for students with documented disabilities. Students should notify us
and the SDAC (sdac@virginia.edu) of disability-related needs.
UVA libraries feature many helpful staff members and librarians who can help you with
your research. One name to keep in mind is Keith Weimer (kw6m@virginia.edu),
Alderman’s research librarian for History, Politics, and Religious Studies. Mr. Weimer
knows everything about the library’s resources, both on paper and online. Do not
hesitate to contact him or his colleagues; they’re eager to hear from you!
The Office of the Dean of Students provides a list of resources that can help if you are
experiencing mental health, housing, safety, or food insecurity issues.
If you or someone you know has experienced or witnessed incidents of bias, hazing, or
sexual or gender-based violence, go to https://justreportit.virginia.edu/ to report such
behaviors. Please note that your instructors are “responsible employees,” which means
that they are required to report issues of violence to the University.
Confidential employees are available if you want to discuss an issue related to violence
in depth but want it to remain confidential.
Covid-19 resources for students are available at:
https://college.as.virginia.edu/COVID19help.
A list of mental health resources is available here:
https://www.studenthealth.virginia.edu/sites/studenthealth.virginia.edu/files/UVaMHReso
urcesWebsiteFinal.pdf.
7
Course Materials
Required texts, available for purchase at the UVa Bookstore:
 Kevin Passmore: Fascism: A Very Short Introduction (Oxford: Oxford University
Press, second, revised edition, 2014)
 Jason Stanley: How Fascism Works: The Politics of Us and Them (New York:
Random House, 2018)
 Marla Stone: The Fascist Revolution in Italy: A Brief History with Documents
(Boston: Bedford/St. Martin’s Press, 2013)
 James Q. Whitman: Hitler’s American Model: The United States and the Making
of Nazi Race Law (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 2017);
 Primo Levi: Survival in Auschwitz (New York: Touchstone, 1996 [1947]).
Primary Sources, on Collab:

HIST 2559, Fascism: A Global History
 UVA, Spring 2021, MW 10:00-10:50AM (EST)
 Co-Instructor: Co-Instructor: Teaching Assistant:

 Office Hours: Tue, 9-11AM
 Click here to schedule

 Office Hours: W 11-1
 Click here to schedule

 Office Hours:
 Click here to schedule
 Course Description
 This class investigates fascism as an ideology, movement, and regime in a global
 framework. We will start our investigation with the cases of Mussolini’s Italy and Hitler’s
 Germany before broadening our perspective to Francoist Spain, Shōwa Statism in
 Japan, and more recent manifestations of (post-)fascism in Latin America, Europe, and
 across the world. As we expand our understanding of the phenomenon, we will explore
 the regional inflections of fascism (such as the genocidal antisemitism of German
 National Socialism) and common characteristics (such fascism’s embrace of violence as
 a means of politics). Thematic perspectives include: the origins and theories of fascism,
 key terms in the fascist lexicon, motives that brought people to fascism, fascism as an
 aesthetics and lived experience, and the role of women in fascism. We will also study
 the historical articulations of antifascism, i.e. those groups and individuals who have
 fought against fascism over the years.
 Throughout this course, we will interrogate the term “fascism,” asking what it means -
 and what it means for us to use it. Today, politicians of all stripes deride their opponents
 as “fascists.” Is it possible to apply this term productively? How can we define fascism,
 and what are the stakes of using such language? Is there a difference between fascist,
 fascistic, and fascistoid? To paraphrase Gertrude Stein, is there a there there?
 Upon successful completion of this course students will be able to:
 · Identify and historicize fascism’s intellectual and sociopolitical origins, as well as
 its major characteristics;
 · Compare and contrast fascist ideologies and movements from the 19th century to
 the present in a global framework;
 · Recognize and analyze different interpretations of and approaches to fascism;
 · Make connections between past and present, using history to inform our
 understanding of current events;
 · Complete writing exercises for different academic and professional purposes,
 including (but not limited to) op-eds, think pieces, and research essays.
 1
 Mode of Instruction
 This course will take place entirely online. All class meetings, discussion sections, and
 office hours will be held via Zoom. If there is anything that makes it difficult for you to
 participate – technology trouble, internet access, time zones – please talk to us as soon
 as possible.
 Most of our Monday meetings will consist of recorded lectures, though some that
 feature guest speakers will be held synchronously. Please refer to the syllabus for
 details and watch our Collab page for updates. Our Wednesday meetings are
 synchronous and attendance is mandatory. Recordings will be available upon request to
 students who have a valid excuse for missing a class.
 To facilitate a safe environment that encourages the free exchange of ideas, smallgroup discussions and sections will not be recorded. If you have to miss a section,
 please contact your teaching assistant to schedule a make-up assignment.
 A Note on Online Education
 In a traditional face-to-face class, you are expected to read the assigned materials
 before coming to class. While in the classroom (about three hours a week), you listen to
 lectures, participate in discussions and activities, interact with your peers, and take
 quizzes/exams. You have several larger out-of-class assignments on top of that.
 Online classes are as demanding as face-to-face classes: after all, they teach
 equivalent content. This class, therefore, also requires you to read first. Then for about
 three hours a week you attend synchronous and asynchronous online lectures,
 participate in virtual discussions, and complete online mini assignments. You also have
 several larger out-of-class assignments on top of that.
 It will be up to you, the students, to manage your time effectively, and to make sure that
 you are setting aside the time each week to complete the readings and assignments on
 time. We, your teaching team, will support you every step along the way. Please do not
 hesitate to contact us if you have questions, need special accommodations, or would
 like to chat about class topics.
 All our class materials, with the exception of the required books, are available through
 Collab. Collab is also where we will post updates, extra credit opportunities, and
 potential tweaks to the syllabus - so watch the space closely.
 This course covers war and genocide, as well as other violent historical events and
 practices. We ask all students to help create an atmosphere of mutual respect and
 sensitivity. When using our virtual classroom spaces, please adhere to the following
 expectations for classroom conduct:
 2
 · Come prepared: do the readings, pay attention, and participate. Encourage
 others to do the same.
 · Listen: keep an open mind and let others present their reasoning and opinions.
 Contribute to the discussion at hand, rather than taking the conversation off topic.
 · Debate: share your point of view and encourage different perspectives. Tackle
 the idea instead of the person.
 · Respect diversity: use respectful language and avoid personal attacks and
 assumptions about peoples’ backgrounds. Give others the benefit of the doubt by
 not taking different opinions personally.
 · Question: encourage debate and try to see things from different perspectives.
 There is no such thing as a bad question.
 This year more than ever, our class depends on your full participation. While on Zoom,
 please refrain from using your computer for anything other than academic work. This
 includes emailing, messaging, texting, txtng, skyping, google-earthing, facebooking,
 myspacing, yourspacing, just spacing out, blogging, vlogging, twittering, tweeting,
 surfing, turfing, yahooing, googling, giggling (might be okay in some circumstances),
 snapchatting, pin-ing, pinteresting, tumblering, linking-in, linking-out, selfie-ing, and any
 other social media-ting that we don’t yet know about. We’ll be watching!
 If you feel comfortable, please leave the camera on during our course sessions. So
 much of community is built in how we react to each other. Zoom is no substitute for
 physical interaction, but at least with the video feature it doesn’t feel as though you are
 speaking into a void.
 Assignments and Grading
 This class emphasizes continuous engagement with the weekly readings, discussions,
 and lectures. There are six primary elements to the course requirements and
 expectations.
 15% Class engagement (attendance, participation, presentation, posts; graded
 holistically)
 5% Map quiz
 25% Weekly responses (to be collected in an electronic learning portfolio)
 15% Reflections on the portfolio (two-page midterm; thee-page final)
 15% Take-home midterm exam (essay with a prompt or source analysis)
 25% Final essay/op-ed (students taking the class C/NC can take the final exam
 instead)
 [25%] Optional final exam
 Attendance: You should come to every class and section, read all assigned materials,
 and watch any films or recorded lectures ahead of time. While we recognize the
 volatility of our lives in these complicated times, we ask you to arrive to synchronous
 meetings on time. Switch on your camera if you can. Please notify us of any technical
 3
 issues or changes in your health and environment that may make staying connected
 difficult. We are here to support you!
 Participation: This class depends on your active participation. Your contributions are
 productive when you listen with an open mind, ask thoughtful questions, offer insightful
 comments, note relevant passages in texts or films, and point out connections between
 ideas.
 Presentation: Once during the semester, you will be asked to make an oral presentation
 in section. This will involve introducing a brief text and raising questions for discussion.
 Your presentation should last about five minutes and will be integrated into our Zoom
 meetings. Alternatively, you may submit your presentation in the form of a nonsynchronous PowerPoint video. Click here for instructions on how to convert
 PowerPoint presentations into videos (it’s easy): https://www.youtube.com/watch?
  v=AGSk_ynrvTA.
 Discussion Board: An online discussion board is one more way for you to contribute to
 our class discussions. You can use it to raise a question; to make a comment on the
 lecture or in-class conversation; or to post a link to a relevant news article. You can also
 respond to your classmates’ posts, not just with “likes” but with substantive comments.
 You should visit the discussion board at least once a week, and ideally more;
 participation in this virtual space is a key aspect of our class discussion. Please
 remember to be as courteous and respectful online as you are in the classroom.
 Map Quiz: in section on Thursday, February 18, you will have a brief map quiz (20
 minutes) on the geography of Europe and the world. You will be given a list of countries,
 cities, and natural features that are important to the subject of this course, and you’ll be
 asked to identify these on a blank map.
 Weekly Responses: each week, you will submit a one-page (300-450 words) written
 response to that week’s readings, lectures, and discussions. Your response should not
 summarize these materials, but rather connect them to the main themes of the class.
 How do each week’s materials shape your understanding of fascism? What new
 aspects and/or experiences of fascism do they illuminate? What lessons can we draw
 from them?
 Your responses will receive check marks, indicating whether they did (or did not) fulfill
 expectations. To receive full credit for this assignment, each response should:
 · identify and develop at least one idea or theme,
 · directly connect to the weekly course readings and discussions,
 · demonstrate critical reflection and original thought.
 Your weekly responses must be posted under the “Assignments” tab on Collab by the
 end of the day (11:59 PM EST) on Wednesdays. Collab will not accept late responses.
 Please contact your TA if you experience any problems with this assignment.
 4
 Portfolio: Over the course of the semester, you will write ten weekly responses in all. At
 two points, we will ask you to re-read all the entries you’ve written and compile them
 into a portfolio with a short (2-3 page) introduction. This portfolio will allow you to reflect
 on the evolution of your own thinking and flesh out your understanding of what fascism
 is and does. Your midterm portfolio is due on Wednesday, March 10, at 11:59PM (EST);
 the final version is due on Wednesday, May 5, at 11:59PM (EST). As with all
 assignments for this class, this is not the place for flattery or arguments you don’t
 believe in.
 Midterm Exam: You will have a take-home final exam due on Thursday, April 1, at
 11:59PM (EST). It will consist of short answer and essay questions covering all the
 material we’ve studied by that point in the course.
 Final paper: Your final paper in this course is an opinion piece, or op-ed, that draws on
 everything you’ve learned in this class to make an argument about current events. It is
 due on Thursday, May 13, at 11:59PM (EST). Students who are taking this class on a
 Credit/No Credit basis have the option of taking a final exam instead of the final paper.
 Final Exam (optional): The final exam will include multiple-choice questions,
 identifications, and short essay prompts. Its main purpose is to give credit/no credit
 students the option to conclude the class with an alternative assignment. Students who
 are taking this class for a letter grade are welcome to take the final exam, but they must
 still submit a final paper. If you choose to complete both a final paper and a final exam,
 the average of those two grades will account for 25% of the total.
 Extra Credit: There will be several opportunities to earn extra credit over the course of
 the semester, by attending (virtual) events or watching extra films and lectures - and
 then writing brief responses to them. Stay tuned for more information. You can improve
 your final grade by at most three percent (3%) through three extra credits (1% for each
 extra credit activity), i.e. B → B+ or B+ → A-. To receive the maximum extra credit of
 three percent (3%), you need to hand in three individual short assignments.
 Rules and Policies
 Grading Policy: Your written work will be assessed for clarity, originality, organization,
 and the effective use of evidence from the readings, films, lectures and discussions. The
 penalty for late papers is 1/3 of a letter grade for each 24 hours the work is overdue.
 Late weekly responses will not be accepted without a valid excuse, but they can be
 included in your learning portfolio for partial credit. Exceptions will be granted on the
 grounds of documented illness or personal emergency.
 If you are concerned about meeting any of the deadlines, please notify us well ahead of
 time or as soon as you can. You will receive more information on all assignments as we
 get closer to their due dates.
 Academic Integrity: We trust that all work turned in for this class was composed
 exclusively for this class, and that all wording and ideas presented in any written work
 5
 are your own. Always cite any sources and resources you use and be sure to use
 bibliographic citations. Plagiarism is a serious academic offence. Definitions of what it is
 and how to avoid it can be found at: https://guides.lib.virginia.edu/c.php?
 g=535505&p=3663691.
 When collaborating with other students, do not copy their answers. Always acknowledge
 the individuals you consulted to complete an assignment and detail the nature of their
 input. If you have a question about what is or is not permitted on an assignment, you
 should clarify your question with your instructors prior to doing the work.
 The Bylaws of the Honor Committee define an Honor offense as “a Significant Act of
 Lying, Cheating or Stealing, which Act is committed with Knowledge.” By enrolling into
 this class, you pledge to adhere to UVa’s Honor Code. If you believe you may have
 committed an Honor Offense, you may wish to file a Conscientious Retraction (“CR”) by
 calling the Honor Offices at (434) 924-7602. For your retraction to be considered valid, it
 must, among other things, be filed with the Honor Committee before you are aware that
 the act in question has come under suspicion by anyone. More information about UVa’s
 Honor Code can be found at: https://honor.virginia.edu/.
 Copyright: You may not record, download, alter, and/or distribute class lectures, lecture
 slides, or any other element of this class. We will consider violations of this policy a
 “significant act of stealing” and thus an honor offence. Violations of these terms may
 also be subject to disciplinary action under the University’s Standards of Conduct; for
 details, see https://ujc.virginia.edu/.
 Your Safety and Wellbeing
 We are living through the greatest public health emergency this country has seen in
 over a century. Please stay safe and do your part to slow the rate of transmission. This
 involves complying with all state and local regulations; following university policies; and
 being courteous, considerate, and compassionate towards others.
 It also means that little about this semester will be “normal.” Learning online is still a
 fairly new experience for all of us, and it will require some trial and error. Lecture
 formats, readings, and even assignments may all change as we go along; we’ll give you
 as much notice as we can, and hope that you’ll bear with us. We also ask for your
 feedback: what’s working, what’s not, and what we can do better. Feel free to email us,
 or use the Anonymous Feedback tab on Collab.
 We recognize that this semester brings new challenges and stresses. Here are a
 number of ways to get help:
 Instructor Support: Feel free to schedule individual Zoom or Skype sessions with us to
 discuss drafts, ideas, and our comments on your work. We also understand that
 personal circumstances or unforeseen events can interfere with your academic
 responsibilities. We can meet during office hours or by appointment to discuss any
 6
 aspect of the course, difficulties you may be experiencing, or suggestions for making
 the course more accessible.
 The Writing Center offers online appointments in non-synchronous mode. Good writers
 know that another pair of eyes on their work is always helpful.
 The Student Disability Access Center offers a range of remote services including
 assessments, consultations, and support with accommodations. We always make
 accommodations for students with documented disabilities. Students should notify us
 and the SDAC of disability-related needs.
 UVA libraries feature many helpful staff members and librarians who can help you with
 your research. One name to keep in mind is Keith Weimer Alderman’s research librarian for History, Politics, and Religious Studies. Mr. Weimer
 knows everything about the library’s resources, both on paper and online. Do not
 hesitate to contact him or his colleagues; they’re eager to hear from you!
 The Office of the Dean of Students provides a list of resources that can help if you are
 experiencing mental health, housing, safety, or food insecurity issues.
 If you or someone you know has experienced or witnessed incidents of bias, hazing, or
 sexual or gender-based violence, go to https://justreportit.virginia.edu/ to report such
 behaviors. Please note that your instructors are “responsible employees,” which means

 Confidential employees are available if you want to discuss an issue related to violence

Pre-processed text 2:
HIST 2559, Fascism: A Global History
 UVA, Spring 2021, MW 10:00-10:50AM (EST)
 Co-Instructor: Co-Instructor: Teaching Assistant:

 Office Hours: Tue, 9-11AM
 Click here to schedule

 Office Hours: W 11-1
 Click here to schedule

 Office Hours:
 Click here to schedule
 Course Description
 This class investigates fascism as an ideology, movement, and regime in a global
 framework. We will start our investigation with the cases of Mussolini’s Italy and Hitler’s
 Germany before broadening our perspective to Francoist Spain, Shōwa Statism in
 Japan, and more recent manifestations of (post-)fascism in Latin America, Europe, and
 across the world. As we expand our understanding of the phenomenon, we will explore
 the regional inflections of fascism (such as the genocidal antisemitism of German
 National Socialism) and common characteristics (such fascism’s embrace of violence as
 a means of politics). Thematic perspectives include: the origins and theories of fascism,
 key terms in the fascist lexicon, motives that brought people to fascism, fascism as an
 aesthetics and lived experience, and the role of women in fascism. We will also study
 the historical articulations of antifascism, i.e. those groups and individuals who have
 fought against fascism over the years.
 Throughout this course, we will interrogate the term “fascism,” asking what it means -
 and what it means for us to use it. Today, politicians of all stripes deride their opponents
 as “fascists.” Is it possible to apply this term productively? How can we define fascism,
 and what are the stakes of using such language? Is there a difference between fascist,
 fascistic, and fascistoid? To paraphrase Gertrude Stein, is there a there there?
 Upon successful completion of this course students will be able to:
 · Identify and historicize fascism’s intellectual and sociopolitical origins, as well as
 its major characteristics;
 · Compare and contrast fascist ideologies and movements from the 19th century to
 the present in a global framework;
 · Recognize and analyze different interpretations of and approaches to fascism;
 · Make connections between past and present, using history to inform our
 understanding of current events;
 · Complete writing exercises for different academic and professional purposes,
 including (but not limited to) op-eds, think pieces, and research essays.
 1
 Mode of Instruction
 This course will take place entirely online. All class meetings, discussion sections, and
 office hours will be held via Zoom. If there is anything that makes it difficult for you to
 participate – technology trouble, internet access, time zones – please talk to us as soon
 as possible.
 Most of our Monday meetings will consist of recorded lectures, though some that
 feature guest speakers will be held synchronously. Please refer to the syllabus for
 details and watch our Collab page for updates. Our Wednesday meetings are
 synchronous and attendance is mandatory. Recordings will be available upon request to
 students who have a valid excuse for missing a class.
 To facilitate a safe environment that encourages the free exchange of ideas, smallgroup discussions and sections will not be recorded. If you have to miss a section,
 please contact your teaching assistant to schedule a make-up assignment.
 A Note on Online Education
 In a traditional face-to-face class, you are expected to read the assigned materials
 before coming to class. While in the classroom (about three hours a week), you listen to
 lectures, participate in discussions and activities, interact with your peers, and take
 quizzes/exams. You have several larger out-of-class assignments on top of that.
 Online classes are as demanding as face-to-face classes: after all, they teach
 equivalent content. This class, therefore, also requires you to read first. Then for about
 three hours a week you attend synchronous and asynchronous online lectures,
 participate in virtual discussions, and complete online mini assignments. You also have
 several larger out-of-class assignments on top of that.
 It will be up to you, the students, to manage your time effectively, and to make sure that
 you are setting aside the time each week to complete the readings and assignments on
 time. We, your teaching team, will support you every step along the way. Please do not
 hesitate to contact us if you have questions, need special accommodations, or would
 like to chat about class topics.
 All our class materials, with the exception of the required books, are available through
 Collab. Collab is also where we will post updates, extra credit opportunities, and
 potential tweaks to the syllabus - so watch the space closely.
 This course covers war and genocide, as well as other violent historical events and
 practices. We ask all students to help create an atmosphere of mutual respect and
 sensitivity. When using our virtual classroom spaces, please adhere to the following
 expectations for classroom conduct:
 2
 · Come prepared: do the readings, pay attention, and participate. Encourage
 others to do the same.
 · Listen: keep an open mind and let others present their reasoning and opinions.
 Contribute to the discussion at hand, rather than taking the conversation off topic.
 · Debate: share your point of view and encourage different perspectives. Tackle
 the idea instead of the person.
 · Respect diversity: use respectful language and avoid personal attacks and
 assumptions about peoples’ backgrounds. Give others the benefit of the doubt by
 not taking different opinions personally.
 · Question: encourage debate and try to see things from different perspectives.
 There is no such thing as a bad question.
 This year more than ever, our class depends on your full participation. While on Zoom,
 please refrain from using your computer for anything other than academic work. This
 includes emailing, messaging, texting, txtng, skyping, google-earthing, facebooking,
 myspacing, yourspacing, just spacing out, blogging, vlogging, twittering, tweeting,
 surfing, turfing, yahooing, googling, giggling (might be okay in some circumstances),
 snapchatting, pin-ing, pinteresting, tumblering, linking-in, linking-out, selfie-ing, and any
 other social media-ting that we don’t yet know about. We’ll be watching!
 If you feel comfortable, please leave the camera on during our course sessions. So
 much of community is built in how we react to each other. Zoom is no substitute for
 physical interaction, but at least with the video feature it doesn’t feel as though you are
 speaking into a void.
 Assignments and Grading
 This class emphasizes continuous engagement with the weekly readings, discussions,
 and lectures. There are six primary elements to the course requirements and
 expectations.
 15% Class engagement (attendance, participation, presentation, posts; graded
 holistically)
 5% Map quiz
 25% Weekly responses (to be collected in an electronic learning portfolio)
 15% Reflections on the portfolio (two-page midterm; thee-page final)
 15% Take-home midterm exam (essay with a prompt or source analysis)
 25% Final essay/op-ed (students taking the class C/NC can take the final exam
 instead)
 [25%] Optional final exam
 Attendance: You should come to every class and section, read all assigned materials,
 and watch any films or recorded lectures ahead of time. While we recognize the
 volatility of our lives in these complicated times, we ask you to arrive to synchronous
 meetings on time. Switch on your camera if you can. Please notify us of any technical
 3
 issues or changes in your health and environment that may make staying connected
 difficult. We are here to support you!
 Participation: This class depends on your active participation. Your contributions are
 productive when you listen with an open mind, ask thoughtful questions, offer insightful
 comments, note relevant passages in texts or films, and point out connections between
 ideas.
 Presentation: Once during the semester, you will be asked to make an oral presentation
 in section. This will involve introducing a brief text and raising questions for discussion.
 Your presentation should last about five minutes and will be integrated into our Zoom
 meetings. Alternatively, you may submit your presentation in the form of a nonsynchronous PowerPoint video. Click here for instructions on how to convert
 PowerPoint presentations into videos (it’s easy): https://www.youtube.com/watch?
  v=AGSk_ynrvTA.
 Discussion Board: An online discussion board is one more way for you to contribute to
 our class discussions. You can use it to raise a question; to make a comment on the
 lecture or in-class conversation; or to post a link to a relevant news article. You can also
 respond to your classmates’ posts, not just with “likes” but with substantive comments.
 You should visit the discussion board at least once a week, and ideally more;
 participation in this virtual space is a key aspect of our class discussion. Please
 remember to be as courteous and respectful online as you are in the classroom.
 Map Quiz: in section on Thursday, February 18, you will have a brief map quiz (20
 minutes) on the geography of Europe and the world. You will be given a list of countries,
 cities, and natural features that are important to the subject of this course, and you’ll be
 asked to identify these on a blank map.
 Weekly Responses: each week, you will submit a one-page (300-450 words) written
 response to that week’s readings, lectures, and discussions. Your response should not
 summarize these materials, but rather connect them to the main themes of the class.
 How do each week’s materials shape your understanding of fascism? What new
 aspects and/or experiences of fascism do they illuminate? What lessons can we draw
 from them?
 Your responses will receive check marks, indicating whether they did (or did not) fulfill
 expectations. To receive full credit for this assignment, each response should:
 · identify and develop at least one idea or theme,
 · directly connect to the weekly course readings and discussions,
 · demonstrate critical reflection and original thought.
 Your weekly responses must be posted under the “Assignments” tab on Collab by the
 end of the day (11:59 PM EST) on Wednesdays. Collab will not accept late responses.
 Please contact your TA if you experience any problems with this assignment.
 4
 Portfolio: Over the course of the semester, you will write ten weekly responses in all. At
 two points, we will ask you to re-read all the entries you’ve written and compile them
 into a portfolio with a short (2-3 page) introduction. This portfolio will allow you to reflect
 on the evolution of your own thinking and flesh out your understanding of what fascism
 is and does. Your midterm portfolio is due on Wednesday, March 10, at 11:59PM (EST);
 the final version is due on Wednesday, May 5, at 11:59PM (EST). As with all
 assignments for this class, this is not the place for flattery or arguments you don’t
 believe in.
 Midterm Exam: You will have a take-home final exam due on Thursday, April 1, at
 11:59PM (EST). It will consist of short answer and essay questions covering all the
 material we’ve studied by that point in the course.
 Final paper: Your final paper in this course is an opinion piece, or op-ed, that draws on
 everything you’ve learned in this class to make an argument about current events. It is
 due on Thursday, May 13, at 11:59PM (EST). Students who are taking this class on a
 Credit/No Credit basis have the option of taking a final exam instead of the final paper.
 Final Exam (optional): The final exam will include multiple-choice questions,
 identifications, and short essay prompts. Its main purpose is to give credit/no credit
 students the option to conclude the class with an alternative assignment. Students who
 are taking this class for a letter grade are welcome to take the final exam, but they must
 still submit a final paper. If you choose to complete both a final paper and a final exam,
 the average of those two grades will account for 25% of the total.
 Extra Credit: There will be several opportunities to earn extra credit over the course of
 the semester, by attending (virtual) events or watching extra films and lectures - and
 then writing brief responses to them. Stay tuned for more information. You can improve
 your final grade by at most three percent (3%) through three extra credits (1% for each
 extra credit activity), i.e. B → B+ or B+ → A-. To receive the maximum extra credit of
 three percent (3%), you need to hand in three individual short assignments.
 Rules and Policies
 Grading Policy: Your written work will be assessed for clarity, originality, organization,
 and the effective use of evidence from the readings, films, lectures and discussions. The
 penalty for late papers is 1/3 of a letter grade for each 24 hours the work is overdue.
 Late weekly responses will not be accepted without a valid excuse, but they can be
 included in your learning portfolio for partial credit. Exceptions will be granted on the
 grounds of documented illness or personal emergency.
 If you are concerned about meeting any of the deadlines, please notify us well ahead of
 time or as soon as you can. You will receive more information on all assignments as we
 get closer to their due dates.
 Academic Integrity: We trust that all work turned in for this class was composed
 exclusively for this class, and that all wording and ideas presented in any written work
 5
 are your own. Always cite any sources and resources you use and be sure to use
 bibliographic citations. Plagiarism is a serious academic offence. Definitions of what it is
 and how to avoid it can be found at: https://guides.lib.virginia.edu/c.php?
 g=535505&p=3663691.
 When collaborating with other students, do not copy their answers. Always acknowledge
 the individuals you consulted to complete an assignment and detail the nature of their
 input. If you have a question about what is or is not permitted on an assignment, you
 should clarify your question with your instructors prior to doing the work.
 The Bylaws of the Honor Committee define an Honor offense as “a Significant Act of
 Lying, Cheating or Stealing, which Act is committed with Knowledge.” By enrolling into
 this class, you pledge to adhere to UVa’s Honor Code. If you believe you may have
 committed an Honor Offense, you may wish to file a Conscientious Retraction (“CR”) by
 calling the Honor Offices at (434) 924-7602. For your retraction to be considered valid, it
 must, among other things, be filed with the Honor Committee before you are aware that
 the act in question has come under suspicion by anyone. More information about UVa’s
 Honor Code can be found at: https://honor.virginia.edu/.
 Copyright: You may not record, download, alter, and/or distribute class lectures, lecture
 slides, or any other element of this class. We will consider violations of this policy a
 “significant act of stealing” and thus an honor offence. Violations of these terms may
 also be subject to disciplinary action under the University’s Standards of Conduct; for
 details, see https://ujc.virginia.edu/.
 Your Safety and Wellbeing
 We are living through the greatest public health emergency this country has seen in
 over a century. Please stay safe and do your part to slow the rate of transmission. This
 involves complying with all state and local regulations; following university policies; and
 being courteous, considerate, and compassionate towards others.
 It also means that little about this semester will be “normal.” Learning online is still a
 fairly new experience for all of us, and it will require some trial and error. Lecture
 formats, readings, and even assignments may all change as we go along; we’ll give you
 as much notice as we can, and hope that you’ll bear with us. We also ask for your
 feedback: what’s working, what’s not, and what we can do better. Feel free to email us,
 or use the Anonymous Feedback tab on Collab.
 We recognize that this semester brings new challenges and stresses. Here are a
 number of ways to get help:
 Instructor Support: Feel free to schedule individual Zoom or Skype sessions with us to
 discuss drafts, ideas, and our comments on your work. We also understand that
 personal circumstances or unforeseen events can interfere with your academic
 responsibilities. We can meet during office hours or by appointment to discuss any
 6
 aspect of the course, difficulties you may be experiencing, or suggestions for making
 the course more accessible.
 The Writing Center offers online appointments in non-synchronous mode. Good writers
 know that another pair of eyes on their work is always helpful.
 The Student Disability Access Center offers a range of remote services including
 assessments, consultations, and support with accommodations. We always make
 accommodations for students with documented disabilities. Students should notify us
 and the SDAC of disability-related needs.
 UVA libraries feature many helpful staff members and librarians who can help you with
 your research. One name to keep in mind is research librarian for History, Politics, and Religious Studies. 
 knows everything about the library’s resources, both on paper and online. Do not
 hesitate to contact him or his colleagues; they’re eager to hear from you!
 The Office of the Dean of Students provides a list of resources that can help if you are
 experiencing mental health, housing, safety, or food insecurity issues.
 If you or someone you know has experienced or witnessed incidents of bias, hazing, or
 sexual or gender-based violence, go to https://justreportit.virginia.edu/ to report such
 behaviors. Please note that your instructors are “responsible employees,” which means
 that they are required to report issues of violence to the University.
 Confidential employees are available if you want to discuss an issue related to violence
 in depth but want it to remain confidential.
 Covid-19 resources for students are available at:
 https://college.as.virginia.edu/COVID19help.
 A list of mental health resources is available here:
 https://www.studenthealth.virginia.edu/sites/studenthealth.virginia.edu/files/UVaMHReso
 urcesWebsiteFinal.pdf.

Course: HIUS 3232: The US South in the Twentieth Century
Text:
Grace Elizabeth Hale ,

Commonwealth Professor of American Studies, Professor of History

 

HIUS 3232: The US South in the Twentieth Century

Spring 2015

Tell about the South.  What's it like there.  What do they do there. Why do they live there. Why do they live at all.

                                                William Faulkner, Absalom, Absalom (1936)

 

            This course examines the broad history of the American South in the twentieth century, with special emphasis on racial oppression and violence, the creation of segregation, class and gender relations within the region, the role of evangelical Christianity, the cultural and economic interdependence of black and white southerners, and the Civil Right Movement and its aftermath.  It explores the idea of the global South by comparing the region to the rest of the US and placing this relationship in a transnational frame.  It also models how historians use primary historical documents, including visual and audio as well as textual sources, to think critically about the past. 

               This course meets for lecture twice a week and for discussion once a week.  Each lecture will start with a primary document of the day, which will range from photographs, songs, and film clips to laws, newspaper editorials, and artifacts. We will begin with an analysis of what this document tells us about southern history.  Please complete the readings and/or viewings before your discussion section meets.

Teaching Assistants:  Your teaching assistants are Jonathan Cohen and Joey Thompson, both PhD students in the department of history.  Jonathan did his undergraduate work at McGill University and is interested in twentieth century US history, working-class culture, the political economy, race, Jewish Studies, and Bruce Springsteen, probably not in that order.  Joey did his undergraduate work at the University of Alabama and an MA in Southern Studies at the Center for the Study of Southern Culture.  He is interested in twentieth century US history, the South, and vernacular and popular music, probably not in that order either.  They will provide you with information about policies for their discussion sections.

 

Office Hours:

Hale: Nau 238 M, W 2-3:30

Cohen: Tuesdays, 10-11am in Nau 396, Wednesdays, 2-3pm in the Alderman lobby

Thompson: 10:30-12:30 at the Greenberry's in Alderman

 

Course Requirements: 

Midterm (25%)

Reading response papers (20%)

Final exam (30%)

Class participation (25%)

 

Reading Response Papers:   Students in this course are required to attend their discussion sections each week with a one page, single-spaced, printed response to the questions provided below.  Your teaching assistant will take up this response 9 unannounced times during the semester.  The grades for 8 of these papers will be combined into one score that counts 20% of your final grade.  Please draw your answers from the readings and viewings, rather than the lectures (there will of course be overlap but the purpose of the responses is to make you think about the readings and other materials).   Use specific references where possible, but no footnotes or citations are required.

 

Class participation includes attendance at lectures; participation in sections; and attendance at an MLK celebration event and two other campus lecture to be approved by your TA.

 

Class Policies:  

Cell phones, tablets, and computers are not allowed in the lecture or discussion sections of this course.  Students using these devices in class will be asked to leave the lecture hall.  If you have an emergency (a hospitalized family, for example) that requires you to leave your phone on vibrate, please clear this with the TA or the professor before class. 

As your professor, I am committed to making UVA a safe space for all students.  If you are feeling overwhelmed, stressed, or isolated, there are many individuals here who can help. The Student Health Center offers Counseling and Psychological Services (CAPS) for its students. Call 434-243-5150 (or 434-972-7004 for after hours and weekend crisis assistance) to get started and schedule an appointment. If you prefer to speak anonymously and confidentially over the phone, call Madison House's HELP Line at any hour of any day: 434-295-8255.  You may also speak to me in office hours or make an appointment.

If you or someone you know is struggling with gender, sexual, or domestic violence, there are many community and University of Virginia resources available.

Course Materials:

Books:

The following four books are required.  You can purchase them at the UVA bookstore or online at the bookstore of your choice. 

 

W. E. B. Du Bois, The Souls of Black Folk (1903) available in its entirety online at

            http://etext.virginia.edu/toc/modeng/public/DubSoul.html

 

Grace Elizabeth Hale, Making Whiteness: The Culture of Segregation in the South, 1890-1940

(1998)

 

William Faulkner, Absalom, Absalom (1936)

 

Daniel McGuire, At the Dark End of the Street: Black Women, Rape, and Resistance: A New History of the Civil Rights Movement from Rosa Parks to the Rise of Black Power (2011)

(on Collab, JSTOR, or online with links as listed below)

 

Theda Purdue, “Southern Indians and Jim Crow,” in The Folly of Jim Crow (2012) (Collab)

Community, and Protest in the Textile South, 1880-1940,” American Historical Review 91 (April 1986) (JSTOR)

South,” Journal of American History 73:2 (September 1986) (JSTOR)

and Racial Identities Among Southern Baptists (1997) (Collab)

 

Donald G. Matthews, “The Southern Rite of Human Sacrifice” (http://jsr.fsu.edu/mathews.htm  and http://jsr.fsu.edu/mathews2.htm (2000)

 

Mark Noll, “The Churches, ‘Redemption,’ and Jim Crow” from God and Race in American

Politics (2008) (Collab)

 

Zora Neale Hurston, “Spunk,” (1925) http://historymatters.gmu.edu/d/5131/

 

Robin D. G. Kelley, “We Are Not What We Seem: Rethinking Black Working-Class

Opposition in the Jim Crow South,” Journal of American History (June 1993) (JSTOR)

 

Jacquelyn Dowd Hall, “The Long Civil Rights Movement and the Political Uses of the Past”

Journal of American History 91: 4 (2005) (JSTOR)

Matt Lassiter and Kevin M. Kruse, “The Bulldozer Revolution: Suburbs and Southern

Bethany Moreton, To Serve God and Wal-mart: The Making of Christian Free

            Enterprise (2009) (excerpt) (Collab)

 

Heather Ann Thompson, “Why Mass Incarceration Matters: Rethinking Crisis, Decline, and

Transformation in Postwar American History” Journal of American History 97:3

Plessy v. Ferguson (1896)

Week 2

1.19  no class: attend an MLK Celebration event.  The schedule is here http://www.virginia.edu/mlk/.  Please turn into your TA a piece of paper with the name of the event you attended and a short description of what you learned at the event by 2.3.

Primary Source: Lynching photographs

 

Discussion: Jim Crow South, Jim Crow Nation

            Primary Source: George Edwin Butler, The Croatan Indians of Sampson County, NC.

Jim Crow,” from The Folly of Jim Crow (2012) (Collab)

 

Week 4

2.2 The Image of Southern Blacks in Early 20th Century Popular Culture: Minstrelsy, Coon

Songs, and Films

            Primary Source: George Johnson, “The Whistling Coon,” 1891

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sVYHSlEssYY&feature=related

 

2.4 Consumer Culture in the South

            Primary Source: Advertisements

 

Discussion: Making Race II: Popular Culture

Readings: Hale, Chapter 4 (121-98) and sources on visual culture of Jim Crow (Collab)

 

Week 5

2.9 The Lost Cause: Fieldtrip to Jackson Park (information to be provided)

Primary Source: Jackson Park and Rufus Holsinger, “Unveiling of Stonewall Jackson Monument, October 19, 1921,” (Photograph) Holsinger Studio Collection (#9862), Special Collections Department, University of Virginia Library

 

2.11 Working-Class Life and Music Across the Color Line

            Primary Sources: The Carter Family, “Wildwood Flower,” (1928) and “Can the Circle

            Be Unbroken” (1928) Charlie Patton, “Tom Rushen Blues” (1929); Robert

Johnson, “Come On in My Kitchen,” (1936)

 

Discussion: Film and Segregation

Teaching The Birth of a Nation” (2007)

Reconstruction) https://archive.org/details/dw_griffith_birth_of_a_nation

Week 6

            Primary Source: Bessie Smith, “St. Louis Blues” (1929)

            http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Who6fTHJ34

 

2.18 The New Ku Klux Klan of the 1920s: White Supremacy in a Region, a Nation, and the

World

            Primary Source: Burning Cross

 

Discussion: New Women and New Racists

Reading: Hale, Chapter 6, (241-280)

Viewing: Gone With the Wind (1939) (we will make this film available online)

 

Week 7

2.23 The New Negro in the South: Veterans, Writers, and Nationalists

            Primary Source: Jean Toomer, Cane (1923)

 

2.25 Evangelical Christianity: Fundamentalism, Pentecostalism, and Pre-millennialism

            Primary Source: Two Hymns: “Steal Away to Jesus,” a Negro Spiritual, no date; and

“When the Role is Called Up Yonder,” (1901)

 

Discussion: New Negros and New Christians

Readings: (these are all very short pieces) Paul Harvey, “Redeeming the South;” Donald G.

Matthews, “The Southern Rite of Human Sacrifice;” Mark Noll, “The Churches, ‘Redemption,’ and Jim Crow;” Collab; Hurston, “Spunk” online

 

Week 8

3. 2 Midterm

 

Unit 3: The Great Depression and World War II: The 1930s and 1940s

 

3.4  Southern Poverty and the New Deal

            Primary Source: National Emergency Council’s Report on the Economic Conditions of

the South,” (1938)

 

Discussion: Poverty and Politics

3.7-3.15 SPRING BREAK  (Start reading Faulkner, Absalom)

 

Week 9

            Primary Source: FSA photographs of the South

 

3.18 The Generation of 1900: The Southern Modernists

            Primary Source: William Faulkner talks about history and Absalom, Absalom at UVA

 

Discussion: Faulkner’s South

Reading: Faulkner, Absalom

 

Week 10

            Primary Source: oral histories of African American migration

            Primary Source: ballot from the election of 1948

Week 11

            Primary Source: Elvis on the Milton Berle Show

Discussion:

Week 12
