RACE, ETHNICITY AND CULTURE (SOC 119N) – Fall 2022
Section 001 & 601 – 4.0 credits
WHERE DOES THE CLASS MEET?
In Person: 100 Thomas Building
TAKING SOC 119 ONLINE OR IN PERSON – WHAT IS POSSIBLE?
Can I take SOC 119 online?
● At this point, we are organizing the class around the idea that everyone will
attend class in person in 100 Thomas Building on Tuesdays and Thursdays at
4:35 – 5:50pm.
What if I cannot attend class?
● Like every other pre-Covid19 semester of SOC 119, students receive points for
being in class because attendance is an “assignment.”
● If you miss class, then you still must make up those points. Even if you have a
valid excuse (medical, academic, personal situation), you will need to make up
those points because attendance is an “assignment.”
How do I make up attendance points when I miss a class?
● You can watch the livestream or a recording of the class and take a Lecture
Attendance Quiz on Canvas afterwards.
● Each class has a Lecture Attendance Quiz associated with it that we activate
within the hour after class ends.
● However, do not attend class and sign the attendance sheet AND then also take
the Lecture Attendance Quiz on Canvas.
How many times during the semester can I NOT come to 100 Thomas for the
in-person class?
● You can watch the livestream or recording instead of attending class on THREE
different occasions throughout the semester.
● Remember, after watching the recording you must take the Lecture Attendance
quiz on Canvas to earn the attendance points.
What happens if I have to take more than THREE of the Lecture Attendance
Quizzes because I’m not in 100 Thomas on more than three occasions?
● After the first three, you can only earn half credit for those attendance points –
even if you take the Lecture Attendance Quizzes and earn all of the points.
What if I get Covid-19 during the semester? Or what if I must go into quarantine?
Or what if I cannot attend class for an extended period because I have
encountered some other issue?
● If you are diagnosed with Covid-19, then as long as we have an email from Penn
State, you will receive another TWO opportunities to not come to class. (You still
have to watch the class and take the Lecture Attendance Quiz, however.)
● So keep in mind that if you decide that you don’t feel like coming to class and so
you stay home, this reduces your flexibility for deciding that you want to miss
class for some random reason later in the semester.
● That said, we will follow Penn State guidelines, just like we do for any extended
illness when instructors are asked to allow students to make up work that they
have missed.
How do I receive attendance credit when I am in 100 Thomas?
● We will take attendance manually by passing around an attendance sheet –
beginning on Tuesday of the second week.
● During the first week, there are no attendance points calculated in Canvas.
Attendance sheets are Old School. I can just sign the name of my friend.
● You can do that. However, we’ve found students to be really bad at forging
names. And besides, we compare signatures, so you’ll probably get caught.
● Cheating is a violation of Penn State policy and it goes on a person’s permanent
record. That sucks.
What should I do if I am sick?
● You can stay home and watch the stream (if you’re feeling well enough) or watch
the recording of the class.
● Each time you do this, however, it counts as one of your THREE opportunities to
not come to 100 Thomas for the class.
What if I am immunocompromised and I want to take SOC 119 as an online
course?
● Reach out to us and then we will consult with Penn State and get back to you.

● HOWEVER, you have to do this during the first week of classes.
What if I am an international student and at the last minute, I have decided not to
risk coming to University Park? Do I need to drop the SOC 119 class?
● Reach out to us and tell us of your plans. We will consult with Penn State and
then get back in touch with you. (staff@soc119.org).
● HOWEVER, you have to do this during the first week of classes.
What if I arrive late at 100 Thomas?
● If you are more than ten minutes (10 min) late, then you need to check in with the
attendance TA who is sitting in the back of the room at the top in the middle
(under the projectors). You will receive partial credit that day for class.
What if I am in class and I need to leave before it ends?
● We will have a TA in the back of the room and this person will have the
attendance sheet. See them as you are exiting the room.
● You will receive partial credit that day for class.
Can I just stay home and watch the SOC 119 live stream instead of coming to the
Thomas Building?
● Yes, but each time that you do this will count as one of your THREE opportunities
to miss the in-person class.
● FYI: SOC 119 is streamed on YouTube every T/R @4:35-5:50pm. We will make
sure that you have the links
Are there any days during the semester when class will be canceled?
● At this point, you will be watching videos of previous SOC 119 classes on
four days (October 18, 20, 25, 27).
● So on these days, you will NOT come to 100 Thomas – BUT YOU WILL WATCH
A VIDEO AND TAKE THE LECTURE ATTENDANCE QUIZ (see below)
● If we do “cancel” an additional class in 100 Thomas, then you will still have to
watch an online class video and take a Lecture Attendance Quiz on Canvas.
● A “canceled” class does not count as one of your THREE opportunities to miss
the in-person class.
What if we have a snow day and class is canceled?
● You will still have to watch an online class video and take the Lecture Attendance
Quiz in Canvas.
● That video will be sent to you and be somewhere on Canvas or by email.
How do I receive attendance credit when I am watching the livestream or the
recordings?
● Each class will have an associated Lecture Attendance Quiz in Canvas that you
will take AFTER you watch the livestream or the recording. The quiz will have
questions pertaining to the class.
● These Lecture Attendance Quizzes on Canvas will be available shortly after each
class period. (Unfortunately, we can only say that we’ll try to have the questions
finished within the hour.)
● Remember, you can only take THREE of these throughout the semester.
● After THREE times that you’re absent from 100 Thomas, then you can only
receive half-credit for your attendance points.
● Again, this policy changes if you are diagnosed with Covid-19.
If I miss a class and I’m not watching the live stream, then how long do I have
before I must watch the recording?
● The Lecture Attendance Quiz on Canvas will be open for exactly three weeks
after the end of each class.
How will my attendance points be calculated?
● We will add up your points derived from the in-person attendance sheets and add
them to your points from the Lecture Attendance Quizzes that you take on
Canvas (i.e., the days that you were not in class)
● For the first THREE Lecture Attendance Quizzes you can earn full credit but any
remaining quizzes can only earn you half credit.
● Remember, don’t come to class AND take the Canvas quiz on the same day.
How do I keep track of my attendance points?
● We do not give you weekly notifications of your attendance grades that are
generated from the attendance sheets.
● So you have to keep track on your own and it is simple: If you miss class and
have to take the Lecture Attendance Quiz, then put THAT particular class (date)
on your to-do list.
How can I contact Sam or Yuli to address anything I need in the course?
● We are available to respond to all class questions or issues ONLY at the email address.
● DO NOT send emails via Canvas because we likely never respond to messages
on those accounts so you will not receive a timely response.
WHAT IS THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THE COURSE?
To inspire you to think on your own terms regarding whatever it is we end up talking about in
class. We shift the specific topics every semester according to what is in the news and what
people are thinking about. Notice that the objective of the course is not to get you to think in
any particular way, and it is certainly not to “teach” you something. Sam does not believe in
“teaching” – his role is to stimulate you to think on your own terms.
HOW CAN I SEE MY GRADES?
Packback: Follow your progress on your personal Packback page:
● Click on "Track My Own Participation" in the blue box on the right
● Click on “Discussion Posts” below the gray box and then scroll down to see each post
that you have done
World in Conversation: Follow your progress on the WinC landing page when you’re logged in
Lecture Attendance Quizzes: You cannot keep track of which quizzes you have done or still
have to do on Canvas. Just keep track on your own. Again, if you miss class and have to
take the Lecture Attendance Quiz, then put THAT particular class (date) on your to-do list.
Readings and Videos Quizzes: These scores auto-populate in the Canvas gradebook
Syllabus Quiz: These scores auto-populate in the Canvas gradebook

volunteer.
You only receive the point if we select you as a Case Study volunteer and not simply by filling
out the volunteer questionnaire.
You do NOT receive extra credit by randomly raising your hand and asking a question or

We will keep track and we will add the points to your Canvas grade at the end of the

STEP ONE: Go to the SOC 119 Canvas page and find “Packback Questions” in the left
column. Click on that and follow directions, including pay.
IMPORTANT: USE YOUR PENN STATE EMAIL ADDRESS
STEP TWO: Then log into: https://www.packback.co/
STEP THREE: Get started
Or you can take the following steps:
1. Go to: www.packback.co
2. Click on “Login” at the top
3. If you have used Packback in other Penn State classes, simply log in with your PSU
email
and link SOC 119N using the Lookup Key (above) to your Packback account
4. If you have never used Packback, then below the Log In button you will see “Sign up for
an Account”
5. That will take you to a page in which you use your PSU email (abc1234@psu.edu) and
create a PW
6. On the next page you’ll need the Lookup Key (3e273bf0-ee78-43a5-8c22-4a86f6188e8e) to
link your Packback account to SOC 119N
7. Then you pay your $20
YOU ONLY GET CREDIT FOR ONE (1) SET OF PACKBACK
ASSIGNMENTS EACH WEEK. IF YOU DO MORE THAN ONE,
GOOD FOR YOU – BUT YOU WILL NOT GET SOC 119 CREDIT
UNLESS YULI TELLS YOU THAT WE’LL GIVE YOU CREDIT.
CURIOSITY SCORE:
In order to receive full points for these assignments, your Curiosity Score must be above the
minimum threshold:
● 80 for the Question-Answer submissions
● 70 for the Response submissions
MINIMUM WORD REQUIREMENT:
● 300 for the Question-Answer submissions
● 150 for the Response submissions
Here are a few things to ensure that you reach the CS thresholds of 80/70:
● Do not have spelling errors
● Use paragraphs and make sure you write at least 300 words for new questions/answers
and 150 for a response
● Include the link to the SOC 119 class YouTube video that you are commenting on while
writing your Question/Answer by clicking on the “Insert Video” tab (do not just put it in
the middle of your text)
● There are no half credit responses, so you will either receive FULL points or ZERO
points for your efforts
IF YOUR CURIOSITY SCORE IS LESS THAN 80/70, JUST CLICK ON THE “OPTIONS”
TAB AND EDIT YOUR SUBMISSION.
You cannot edit your submission if someone has commented on it. If that happens, then
just copy what you wrote and resubmit it with the changes that you want to make. So,
for that week you will have two submissions and that is fine.
TWELVE - Question-Answer Submissions – 24 points
You submit twelve (12) of these assignments – one each week. You can forget to submit
assignments for two different weeks and you are still good and will not miss those points
because in week fourteen week of the semester you can make up TWO of your missed
assignments. If you miss more than two, then you are out of luck because the system will only
give you credit for UP TO 4 POINTS for two of these assignments during that week.
You receive TWO (2) points for each Question-Answer submission with a Curiosity Score at 80
or above.
Each week you will select a segment from the lecture that sparks a question in you. On the
Packback platform, you will type in the question and provide the video link from the SOC 119
lecture that points to the part of the class that addresses your question. Then you are going to
answer your own question in a minimum of 300 words. So, each submission will have three
parts to it:
1. Your question
2. A “lecture video” link that you will get from the SOC 119 website (www.soc119.org)
3. Your 300-word response to your own question
If you want, you can include another source in the Source box at the bottom, but definitely, you
HAVE to include the link of the lecture you are commenting on.
We want you to use videos from more recent classes. It takes us a week to get videos up so
focus on the previous three weeks of Lecture when you are formulating your questions.
Twelve of these submissions are due throughout the course of the semester, beginning during
Week Three. However, during week fourteen of the semester, you can make up TWO of these
assignments if you miss two. Again, if you miss more than two, then you are out of luck
because the system will only give you credit for UP TO 4 POINTS during that final week.
HOW TO SUBMIT A NEW QUESTION IN PACKBACK:
STEP ONE: Go to www.soc119.org and select a video segment from class about which you
want to comment
STEP TWO: Log into Packback and go to the SOC 119 page
STEP THREE: Click on “Ask a New Question” and type in the question that you want to
answer pertaining to a segment from the class that you have selected REMEMBER, USE
OPEN-ENDED QUESTIONS.
STEP FOUR: Paste the YouTube link into the “Add a Video” box by clicking on the Insert Video
tab (do not just paste it into your text)
STEP FIVE: Write a 300-word answer to your own question. Use paragraphs and do not
make spelling errors.
STEP SIX: Make sure your Curiosity Score is above 80 and then log out
TWELVE - Response Submissions – 24 points
Along with your weekly Question-Answer submission, each week you will also formulate ONE
150-word response to a classmate’s Question-Answer submission assignment that is posted
on the Packback platform. For this response, you MUST get your Curiosity Score to 70.
Each Response Submission is worth TWO (2) points and each response must receive a
“Curiosity Score” of at least 70 for you to receive the points.
Twelve of these submissions are due throughout the course of the semester, beginning during
Week Three. However, as with the Question-Answer submissions, during week fourteen of the
semester, you can make up TWO of these assignments if you miss two. If you miss more than
two, then you are out of luck because the system will only give you credit for UP TO 4 POINTS
during that week.
HOW TO SUBMIT A RESPONSE TO A CLASSMATE’S QUESTION IN PACKBACK :
STEP ONE: Log into Packback and scroll through the Question-Answer submissions from
other students on the SOC 119 Packback page
STEP TWO: Read through questions from your classmates to find one that you would like to
talk about. We pin what we think are some of the more interesting ones at the top.
STEP THREE: Start your Response submission by clicking "Add Response" on someone’s
question. Or provide a counter/supporting point to a classmate’s response by selecting "Add
Response" on someone’s reply.
STEP FOUR: Check your Curiosity score and make sure that it is at least 70 (remember there
is no half credit) and make sure you hit 150 words.
VERY IMPORTANT:
These assignments are due on Sundays at 11:59pm. If you submit them after 11:59pm, then
they count toward the next week’s required assignments – which means that you do not have
to do them during that next week. But keep track because you can only miss TWO and still
“retrieve” the points during the fourteen week of the semester.
Lecture Participation – 84 Points
Throughout each lecture class on Tuesday and Thursday (4:35 – 5:50pm) we will pass around
an attendance sheet and you’ll sign it. Each class is worth three points. If you arrive more than
10 minutes late, you get either 1.5 points or less, depending on how late you are. If you leave
early, the same thing will happen.
If you try to sign someone else into the class and we catch you doing that, then we’re going to
report you to the Office of Judicial Affairs. We check signatures, by the way, and most people
are terrible at forging signatures.
WATCHING CLASS RECORDINGS OUTSIDE OF CLASS TIME
We will allow you to not be in 100 Thomas (i.e., “miss class”) and either watch the live stream
in real time or watch the recorded class lectures outside of class time (i.e., T/R @ 4:35pm) on
THREE different occasions throughout the semester AND STILL RECEIVE YOUR THREE
LECTURE CLASS PARTICIPATION POINTS. Your attendance grade for these online lectures
will be based on how well you do on the Lecture Attendance Quizzes that are on Canvas.
There is one quiz linked to each of the 28 classes this semester.
Each of these quizzes has THREE questions about the information discussed during the
corresponding lectures. These three questions are each worth 1 point, adding up to a total of 3
points per quiz, the same number of points that you would be able to receive if you were in
class and signed the attendance sheet. Once you start one of those four questions, you have 2
minutes to complete the quiz.
These Canvas quizzes will open after class (generally within the hour) and will remain open for
three weeks from the end of that particular class. After they close, we are not reopening them.
Therefore, you cannot wait until the end of the semester to make up class work.
We are going to say this another way:
YOU CAN ONLY EARN UP TO NINE (9) ATTENDANCE POINTS WATCHING THE LIFE
STREAM OR RECORDINGS OF THREE CLASSES AND TAKING THE CORRESPONDING
LECTURE PARTICIPATION QUIZ ON CANVAS – which means that if you want FULL credit,
then you can only miss in-person class THREE (3) times.
NOTE: If you have an ongoing medical issue that requires that you miss
class on a regular basis or for an extended period, contact the SOC 119 staff
(staff@soc119.org) and let us know what is going on.
ACADEMIC INTEGRITY: Academic integrity is the pursuit of scholarly activity free from fraud
and deception and is an educational objective of this institution. Academic dishonesty includes
cheating, plagiarizing, or facilitating acts of dishonesty of others, having unauthorized
possession of examinations, submitting work of another person.
World in Conversation Dialogue - 36 points
Throughout the semester, you need to have completed THREE World in Conversation
dialogues:
● Some of these are “local” – meaning that you will speak with other students in the class
and maybe a few outside of class.
● Some of these are “global” – meaning that students from Afghanistan, Yemen, Iraq,
Colombia, Brazil, and Russia will be in the dialogues with you.
Each dialogue is worth 12 points toward your final SOC 119 grade, and because this is an
essential part of the course, we want to emphasize that getting an “A” in this class is almost
impossible if you don’t complete this assignment.
All Global Dialogues occur in Zoom, and by joining them, you will have the chance to have a
conversation with students from different parts of the world. We HIGHLY encourage you to join
AT LEAST one of these dialogues during the semester.
The Local Dialogues will occur both in Zoom rooms and, if Covid-19 allows it, some will
happen in rooms in Pond Lab where you will sit in circles. You can decide which ones you
would like to do, although on some days (e.g., Sundays) all dialogues happen in Zoom.
Keep in mind that:
● Each dialogue is 95 minutes, and you must be in the room the entire time
● You can only register for ONE dialogue at a time per three-week period
● You can choose how many locals and how many globals you want to take during the
semester, as long as you earn the total amount of points for the assignment. However,
again, we really want you to have AT LEAST one Global Dialogue.
● If you miss a dialogue for which you are registered or arrive more than 10 minutes late
and are not allowed in the room, you will have to make it up. We are plannig to have a
makeup week during the fourteenth week of the semester, HOWEVER, you can only
make-up ONE dialogue during that week and also, seats are VERY LIMITED so we
cannot guarantee you an opportunity to do it.
● If you are required to have a World in Conversation dialogue for another course, it
cannot “double count” for this one and this assignment cannot “double count” for your
other course.
More information about this assignment will be posted on the website and sent to you via
email. However, please note the following information about registration:
Here is how this works: EVERY THREE WEEKS you must complete one of your World in
Conversation dialogues (we call that period: Blocks). It is up to you to get them in
during those three weeks. If something happens and you miss one, then re-register for
it during that three-week window or Block. If you cannot fit a dialogue in or there are no
available seats, then you will probably have an opportunity to make ONE of them up
during week fourteen of the semester, but we cannot guarantee you a seat.
Please note:
YOU CAN ONLY MAKE UP ONE OF THREE REQUIRED DIALOGUES AND WE CANNOT
GUARANTEE ENOUGH SEATS DURING WEEK FOURTEEN IF DEMAND IS TOO HIGH.
Let us say that again: During week fourteen of the semester, we cannot have unlimited
dialogues available for people to attend. As such, there will be competition for the seats
available for make-up groups, and you might not get registered. Our best advice is that you do
not slack on this assignment, or you will be in dire straits at the end of the term.

About SOC 119 Grades:
Just over 50 percent of you will earn an “A” as your final grade and another 20 percent
will earn an “A-“ as your final grade. That is a really high GPA for any class.
How is that possible given the very rigorous grading scale? This is because this class
is based on “contract grading” – you decide what grade you want in the class and then
do the work that allows you to accumulate the points that you need for that grade. It’s a
contract and nothing is left up in the air. Most people decide to do enough work to earn
an “A” and so grades are high in SOC 119.
You might think that the three quizzes are still “up in the air.” Indeed, you might.
However, the median grade for those quizzes is over 90 percent and it’s really easy to
do well if you actually take the time to do the readings and watch the videos.
For the record, there is no standard PSU grading scale and so please don’t email us
about that. If you do not earn an “A” as your final grade, just remember that over half of
your classmates did – so it’s not that hard, nor is it impossible.

RACE, ETHNICITY AND CULTURE (SOC 119N) – Fall 2022
Section 001 & 601 – 4.0 credits
WHERE DOES THE CLASS MEET?
In Person: 100 Thomas Building
TAKING SOC 119 ONLINE OR IN PERSON – WHAT IS POSSIBLE?
Can I take SOC 119 online?
● At this point, we are organizing the class around the idea that everyone will
attend class in person in 100 Thomas Building on Tuesdays and Thursdays at
4:35 – 5:50pm.
What if I cannot attend class?
● Like every other pre-Covid19 semester of SOC 119, students receive points for
being in class because attendance is an “assignment.”
● If you miss class, then you still must make up those points. Even if you have a
valid excuse (medical, academic, personal situation), you will need to make up
those points because attendance is an “assignment.”
How do I make up attendance points when I miss a class?
● You can watch the livestream or a recording of the class and take a Lecture
Attendance Quiz on Canvas afterwards.
● Each class has a Lecture Attendance Quiz associated with it that we activate
within the hour after class ends.
● However, do not attend class and sign the attendance sheet AND then also take
the Lecture Attendance Quiz on Canvas.
How many times during the semester can I NOT come to 100 Thomas for the
in-person class?
● You can watch the livestream or recording instead of attending class on THREE
different occasions throughout the semester.
● Remember, after watching the recording you must take the Lecture Attendance
quiz on Canvas to earn the attendance points.
What happens if I have to take more than THREE of the Lecture Attendance
Quizzes because I’m not in 100 Thomas on more than three occasions?
● After the first three, you can only earn half credit for those attendance points –
even if you take the Lecture Attendance Quizzes and earn all of the points.
What if I get Covid-19 during the semester? Or what if I must go into quarantine?
Or what if I cannot attend class for an extended period because I have
encountered some other issue?
● If you are diagnosed with Covid-19, then as long as we have an email from Penn
State, you will receive another TWO opportunities to not come to class. (You still
have to watch the class and take the Lecture Attendance Quiz, however.)
● So keep in mind that if you decide that you don’t feel like coming to class and so
you stay home, this reduces your flexibility for deciding that you want to miss
class for some random reason later in the semester.
● That said, we will follow Penn State guidelines, just like we do for any extended
illness when instructors are asked to allow students to make up work that they
have missed.
How do I receive attendance credit when I am in 100 Thomas?
● We will take attendance manually by passing around an attendance sheet –
beginning on Tuesday of the second week.
● During the first week, there are no attendance points calculated in Canvas.
Attendance sheets are Old School. I can just sign the name of my friend.
● You can do that. However, we’ve found students to be really bad at forging
names. And besides, we compare signatures, so you’ll probably get caught.
● Cheating is a violation of Penn State policy and it goes on a person’s permanent
record. That sucks.
What should I do if I am sick?
● You can stay home and watch the stream (if you’re feeling well enough) or watch
the recording of the class.
● Each time you do this, however, it counts as one of your THREE opportunities to
not come to 100 Thomas for the class.
What if I am immunocompromised and I want to take SOC 119 as an online
course?
● Reach out to us and then we will consult with Penn State and get back to you.

● HOWEVER, you have to do this during the first week of classes.
What if I am an international student and at the last minute, I have decided not to
risk coming to University Park? Do I need to drop the SOC 119 class?
● Reach out to us and tell us of your plans. We will consult with Penn State and
then get back in touch with you. (staff@soc119.org).
● HOWEVER, you have to do this during the first week of classes.
What if I arrive late at 100 Thomas?
● If you are more than ten minutes (10 min) late, then you need to check in with the
attendance TA who is sitting in the back of the room at the top in the middle
(under the projectors). You will receive partial credit that day for class.
What if I am in class and I need to leave before it ends?
● We will have a TA in the back of the room and this person will have the
attendance sheet. See them as you are exiting the room.
● You will receive partial credit that day for class.
Can I just stay home and watch the SOC 119 live stream instead of coming to the
Thomas Building?
● Yes, but each time that you do this will count as one of your THREE opportunities
to miss the in-person class.
● FYI: SOC 119 is streamed on YouTube every T/R @4:35-5:50pm. We will make
sure that you have the links
Are there any days during the semester when class will be canceled?
● At this point, you will be watching videos of previous SOC 119 classes on
four days (October 18, 20, 25, 27).
● So on these days, you will NOT come to 100 Thomas – BUT YOU WILL WATCH
A VIDEO AND TAKE THE LECTURE ATTENDANCE QUIZ (see below)
● If we do “cancel” an additional class in 100 Thomas, then you will still have to
watch an online class video and take a Lecture Attendance Quiz on Canvas.
● A “canceled” class does not count as one of your THREE opportunities to miss
the in-person class.
What if we have a snow day and class is canceled?
● You will still have to watch an online class video and take the Lecture Attendance
Quiz in Canvas.
● That video will be sent to you and be somewhere on Canvas or by email.
How do I receive attendance credit when I am watching the livestream or the
recordings?
● Each class will have an associated Lecture Attendance Quiz in Canvas that you
will take AFTER you watch the livestream or the recording. The quiz will have
questions pertaining to the class.
● These Lecture Attendance Quizzes on Canvas will be available shortly after each
class period. (Unfortunately, we can only say that we’ll try to have the questions
finished within the hour.)
● Remember, you can only take THREE of these throughout the semester.
● After THREE times that you’re absent from 100 Thomas, then you can only
receive half-credit for your attendance points.
● Again, this policy changes if you are diagnosed with Covid-19.
If I miss a class and I’m not watching the live stream, then how long do I have
before I must watch the recording?
● The Lecture Attendance Quiz on Canvas will be open for exactly three weeks
after the end of each class.
How will my attendance points be calculated?
● We will add up your points derived from the in-person attendance sheets and add
them to your points from the Lecture Attendance Quizzes that you take on
Canvas (i.e., the days that you were not in class)
● For the first THREE Lecture Attendance Quizzes you can earn full credit but any
remaining quizzes can only earn you half credit.
● Remember, don’t come to class AND take the Canvas quiz on the same day.
How do I keep track of my attendance points?
● We do not give you weekly notifications of your attendance grades that are
generated from the attendance sheets.
● So you have to keep track on your own and it is simple: If you miss class and
have to take the Lecture Attendance Quiz, then put THAT particular class (date)
on your to-do list.
How can I contact Sam or Yuli to address anything I need in the course?
● We are available to respond to all class questions or issues ONLY at the email address.
● DO NOT send emails via Canvas because we likely never respond to messages
on those accounts so you will not receive a timely response.
WHAT IS THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THE COURSE?
To inspire you to think on your own terms regarding whatever it is we end up talking about in
class. We shift the specific topics every semester according to what is in the news and what
people are thinking about. Notice that the objective of the course is not to get you to think in
any particular way, and it is certainly not to “teach” you something. Sam does not believe in
“teaching” – his role is to stimulate you to think on your own terms.
HOW CAN I SEE MY GRADES?
Packback: Follow your progress on your personal Packback page:
● Click on "Track My Own Participation" in the blue box on the right
● Click on “Discussion Posts” below the gray box and then scroll down to see each post
that you have done
World in Conversation: Follow your progress on the WinC landing page when you’re logged in
Lecture Attendance Quizzes: You cannot keep track of which quizzes you have done or still
have to do on Canvas. Just keep track on your own. Again, if you miss class and have to
take the Lecture Attendance Quiz, then put THAT particular class (date) on your to-do list.
Readings and Videos Quizzes: These scores auto-populate in the Canvas gradebook
Syllabus Quiz: These scores auto-populate in the Canvas gradebook
EARN EXTRA CREDIT
You can earn ONE extra credit point each day that you are selected to be a Case Study
volunteer.
You only receive the point if we select you as a Case Study volunteer and not simply by filling
out the volunteer questionnaire.
You do NOT receive extra credit by randomly raising your hand and asking a question or
making a comment during class.
We will keep track and we will add the points to your Canvas grade at the end of the
semester.
The maximum extra credit you can earn is TWO points.
You must fill out the volunteer survey and sign the Case Study Volunteer consent form to
volunteer and receive the extra credit.
TO VOLUNTEER: Volunteer — SOC 119

information and details about registering for the NYT can be found in the “Quiz Readings and
Videos” section on our website www.soc119.org/quiz-readings-videos
PACKBACK ASSIGNMENTS – 48 POINTS
PURCHASING PACKBACK: $20.00 (This is a special SOC 119 rate, and it is NOT optional.)
STEPS FOR PURCHASING PACKBACK:

column. Click on that and follow directions, including pay.
IMPORTANT: USE YOUR PENN STATE EMAIL ADDRESS

STEP THREE: Get started
Or you can take the following steps:

2. Click on “Login” at the top

email
and link SOC 119N using the Lookup Key (above) to your Packback account

YOU ONLY GET CREDIT FOR ONE (1) SET OF PACKBACK
ASSIGNMENTS EACH WEEK. IF YOU DO MORE THAN ONE,
GOOD FOR YOU – BUT YOU WILL NOT GET SOC 119 CREDIT
UNLESS YULI TELLS YOU THAT WE’LL GIVE YOU CREDIT.
CURIOSITY SCORE:
In order to receive full points for these assignments, your Curiosity Score must be above the
minimum threshold:
● 80 for the Question-Answer submissions
● 70 for the Response submissions
MINIMUM WORD REQUIREMENT:
● 300 for the Question-Answer submissions
● 150 for the Response submissions
Here are a few things to ensure that you reach the CS thresholds of 80/70:
● Do not have spelling errors
● Use paragraphs and make sure you write at least 300 words for new questions/answers
and 150 for a response
● Include the link to the SOC 119 class YouTube video that you are commenting on while
writing your Question/Answer by clicking on the “Insert Video” tab (do not just put it in
the middle of your text)
● There are no half credit responses, so you will either receive FULL points or ZERO
points for your efforts
IF YOUR CURIOSITY SCORE IS LESS THAN 80/70, JUST CLICK ON THE “OPTIONS”
TAB AND EDIT YOUR SUBMISSION.
You cannot edit your submission if someone has commented on it. If that happens, then
just copy what you wrote and resubmit it with the changes that you want to make. So,
for that week you will have two submissions and that is fine.
TWELVE - Question-Answer Submissions – 24 points
You submit twelve (12) of these assignments – one each week. You can forget to submit
assignments for two different weeks and you are still good and will not miss those points
because in week fourteen week of the semester you can make up TWO of your missed
assignments. If you miss more than two, then you are out of luck because the system will only
give you credit for UP TO 4 POINTS for two of these assignments during that week.
You receive TWO (2) points for each Question-Answer submission with a Curiosity Score at 80
or above.
Each week you will select a segment from the lecture that sparks a question in you. On the
Packback platform, you will type in the question and provide the video link from the SOC 119
lecture that points to the part of the class that addresses your question. Then you are going to
answer your own question in a minimum of 300 words. So, each submission will have three
parts to it:
1. Your question
2. A “lecture video” link that you will get from the SOC 119 website (www.soc119.org)
3. Your 300-word response to your own question
If you want, you can include another source in the Source box at the bottom, but definitely, you
HAVE to include the link of the lecture you are commenting on.
We want you to use videos from more recent classes. It takes us a week to get videos up so
focus on the previous three weeks of Lecture when you are formulating your questions.
Twelve of these submissions are due throughout the course of the semester, beginning during
Week Three. However, during week fourteen of the semester, you can make up TWO of these
assignments if you miss two. Again, if you miss more than two, then you are out of luck
because the system will only give you credit for UP TO 4 POINTS during that final week.
HOW TO SUBMIT A NEW QUESTION IN PACKBACK:
STEP ONE: Go to www.soc119.org and select a video segment from class about which you
want to comment
STEP TWO: Log into Packback and go to the SOC 119 page
STEP THREE: Click on “Ask a New Question” and type in the question that you want to
answer pertaining to a segment from the class that you have selected REMEMBER, USE
OPEN-ENDED QUESTIONS.
STEP FOUR: Paste the YouTube link into the “Add a Video” box by clicking on the Insert Video
tab (do not just paste it into your text)
STEP FIVE: Write a 300-word answer to your own question. Use paragraphs and do not
make spelling errors.
STEP SIX: Make sure your Curiosity Score is above 80 and then log out
TWELVE - Response Submissions – 24 points
Along with your weekly Question-Answer submission, each week you will also formulate ONE
150-word response to a classmate’s Question-Answer submission assignment that is posted
on the Packback platform. For this response, you MUST get your Curiosity Score to 70.
Each Response Submission is worth TWO (2) points and each response must receive a
“Curiosity Score” of at least 70 for you to receive the points.
Twelve of these submissions are due throughout the course of the semester, beginning during
Week Three. However, as with the Question-Answer submissions, during week fourteen of the
semester, you can make up TWO of these assignments if you miss two. If you miss more than
two, then you are out of luck because the system will only give you credit for UP TO 4 POINTS
during that week.
HOW TO SUBMIT A RESPONSE TO A CLASSMATE’S QUESTION IN PACKBACK :
STEP ONE: Log into Packback and scroll through the Question-Answer submissions from
other students on the SOC 119 Packback page
STEP TWO: Read through questions from your classmates to find one that you would like to
talk about. We pin what we think are some of the more interesting ones at the top.
STEP THREE: Start your Response submission by clicking "Add Response" on someone’s
question. Or provide a counter/supporting point to a classmate’s response by selecting "Add
Response" on someone’s reply.
STEP FOUR: Check your Curiosity score and make sure that it is at least 70 (remember there
is no half credit) and make sure you hit 150 words.

WATCHING CLASS RECORDINGS OUTSIDE OF CLASS TIME

World in Conversation Dialogue - 36 points
Throughout the semester, you need to have completed THREE World in Conversation
dialogues:
● Some of these are “local” – meaning that you will speak with other students in the class
and maybe a few outside of class.
● Some of these are “global” – meaning that students from Afghanistan, Yemen, Iraq,
Colombia, Brazil, and Russia will be in the dialogues with you.
Each dialogue is worth 12 points toward your final SOC 119 grade, and because this is an
essential part of the course, we want to emphasize that getting an “A” in this class is almost
impossible if you don’t complete this assignment.
All Global Dialogues occur in Zoom, and by joining them, you will have the chance to have a
conversation with students from different parts of the world. We HIGHLY encourage you to join
AT LEAST one of these dialogues during the semester.
The Local Dialogues will occur both in Zoom rooms and, if Covid-19 allows it, some will
happen in rooms in Pond Lab where you will sit in circles. You can decide which ones you
would like to do, although on some days (e.g., Sundays) all dialogues happen in Zoom.
Keep in mind that:
● Each dialogue is 95 minutes, and you must be in the room the entire time
● You can only register for ONE dialogue at a time per three-week period
● You can choose how many locals and how many globals you want to take during the
semester, as long as you earn the total amount of points for the assignment. However,
again, we really want you to have AT LEAST one Global Dialogue.
● If you miss a dialogue for which you are registered or arrive more than 10 minutes late
and are not allowed in the room, you will have to make it up. We are plannig to have a
makeup week during the fourteenth week of the semester, HOWEVER, you can only
make-up ONE dialogue during that week and also, seats are VERY LIMITED so we
cannot guarantee you an opportunity to do it.
● If you are required to have a World in Conversation dialogue for another course, it
cannot “double count” for this one and this assignment cannot “double count” for your
other course.
More information about this assignment will be posted on the website and sent to you via
email. However, please note the following information about registration:
Here is how this works: EVERY THREE WEEKS you must complete one of your World in
Conversation dialogues (we call that period: Blocks). It is up to you to get them in
during those three weeks. If something happens and you miss one, then re-register for
it during that three-week window or Block. If you cannot fit a dialogue in or there are no
available seats, then you will probably have an opportunity to make ONE of them up
during week fourteen of the semester, but we cannot guarantee you a seat.
Please note:
YOU CAN ONLY MAKE UP ONE OF THREE REQUIRED DIALOGUES AND WE CANNOT
GUARANTEE ENOUGH SEATS DURING WEEK FOURTEEN IF DEMAND IS TOO HIGH.
Let us say that again: During week fourteen of the semester, we cannot have unlimited
dialogues available for people to attend. As such, there will be competition for the seats
available for make-up groups, and you might not get registered. Our best advice is that you do
not slack on this assignment, or you will be in dire straits at the end of the term.

About SOC 119 Grades:
Just over 50 percent of you will earn an “A” as your final grade and another 20 percent
will earn an “A-“ as your final grade. That is a really high GPA for any class.
How is that possible given the very rigorous grading scale? This is because this class
is based on “contract grading” – you decide what grade you want in the class and then
do the work that allows you to accumulate the points that you need for that grade. It’s a
contract and nothing is left up in the air. Most people decide to do enough work to earn
an “A” and so grades are high in SOC 119.
You might think that the three quizzes are still “up in the air.” Indeed, you might.
However, the median grade for those quizzes is over 90 percent and it’s really easy to
do well if you actually take the time to do the readings and watch the videos.
For the record, there is no standard PSU grading scale and so please don’t email us
about that. If you do not earn an “A” as your final grade, just remember that over half of
your classmates did – so it’s not that hard, nor is it impossible.

Course: Composition for American Academic Communication II
Text:
ESL 015
Composition for American Academic Communication II
Department of Applied Linguistics
The Pennsylvania State University
Spring 2013
Instructor: Meghan Cavanaugh Office: 312 Sparks
Course Section: Section #1 Office Hours: Wednesday 4:30-6:30
Course Meetings: T/R 9:45-11:00 Email: mrc268@psu.edu
Class Location: 123 Pond Lab
Course Description
The goal of this course is to help you develop the reading and writing skills you need to
participate successfully in academic reading and writing tasks at an American university.
In this course you will practice academic writing, which includes summarizing,
paraphrasing, quoting, organizing your ideas, doing basic library research, supporting
your claims with good forms of evidence, and preparing citations. You will participate in
all stages of the writing process, which means that you will brainstorm, draft, revise, give
and get feedback through peer review, and proofread. You will also learn and practice
useful reading skills and strategies to support your research and writing activities. [use
‘you’ in this section and the next; your students are mostly new the US and to college
life, and a difficult-to-read syllabus doesn’t help them]
Learning Objectives
By the end of this course, you will be able to:
1. Use the writing process effectively. This means that you will be able to generate
ideas, plan and draft essays, revise your writing, and identify and correct major
grammatical problems. You will also be able to give and take guided feedback
through peer-review.
2. Write different kinds of essays that meet the needs of different audiences and
purposes. Your essays will demonstrate that you understand the concept of
audience, genre, and voice.
3. Use critical reading skills to get information from academic texts. You will be
able to identify main points and details, determine audience and purpose,
summarize, and respond to written English texts.
4. Use academic vocabulary related to course readings accurately and appropriately.
5. Use outside source material effectively and ethically through summarizing,
paraphrasing, quoting, and citing sources appropriately.
6. Write clear and comprehensible sentences and paragraphs that form coherent and
cohesive texts.
7. Identify and correct common grammatical and mechanical errors, and know how
to seek further help from sources outside of class.
Required Textbook
Rosa, A. & Escholz, P. (2012). Models for Writers: Short Essays for Composition. (11th
Ed.) Boston: Bedford St. Martins.
Additional Materials
• A notebook or paper for in-class writing assignments.
• We will regularly use ANGEL, PSU’s online platform. Assignments and
important activities will be posted on ANGEL at https://angel.psu.edu
Course Requirements
Attendance & in-class participation 5%
Peer reviews & HW 5%
Journal entries 10%
Reading assignments & responses 10%
Major Writing Assignments (total 70%):
1. Extended definition text 10%
2. Comparison/Contrast Poster 10%
3. Analytic Essay 20 + 5% for 1st draft
4. Argumentative Essay 20 + 5% for 1st draft

Total: 100%
A 95-100
A- 90-94.9
B+ 87.9-89.9
B 83.33-87.8
B- 80-83.32
C+ 75-79.9
C 70-74.9
D 60-69.9
F <59.9
The Penn State grading
scale does not allow the
option of awarding grades
of C-, D+ or D- grades.
Course Policies
Preparation of HW and written assignments
All major assignments must be prepared digitally and will be handed in via
psu.turnitin.edu or angel.psu.edu. All assignments need to follow the following
guidelines: 12 point Times New Roman font, 1-inch margins around, and double spaced.
NO EXCEPTIONS! Points will be deducted for improper formatting.
Classroom Distractions
There may be class time allotted to in-class lab days. You will either be expected to meet
in a computer lab on campus or bring laptops to class to work. Otherwise, cell phones,
laptops, tablets, and any other electronic devices need to be turned off before class starts.
Late Assignments & Extra Credit
Turn in your assignments on time. Absolutely no late assignments will be accepted! If it
is not turned in online before the dropbox closes, you will receive a zero for that
assignment/project. Please note that the Extra Credit projects must be turned in by the
stated deadline to earn points!
HOW YOU WILL BE EVALUATED
Attendance & in-class participation (5% of your total grade)
Come to class on time; participate in the activities; do the assigned readings and HW
before class; bring your textbook and HW papers to class; contact the instructor if you
know that you will have a problem attending on a certain day. You will be assigned
various tasks, such as an office hour consultation with the instructor; a library orientation
workshop; a visit to a campus activity, etc. These tasks are required! You will be allowed
3 absences for the semester. You will lose 2% off your final grade for every additional
absence you have.
Peer reviews & other HW (5% of your total grade)
A good writer knows how to read and revise a text. In this class, you will have a chance
to work closely with your classmates in giving, and receiving, peer feedback to make
your revising better. This is a required part of the class and I will help you develop your
peer reviewing skills.
Sometimes you will be assigned HW outside of the writing assignments or reading
textbook. These assignments must be completed before class, and you are responsible for
bringing them to class with you. No late assignments will be accepted!
Journal entries/Reading Responses (10% of your total grade each)
In addition to the 4 major writing assignments, you will be required to write several
informal, journal texts. The journal entry assignments are designed to help you develop
ideas for your writing; understand the readings better; organize information for better
communication; and practice using sentence structures and lexical items that are useful
for your writing. Some journals will be personal topics, some will be based on the
readings. There will be an equal amount of each.
Major Writing Assignments (70% of your total grade)
• Major Assignment ONE: Extended Definition (10%)
Focus: sentence & paragraph structure; choosing good illustrative information; domainspecific vocabulary; organization of text; identifying and writing for an audience
Description: Choose an important concept or object from your field of study (your major)
and write an extended definition of what it is, what it means, how it is used or how it
functions, etc. You may gather information from library sources, the internet, your own
experience, and other people. This assignment will be drafted, reviewed, and revised.
Length: 600-700 words.
• Major Assignment TWO: Comparison/Contrast Poster Presentation (10%)
Focus: Organization of text; use of research information; presentation skills
Description: Choose a topic, as guided by your instructor, and organize information about
it using visual design elements to clarify the comparison or contrast you make. You will 
present the poster or ppt in class, and submit a summary of the information as well.
Length: one poster or 12 ppt slides; 4 minute-presentation; 500-700 word text
• Major Assignment THREE: Analytic Essay (20% + 5% for 1st draft)
Focus: Use and citation of research information; textual organization; choice of good
supporting examples and arguments
Description: Choose a topic relating to plagiarism, academic dishonesty, scientific fraud,
identity theft, cybercrime, or some other issue that is related to the issue of trust, and do
basic library research about the WHO, WHAT, WHY and WHERE of the problem,
including the social impact and potential solutions.
This assignment will be drafted, reviewed, and revised. Length: 1200 words
• Major Assignment FOUR: Argumentative Essay (20% + 5% for 1st draft)
Focus: Development of research question; use of research information; citation and
reference formatting; development and support of arguments and evidence; oral
presentation skills
Description: Develop a research question about a contemporary controversial topic, do
basic library research about it; organize and write an essay that takes a position on the
controversy and argues for one point of view over another. Ideas for this essay will be
suggested and discussed by the instructor and the students, and final choices will be made
from a selected list of topics. Present your final topic in a brief oral presentation in class.
This assignment will be drafted, reviewed, and revised. Length: 1200-1600 words.
PSU Policies
Enrollment & Withdrawal
You are responsible for making all decisions regarding your enrollment status in and any
Financial Holds for Penn State courses. Should you decide to withdraw from this course, you
must either (1) drop via eLion or (2) complete an official “add/drop” form and submit it to your
advisor by University deadlines. If you are failing the course and do not officially withdraw, you
will receive a final grade of F. Please talk to me if you have any questions about this process.
Academic Integrity & Plagiarism
Plagiarism is using someone else’s words, ideas, and/or data in your work and treating it as your
own by either not citing it or by citing it inappropriately. Plagiarism is a very serious issue in the
American university system. Within Penn State, the College of Liberal Arts has the following
policy regarding academic honesty and plagiarism:
“Penn State defines academic integrity as the pursuit of scholarly activity in an open, honest and
responsible manner. All students should act with personal integrity, respect other students’
dignity, rights and property, and help create and maintain an environment in which all can
succeed through the fruits of their efforts (Faculty Senate Policy 49-20).
Dishonesty of any kind will not be tolerated in this course. Dishonesty includes, but is not limited
to, cheating, plagiarizing, fabricating information or citations, facilitating acts of academic
dishonesty by others, having unauthorized possession of examinations, submitting work of
another person or work previously used without informing the instructor, or tampering with the
academic work of other students. Students who are found to be dishonest will receive academic 
sanctions and will be reported to the University’s Judicial Affairs office for possible further
disciplinary sanction.” (http://www.la.psu.edu/CLA-Deans_Area/Preparingyoursyllabus.shtml)
Questions about academic integrity can be referred to Ashley Tarbet at aet143@psu.edu or (814)
865-1070.
Disability Access Statement
“The Pennsylvania State University encourages qualified people with disabilities to participate in
its programs and activities and is committed to the policy that all people shall have equal access
to programs, facilities, and admissions without regard to personal characteristics not related to
ability, performance, or qualifications as determined by University policy or by state or federal
authorities. If you anticipate needing any type of accommodation in this course or have questions
about physical access, please tell the instructor as soon as possible.”
(http://www.la.psu.edu/CLA-Deans_Area/Preparingyoursyllabus.shtml)
Questions about disability access can be referred to Jennifer Morris at jxm2@psu.edu or (814)
863-5538.
Statement of Nondiscrimination
“The Pennsylvania State University is committed to the policy that all persons shall have equal
access to programs, facilities, admission, and employment without regard to personal
characteristics not related to ability, performance, or qualifications as determined by University
policy or by state of federal authorities. The Pennsylvania State University does not discriminate

Pre-processed text 1:
ESL 015
Composition for American Academic Communication II
Department of Applied Linguistics
The Pennsylvania State University
Spring 2013
Course Description
The goal of this course is to help you develop the reading and writing skills you need to
participate successfully in academic reading and writing tasks at an American university.
In this course you will practice academic writing, which includes summarizing,
paraphrasing, quoting, organizing your ideas, doing basic library research, supporting
your claims with good forms of evidence, and preparing citations. You will participate in
all stages of the writing process, which means that you will brainstorm, draft, revise, give
and get feedback through peer review, and proofread. You will also learn and practice
useful reading skills and strategies to support your research and writing activities. [use
‘you’ in this section and the next; your students are mostly new the US and to college
life, and a difficult-to-read syllabus doesn’t help them]
Learning Objectives
By the end of this course, you will be able to:
1. Use the writing process effectively. This means that you will be able to generate
ideas, plan and draft essays, revise your writing, and identify and correct major
grammatical problems. You will also be able to give and take guided feedback
through peer-review.
2. Write different kinds of essays that meet the needs of different audiences and
purposes. Your essays will demonstrate that you understand the concept of
audience, genre, and voice.
3. Use critical reading skills to get information from academic texts. You will be
able to identify main points and details, determine audience and purpose,
summarize, and respond to written English texts.
4. Use academic vocabulary related to course readings accurately and appropriately.
5. Use outside source material effectively and ethically through summarizing,
paraphrasing, quoting, and citing sources appropriately.
6. Write clear and comprehensible sentences and paragraphs that form coherent and
cohesive texts.
7. Identify and correct common grammatical and mechanical errors, and know how
to seek further help from sources outside of class.
Required Textbook
Rosa, A. & Escholz, P. (2012). Models for Writers: Short Essays for Composition. (11th
Ed.) Boston: Bedford St. Martins.
Additional Materials
• A notebook or paper for in-class writing assignments.
• We will regularly use ANGEL, PSU’s online platform. Assignments and
important activities will be posted on ANGEL at https://angel.psu.edu
Course Requirements
Attendance & in-class participation 5%
Peer reviews & HW 5%
Journal entries 10%
Reading assignments & responses 10%
Major Writing Assignments (total 70%):
1. Extended definition text 10%
2. Comparison/Contrast Poster 10%
3. Analytic Essay 20 + 5% for 1st draft
4. Argumentative Essay 20 + 5% for 1st draft

Total: 100%
A 95-100
A- 90-94.9
B+ 87.9-89.9
B 83.33-87.8
B- 80-83.32
C+ 75-79.9
C 70-74.9
D 60-69.9
F <59.9
The Penn State grading
scale does not allow the
option of awarding grades
of C-, D+ or D- grades.
Course Policies
Preparation of HW and written assignments
All major assignments must be prepared digitally and will be handed in. All assignments need to follow the following
guidelines: 12 point Times New Roman font, 1-inch margins around, and double spaced.
NO EXCEPTIONS! Points will be deducted for improper formatting.
Classroom Distractions
There may be class time allotted to in-class lab days. You will either be expected to meet
in a computer lab on campus or bring laptops to class to work. Otherwise, cell phones,
laptops, tablets, and any other electronic devices need to be turned off before class starts.
Late Assignments & Extra Credit
Turn in your assignments on time. Absolutely no late assignments will be accepted! If it
is not turned in online before the dropbox closes, you will receive a zero for that
assignment/project. Please note that the Extra Credit projects must be turned in by the
stated deadline to earn points!
HOW YOU WILL BE EVALUATED
Attendance & in-class participation (5% of your total grade)
Come to class on time; participate in the activities; do the assigned readings and HW
before class; bring your textbook and HW papers to class; contact the instructor if you
know that you will have a problem attending on a certain day. You will be assigned
various tasks, such as an office hour consultation with the instructor; a library orientation
workshop; a visit to a campus activity, etc. These tasks are required! You will be allowed
3 absences for the semester. You will lose 2% off your final grade for every additional
absence you have.
Peer reviews & other HW (5% of your total grade)
A good writer knows how to read and revise a text. In this class, you will have a chance
to work closely with your classmates in giving, and receiving, peer feedback to make
your revising better. This is a required part of the class and I will help you develop your
peer reviewing skills.
Sometimes you will be assigned HW outside of the writing assignments or reading
textbook. These assignments must be completed before class, and you are responsible for
bringing them to class with you. No late assignments will be accepted!
Journal entries/Reading Responses (10% of your total grade each)
In addition to the 4 major writing assignments, you will be required to write several
informal, journal texts. The journal entry assignments are designed to help you develop
ideas for your writing; understand the readings better; organize information for better
communication; and practice using sentence structures and lexical items that are useful
for your writing. Some journals will be personal topics, some will be based on the
readings. There will be an equal amount of each.
Major Writing Assignments (70% of your total grade)
• Major Assignment ONE: Extended Definition (10%)
Focus: sentence & paragraph structure; choosing good illustrative information; domainspecific vocabulary; organization of text; identifying and writing for an audience
Description: Choose an important concept or object from your field of study (your major)
and write an extended definition of what it is, what it means, how it is used or how it
functions, etc. You may gather information from library sources, the internet, your own
experience, and other people. This assignment will be drafted, reviewed, and revised.
Length: 600-700 words.
• Major Assignment TWO: Comparison/Contrast Poster Presentation (10%)
Focus: Organization of text; use of research information; presentation skills
Description: Choose a topic, as guided by your instructor, and organize information about
it using visual design elements to clarify the comparison or contrast you make. You will 
present the poster or ppt in class, and submit a summary of the information as well.
Length: one poster or 12 ppt slides; 4 minute-presentation; 500-700 word text
• Major Assignment THREE: Analytic Essay (20% + 5% for 1st draft)
Focus: Use and citation of research information; textual organization; choice of good
supporting examples and arguments
Description: Choose a topic relating to plagiarism, academic dishonesty, scientific fraud,
identity theft, cybercrime, or some other issue that is related to the issue of trust, and do
basic library research about the WHO, WHAT, WHY and WHERE of the problem,
including the social impact and potential solutions.
This assignment will be drafted, reviewed, and revised. Length: 1200 words
• Major Assignment FOUR: Argumentative Essay (20% + 5% for 1st draft)
Focus: Development of research question; use of research information; citation and
reference formatting; development and support of arguments and evidence; oral
presentation skills
Description: Develop a research question about a contemporary controversial topic, do
basic library research about it; organize and write an essay that takes a position on the
controversy and argues for one point of view over another. Ideas for this essay will be
suggested and discussed by the instructor and the students, and final choices will be made
from a selected list of topics. Present your final topic in a brief oral presentation in class.
This assignment will be drafted, reviewed, and revised. Length: 1200-1600 words.
PSU Policies
Enrollment & Withdrawal
You are responsible for making all decisions regarding your enrollment status in and any
Financial Holds for Penn State courses. Should you decide to withdraw from this course, you
must either (1) drop via eLion or (2) complete an official “add/drop” form and submit it to your
advisor by University deadlines. If you are failing the course and do not officially withdraw, you
will receive a final grade of F. Please talk to me if you have any questions about this process.
Academic Integrity & Plagiarism
Plagiarism is using someone else’s words, ideas, and/or data in your work and treating it as your
own by either not citing it or by citing it inappropriately. Plagiarism is a very serious issue in the
American university system. Within Penn State, the College of Liberal Arts has the following
policy regarding academic honesty and plagiarism:
“Penn State defines academic integrity as the pursuit of scholarly activity in an open, honest and
responsible manner. All students should act with personal integrity, respect other students’
dignity, rights and property, and help create and maintain an environment in which all can
succeed through the fruits of their efforts (Faculty Senate Policy 49-20).
Dishonesty of any kind will not be tolerated in this course. Dishonesty includes, but is not limited
to, cheating, plagiarizing, fabricating information or citations, facilitating acts of academic
dishonesty by others, having unauthorized possession of examinations, submitting work of
another person or work previously used without informing the instructor, or tampering with the
academic work of other students. Students who are found to be dishonest will receive academic 
sanctions and will be reported to the University’s Judicial Affairs office for possible further
disciplinary sanction.” (http://www.la.psu.edu/CLA-Deans_Area/Preparingyoursyllabus.shtml)
Questions about academic integrity can be referred to Ashley Tarbet at aet143@psu.edu or (814)
865-1070.
Disability Access Statement
“The Pennsylvania State University encourages qualified people with disabilities to participate in
its programs and activities and is committed to the policy that all people shall have equal access
to programs, facilities, and admissions without regard to personal characteristics not related to
ability, performance, or qualifications as determined by University policy or by state or federal
authorities. If you anticipate needing any type of accommodation in this course or have questions
about physical access, please tell the instructor as soon as possible.”
(http://www.la.psu.edu/CLA-Deans_Area/Preparingyoursyllabus.shtml)
Questions about disability access can be referred to Jennifer Morris at jxm2@psu.edu or (814)
863-5538.
Statement of Nondiscrimination
“The Pennsylvania State University is committed to the policy that all persons shall have equal
access to programs, facilities, admission, and employment without regard to personal
characteristics not related to ability, performance, or qualifications as determined by University
policy or by state of federal authorities. The Pennsylvania State University does not discriminate
against any person because of age, ancestry, color, disability or handicap, national origin, race,
religious creed, sex, sexual orientation, or veteran status.”
(http://ets.tlt.psu.edu/learningdesign/syllabus/policy)

Text: TOO MANY CHARACTERS

STAT 319: Applied Statistics in Science
Spring 2013
Syllabus    Lectures    Computing    Assignments    Readings    Calendar     Announcement    Feedback   
This web page, http://www.personal.psu.edu/yoh5109/319spring2013/syl.html , is the official syllabus for STAT 319 in Spring 2013.

MODIFICATIONS TO THE SYLLABUS: All changes that have been made to the syllabus since the first day of class will be shown on this website in red. They will also be announced in class.
Time and Place	MWF 03:35P-04:25P in 216 Thomas
Instructor	Yuan Huang
Office: 418 Thomas
Email: yoh5109@psu.edu
Office hours: M 2:30 - 3:30 / W 11:30~12:30
TA	Ye Yu
Office: 418 Thomas
Email: ywy5092@psu.edu
Office hours: Thur: 2:00~3:00 / Fri: 10:00~11:00
Purpose	This course is a continuation of MATH/STAT 318 and covers statistical inference, point and interval estimation, hypothesis testing, regression and correlation analysis, and analysis of variance. Some computer analysis may appear from time to time as well.
Required Textbook	Devore and Berk Modern Mathematical Statistics with Applications ( 2007)
Chapters Covered	Chapter 6 - 12 (13, 14 if time permits)
Course Website:	http://www.personal.psu.edu/yoh5109/319spring2013/index.html Please check it regularly and frequently.
You still need to use Angel to download the solutions and check your grades.
Grading	There will be two midterms (15% each), a comprehensive final exam (30%), homework (25%), quizzes (15%). Final semester grades are assigned according to the scale:
93 - 100%    A	      	90 - 92%    A-	      	87 - 89%    B+	      
83 - 86%    B	      	80 - 82%    B-	      	77 - 79%    C+	      
70 - 76%    C	      	60 - 69%    D	      	0 - 59%    F	      
Grade Calculator: 1. Use for grades before April 1st.      2. The amazingly comprehensive version.
Homework Homework is due by the beginning of class on its due date. Unless you inform TA at least 24 hours before homework is due about any extenuating circumstances, late homework will not be accepted. Late work is penalized 10% and accepted only if solutions have not been posted. I will drop one lowest homework.
Solutions for each assignment will be posted on Angel, typically by the time the homework is returned to you. Homework will usually be returned within one week from the due date.
Quizzes Randomly timed, in-class quizzes will be given. Such a quiz might be announced or unannounced. No make-up quizzes will be given for any reason. However, I will drop three lowest quizzes.
Exams There will be two midterm exams on dates to be announced. The second midterm will not be comprehensive; i.e., it will cover only the period of time between the two midterms. If you must miss any midterm, you should provide a valid reason IN WRITING to the instructor 48 hours PRIOR TO the midterm. If you have to miss a midterm at the last minute for some reason, be sure to notify the instructor prior to the midterm time by email; in these cases, you should later back up your excuse with written documentation. An unexcused absence on an midterm date will result in a score of 0.
The comprehensive final exam will take place at the registrar-designated time and place during the week of April 29 - May 3. Unlike the midterms, it will cover the entire semester and not merely the period after the second midterm. No rescheduled final exams will be allowed except for those mandated by the Penn State registrar because of conflicts. This means that you must attend the final exam and should under no circumstances make end-of-semester travel arrangements before knowing your final exam schedule.
OTHER GRADING NOTES:
Solution sets for the homeworks will be provided; login to the course ANGEL page to access them. You are strongly encouraged to learn how to do any homework problems you had trouble with, either by reading the solutions, discussing them with colleagues in the course, or asking questions of the grader or me. This is especially important in this course, where solving problems is absolutely essential to learn the material. I am happy to devote some class time to answering homework questions as necessary.
Don't overlook office hours (mine or the grader's) as a great opportunity to discuss homework, both past and present. You do not need an appointment to show up to office hours; simply walk in!
Academic Integrity	The University policy on academic integrity, covering cheating, plagiarizing, and other acts of academic dishonesty, given in Section 49-20 of the Student Guide on Policies and Rules of the University, will be adhered to in this course. See http://science.psu.edu/current-students/Integrity/ Policy.html concerning academic integrity for details.	
Other Course Rules	
Students are responsible for all announcements and supplements given within any lecture.
If you need to leave class early, please sit in the rear and leave as quietly as possible.
Please be courteous to your classmates and keep extra noise to a minimum.

This web page, http://www.personal.psu.edu/yoh5109/319spring2013/syl.html , is the official syllabus for STAT 319 in Spring 2013.

MODIFICATIONS TO THE SYLLABUS: All changes that have been made to the syllabus since the first day of class will be shown on this website in red. They will also be announced in class.
Purpose        This course is a continuation of MATH/STAT 318 and covers statistical inference, point and interval estimation, hypothesis testing, regression and correlation analysis, and analysis of variance. Some computer analysis may appear from time to time as well.
Required Textbook        Devore and Berk Modern Mathematical Statistics with Applications ( 2007)
Chapters Covered        Chapter 6 - 12 (13, 14 if time permits)
Course Website:        http://www.personal.psu.edu/yoh5109/319spring2013/index.html Please check it regularly and frequently.
You still need to use Angel to download the solutions and check your grades.
Grading        There will be two midterms (15% each), a comprehensive final exam (30%), homework (25%), quizzes (15%). Final semester grades are assigned according to the scale:
93 - 100%    A                      90 - 92%    A-                      87 - 89%    B+              
83 - 86%    B                      80 - 82%    B-                      77 - 79%    C+              
70 - 76%    C                      60 - 69%    D                      0 - 59%    F              
Grade Calculator: 1. Use for grades before April 1st.      2. The amazingly comprehensive version.
Homework Homework is due by the beginning of class on its due date. Unless you inform TA at least 24 hours before homework is due about any extenuating circumstances, late homework will not be accepted. Late work is penalized 10% and accepted only if solutions have not been posted. I will drop one lowest homework.
Solutions for each assignment will be posted on Angel, typically by the time the homework is returned to you. Homework will usually be returned within one week from the due date.
Quizzes Randomly timed, in-class quizzes will be given. Such a quiz might be announced or unannounced. No make-up quizzes will be given for any reason. However, I will drop three lowest quizzes.
Exams There will be two midterm exams on dates to be announced. The second midterm will not be comprehensive; i.e., it will cover only the period of time between the two midterms. If you must miss any midterm, you should provide a valid reason IN WRITING to the instructor 48 hours PRIOR TO the midterm. If you have to miss a midterm at the last minute for some reason, be sure to notify the instructor prior to the midterm time by email; in these cases, you should later back up your excuse with written documentation. An unexcused absence on an midterm date will result in a score of 0.
The comprehensive final exam will take place at the registrar-designated time and place during the week of April 29 - May 3. Unlike the midterms, it will cover the entire semester and not merely the period after the second midterm. No rescheduled final exams will be allowed except for those mandated by the Penn State registrar because of conflicts. This means that you must attend the final exam and should under no circumstances make end-of-semester travel arrangements before knowing your final exam schedule.
OTHER GRADING NOTES:
Solution sets for the homeworks will be provided; login to the course ANGEL page to access them. You are strongly encouraged to learn how to do any homework problems you had trouble with, either by reading the solutions, discussing them with colleagues in the course, or asking questions of the grader or me. This is especially important in this course, where solving problems is absolutely essential to learn the material. I am happy to devote some class time to answering homework questions as necessary.
Don't overlook office hours (mine or the grader's) as a great opportunity to discuss homework, both past and present. You do not need an appointment to show up to office hours; simply walk in!
Academic Integrity        The University policy on academic integrity, covering cheating, plagiarizing, and other acts of academic dishonesty, given in Section 49-20 of the Student Guide on Policies and Rules of the University, will be adhered to in this course. See http://science.psu.edu/current-students/Integrity/ Policy.html concerning academic integrity for details.        
Other Course Rules        
Students are responsible for all announcements and supplements given within any lecture.
If you need to leave class early, please sit in the rear and leave as quietly as possible.
Please be courteous to your classmates and keep extra noise to a minimum.

Text:
PENN STATE UNIVERSITY
SMEAL COLLEGE OF BUSINESS
MKTG 450W: Marketing Strategy (3.0 Credits)
Summer Session I 2020 (SU-I 2020)
Instructor: Matthew Checchio, 422 Business Building
mmc229@psu.edu, 814-865-9306
Office Hours: By appointment online or phone call
Course Description and Objectives:
 Analyzing market-oriented problems of the firm
 Identification and selection of market opportunities
 Formulation of competitive strategies
 Developing and executing marketing policies and programs
Learning Objectives:
 Learn concepts, tools and theory to analyze and develop a marketing strategy.
 Develop your ability to use fact-based analysis to develop and support your marketing strategies.
 Expand your decision-making ability to address realistic problems and situations, often with
incomplete information.
 Develop your ability to verbally defend positions and proposed actions
 Improve your writing skills related to making sound recommendations in a business setting
 Promote teamwork as a main problem-solving approach in marketing.
Required Course Materials:
Course Packet: A packet of articles and cases available via Harvard Business Publishing. These
instructions will be available via Canvas and an email sent to you. Do not purchase any case packet
for any other professors, or for any section taught by Checchio in a prior semester.
There will also be some required readings specified in the course outline that will be available without
cost for download through the MarkStrat website.
Software License: You must also purchase an individual license for the Markstrat simulation. You
will receive an email to make this purchase at the start of the course.
Articles, lecture slides, materials and other content will be provided through Canvas site.
Teaching Approach
This is a discussion-based seminar course using a combination of video lectures, case discussions,
exercises, and a marketing simulation game. There will be some lectures via online as a powerpoint
with audio to help provide you with a framework for making marketing strategy decisions, and we will
be discussing a lot of marketing strategy concepts through the articles assigned and discussion board
responses.
